Thus, they inherited them, and prayer is performed over them if they die, and all the rulings of Submission are established for them, despite their being in a state where they do not comprehend anything at all. Then He said: <<وما أَلَتْناهُمْ من عَمَلِهِمْ من شَيْ‏ءٍ>> (And We will not deprive them of anything from [the reward of] their deeds)—meaning those children, We did not diminish anything from their deeds. He attributed the deed to them, meaning their saying: "Yes!" (balā). Thus, it remained for them in complete perfection; He did not diminish anything from it, because no state arose upon them that removed them in any of their actions from that first acknowledgment, as happened to the adult rational person. Thus, his deed was diminished by the measure of what arose upon him, and Allah diminished it according to the measure of his deficiency.

### [The Infant is Undoubtedly More Complete in Faith than the Adult]

The infant is undoubtedly more complete in faith than the adult, so his Hajj is more complete than the Hajj of the adult. For he performed Hajj by the primordial nature (al-Fiṭra) and directly performed the actions himself, while being acted upon in them, just as the matter is upon him in his self, for all actions belong to Allah. Thus, from every perspective, Hajj is valid for him, essentially and legally. The child is undoubtedly a direct performer (mubāshir), and undoubtedly not rational with the rationality considered in the adult, and undoubtedly not uttering Submission, nor having a conviction or knowledge of it. We mean the conviction and knowledge known to the scholars of external forms in common usage. All of this is non-existent in the nursing child. Yet he directly performed the act, and he is acted upon in it, and the Lawgiver attributed Hajj to him. The child is capable (mustaṭī’) in this state by the preparedness (al-Isti’dād) he possesses to be acted upon by all the rites of Hajj. He is the locus of the action, because he is made to stand at ‘Arafat, so he stands as the rider stands with his mount, and the standing is attributed to him. He circumambulates on his mount, and runs between Ṣafā and Marwa, and the mount is the one that runs, circumambulates, and stands, yet all of that is attributed to him by the ruling of direct performance, and that he performed the actions of Hajj himself. Similarly, the small nursing child is circumambulated with and run with, so he is the direct performer of the actions of Hajj, and he is made to stand, capable in the manner we mentioned: the preparedness to accept what is done with him, just as the adult rider is prepared to accept what his mount does with him, of stillness and movement. The action is attributed to him, not to the mount, following the ruling of the Divine Origin, where actions are attributed to the servants, while the actions—meaning their creation—are truly Allah’s, and the servants are merely the loci of their manifestation.

(Section on Capacity (Istīṭā’a))

Some say capacity means provision (al-Zād) and a mount (al-Rāḥila). Others say that whoever is able to walk, the mount is not a condition. Likewise, provision is not a condition if one can earn in the caravan, even by begging. This is in the case of direct performance.

### [The Mount is the Essence of This Body, for it is the Vehicle of the Spirit]

The mount (al-Rāḥila) is the essence of this body, for it is the vehicle of the spirit (al-Rūḥ), which is the subtle human essence (al-Laṭīfa al-Insāniyya) breathed into it, in what issues from it through the mediation of this body, such as acts of prayer, charity, Hajj, removal of harm, and utterance of remembrance. All of this is action leading to Allah, the Mighty and Majestic, and to eternal bliss. The body is the direct performer of these, and the spirit acts through its mediation. Therefore, the mount must be stipulated as a condition in this specific action in this form.

### [Provision is the Means by Which Nourishment Occurs]

As for provision (al-Zād), whoever considers the increase (al-Ziyāda) in it—it is the means by which nourishment occurs, which produces the strength by which these actions are achieved. By whatever means that strength is achieved, whether by its essence or by this surplus called provision, because Allah increased it in the veil (al-Ḥijāb). For this reason, the soul (al-Nafs) attached itself to it in achieving strength, and found rest and tranquility upon its existence, and was veiled from Allah by it, being delighted by the existence of this veil because of the rest it achieved through it, since movement was tiring, outwardly and inwardly. If provision is lost, the inner self becomes disturbed and agitated, naturally and psychologically, and becomes anxious upon the loss of this means called provision, and that rest and tranquility depart from it. Thus, everything that leads to rest is provision, and it is a veil (ḥijāb) that the Real affirmed by action and the Law confirmed by ruling, thereby strengthening its foundation.

### [The Effect of Means is Stronger than Detachment from Them]

For this reason, the effect of means (al-Asbāb) is stronger than detachment from them, because detachment from them contradicts wisdom, and reliance upon them contradicts knowledge. Therefore, man should affirm them and act by them without relying upon them. That is the strong man. However, he does not attain the station of this strength—that means do not affect him—except after undergoing the trial of being stripped of the customary means, casting them away from his exterior, and engaging with them. When he achieves this first strength, he then moves to the other strength, in which the action of means does not affect him. Before that, the assertion of this is not accepted from the servant. This is the knowledge of spiritual taste (al-’Ilm al-Dhawq) and its state. The scholar who experiences agitation and lack of rest—that knowledge is not the intended and discussed knowledge, for it is not considered. Rather, if you examine its verification closely, you will find that it is neither knowledge nor conviction. Therefore, it has no effect or ruling in this sought-after strength achieved through the knowledge of taste and state. This is the sickness of the soul (marḍ al-nafs). As for the existence of sensory pains from hunger and fatigue, that does not detract, for it is a matter required by nature, in which the soul has no agency, and it is not a psychological pain.

(Section on Capacity by Representation (Niyāba) with Inability for Direct Performance)

Some say representation is necessary, and others say it is not necessary with the inability for direct performance. It is legally established with us that the command to perform Hajj on behalf of one who is unable is incumbent upon his guardian, or by hiring someone for it from his wealth if he possesses wealth. The details of this will follow, if Allah wills.

### [The Representation of the Servant for Allah and the Representation of Allah for the Servant]

Know that representation (al-Niyāba) is valid.

For Allah said, upon the tongue of His servant: "Allah hears the one who praises Him."

Thus, He acted as His representative in that saying. And He said: <<فَأَجِرْهُ حَتَّى يَسْمَعَ كَلامَ الله>> (then grant him protection until he hears the Word of Allah). Thus, the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, acted as the representative of the Real (al-Ḥaqq) if the speech came from Him without mediation. And He said regarding representation: <<يا داوُدُ إِنَّا جَعَلْناكَ خَلِيفَةً في الْأَرْضِ>> (O David, indeed We have made you a vicegerent [khalīfa] upon the earth). And He said generally: <<وأَنْفِقُوا مِمَّا جَعَلَكُمْ مُسْتَخْلَفِينَ فِيهِ>> (and spend from that over which He has made you vicegerents). Vicegerency (al-Istikhlāf) is representation. For the wealth belongs to Allah, and your disposal of it is according to the limit set by the one who made you the vicegerent over it. This is all the representation of the servant for Allah in matters.

As for the representation of the Real for the servant, it is His saying to the Children of Israel: <<أَلَّا تَتَّخِذُوا من دُونِي وَكِيلًا>> (Do not take besides Me a trustee [wakīl]). And He said, commanding: <<لا إِلهَ إِلَّا هُوَ فَاتَّخِذْهُ وَكِيلًا>> (There is no god but Him, so take Him as a trustee). And the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said, addressing his Lord: "O Allah, You are the Companion in the journey and the Successor (al-Khalīfa) over the family."

Trusteeship (al-Wakāla) is representation on behalf of the one who appointed the trustee, in what he entrusted him with, so that he stands in his place. Thus, He affirmed the thing for you and asked you to appoint Him as your representative in it by the ruling of trusteeship. From every perspective, representation is prescribed.

### [Is Representation Valid from the Perspective of Reality?]

Is it valid from the perspective of Reality (al-Ḥaqīqa) or not? Some of us say that it is valid from the perspective of Reality, for wealth was created only for us, as Allah has no need for it, so it is truly ours. Then the Real, the Exalted, appointed us as trustees to dispose of it for us, knowing that He is more knowledgeable of the benefit. So He disposed of it according to the wisdom that requires benefit to return to the one who appointed the trustee. Thus, this Trustee, the Real, the Exalted, destroyed his wealth by drowning, burning, sinking, or whatever He willed, as a trade for him, so that He might earn him more in the Hereafter than what was outwardly called destruction. It is not destruction, but rather a trade—a sale on credit—which is called a risky trade (tijārat ruz’), but its profit is immense. This is knowledge known to the Trustee, not the one who appointed the trustee. He preserves his wealth for him for another benefit required by His knowledge concerning it.

And among us is the one who appointed Allah as trustee, and the Trustee appointed him as vicegerent (istakhlafahu) to dispose of it according to the limit the Trustee prescribes, because the Trustee knows the benefit. Thus, the one who appointed the trustee became a trustee for his Trustee. This is the one who does not transgress the prescribed command in his disposal. Even though the wealth belongs to him, the disposal of it is according to the ruling of his Trustee. This is a strange perspective.

And among us is the one who said that it is not valid from the perspective of Reality, for Allah created things and wealth from things only for Himself, the Exalted, for His glorification. The benefit occurred to us by way of dependence. For this reason, He said: <<وإِنْ من شَيْءٍ إِلَّا يُسَبِّحُ بِحَمْدِهِ>> (And there is not a thing except that it glorifies Him with His praise). If He created things for His sake, not for our sake, then we have nothing to appoint Him as trustee over. Rather, we are His trustees over things. He set limits for us, so we dispose of them according to what He limited for us. If we exceed what He prescribed for us or fall short, He punishes us. If the wealth belonged to us, our disposal of it would be absolute. But the matter is not so; rather, He restricted our disposal of it. Thus, it is not a delegated trusteeship, but one restricted by specific aspects from the Lord of the wealth, who is the Real, the Appointer of the Trustee. In every case, representation is achieved, either from Him, the Exalted, or from us. The sixty-second part ends here.

(In the Name of Allah, the Most Gracious, the Most Merciful)

(Section on the Description of the Representative in Hajj)

The scholars of external forms (al-Rusūm) differed on whether it is a condition for the representative to have performed Hajj for himself, regardless of whether the Hajj is performed on behalf of a living or deceased person. Some say it is not a condition for him to have performed Hajj for himself, although it is better if he has. Others say that it is a condition that he must have fulfilled his obligatory duty. I hold the latter view.

### [Altruism (Īthār) in This Path]

Know that whoever believes that altruism (al-Īthār) is valid in this path says that it is not a condition for him to have performed Hajj for himself. He links this to spiritual chivalry (al-Futūwa), where one benefits another and strives for his right before striving for his own right. This is permissible for him, especially if he sees that such an act is ultimately for his own right, due to the reward he gains through altruism. Thus, he only preferred himself.

Whoever believes that his own right is more obligatory upon him than the right of another, and treats himself as a stranger, and that he is the neighbor with the greater right, is in the position of one who says that he should not perform Hajj for another until he has performed Hajj for himself. This is the preferred path of adherence (al-Ittibā’) and the one to which reference is made, because it is the Reality (al-Ḥaqīqa). This is because if he strives first for his own right, he is the one with the greater right, without dispute. If he strives for the right of another, his striving in it is only for his own right, for he is the one who reaps the fruit of that through praise and reward. Thus, he strives for himself in both cases. However, his striving for the right of another is called altruism, where he outwardly prefers the right of another over his own right—a right that is obligatory upon that other, not upon him. In this, he has fulfilled what was not obligatory upon him, and the reward for the obligatory is higher than the reward for the non-obligatory, due to the fulfillment of the essence of servitude (al-’Ubūdiyya) in the obligatory, and in the other, there is elevation and a state of favor upon the one for whom the chivalry is performed.

### [The One Who Strives for His Own Right and the One Who Strives for the Right of Another]

Thus, he stands in the right of the other with a Divine Attribute, because it possesses the favor (al-Imtinān). And in fulfilling his own right, he stands by way of obligation, established by a pure Attribute of servitude (al-’Ubūdiyya al-Maḥḍa). This is the correct thing sought from the servant: that he attributes the blameworthy and disliked action—in nature, custom, and convention—to himself, out of preference for the Divine Presence, so that what the tongue of blame utters, like sin, and the tongue of natural dislike, like sickness and other defects, is not attributed to Him, out of zeal for that Divine Presence and self-sacrifice for Him. Likewise, if he protects the honor of his brother with his own honor, like the believer with the believer, and protects a great harm from a Prophet or Messenger with his own self, he is higher than one who did not do so and preferred himself. This returns to the measure of the one you prefer over yourself. Whoever observes altruism and chivalry generalizes, and whoever observes the one he prefers divides the matter as we mentioned. It is according to what he is established in and what occurs to him. All of this is provided that no hiring (ijāra) is involved. If the representation occurs through hiring, it has a different ruling.

(Section on the Man Who Hires Himself for Hajj)

Some disliked it, though permitting it, and others forbade it.

### [Action and Compensation]

The action inherently requires compensation (al-’Awaḍ) for itself, which is the recompense for what one gave of oneself. The only question is from whom it is taken. Some of us said that he should not take it from Allah the Exalted, because He is the one who employed us in that action, so the compensation is incumbent upon Him. No Prophet or Messenger failed to say, when commanded to speak: <<ما أَسْئَلُكُمْ عَلَيْهِ من أَجْرٍ>> (I ask you no reward for it)—meaning for the conveyance—<<إِنْ أَجْرِيَ إِلَّا عَلَى الله>> (My reward is only upon Allah). They did not depart from compensation. Conveying from Allah is one of the best acts of proximity to Allah, and Allah employed him in the conveyance despite his being a servant. Thus, the compensation became incumbent upon Him, glory be to Him, by His designation of recompense for what the servant gave of himself in what He employed him in, and his abandonment of what was permissible for him and his choice.

Whoever believes that compensation is only deserved from the one who received the benefit from that conveyance seeks the compensation from the learner, because he obtained the benefit, so the compensation is sought from him. The point of consensus is the affirmation of hiring (al-Ijāra), for the one who forbids it does not forbid it absolutely, but forbids it from the side of the Real, out of zeal that He should be worshipped for His own sake, not for something else, due to the lack of veneration for the Divine Presence in that. This is common, such as the prohibition against singling out Friday for fasting for its own sake, or singling out its night for standing in prayer. Likewise, one who finds it good to perform an act of worship in a place he finds aesthetically pleasing. This is not the way of the People (al-Qawm), for they have realized the deprivation and loss of that through spiritual taste (dhawq).

### [The Divine Impetus and the Natural Impetus]

A man from the People passed with a group for whom the air was subjugated, and they were traveling through it. One of them turned his gaze during his journey and looked at the earth. They had passed a green spot with a flowing spring, and he found it naturally pleasing. The thought occurred to him to perform two cycles of prayer (rak’atayn) there. He fell from among the group and never returned to that state, because he did not seek the worship for what the Real deserves; rather, the impetus for that seeking was nature (al-Ṭab’) in that place due to its natural beauty. Thus, he was punished. Whoever sees this says: "There is no compensation except from Allah," for the action inherently seeks compensation, and it must have it.

(Section on the Hajj of the Slave)

Some say it is obligatory upon him, and others say it is not obligatory until he is freed. I hold the former view, and if his master prevents him while being able to leave him, that master is, in our view, among <<الَّذِينَ يَصُدُّونَ عَنْ سَبِيلِ الله>> (those who avert [people] from the path of Allah).

### [Ibn Ḥanbal During His Imprisonment in the Time of Trial]

Aḥmad ibn Ḥanbal, during his imprisonment in the time of trial (al-Miḥna), when he heard the call for the Friday prayer, would perform ablution and go to the prison door. If the jailer prevented him and turned him back, he had an excuse due to the impediment preventing him from performing what was obligatory upon him. Likewise is the slave, for he is included among the "people" (al-Nās) mentioned in the verse.

### [He Whom the Cosmos Enslaves]

Know that he whom the cosmos (al-Kawn) enslaves is either enslaved by a legally prescribed ruling, such as striving for the right of another, or striving in gratitude to a creature who bestowed a favor upon him by which he was enslaved. This is a servant upon whom the Real is not obligatory, for he is fulfilling a necessary, legally prescribed right sought by that time. He is, in the sight of Allah, a servant to other than Allah by the command of Allah, in order to fulfill the right of Allah.

If he is enslaved by a personal objective (gharaḍ nafsī) or a cosmic desire (hawā kiyānī) in which there is no trace of the legally prescribed right, then it is obligatory upon him to respond to the Real in what Allah called him to of Hajj, in that action. If he looks at the Face of the Real in that objective, that is his freedom, and Hajj becomes obligatory upon him. If that is absent from him due to heedlessness, it is not obligatory upon him, and he is disobedient, due to his knowledge that Allah addressed him with Hajj absolutely.

### [The Sincere Servant of Allah]

If his witnessing (mashhad) at that time is that he is merely a locus of manifestation (maẓhar), and the one addressed by Hajj is the apparent one in him, not his essence, then Hajj is not obligatory upon him. This is the sincere servant (al-’Abd al-Mukhliṣ) of Allah. This is a servitude (al-’Ubūda) in which there is no freedom. Do you not see that the Lawgiver said regarding the child who performs Hajj, and the slave who performs Hajj before he is freed, and then the slave dies before freedom, and the child dies before puberty, that that Hajj is recorded for him as his obligatory duty? This is because by death, he exited the servitude of the other, so he was freed by death. At that point, that Hajj was recorded for him as the fulfillment of an obligation, even if he performed it outside the time of obligation, according to those who hold that view.

(Section on Whether This Act of Worship is Immediate or Delayed)

Some say it is immediate (alā al-Fawr), and others say it is delayed and expansive (alā al-Tarākhī wa al-Tawsi’a). I hold that it is immediate upon capacity (al-Istīṭā’a).

### [The Divine Names and Their Ruling in the Cosmos]

The Divine Names (الأسماء الإلهية) are of two types regarding their ruling (حكم) in the World (العالم). Among the Names are those whose ruling extends as long as Allah wills and endures. If you relate it from its beginning to its end, you speak of expansion (التوسع) and relaxation, like an obligation (الواجب) expanded by time. Any obligation you place within the expanded time is its time, whether you place it at the beginning of the time, or at its end, or in between; for all of it is its time, and you have fulfilled an obligation. Thus, the continuity (استصحاب) of the ruling of the Divine Name upon that which is ruled (المحكوم عليه) is expanded, like Knowledge (العلم) in its continuity for the known things (المعلومات), and like the Will (المشيئة). Similarly, the obligated person (المكلف) may act at the beginning if he wills, or act at the end if he wills. It is not said here, "and if he wills, he does not act," because the reality of acting is an effect (أثر), and the reality of not acting is the continuity of the origin (استصحاب الأصل), so there is no effect. Thus, the Will has no manifest (عياني) ruling here.

And among the Names are those whose ruling does not extend, such as The Originator (الموجد), which is equivalent to that which is instantaneous (على الفور). When it occurs, its ruling does not remain in it, for when He wills a thing, He only says to it, "Be!" (<<كُنْ>>) instantaneously, without delay. For The Originator looks to the attachment of the Will (الإرادة) to the existence (الكون). When He sees that its ruling has attached to the specification (التعيين), He originates instantaneously, such as when the capacity (الاستطاعة) is attained, the Hajj becomes specified.

(Continuation: A chapter on the obligation of Hajj upon a woman, and whether it is a condition of its obligation that a husband or a close relative (ذو محرم) travels with her, or not)

It was said that this is not a condition of the obligation, and it was said that the existence of the *mahram* and his compliance is a condition.

### The Contemplation of Gnosis of Allah through the Path of Witnessing

The soul (النفس) desires the Hajj to Allah, which is the contemplation of the Gnosis (معرفة الله) of Allah through the path of Witnessing (الشهود). Does the seeker (المريد) enter into this by himself, or does he only enter into it with a guide (مرشد)? The guide is one of two persons: either a perfect intellect (عقل وافر), which is in the position of the husband to the woman, or knowledge of the Sacred Law (علم بالشرع), which is the *dhū maḥram*.

The answer is that this seeker (الطالب) must either be one who is willed and attracted (مجذوبا), or not. If he is attracted, then the Divine Providence (العناية الإلهية) accompanies him, and he does not need a guide of his own kind; this is rare. If he is not attracted, then he must enter by the hand of a guide, either the Intellect (عقل) or the Sacred Law (شرع). If he seeks the First Gnosis (المعرفة الأولى), then the Intellect is necessary due to the legal obligation (الوجوب الشرعي). If he seeks the Second Gnosis (المعرفة الثانية), then the Sacred Law is necessary to take him by the hand in that. Through the First Gnosis, the Sacred Law is established for him; and through the Second Gnosis, The Real (الحق) is established for him, and half of the rulings of the rational First Gnosis are removed from him, while the other half are established for him. Thus, the Intellect is with the Sacred Law in this matter.

### The Parable of the One Given the First Gnosis and the One Given the Second Gnosis

This is like a King who appointed a deputy (نائبا) in his kingdom, supported and strengthened him. The King veiled himself from his subjects, and the deputy took control and became powerful. When he became strong and established, and the hearts of the subjects inclined toward him, loved him, and he possessed them through his benevolence, he gained strength over the King and deposed and removed him without the subjects knowing.

The King said to him: "Since you have deposed me, do not reveal to the subjects that you have deposed me, lest you be attributed with lack of integrity, for I appointed you with their knowledge, and you have repaid me with ill-treatment. Blame may reach you, so do not do it. I had already commanded the subjects, when I appointed you and made you my deputy, that they should listen to you and obey you. I gave you the authority to govern them as you see fit, and I told them: 'Whatever this deputy sees fit, act upon it, whether it contradicts my view and opinion or agrees with it, for I know that he will only command you with what is beneficial for you.' I have granted you your desire in the kingdom, but you will need me at times. For if I did not command them from where you do not perceive, they would not obey you and would reject your command. It is not in your interest to reveal my deposition and removal, for if they confirm my removal, they will not accept you, and they will depose you, and they will neither listen to you nor obey you."

This is the parable of the Intellect (العقل), which was given the First Gnosis (المعرفة الأولى) and is the King, and the Sacred Law (الشرع) is like the Deputy. The Lawgiver (الشارع) only addresses people so that they may hear, and none hears from him except one possessing intellect (ذو عقل). By the Intellect that appointed him, the obligated person (المكلف) hears his address, because if the Intellect is removed, the obligation (التكليف) falls away, and the Sacred Law retains neither authority nor proof over him. Thus, those who possess understanding (أولو الألباب) and restraint (النهي) are the ones addressed. This is the very support (إمداد) given by the King to the subjects, which he commanded him to preserve over them. Understand this.

This Second Gnosis (المعرفة الثانية) of Allah, which the Deputy gave to the common people, the King, who is the Intellect, does not know it, but he commanded its acceptance so that he would not be attributed with deficiency or have it said that he was deposed. For this reason, some rational people (العقلاء) interpreted what the Sacred Law brought that contradicted the view of the Intellect, while others accepted it without saying anything about it. For they said: "It has been established for us by the King, when he appointed him, that we must listen to him and obey him in every circumstance. Thus, we do not deem foolish the opinion of the Intellect in appointing the Sacred Law as his deputy." This is how the situation appears to one who contemplates and gains insight. This is the consideration of the woman traveling for Hajj and the preceding disagreement regarding the necessity or omission of the *dhū maḥram*.

(Continuation: A chapter on the obligation of Umrah)

Some say it is obligatory, some say it is a recommended practice (*sunnah*), and some say it is a supererogatory act (تطوع). Umrah is the Visit (الزيارة).

### The Real, after His Gnosis, Communing Secretly in His House

For The Real (الحق), after His Gnosis through prescribed matters (الأمور المشروعة), if He wishes to commune secretly (يناجيه), He cannot do so except by visiting Him in His House, which is every place where prayer is valid. So He inclines toward Him through prayer and communes secretly with Him, because *ziyārah* (visitation) is inclination (*mayl*). From this comes *az-zūr* (falsehood/inclination) and "so-and-so visited (*zāra*) the people" when he inclined toward them. Likewise, if He wishes to visit Him with His robe of honor (خلعته), He clothes Himself in fasting (الصوم) and adorns Himself with it to enter upon Him. And if He wishes to visit Him with His servitude (عبوديته), He clothes Himself in Hajj. Thus, the visitation is necessary. Umrah is obligatory in the performance of mandatory duties (الفرائض), a *sunnah* in desirable acts (الرغائب), and supererogatory in the voluntary acts (النوافل) not explicitly mentioned in the Sacred Law. So, whichever aspect of what we have mentioned rules over you, you rule upon Umrah accordingly, whether it be obligation, *sunnah*, or supererogation. Understand this.

(Continuation: A chapter on the spatial appointed times (المواقيت المكانية) for assuming the state of ritual consecration (الإحرام))

They are four by consensus and five by disagreement: Dhū al-Ḥulayfah, Al-Juḥfah, Qarn, Yalamlam, and Dhāt ‘Irq, which is the point of disagreement—meaning Dhāt ‘Irq—whether the Messenger of Allah (may Allah bless him and grant him peace) appointed it, or ‘Umar ibn al-Khaṭṭāb. And it was said Al-‘Aqīq, and they made it more cautious than Dhāt ‘Irq, making it a sixth point of disagreement. Thus, the number of *mawāqīt* resembles the number of prayers.

### The Consideration of the Number of *Mawāqīt*

Whoever made them four considered that the Sunset Prayer (*al-Maghrib*) is the odd number (*witr*) of the daytime prayers, as if it were brought for the sake of others, not for itself, as in the obligatory prayers. Whoever considered the obligatory nature in all of them said five. And whoever considered his saying (peace be upon him), "Indeed, Allah has added a prayer to your prayers," affirmed the obligation of the *Witr* prayer. Because every mandatory duty (*farḍ*) is obligatory (*wājib*). Thus, the *Witr* prayer is combined with the five mandatory prayers in terms of obligation definitively, though not in terms of mandatory status (*farḍiyyah*), thereby elevating it above the degree of supererogation. What strengthens its obligation is its resemblance to the Maghrib prayer, for he said regarding *Witr* that it is the prayer of the night. It is strengthened by its resemblance to the mandatory nature of Maghrib, which is made the *witr* of the daytime prayer. Yet, Maghrib is weakened compared to the rest of the mandatory prayers because the *Witr*, which is not mandatory by consensus, was likened to it. Thus, the very thing that strengthens *Witr* is what weakens Maghrib.

### Prayer is Light and Hajj is Servitude, so They are Connected

Prayer (الصلاة) is Light (نور), and Hajj is servitude (عبودية), so they are connected. For Allah divided the Prayer between Himself and the servant. The *mawāqīt* are spatial, and the *mawāqīt* of the mandatory duties are the congregation in the mosques.

(Continuation: A chapter on the ruling concerning these *Mawāqīt*)

Whoever passes by them intending Hajj or Umrah, and bypasses them without entering the state of *iḥrām* from them, must offer a sacrifice (*dam*). Some said no sacrifice is due. Among those who required a sacrifice, some said that if he returns to the *mīqāt* and enters *iḥrām*, the sacrifice is waived. Others said it is not waived even if he returns. And some said that if he does not return to the *mīqāt*, his Hajj is invalidated if the sacrifice is specified, and thus it is not waived for one upon whom it is specified.

### The Reason for the *‘Aqīqah* by which Every Human is Held in Pledge

When the sacrifice of the son of Abraham the Intimate (الخليل) was specified for Abraham, the blood (الدم) was not waived from him at all. So Allah ransomed him with a great sacrifice (<<بِذِبْحٍ عَظِيمٍ>>), which was the ram. This was because it was made a substitute for the destruction of the structure of an honored prophet. Thus, the blood occurred because it became obligatory, and once obligatory, it is not removed. So the form of Abraham’s son became the form of a ram, like the markets of Paradise (سوق الجنة) which one enters in whatever form one wills. Thus, the form of the ram was sacrificed, and the son of Abraham was not in the form of a human. This is the reason for the *‘Aqīqah* (sacrifice for a newborn), by which every human is held in pledge.

(A Story We Witnessed)

It was said to one of our Shaykhs concerning a daughter of the kings, one from whom people benefited, and she held faith in this Shaykh. She sent for him to come to her. He entered upon her while the King, her husband, was present. The Sultan stood up for him in reverence. Then the Shaykh looked at her while she was in the throes of death (النزع). The Shaykh said, "Save her before she passes away." The King asked him, "With what?" He said, "Buy her ransom (*diyah*)." Her full ransom was brought to him. The throes of death and the distress she was in ceased. She opened her eyes and greeted the Shaykh.

The Shaykh said to her, "You are fine, but there is a subtle point: after death has become due, it cannot return empty-handed. It must leave an effect. We have taken you from its grasp, and it demands its right from us, so it will not depart except with a soul seized. If you live, people will benefit from you, and you are of great status. We will only ransom you with the greatest thing I possess from this death. I have a daughter who is the dearest of my daughters to me. I will ransom you with her."

Then he turned his face toward the Angel of Death and said to him, "You must return to your Lord with a soul. This is my daughter; you know my love for her. Take her soul instead of this soul, for I have purchased this one from The Real (الحق), and He sold her to me. My daughter makes you worthy, and your coming is justified." Then he stood up and went out to his daughter, who was fine, and said to her, "O my daughter, grant me yourself, for you do not stand in the place of Zaynab bint Amīr al-Mu’minīn in benefit to the people." She said, "O father, I have granted you myself by your command." He said to Death, "Take her." She died instantly. This is the very issue of the Intimate Friend (Abraham) and his son (peace be upon them both). These Divine Balances (الموازنات الإلهية) are known only by their people.

### Indeed, Allah has Purchased from the Believers Their Souls and Their Wealth

In our view, the substitution (الجعل) is necessary, but we are not bound to necessarily take a soul. We have seen such cases concerning our own souls, and we purchased them without giving a soul in return. The Shaykh only did that due to a spiritual state (*ḥāl*) that overcame him, which necessitated what he did in giving his daughter, because his witnessing (*mashhad*) at that time was the story of Abraham (peace be upon him). Thus, the state of Abraham ruled over him. If you understand what we have said, you will be fortunate.

Allah the Exalted said: <<إِنَّ اللهَ اشْتَرَى مِنَ الْمُؤْمِنِينَ أَنْفُسَهُمْ وَأَمْوَالَهُمْ بِأَنَّ لَهُمُ الْجَنَّةَ يُقَاتِلُونَ فِي سَبِيلِ اللهِ فَيَقْتُلُونَ وَيُقْتَلُونَ وَعْدًا عَلَيْهِ حَقًّا>> (Indeed, Allah has purchased from the believers their souls and their wealth, for theirs is Paradise. They fight in the cause of Allah, so they kill and are killed—a promise binding upon Him in truth), meaning Paradise. If He had not purchased their wealth, even if He had intervened between them and it, they would have had what they could use to attain protection by the continuation of life, due to the continuation of the ransom achieved through wealth. But when He impoverished them, He annihilated them. The Shaykh's witnessing was from the verse: <<فَيَقْتُلُونَ وَيُقْتَلُونَ>> (so they kill and are killed). Our witnessing in this matter, however, is the very act of purchase and nothing else, and that is the Living One (الحي). Whoever had a living person who must remain alive, we gave the compensation with which we purchased his life, and he remained alive, and death showed no effect in that witnessing.

### The Balance of Generality, the Balance of Specificity, and the Balance of Independent Judgment

These are the effects of the spiritual states (الأحوال) according to the measure of the Witnessing (الشهود). They are the sciences of spiritual tastes (علوم الأذواق), difficult to attain, and not every Gnostic (عارف) knows them. They are balances (موازين) that do not err, for they were sent down by Divine placement (الوضع الإلهي) for the Day of Resurrection, unlike their descent in the world, where they were sent down for definition and are with the People of Witnessing (أهل الشهود) in the world, like the Prophets. On the Day of Resurrection, they descend as a Reality (حقيقة) by the hand of The Real (حق). Therefore, no prophet was unjust in a ruling, and infallibility (العصمة) was mandated for him in his judgments. Likewise, the Saint (الولي) is preserved in his balance, even if the common people attribute injustice (الجور) to him. It is not injustice in reality (نفس الأمر), but rather injustice when viewed through their balances, as it does not conform to them.

For every truth, there is a balance of generality (ميزان عموم), like the balance of consensus (*ijmā‘*), a balance of specificity (ميزان خصوص), like this balance, and the balance of the jurist who exercises independent judgment (ميزان المجتهد) in ruling. But the question remains: which specific balance is superior? Is it the balance of the *mujtahid* or the balance of the person of Unveiling (صاحب الكشف)? Just as they disagreed on whether a man should enter *iḥrām* from the *mīqāt* or from his dwelling outside the *mīqāt*. Some said that entering *iḥrām* from his dwelling outside the *mīqāt* is superior, and some said that entering *iḥrām* from the *mīqāt* is superior, but this applies to those who permit *iḥrām* before the *mīqāt*. Whoever observed adherence (الاتباع) preferred the *mīqāt*. Whoever observed hastening (المسارعة) to engage in acts of worship for fear of missing them preferred entering *iḥrām* from the dwelling outside the *mīqāt*. However, the consensus is on the *mīqāt*, and that is restriction (تقييد).

### Restriction in Religion is Superior

Restriction (التقييد) in religion is superior, for the permissible (*mubāḥ*), which is the absolute (المطلق), carries neither reward nor sin. Acts of worship are obligations (*taklīf*), and obligation is restriction. The reward for restricting the obligatory (الواجب) is higher than the reward for the unrestricted, because the one who made it obligatory is higher than the reward in the unrestricted. For it has been narrated that Allah says: "No one draws near to Me with anything more beloved to Me than drawing near with what I have made obligatory upon him." Thus, He made it more beloved to Him than anything else. Herein lie Divine secrets (أسرار إلهية) that are only unveiled to the People of Understanding from Allah, the People of Concealment and Secrecy. May Allah make us among them, and I hope that I am.

(Continuation: A chapter on the ruling concerning one who passes a *mīqāt* when another *mīqāt* is ahead of him, while intending Hajj or Umrah)

People disagreed concerning one who intends Hajj or Umrah, passes one *mīqāt* with another *mīqāt* ahead of him, and does not enter *iḥrām* at the first but bypasses it to the second—like one passing Dhū al-Ḥulayfah without entering *iḥrām* and bypassing it to Al-Juḥfah, which is on his route. Some said he must offer a sacrifice (*dam*), and others said nothing is due upon him. Whoever observed hastening to engage in the worship—meaning this specific worship—and saw that hastening to good deeds is an emphasized *sunnah*, said that a sacrifice is due upon him for bypassing it. And whoever saw that the fundamental principle in religion is the removal of hardship, and Allah the Exalted's saying: <<يُرِيدُ اللهُ بِكُمُ الْيُسْرَ>> (Allah intends for you ease), then the will to conform to The Real in what He willed is superior, and he delayed every act of worship and said no sacrifice is due.

### The Divine Names Have No Ruling Over Things Except Through Their Readiness

The Gnostic (العارف), if his witnessing (*mashhad*) is the First Name (الاسم الأول) restricted by the Last (الآخر), the Absolute First (الأول المطلق) which is not restricted by the Last, sees that engaging in the worship at the Last *mīqāt*, which cannot be bypassed and allows no latitude, is superior. For in it, he is the master of the mandatory duty (*farḍ*) in every respect, which he cannot abandon. And whoever sees that engaging in this worship by the ruling of the First Name is superior, because he has no knowledge of its completion, and does not know whether he will die before the Last Name receives him. If he does not enter *iḥrām*, he leaves the station of obligation (موطن التكليف) without having engaged in the worship of Allah that the station required of him, thus being deprived of its Divine Theophany (تجليها الإلهي). So, it is according to what The Real makes him witness, and in all this, he has not departed from the ruling of a Divine Name based on his witnessing.

If it is asked: How can he bypass it without engaging in this worship, when the *mīqāt* rules over him with its authority, which is the First Name? We say: The Names have no ruling over things except through the readiness (استعدادات) of those things for acceptance, and their acceptance is according to the state they are in, in themselves, from their Essence (ذاتها). For the external causes that necessitate a certain matter are weak against resisting the internal causes within the obligated person. Perhaps the state of this bypasser is the state of the Seal (الختم), so it demands delay from him. The First Name recognizes this, and the station of its *mīqāt* weakens in its effect upon him because it is not the focus of his witnessing. Thus, he bypasses it to the Second *mīqāt*, because it possesses the Last Name (الاسم الآخر). There is no doubt that the Last in the path includes the ruling of what preceded it, in addition to its own specificity, unlike the First. The First is contained within the Second, but the Second is not contained within the First.

### Every Later Divine Moment Includes What Preceded It and Contains Its Specificity

It is among the principles of the People (Sufis) that if the Gnostic sat with Allah for such and such a year, and missed a single Divine moment (لحظة إلهية) in its time, what he gained in that moment was greater than what he attained before it. The reason for this is that every later Divine moment includes the moments that preceded it, and it contains its own specificity (خصوصيتها) by which it is distinguished. By that specificity, its multiplicity (الكثرة) over what preceded it is validated. For this reason, he saw no harm in bypassing. Muhammad (may Allah bless him and grant him peace) is the Last of the Messengers, so he attained all the stations (مقامات) of the Messengers and surpassed them by his specificity, without doubt, because he is the Seal of the Prophets. In this is a sign for one who understands.

If it is said: If he engaged in the worship at the first *mīqāt* and passed the last one while engaged, he has attained what is in the last one by passing it while engaged. We say: This is true, except that he did not attain in the second *mīqāt* the specific ruling of the second, which is the origination (الإنشاء) from it, which is its priority (أوليته). Thus, he misses the priority of the origination of this worship from the Last Name (الاسم الآخر). For this reason, he bypassed it. The questioner said: Likewise, he also misses the priority of the First in origination. We say: Every relative priority (أولية مضافة) is governed by the Reality of Priority (حقيقة الأولية) which is not relative, and that is what is considered. So he did not miss what he should regret, since its reality is present in the priority of the Last, but the Last has no existence in the First.

### Meanings Necessitate Their Rulings for the One in Whom They Subsist

Whoever looks at the Names with this eye knows how to accept their disposition (تصريفها) within himself and assigns to them from his Essence (ذاته) what is appropriate for them, based on his witnessing, clear evidence, and sound knowledge. By this, he is distinguished. Because in reality (*fī nafs al-amr*), he only receives from Him what is appropriate for him, but not everyone has knowledge of this. By this, people differ, and Allah raises the ranks of some above others. He also knows how to dispose of them in others if they enable him to do so, or if his spiritual state (*ḥāl*) enables him to do so. For in reality, Knowledge (العلم) cannot subsist in you without you being a Knower (*‘ālim*). This is the empowerment of the spiritual state (التمكن الحالي) that his Essence requires, and nothing else is valid, because Meanings necessitate their rulings for the one in whom they subsist. Were it not for this, the existence of the World (العالم) from The Real (الحق) would not be valid. Do you not see that the impossible (المحال), since it lacked the readiness (استعداده) to accept existence (الوجود) that the possible (الممكن) accepts, had no existence and is not valid, such as a partner to Allah the Exalted in His Divinity (ألوهيته)? And since the possible had in its essential readiness the acceptance of origination (الإيجاد), it came into existence. So, do not be absent from the Realities of things (حقائق الأمور), for they interpenetrate in the judgment of the one who contemplates them, not in themselves. Whoever is absent from the Realities falls into the abysses of ignorance (الجهالات) and misses the degree of Knowledge (العلم) of which Allah commanded His Prophet to seek increase. Nothing is nobler than Knowledge, and He did not command seeking increase in any other Attribute, because it is the general Attribute (الصفة العامة) that encompasses every attribute and qualified subject.

(Continuation: A chapter on the non-Makkan (*āfāqī*) who passes the *mīqāt* intending Makkah but not intending Hajj or Umrah)

Scholars disagreed concerning one who is not from the people of Makkah, intends Makkah, but does not intend Hajj or Umrah, and passes one of the *mawāqīt*. Is he required to enter *iḥrām* or not, provided he is not one who frequently travels to Makkah? Some said he is required to enter *iḥrām*. Others said he is not required to enter *iḥrām*. And this is what I affirm.

### The Guided Men of Allah and the Traveling Men of Allah

The Men of Allah (رجال الله) are of two types: men who see that they are being guided/moved (مسيرون), and men who see that they are traveling/moving (يسيرون). Whoever sees that he is being guided is required to enter *iḥrām* in every circumstance, for he is being guided in every circumstance. And whoever sees that he is merely traveling, he is subject to the ruling of what motivated him to travel. If his motive (باعث) necessitates *iḥrām*, he enters *iḥrām*, for he is like one who intended Hajj or Umrah or both together. If his motive is other than that, then it is according to his motive, just as he (may Allah bless him and grant him peace) said concerning one who intended Hajj and Umrah. And he (may Allah bless him and grant him peace) also said in the *Ṣaḥīḥ*: "Actions are only by intentions (النيات), and every person shall have only what he intended." Thus, he should not enter *iḥrām* when he has not intended Hajj or Umrah. We have no Sacred Law that obligates him to intend Hajj or Umrah necessarily. Then the Messenger of Allah (may Allah bless him and grant him peace) explained to us what he intended, and he neither restricted nor blamed. He said: "So whoever's emigration (*hijrah*) was for Allah and His Messenger, his emigration is for Allah and His Messenger. And whoever's emigration was for worldly gain he might acquire, or a woman he might marry, his emigration is for what he emigrated for."

(Continuation: A chapter on the temporal appointed time (*mīqāt az-zamān*))

Allah the Exalted says: <<الْحَجُّ أَشْهُرٌ مَعْلُومَاتٌ>> (The Hajj is in months well-known). Some say they are Shawwāl, Dhū al-Qa‘dah, and Dhū al-Ḥijjah—and this is what I affirm. Others say Shawwāl, Dhū al-Qa‘dah, and the first nine days of Dhū al-Ḥijjah. Some say it is at any time of the year he wills, and likewise Umrah is at any time of the year he wills. Some disliked it on the Day of ‘Arafah, the Day of Sacrifice (*Yawm an-Naḥr*), and the Days of *Tashrīq*. They disagreed on repeating it in a single year. Some recommended one Umrah per year and disliked more than that. Others said there is no dislike in that, and this is what I affirm.

### Time Above Nature and Time Below Nature

Know that the temporal *mīqāt* was only specified by the Divine Name, Time/Eternity (الدهر - *ad-Dahr*). Know that Time (الزمان) is partly above nature, which is the doctrine of the theologians (*mutakallimūn*), and partly below nature, which has the general ruling. That which has a ruling below nature is a corporeal ruling (حكم جسماني) distinguished by the movements of the celestial spheres. Time in itself is intelligible, and the path to its intelligibility is imagination (الوهم). It is an imagined extension (امتداد متوهم) cut by the movements of the spheres, like the void (الخلاء), which is an imagined extension not in a body. The result, according to this saying, is that it is non-existence (*‘adam*), not existence (*wujūd*). As for the Time above nature, it is distinguished by the spiritual states (الأحوال) and is specified in an existent matter (أمر وجودي) that the Name *ad-Dahr* casts upon the Intellect. The word *matā* (when) accompanies it in the Arabic language. Thus, *matā* accompanies both natural and non-natural time. The relation of time and place (الزمان والمكان), which are two containers (*ẓarfān*), has occurred in Divine and temporal matters and relations.

Regarding place, there is the saying of the Messenger of Allah (may Allah bless him and grant him peace) to the black woman: "Where is Allah?" And His saying, the Exalted: <<هَلْ يَنْظُرُونَ إِلَّا أَنْ يَأْتِيَهُمُ اللهُ فِي ظُلَلٍ مِنَ الْغَمَامِ>> (Do they await but that Allah should come to them in the shadows of the clouds?). He mentioned their belief, and He neither criticized nor approved, neither denied nor affirmed. And there is much of this in the Sacred Law. Regarding time, there is His saying: <<سَنَفْرُغُ لَكُمْ أَيُّهَ الثَّقَلَانِ>> (We will attend to you, O two weighty beings), and <<وَلِلَّهِ الْأَمْرُ مِنْ قَبْلُ وَمِنْ بَعْدُ>> (And to Allah belongs the command before and after).

### Temporal *Dahr* is a Manifestation of the Divine Name *ad-Dahr*

It has been narrated in the *Ṣaḥīḥ*: "Do not curse Time (*ad-Dahr*), for Allah is Time (*ad-Dahr*)." This is an affirmation of the transcendence (*tanzīh*) of this word, meaning that it is among the shared terms, like *al-‘ayn* (eye/essence) and *al-Mushtarī* (Jupiter/buyer). The temporal *Dahr* is a manifestation (مظهر) of the Divine Name *ad-Dahr*. The Name, in effect, is the Manifest (الظاهر) in it, and the Act (الفعل) in the cosmos is for the Manifest, not for the manifestation. The ruling of the manifestation is only in the Manifest, since He named it by Himself. For this reason, some interpreters interpreted it, saying its meaning is that He is the Doer (الفاعل) in Time (*ad-Dahr*). This is a clear error, because he did not distinguish between the Act (الفعل) in terms of its relation to the Doer (الفاعل) and its relation to the effect (المفعول). The Real (الحق) is the Doer, and the effect occurs in *ad-Dahr*, and the Act is a state between the Doer and the effect. This interpreter did not distinguish between the Doer and the effect. Why did he not submit the knowledge of that to its Speaker, who is Allah the Exalted, and not interpret it with the interpretation of one who does not know the reverence that Allah's Majesty deserves?

(Continuation: A chapter on *Iḥrām*)

### Hajj in Its Rituals and Its Realities

It is the beginning of engaging in this worship.

(The Story of Al-Shiblī concerning that)

The companion of Al-Shiblī—who is the narrator of the story about himself—said: Al-Shiblī said to me, "Did you contract the Hajj?" I said, "Yes." He said to me, "Did you annul, by your contract, every contract you have made since you were created that contradicts that contract?" I said, "No." He said to me, "Then you have not contracted."

Then he said to me, "Did you remove your clothes?" I said, "Yes." He said to me, "Did you strip yourself bare of everything?" I said, "No." He said to me, "Then you have not removed them."

Then he said to me, "Did you purify yourself?" I said, "Yes." He said to me, "Did every ailment depart from you through your purification?" I said, "No." He said, "Then you have not purified yourself."

Then he said to me, "Did you utter the *talbiyah*?" I said, "Yes." He said to me, "Did you find a response to your *talbiyah* similar to it?" I said, "No." He said, "Then you have not uttered the *talbiyah*."

Then he said to me, "Did you enter the Sacred Precinct (*al-Ḥaram*)?" I said, "Yes." He said, "Did you resolve upon abandoning everything forbidden (*muḥarram*) upon entering the Sacred Precinct?" I said, "No." He said, "Then you have not entered."

Then he said to me, "Did you overlook Makkah?" I said, "Yes." He said, "Did a spiritual state (*ḥāl*) from The Real overlook you because of your overlooking Makkah?" I said, "No." He said, "Then you have not overlooked Makkah."

Then he said to me, "Did you enter the Mosque?" I said, "Yes." He said, "Did you enter into His nearness from the perspective you knew?" I said, "No." He said, "Then you have not entered the Mosque."

Then he said to me, "Did you see the Ka‘bah?" I said, "Yes." He said, "Did you see what you intended it for?" I said, "No." He said, "Then you have not seen the Ka‘bah."

Then he said to me, "Did you trot (*ramal*) three times and walk four?" I said, "Yes." He said, "Did you flee from the world with a flight such that you knew you had separated from it and cut yourself off from it, and did you find security from what you fled from in your four walks, thereby increasing your gratitude to Allah for that?" I said, "No." He said, "Then you have not trotted."

Then he said to me, "Did you touch the Stone (الحجر) and kiss it?" I said, "Yes." He cried out a cry and said, "Woe to you! It has been said that whoever touches the Stone has touched The Real (الحق), the Exalted. And whoever touches The Real, the Exalted, is in a station where none can manifest an effect upon him except The Real. Did The Real manifest an effect upon you?" I said, "No." He said, "Then you have not touched it."

Then he said to me, "Did you stand the standing (الوقفة) before Allah the Exalted behind the Station (المقام) and pray two cycles?" I said, "Yes." He said, "Did you stand upon your station with your Lord, and were you shown your intention?" I said, "No." He said, "Then you have not prayed."

Then he said to me, "Did you go out to Al-Ṣafā and stand there?" I said, "Yes." He said, "What did you do?" I said, "I magnified Allah seven times, mentioned the Hajj, and asked Allah for acceptance." He said to me, "Did you magnify Allah with the magnification of the angels, and did you find the reality of your magnification in that place?" I said, "No." He said, "Then you have not magnified Him."

Then he said to me, "Did you descend from Al-Ṣafā?" I said, "Yes." He said, "Did every ailment depart from you until you became pure (*ṣafīt*)?" I said, "No." He said, "Then you neither ascended nor descended."

Then he said to me, "Did you hasten (*harwalt*)?" I said, "Yes." He said, "Did you flee to Him, and were you acquitted of your flight, and did you reach your existence (*wujūd*)?" I said, "No." He said, "Then you have not hastened."

Then he said to me, "Did you reach Al-Marwah?" I said, "Yes." He said, "Did you see Tranquility (*as-Sakīnah*) upon Al-Marwah and take it, or did it descend upon you?" I said, "No." He said, "Then you have not reached Al-Marwah."

Then he said to me, "Did you go out to Minā?" I said, "Yes." He said, "Did you wish upon Allah a state other than the one in which you disobeyed Him?" I said, "No." He said, "Then you have not gone out to Minā."

Then he said to me, "Did you enter the Mosque of Al-Khayf?" I said, "Yes." He said, "Did you fear Allah in your entering and exiting, and did you find a fear that you find only in Him?" I said, "No." He said, "Then you have not entered the Mosque of Al-Khayf."

Then he said to me, "Did you proceed to ‘Arafāt?" I said, "Yes." He said, "Did you stand there?" I said, "Yes." He said, "Did you know the state for which you were created, the state you desire, and the state to which you will return? And did you know the One who made these states known to you, and did you see the place to which the allusions point, for He is the One who breathes the breaths in every state?" I said, "No." He said, "Then you have not stood at ‘Arafāt."

Then he said to me, "Did you depart to Al-Muzdalifah?" I said, "Yes." He said, "Did you see the Sacred Monument (*al-Mash‘ar al-Ḥarām*)?" I said, "Yes." He said, "Did you remember Allah with a remembrance that made you forget the remembrance of everything else, so you became preoccupied with Him?" I said, "No." He said, "Then you have not stood at Al-Muzdalifah."

Then he said to me, "Did you enter Minā?" I said, "Yes." He said, "Did you sacrifice?" I said, "Yes." He said, "Your soul (*nafs*)?" I said, "No." He said, "Then you have not sacrificed."

Then he said to me, "Did you stone?" I said, "Yes." He said, "Did you stone your ignorance away from yourself with an increase of knowledge that appeared to you?" I said, "No." He said, "Then you have not stoned."

Then he said to me, "Did you shave?" I said, "Yes." He said, "Did your hopes decrease from you?" I said, "No." He said, "Then you have not shaved."

Then he said to me, "Did you visit (the Ka‘bah)?" I said, "Yes." He said, "Were you unveiled (كوشفت) to some of the Realities (الحقائق), or did you see increases in miraculous gifts (*karāmāt*) upon you due to the visitation? For the Prophet (may Allah bless him and grant him peace) said: 'The pilgrims performing Hajj and Umrah are the visitors of Allah, and it is incumbent upon the Visited One to honor His visitors.'" I said, "No." He said, "Then you have not visited."

Then he said to me, "Did you exit the state of *iḥrām*?" I said, "Yes." He said, "Did you resolve to consume only the lawful (*ḥalāl*)?" I said, "No." He said, "Then you have not exited *iḥrām*."

Then he said to me, "Did you bid farewell (*wadda‘t*)?" I said, "Yes." He said, "Did you depart entirely from your soul (*nafs*) and your spirit (*rūḥ*)?" I said, "No." He said, "Then you have not bid farewell, and you must return. Look how you perform Hajj after this, for I have made you know. And when you perform Hajj, strive to be as I have described to you."

### The People of Allah, None of Them But Has a Known Station

Know, may Allah support you, that I have only related this story as an alert, a reminder, and an indication that the path of the People of Allah (أهل الله) is based on this, and their spiritual state (*ḥāl*) proceeded in it. Al-Shiblī's realization in his Hajj was like this, for he only asked about his spiritual taste (*dhawq*): whether others attained it or not. Others may attain this, or they may attain what is higher or lower than it. There is none among them except that he has a known station (*maqām ma‘lūm*). I have not invented a method in my considerations of these acts of worship that I was not preceded in, except that the spiritual tastes (الأذواق) vary according to the Divine Providence (عناية الله) granted to the servant in that matter.

### What the Consecrated Person is Forbidden to Wear

Then we return and speak in the manner that preceded in the chapters. Let us begin first with what the consecrated person (*muḥrim*) is forbidden to wear: the shirt (*qamīṣ*), the turban (*‘imāmah*), the hooded cloak (*burnus*), and the leather socks (*khuff*)—unless he cannot find sandals (*na‘l*). And trousers (*sarāwīl*)—unless he cannot find the lower garment (*izār*). And no garment touched by saffron or *wars* (a type of dye). What we have mentioned includes agreed-upon and disputed matters. The detailed explanation will follow, if Allah wills. The situation of the man in this differs from the situation of the woman. The woman wears sewn garments (المخيط), leather socks (*khuff*), and head coverings (*khumur*). The woman's *iḥrām* is only in her face and her palms.

### Most Acts of Hajj are Acts of Devotion that are Not Rationally Explained

The acts of Hajj are mostly acts of devotion (*ta‘abbudāt*) that are not rationally explained (لا تعلل), and their meaning is not known through rational contemplation. However, they are sometimes attained through Unveiling (الكشف) and Divine information (الإخبار الإلهي) that descends upon the hearts of the Gnostics (العارفين) who arrive, from the specific aspect (الوجه الخاص) that every existent has from its Lord. The adornment of the pilgrim differs from the adornment of all other acts of worship, for they are the delegation (*wafd*) of Allah—the one performing Hajj and the one performing Umrah. I mean the one who performs Hajj alone and the one who performs Umrah alone; they are two delegations. The one who combines them (*qārin*) has a specific description because he combines the rank of the two delegations. For the delegations of Allah are three, as narrated by Al-Nasā’ī from Abū Hurayrah, who said: The Messenger of Allah (may Allah bless him and grant him peace) said: "The delegations of Allah are three: the warrior (*ghāzī*), the pilgrim performing Hajj, and the pilgrim performing Umrah."

End of the Sixty-Second Part.

(In the Name of Allah, the Most Compassionate, the Most Merciful)

### Continuation: The State of the Woman Differs from the State of the Man in Most Hajj Rulings

Know also that the woman only differed from the man in most of the rulings of Hajj because she is a part of him, even though they share humanity. However, they are distinguished by an accidental matter that occurred to them: masculinity for the man and femininity for the woman.

### The Man's Love for the Woman and the Woman's Love for the Man

She was created passive (منفعلة) to him so that he might yearn for her with the yearning of one whose mastery (سيادته) appeared through her. Thus, he loves her with the love of one who was given the degree of mastery by her. And she yearns for him and loves him with the yearning of the part for the whole, which is the yearning for the homeland, because he is her homeland. In addition to this, each is a place for the other's desire and pleasure. The woman may reach the degree of men in perfection, and the man may descend in deficiency to what is less than the degree of deficiency belonging to the woman. They may agree on rulings concerning acts of worship and they may differ.

### The Superiority of the Man's Intellect is Prevalent

However, the prevalent view is the superiority of the man's intellect (عقل الرجل) over the woman's intellect, because he intellectualized concerning Allah before the woman's intellect, since he preceded her in Existence (الوجود), and the Divine Command (الأمر الإلهي) is not repeated. The witnessing (*mashhad*) that occurred for the predecessor cannot possibly occur for the successor, due to what we said: that He, the Exalted, does not manifest Himself (يتجلى) in one form twice, nor to two persons in a single form, due to the Divine Expansion (التوسع الإلهي). This is the degree by which the man surpasses the woman. And where is the whole compared to the part, even if the part attains perfection? But it is a specific perfection, just as some human limbs, if severed, are compensated for in blood money (*diyah*) as if the whole human were destroyed in its perfection, while some limbs are compensated for by half of that or less. Not every part attains the whole in all degrees.

### The Creation of Man and the Creation of Woman

Sewn garments (المخيط) were forbidden to the man in *iḥrām* but not forbidden to the woman. For the man, although created from a composite, is closer to the simples (البسائط); he is the closest of the close. The woman was created from a verified composite, for she was created from the man, so she is further from the simples than the man is. Sewn garments are composition (تركيب). So she was told, "Remain upon your origin," and the man was told, "Ascend above your composition." Thus, he was commanded to strip himself bare of sewn garments so that he might approach his simple origin, which contains no sewing. Although the *iḥrām* garment is composite—it is a woven cloth—it is closer to the primordial dust (*habā’*) than the shirt, trousers, and all sewn garments. The *habā’* is simple. So, what is close to it is treated according to its treatment, and what is far from it is distinguished in ruling from what is close.

### The Creation of Children from the Blending of the Two Parents, Not from One of Them

Furthermore, the man, who is Adam, was created upon His form, and Eve (Ḥawwā’) was created upon the form of Adam, and the children (البنون) were created from the blending (امتزاج) of the two parents, not from one of them, but from the totality, sensually and imaginatively. Thus, the readiness (استعداد) of the children was stronger than the readiness of the two parents, because the son combined the readiness of both. The perfection of the Perfect Son is greater than the perfection of the Father. For this reason, Muhammad (may Allah bless him and grant him peace) was distinguished by the Most Complete Perfection (الكمال الأتم) by virtue of being a son. Every son in the generated world (*nash’ah*) possesses this perfection, except that they differ in perfection due to the celestial movements, the luminous ascendants, and the felicitous conjunctions. Not every son possesses this second perfection that is additional to his generated nature. This is another subtle point (دقيقة) granted by the specific Divine Aspect (الوجه الخاص الإلهي) in the Theophany (التجلي) to the cause from which this son originates. That Aspect is specified by a Divine Name (اسم إلهي) that is more complete than other Names in encompassing perfection (الكمال الإحاطي), such as The All-Knowing (*al-‘Ālim*), for it is more perfect in encompassing than all other Names by an incomparable degree.

### The Creation of Jesus, Adam, and Eve

Whoever had a father and a mother and a specific, high-ranking, encompassing Divine Name is more perfect than one who had a father and a mother and a Divine Name below it in encompassing and rank. And whoever originated from a mother and an imagined, exemplary father resembles his maternal grandfather, since he has no father, like Jesus (peace be upon him). His attribute is the attribute of his grandfather Adam in his issuance from the Command. Thus, the Divine definition came: <<إِنَّ مَثَلَ عِيسَى عِنْدَ اللهِ كَمَثَلِ آدَمَ>> (Indeed, the example of Jesus to Allah is like that of Adam). That is, the Divine Name from which Adam came into existence is the same from which Jesus came into existence. <<خَلَقَهُ مِنْ تُرَابٍ>> (He created him from dust)—the pronoun refers to Adam. Thus, Jesus is the brother of Eve, and he is the son of her daughter. And whoever originated from a father without a mother fell short of the degree of his father, like Eve, who was created from the short rib (القصيري) and thus fell short. Her crookedness (عوجها) is her straightness (استقامتها). Her curvature is her tenderness (حنوها) toward her children and toward what she possesses of treasures, like the curvature of the ribs over the viscera and intestines stored within the abdomen for the well-being of its owner. Her crookedness is the very straightness intended for her. For this reason, the crookedness of the bow is its very straightness. If you attempt to straighten it according to the known linear straightness, you will break it, and you will not achieve the purpose you hope for with the straightness you seek from it. This is due to your ignorance of the straightness appropriate for it.

### Nothing in the World is Not Straight, According to the Scholars of Allah

There is nothing in the World (العالم) that is not straight, according to the scholars of Allah (العلماء بالله) who are aware of Allah's secrets in His creation. For He has made that clear to us in His saying, the Exalted: <<أَعْطَى كُلَّ شَيْءٍ خَلْقَهُ>> (He gave every thing its creation), which is the very perfection of that thing, so nothing is deficient. The reason for this is that we are created upon the form of the One who possesses Absolute Perfection (الكمال المطلق), so we resemble Him in restriction by His absoluteness, for absoluteness is restriction, without doubt, since by it, it is distinguished from the restricted. Nothing issues from the Perfect One except that it is upon its appropriate perfection. Thus, nothing in the World is deficient at all. Were it not for the accidents (*a‘rāḍ*) that generate illnesses, man would stroll in the form of the World, just as the World strolls and is viewed in it, for it is the garden of The Real (بستان الحق), and the Names (الأسماء) are its owners in partnership, so every Name has a share in it. This is what the Realities (الحقائق) grant. Perfection is an essential attribute of things, and deficiency is an accidental matter, and deficiency has perfection in its own essence. Understand this. No man who knew his worth perished. The status of the woman compared to the man has become clear to you, and that even if they differ from one aspect, they agree from another.

(Continuation: A chapter on the disagreement among scholars concerning the consecrated person (*muḥrim*): if he finds nothing but trousers, is he permitted to wear them?)

Some said he is not permitted to wear them, and if he wears them, he must offer a ransom (*fidyah*). Others said he may wear them if he does not find an *izār*.

### The Attributes of Meaning are Not Entities Added to the Essence

Know that since the *izār* (lower garment) and the *ridā’* (upper garment) are not sewn, they are not composite (مركبين). For this reason, The Real (الحق) described Himself with them, due to the absence of composition, since every composite is subject to separation. This is the reason why one must say that the Attributes of Meaning (صفات المعاني) of the Divine are not entities (*a‘yān*) added to the Essence (الذات), for fear of composition. Those who affirm them as additions were compelled to say concerning them: "They are neither He nor other than He," due to the deficiency inherent in composition. For if the separation of the connected were hypothesized, its separation would be valid and not impossible from one aspect. That is only impossible if it is impossible due to its description of Pre-eternity (*qidam*), which is the negation of beginning. The Pre-eternal (القديم) is undoubtedly impossible to cease to exist by rational proof. If we hypothesize the non-existence of the Attributes of Meaning, by whose existence the perfection of the described subject is realized, the deficiency of the described subject would appear, even though this is an impossible hypothesis due to the impossibility of the non-existence of the Pre-eternal. And Allah says: <<لَوْ كَانَ فِيهِمَا آلِهَةٌ إِلَّا اللهُ لَفَسَدَتَا>> (Had there been within them [the heavens and earth] gods besides Allah, they both would have been ruined). This is by way of hypothesizing the impossible. The Real is Perfect in Essence (كامل الذات), so pay attention.

### The Consecrated Person is Clothed in a Sensory Attribute that is Conceptual for The Real

He, the Exalted, says: "Arrogance (*al-kibriyā’*) is My upper garment (*ridā’*), and Majesty (*al-‘aẓamah*) is My lower garment (*izār*)." This is a Divine *iḥrām*, for He mentioned two garments that are not sewn. The Real, the Exalted, consecrated the men with what He described Himself with, and He did not do that with the woman, nor did He restrict it upon her, for she may attain perfection in that, just as men attain perfection. If the woman wore it, it would be superior for her in our view. The consecrated person (*muḥrim*) has clothed himself in an attribute that is conceptual (معنوية) for The Real and sensory (حسية) in creation: it is Arrogance and Majesty in The Real, and *ridā’* and *izār* in creation. Just as the fasting person clothes himself in an attribute belonging to The Real. For this reason, fasting was made adjacent to Him in the foundations of Islam. Although, in reality, the locus of Majesty and Arrogance is the servant's exterior, not his heart. Majesty and Arrogance may be a spiritual state (*ḥāl*) for man, not his attribute. If he were to attribute himself with them, he would perish out of ignorance. But if they are a state for him in their proper station, he is saved, made happy, and thanked for that. The first degree of this worship is that the one who engages in it among His servants is joined to his Lord in transcendence (*tanzīh*) from being described by composition, thus clothing himself in perfection at the very first step in it. For this reason, we do not permit the *muḥrim* to wear any sewn garment or cover his head, except out of necessity due to harm that afflicts him, which cannot be repelled except by wearing what was restricted from him. But if he does it for reasons other than harm, he has not engaged in the worship, nor performed Hajj, and only one who wore it due to harm offers a ransom. The harm (*adhā*) in the Divine Presence (الجناب الإلهي) is that He be attributed with composition, due to the deficiency inherent in it. He, the Exalted, said: <<إِنَّ الَّذِينَ يُؤْذُونَ اللهَ>> (Indeed, those who harm Allah). Thus, He described Himself as being harmed, and He assigned to this harm the Name The Patient (الصبور). "No one is more patient with harm than Allah," due to His power to seize them, yet He does not seize them and grants respite.

### Wearing Trousers is Concealing the *‘Awrah*, Which is the Locus of the Divine Secret

Wearing trousers is the concealment of the *‘awrah* (private parts), which is the locus of the Divine Secret (السر الإلهي), and a concealment of harm, because they are also the locus of the exit of harm. Thus, their concealment is confirmed by what suits them, which is trousers. Trousers are stronger in concealing the *‘awrah* than the *izār*, the shirt, and others. Because deviation from straightness (الاستقامة) is a defect, and the defect should be concealed. For this reason, it was named *‘awrah* (private part/defect) due to its deviation. It holds the degree of the Secret (السر) in the Divine Origination (الإيجاد الإلهي), and The Real assigned it the rank of the Divine Pen (القلم الإلهي), just as He assigned the woman the rank of the Tablet (اللوح) for the inscription of this Pen. When it deviated from this great rank and elevated station to become a locus for the existence of foul odors exiting from them—from the harm of feces and urine—and made itself a path for what the expulsive force removes from the body, it was named *‘awrah* and concealed, because it is a deviation toward a defect. Thus, it joined the World of the Unseen (عالم الغيب) and was veiled from the World of Witnessing (عالم الشهادة). With trousers, it neither witnesses nor is witnessed. Trousers are more concealing in its regard, but The Real preferred the *izār* because He created the servant to resemble Him, since He created him upon His form.

(Continuation: A chapter on the consecrated person wearing leather socks (*khuff*))

Some said—and this is the majority—that the *muḥrim* wears the *khuff* if he does not find sandals, and he must cut them below the ankles. Others said he wears them and does not cut them. ‘Aṭā’ justified cutting them by saying it is corruption (*fasād*), and Allah does not love corruption. The absolute *ḥadīth* of Ibn ‘Abbās states that the *khuff* are for one who does not find sandals, narrated from the Messenger of Allah (may Allah bless him and grant him peace), and it did not mention cutting them. Aḥmad and ‘Aṭā’ affirmed this.

### Observing Transcendence and Observing What The Real Has Manifested

The Foot (*al-qadam*) is a Divine Attribute (صفة إلهية) with which The Real described Himself, and <<لَيْسَ كَمِثْلِهِ شَيْءٌ>> (There is nothing like unto Him). Whoever observed transcendence (*tanzīh*) and was overcome by zeal (*ghīrah*) for The Real in His descent to what is an attribute of the created servant, affirmed wearing the uncut *khuff* because it is greater in concealment. And whoever observed the manifestation of what The Real manifested, because The Real knows Himself better than His servant knows Him, and affirmed His transcendence in another station, did not wish to impose his intellect upon The Real. He said that returning to Him is superior to zealotry over Him, for the Reality (الحقيقة) dictates that zealotry should be *for* Him, not *against* Him, according to the Sacred Law. The wearing of *khuff* was only legislated for one who does not find sandals, and the sandal is a protector but not a concealer. So he affirmed cutting the *khuff*, and this is superior.

(Continuation: A chapter on one who wears them (the *khuff*) cut, despite the availability of sandals)

Some said he must offer a ransom (*fidyah*), and others said no ransom is due upon him.

### Gnosis of Allah through Report is Higher than Gnosis through Contemplation

Since the *khuff* and the sandal agree in protecting against the harm of the Lower World (العالم الأسفل), and the *khuff* adds protection against the harm of the Higher World (العالم الأعلى)—insofar as they are both a world of shared indication (الدلالة), and indication accepts ambiguity, which is the harm that attaches to it. For this reason, Gnosis of Allah (معرفة الله) through the path of Report (الخبر) is higher than Gnosis of Allah through the path of Contemplation (النظر). The path of Report concerning the Gnosis of Allah only came with what His Essence (ذاته) is not upon, in the knowledge of the contemplator. Gnosis through rational proofs is negative (سلبية), while through reported proofs it is affirmative (ثبوتية) and negative in affirmation, and negative in establishment. Since it was more revealing (أكشف), the aspect of concealment was not preferred. Thus, the sandal was made the origin in *iḥrām*, for the adoption of the sandal only came for adornment and protection from earthly harm. If it is unavailable, one turns to the *khuff*.

### Everything the Sacred Law is Silent About is Well-Being

If the name *khuff* is removed by cutting, and it does not attain the degree of the sandal because it conceals the top of the foot, then it is neither *khuff* nor sandal. It is something the Law is silent about, like one who walks barefoot, concerning whom there is no disagreement regarding the validity of his *iḥrām*, and he is something the Law is silent about. Everything the Sacred Law is silent about is well-being (*‘āfiyah*). The command to cut has come, so it is joined to what is explicitly stated.
