This is a sound, additional ruling that grants what the absolute ruling does not grant, so adherence to it is specified. He only cut them to join them to the degree of the sandal, except that it involves concealment of the foot, so it differs from the sandal, and it does not conceal the shin, so it differs from the *khuff*. Thus, it is neither *khuff* nor sandal, but it is close to the *khuff* and close to the sandal. We made it a protection in the higher aspect due to the existence of wiping over the top of the *khuff*. Were it not for the consideration of some harm in that aspect, the top of the *khuff* would not be wiped in ablution, because initiating purification indicates an existent ailment that one wishes to remove by initiating that purification. Purification that is not initiated does not have this ruling, for it is pure by origin, not by purification.

### The Gnostic Acts According to His Station and His Witnessing

In this matter, man, if he is a Gnostic (عارف), acts according to the station in which he is placed and what his witnessing (*mashhad*) is. If his witnessing grants him that he should wear them (the cut *khuff*) even with sandals available, fearing the effect of the high realm (العلو) on the top of his foot, he protects his foot from that effect by wearing them. But if he possesses a Divine power (قوة إلهية) by which he repels that effect before it descends upon him, he wears the sandals, and it is not permissible for him to wear the cut *khuff*, since the origin of their use was the absence of sandals. Thus, Unveiling (الكشف) and declaration are preferred over concealment and secrets in the Gnosis of Allah in the Highest Assembly (*al-Malā’ al-A‘lā*), which is the science of legislated and rational transcendence (*tanzīh*).

### Degrees of Transcendence in the Intellect

Transcendence has degrees in the Intellect. What is below it is transcendence with anthropomorphism (*tashbīh*), and the highest degree, according to the Intellect, is transcendence without anthropomorphism, to which no creature has access except by referring the knowledge of it back to Allah the Exalted. Transcendence without anthropomorphism was also brought by the Sacred Law. As for what is found in the Intellect, the utmost rational contemplation in transcending The Real, for example, from *istiwā’* (settling/ascending), is that it moves from explaining corporeal *istiwā’* over the spatial Throne by transcending it, to anthropomorphism with the contingent sovereign *istiwā’*, which is the domination over the greatest encompassing place or over the kingdom. Thus, in its transcendence, it has not ceased anthropomorphism, moving from anthropomorphism with one contingent thing to anthropomorphism with another contingent thing higher in rank. The Intellect has not reached the level of the Sacred Law in transcendence, in His saying: <<لَيْسَ كَمِثْلِهِ شَيْءٌ>> (There is nothing like unto Him). Do you not see that they cited as evidence for rational transcendence concerning *istiwā’* the saying of the poet:

> Bishr settled over Iraq
> Without a sword or blood spilled.

And where is the *istiwā’* of Bishr over Iraq compared to the *istiwā’* of The Real over the Throne? The falsifiers have certainly lost. Where is this spirit compared to His saying: <<لَيْسَ كَمِثْلِهِ شَيْءٌ>> (There is nothing like unto Him)? For the *istiwā’* of Bishr is among the things. Abū Sa‘īd al-Kharrāz and his likes spoke truly when they said: "None knows Allah but Allah."

> None knows yearning save he who suffers it,
> Nor passionate love save he who endures it.

(Continuation: A chapter on the disagreement among people concerning the consecrated person wearing saffron-dyed garments (*mu‘aṣfar*), after their agreement that he should not wear garments dyed with *wars* or saffron)

Some said there is no harm in wearing saffron-dyed garments, for they are not perfume (*ṭīb*). Others said they are perfume, so a ransom (*fidyah*) is due if he wears them.

### Perfume is Not Permissible for the Consecrated Person

The use of perfume (*al-taṭayyub*) by the pilgrim in the state of *ihram* (المحرم)—and I mean the act of applying perfume, not the mere presence of perfume applied before the intention of *ihram* (عقد الإحرام) and carried over—is not permissible, except when he intends to exit the state of *ihram* (الإحلال). Before he exits *ihram*, it is a Sunnah (recommended practice) to apply perfume.

I do not say regarding the first and second instances (before *ihram* and before exiting *ihram*) that his application of perfume, peace be upon him, was for his state of *ihram* and his state of non-*ihram* (حلّه), for that was not transmitted from the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him. Rather, it was transmitted from the saying of Aisha, which allows for the possibility that it was based on an instruction she understood from the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, concerning what her own insight and understanding dictated, or based on an explicit text (نص صريح) from him to her regarding that matter. And we have seen that he forbade perfume during the period of remaining in *ihram*, except when one intended to exit the state of *ihram*.

### [Safflower's ruling is like perfume (العصفر حكمه حكم الطيب)]

Safflower (*al-ʿuṣfur*), even though it is not perfume, its ruling is like that of perfume. If one wears a safflower-dyed garment (*al-ridā’ al-muʿaṣfar*) before entering *ihram* and at the time of *ihram*, and there is no explicit text commanding its avoidance, he may remain in it. Or, he may wear it when exiting *ihram* and before exiting *ihram*. However, he should not wear it initially during the period of remaining in *ihram*. This is the most apparent ruling on this matter according to us, unless an explicit text (نص جلي) is transmitted concerning the safflower-dyed garment, forbidding it initially, finally, and in between, in which case we would abide by it.

### [The servant's emptiness from himself or from his Lord in this worship (خلو العبد عن نفسه أو عن ربه في هذه العبادة)]

The yellowness (*al-ṣufra*) of the safflower-dyed item signifies emptiness (*al-khālī*) and voidness (*al-khalī*). It is for this reason that the month of Safar was named so when this name was first established, due to the earth being empty of vegetation at that time, corresponding to the establishment of this name. This is why it was permitted, despite its remoteness, due to the arrival of spring which removed the earth's emptiness in the first crescent moon called Safar.

If the servant empties himself (خلى العبد عن نفسه) in this act of worship, then he is the one for whom wearing the safflower-dyed garment is permissible. But if he empties himself of his Lord (خلى عن ربه) in it, wearing the safflower-dyed garment is not permissible for him. This is why the difference of opinion (الخلاف) arose concerning it.

(Chapter on their difference regarding the permissibility of perfume for the pilgrim at the time of *ihram* and before entering *ihram*, due to the lingering effect remaining after *ihram*)

Some people disliked it, and others permitted it. I hold the view that it is permissible; indeed, it is the Sunnah according to me, without doubt. As for before *ihram*, it is permissible. But once he has entered *ihram*, the true point of contention among scholars is whether he must wash off that perfume due to the lingering scent or not.

### [Perfume is the praise of the servant with Divine descriptions (الطيب هو الثناء على العبد بالنعوت الإلهية)]

The scent of perfume is enjoyed by the possessor of a sound nature (*al-ṭabʿ al-salīm*), and his soul does not find it foul. This scent is the praise (*al-thanā’*) bestowed upon the servant through the Divine descriptions (*al-nuʿūt al-ilāhiyya*), which is the assumption of the character of the Beautiful Names (*al-Asmā’ al-Ḥusnā*), not merely the Names in general.

In this act of worship (Hajj), the state of servanthood (*maqām al-ʿubūdiyya*) predominates, due to the restrictions (*al-taḥjīr*) and the actions whose wisdom is unknown to rational consideration (*al-naẓar al-ʿaqlī*). It is as if it is pure worship, which can only be established through the descriptions of servanthood (*awṣāf al-ʿubūda*).

Whoever holds this view prohibits the assumption of the character of the Names (*al-takhalluq bi’l-Asmā’*) in this state and at the beginning of entering it, because one does not enter it with a Divine Name (اسم إلهي). Thus, he does not apply perfume when entering *ihram*, fearing the scent that remains during *ihram*. This is analogous to the ruling of the Divine creation (*al-khalq al-ilāhī*) in the one who assumes its character.

### [There is no created thing except that Allah has been described by it among the descriptions of the servants (ما ثم خلق إلا وقد اتصف الله به من أوصاف العباد)]

And whoever holds that it is permissible for him, his witnessing (*mashhad*) is that there is no created thing (*khalq*) except that Allah the Exalted has been described by it, among the descriptions of the servants, such as joy, laughter, wonder, and other things, explicitly, as we have explained, and implicitly, such as His saying: "And lend to Allah" (وأَقْرِضُوا الله), and His saying: "Allah mocks them" (الله يَسْتَهْزِئُ بِهِمْ), and His saying: "And Allah planned" (ومَكَرَ الله), and similar examples.

Whoever has this witnessing says that the human servant is never devoid of a Divine description (*naʿt ilāhī*) that rests upon him, so he permits it (the perfume). However, he does not initiate the application of perfume during the period of remaining in *ihram* until he intends to exit *ihram*, because during the period of remaining in *ihram*, he is under the subjugation (*qahr*) of the Name of Servanthood (*ism al-ʿubūda*). Thus, he is not permitted to initiate a Divine praise (*thanā’ ilāhī*) that would remove the ruling granted by the Ruling Name (*al-ism al-ḥākim*) for that worship. For that worship cannot be conceived except by the ruling of this Name. If it were removed, there would be none to establish it except the substitute (*al-nā’ib*), which is the expiation (*al-fidya*), and nothing else.

### [The First of everything is strong, not overcome, and truthful, not lying (الأول من كل شي‏ء قوى لا يغلب وصادق لا يكذب‏)]

As for the ruling of perfume for *ihram* and exiting *ihram* (الإحلال), it belongs to the sovereignty of the Name *al-Awwal* (The First). For the First of everything is strong, not overcome, and truthful, not lying. No other Name possesses this strength, so no contender can resist it. Its reality is pure primacy, so it cannot be intermediate. Thus, it rules at the beginning of *ihram* and at the end of *ihram*. This is what Aisha understood from the matter.

So she said: "I perfumed the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, for his state of non-*ihram* (حلّه) and for his state of *ihram* (حرمه)," before the existence of *ihram* from him and before the exiting of *ihram* (التحليل). She did not say, "I perfumed him for the end of his *ihram* when he intended it to conclude and be followed by exiting *ihram*." Rather, she observed the exiting of *ihram* in the last actions of the Hajj, which is the *Tawaf al-Ifadah* (Circumambulation of Overflowing), just as she observed the future *ihram* (الإحرام المستقبل) by not washing off the perfume.

(Chapter on sexual intercourse with women)

Muslims are unanimous that sexual intercourse (*al-waṭ’*) is absolutely forbidden for the pilgrim in *ihram*. I hold this view, except that if it occurs, we have a consideration regarding the time of its occurrence. If it occurs after the standing at Arafat (الوقوف بعرفة)—that is, after the time of permissible standing at Arafat has passed, whether night or day—the Hajj is vitiated (*fāsid*) but not void (*bāṭil*), because he is commanded to complete the rituals (*al-manāsik*) despite the vitiation, and he must perform Hajj again afterward.

If he has intercourse before the standing at Arafat but after entering *ihram*, the ruling among scholars is the same as if it occurred after the standing: it vitiates the Hajj, and this is necessary, without any known difference of opinion. I do not know their evidence for this. Although we adopt their view and follow them in it, rational consideration (*al-naẓar*) dictates that if it occurred before the standing, he should abandon what has passed, renew his *ihram*, and offer a sacrifice (*yahdī*). If it occurred after the standing, he should not, because the time for standing has passed. Here (before Arafat), the time for *ihram* remains. However, since no one has stated this, we follow what the scholars have agreed upon, even though I cannot dismiss this ruling from my mind, nor do I act upon it, nor do I issue a legal opinion based on it, nor do I find evidence for it.

Aisha abandoned the *Umrah* when she menstruated after having entered into it, and she entered into *ihram* for Hajj. Thus, she abandoned an *ihram*. Regarding Aisha’s situation, I have a consideration: Did she combine Hajj with her *Umrah* (أردفت على عمرتها) or did she abandon it entirely? If the abandonment (*al-rafḍ*) meant leaving the *ihram* of *Umrah*, and that the presence of menstruation affected its validity while the time for *ihram* remained, then intercourse (*al-jimāʿ*) is similar in ruling. If, however, the abandonment did not mean exiting the *Umrah*, but rather introducing Hajj upon it, then she abandoned the singularity (*aḥadiyya*) of the *Umrah*, not its conjunction with Hajj. In this case, she remained in her *ihram* for *Umrah*, with Hajj added upon it.

### [The human being is directed under the ruling of the Divine Names (الإنسان مصرفا تحت حكم الأسماء الإلهية)]

Regarding sexual intercourse during Hajj on the path, there is no doubt that the human being is directed (*muṣarrafan*) under the ruling of the Divine Names (*al-Asmā’ al-Ilāhiyya*) and is the locus for the manifestation of their sovereignty’s effects. However, their ruling upon him is according to what the human’s state, time, or place makes possible for them. The Divine Names govern the states and times, even though every state he is in, or the human’s entry into the capacity (*ẓarfiyya*) of a specific time or place, is only by the ruling of a Divine Name concerning that.

Many rulings of Divine Names may be directed toward the human being simultaneously, and he accepts all of that according to his state, because he may be in different states, each state demanding the ruling of a specific Name. Thus, only that Name demanded by that specific state is directed toward him. Despite all this, the Greatest Ruler (*al-Ḥākim al-Akbar*) must be a Name that has ultimate authority (*al-maḍā’*) in the matter and to which the return is made, even with this participation.

### [The human being is one in himself, possessing multiple instruments (الإنسان واحد في نفسه ذو آلات متعددة)]

Then I will clarify for you an example of what we have mentioned. We see the human being avoiding what Allah has forbidden for his eye to look at, while violating the sanctity of what is forbidden for his ear, such as listening to backbiting, while simultaneously violating the sanctity of what is forbidden for his tongue, such as lying or slander, while also giving obligatory charity (*zakāt*) or voluntary supererogatory charity (*nadb*) through his spending hand, which was commanded to do so. All of this occurs at one time, from one person, who is the addressed human being, directing all his limbs, accepting the commands of the Names (*al-awāmir al-asma’iyya*) in his inner being, which rule over him and execute the direction of the limbs by his command to them in what he sees them doing. He is one in himself, possessing multiple instruments (*ālat*).

Were it not for the multiplicity of these instruments, it would only be valid for a single Name to rule over him. Thus, the existence of multiplicity, caused by the instruments, necessitated for him—despite his oneness in himself (*aḥadiyya*)—the acceptance of the differing rulings of the Divine Names upon him. Therefore, the human being may be victorious (*manṣūr*) from one perspective, yet abandoned (*makhdhūl*) at the very moment he is victorious, but from another perspective. The directing, responsible essence (*al-ʿayn al-muṣarrifa al-mukallafa*) is one: the rational soul (*al-nafs al-nāṭiqa*).

He may be honored (*ʿazīz*) by the Name *al-Muʿizz* (The Bestower of Honor) while simultaneously being humiliated (*dhalīl*) by the Name *al-Mudhill* (The Humiliator) toward a person of honor who holds a high status with him; he meets him, and he honors him, so he becomes honored. At that very same moment, the Name *al-Mudhill* empowers another person he does not know over him, who humiliates him, so he is humiliated from this direction and honored from that direction, all in the same time, with both rulings occurring simultaneously. The recipient of these two rulings is the same essence (*al-ʿayn*).

Because of what we have established, the pilgrim in *ihram* who has intercourse with his wife is commanded to proceed in the station of his ritual (*maqām nusukih*) until he finishes, despite its vitiation, and it is not counted (as valid Hajj). He must perform the Hajj again the following year in a specific manner prescribed by the Lawgiver (*al-Shāriʿ*). This is because the Master of the Time (*ṣāḥib al-waqt*), who is the one forbidden specific actions necessitated by this worship he has undertaken, is the Greatest Ruler (*al-Ḥākim al-Akbar*). It happened that this pilgrim turned, by the Abandoning Name (*al-ism al-khādhi*l), toward his wife and had intercourse with her while in *ihram*. Since the time was not legally his, but belonged to another, it did not strengthen his power, so it vitiated what it vitiated. The ruling remained with the Master of the Time, who commanded him to proceed with his ritual despite its vitiation, and punished him for that turning toward the Abandoning Name—since he aided it by looking at his wife and approving the act—by the ruling of the Ruler of the Time, which is to repeat the Hajj the following year. If the Hajj had been voided and its ruling removed from him at that time, and the intercourse occurred after *ihram* and before the standing, he would have abandoned what had passed and started the Hajj anew, and would only owe a sacrifice (*dam*) and nothing else, because it was voided. Since the ruling was not removed from him by that act, he was commanded to complete the ritual he intended in his contract. He is rewarded for what he performed of that worship and burdened with sin (*ma’zūr*) for what he vitiated of it by committing what was forbidden to him, as the Exalted said: <<فَلا رَفَثَ ولا فُسُوقَ ولا جِدالَ في الْحَجِ>> (There shall be no sexual intimacy [rafath], nor wickedness [fusūq], nor disputing [jidāl] during the Hajj).

### [The Interpreter of The Real is the Master of the Time and the Ruler of the Moment (ترجمان الحق هو صاحب الزمان وحاكم الوقت‏)]

Abu Dawud transmitted in *Al-Marasil* (The Disconnected Narrations), saying: Abu Tawbah narrated to us, saying: Mu'awiyah—meaning Ibn Salam—narrated to us, saying: Yazid ibn Nu'aym or Zayd ibn Nu'aym (Abu Tawbah was doubtful) informed me that a man from Judham had intercourse with his wife while they were both in *ihram*. The man asked the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, who said to them: "Complete your ritual (*nusuk*), offer a sacrifice (*hady*), then return until you are at the place where you committed what you committed. Separate, and let neither of you see the other. You must perform another Hajj. You shall approach until you are at the place where you committed what you committed. Separate, and let neither of you see the other. Then enter *ihram*, complete your ritual, and offer a sacrifice."

This Interpreter of The Real (*turjumān al-Ḥaqq*), who is the Messenger, strengthened the Divine Name which is the Ruler of the Moment (*ḥākim al-waqt*) and the Master of the Time (*ṣāḥib al-zamān*) in what it desired: the completion of this worship despite the violation that occurred in it. This is because the Ruling Name does not allow the one ruled over to hear its address directly, for Allah has taken his hearing away from it. So He said to the one whose hearing Allah opened to hear His speech—who is expressed as the Messenger—"Convey to this responsible person (*mukallaf*) on My behalf that he must proceed with his action until it is completed." And He mentioned to him what He said and clarified it to this person, because the Messenger <<ما يَنْطِقُ عَنِ الْهَوى>> (does not speak from [his own] inclination). The believer is abundant through his brother. Thus, the Messenger stood in the position of the chamberlain (*al-ḥājib*) who executes the commands of the King, the possessor of the ruling. This is how it is in the general ruling.

### [The ruling of the natural soul over a Divine intellect that returned to it (حكم النفس الطبيعية على عقل إلهى رجع إليها)]

As for the more specific world (*al-ʿālam al-akhaṣṣ*), it is the ruling of a natural soul (*nafs ṭabīʿiyya*) over a Divine intellect (*ʿaql ilāhī*) that returned to it, based on the intellect’s knowledge that the soul has a specific aspect toward its Creator. Thus, the intellect failed to verify what the Interpreter of The Real, who is the Messenger, conveyed to it. So the soul agreed with what the nature (*al-ṭabʿ*) ruled upon it concerning what it commanded. Were it not for that specific aspect, the intellect would not have been deceived and characterized by baseness (*al-lu’m*), which is the original characteristic of nature. Regarding such a situation, we said:

> It is grievous for us that our intellects should be under the rule of souls; indeed, that is immense.
> If base nature overcomes its neighbor, the intellect of a person, then he is base.

### [The nadir opposes its zenith (الحضيض يقابل أوجه‏)]

Although the intellects (*al-ʿuqūl*) are at a high zenith (*al-awj*), the nadir (*al-ḥaḍīḍ*) opposes its zenith. The nadir is the locus of the psychic nature (*al-ṭabʿ al-nafsī*). It looks at the intellects from various aspects and sees them opposite itself on a straight line without deviation. That line is the path upon which the ascent from the nadir to the zenith occurs when the soul is purified (*zakāt al-nafs*), and it is also the path upon which the intellect descends from the zenith to the nadir when the intellect is abandoned (*khudhila al-ʿaql*). What abandoned it was the straightness of the line, for it was created upon straightness. Then it saw that the soul was purified by its ascent upon it. This is what deceived the intellect from the soul, for the intellect has no share in nature, yet it aided the descent.

The saying of the Interpreter, the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him: "If you were to lower a rope, it would descend upon Allah."

The intellect is naturally inclined to seek an increase in the Knowledge of Allah. So, in its descent toward nature along that line, it intended to see whether the relationship of The Real (*al-Ḥaqq*) to the nadir is the same as its relationship to the zenith, or not. It desires knowledge through direct experience (*dhawq*) as to whether it is upon that limit or not, or if it has another relationship. Thus, benefit is achieved in any case. It was for this purpose, too, that he was commanded to complete his ritual, and his action was not voided. Especially since it has been heard that four angels met: one coming from the West, another approaching from the East, another descending from above, and another ascending from below. Each asked his companion, "Where have you come from?" and each replied, "From Allah." Therefore, the intellect, with its yearning to seek an increase in Knowledge, must move to attain this Knowledge of Allah through immediate, experiential tasting (*dhawq ḥāliyy*) that contains no imitation (*taqlīd*). It cannot achieve this while remaining at its zenith unless it contents itself with imitation. So it descended along that line seeking these gnoses (*maʿārif*). In its descent, it must see the point where the lines meet, and thus witness much knowledge. This slip (*zalla*) necessitated knowledge, and that knowledge interceded for the owner of this slip, thereby compensating for his deficiency. Were it not for the slip of this person who had intercourse during Hajj, we would not have known the legal ruling concerning it had this occurred after the death of the Interpreter, peace and blessings be upon him. Thus, out of Allah’s mercy, the establishment of this knowledge occurred, so that we may be upon clear insight (*baṣīra*) from our Lord in our acts of worship.

(Chapter on the washing of the pilgrim after *ihram*)

They agreed that it is permissible for him to wash his head due to ritual impurity (*janāba*). They differed regarding the dislike (*karāhiyya*) of washing it for reasons other than ritual impurity. Some said there is no harm in washing it, and I hold this view. Others disliked it.

### [The head is the locus of human powers and the gathering place of spiritual powers (الرأس محل القوى الإنسانية ومجمع القوى الروحانية)]

Since the head is the locus of all human powers (*al-quwā al-insāniyya*) and the gathering place of spiritual powers (*al-quwā al-rūḥāniyya*), the ruling is considered in relation to it, rather than other limbs, due to its comprehensiveness (*jamʿiyya*). Its share among the Divine Names is Allah, because it is the comprehensive, described Name. Therefore, its preservation is incumbent upon the responsible person (*al-mukallaf*). For if one of its powers were to fail, that failure would lead either to a vitiation that can be rectified, or to a vitiation that cannot be rectified, or to a vitiation that results in his destruction, whereby he loses his humanity and reverts to the category of animals. In this case, the religious obligation (*al-taklīf*) falls away from him, and the relationship between him and Allah is severed—I mean specifically the relationship of proximity (*munāsabat al-taqrīb*), not the relationship of need (*munāsabat al-iftiqār*), because the relationship of need never leaves the contingent being (*al-mumkin*), neither in its state of non-existence nor in its state of existence.

### [If The Real wills to grant you, He descends to what you ascend to (إذا أراد الحق أن يمنحك نزل إليك ما أنت تصعد إليه‏)]

When the human being becomes estranged from the station of his servanthood (*mawṭin ʿubūdiyyatih*), that is his ritual impurity (*janāba*). He is told: "Return to your homeland, for you have no footing in Lordship (*al-rubūbiyya*) whatsoever from your own essence (*dhāt*)." If The Real (*al-Ḥaqq*) wills to grant you what He wills of it, He descends to you what you ascend to, because He knows you, your place, and your location, while you do not know Him, so where would you seek Him? You only departed from your servanthood due to your ignorance. Do you not see that when the Exalted willed to bestow upon you what He willed of Lordship (*al-rubūbiyya*), He descended to you with a matter He called Law (*Sharʿ*), through the mediation of an angelic messenger? He made you master of certain matters and granted you authority over them according to what He prescribed for you. Your being a ruler in these matters is the measure of Lordship He granted you, and the measure He limited for you and prevented you from exceeding is what He retained of servanthood upon you.

> So you are a king and you are a servant, and you are in yourself borrowed.
> And there is no existence except in the essence, so there is neither ruling nor need.
> One like me is bewildered by the one in whom you are bewildered, so there is neither compulsion nor choice.
> And there is neither annihilation (*fanā’*) nor subsistence (*baqā’*), nor flight nor settlement.

### [Purity and cleanliness are the aim of the Lawgiver (الطهارة والنظافة مقصود الشارع‏)]

Therefore, washing due to ritual impurity (*janāba*) is obligatory by consensus, because you are a servant by consensus and not a Lord by consensus. As for washing for reasons other than ritual impurity:

> The wisdom of washing is to preserve the powers, and their preservation is among the most obligatory rulings.
> Especially since its being obligatory is because it indicates Knowledge.
> By its essence, and all knowledge belongs to it, intrinsically, such as quality and quantity.
> Allah has favored it over His creation due to its excellence of understanding.

Whoever observed the preservation of these powers from harm that might afflict them—such as the closing of pores and the reflection of harmful vapors that affect them—affirmed the washing. And whoever prioritized the sanctity (of *ihram*) due to the short duration and the rarity of harm, the necessitating factor was weak for him, so he disliked it. Do you not see how they agreed on washing for ritual impurity due to the strength of the necessitating factor, even though washing with water increases the dishevelment (*shaʿath*) in matting the hair? Allah the Exalted has commanded us to cast off dirt (*al-tafath*) from ourselves for the sake of preserving the powers and what is analogous to them, because purity (*al-ṭahāra*) and cleanliness (*al-naẓāfa*) are intended by the Lawgiver (*al-Shāriʿ*), for He is *al-Quddūs* (The Holy), and He has no Name that opposes Him such that it would have a ruling.

### [The strongest transcendence in the Divine Presence (التنزيه الأقوى في الجناب الإلهى‏)]

When the scholars of external forms (*ʿulamā’ al-rusūm*) were ignorant of the wisdom of this worship, since they lacked Divine unveiling (*kashf ilāhī*) from the side of The Real, they deemed most of its actions to be purely devotional (*taʿabbudan*). And excellent is what they did, for this is our doctrine concerning all acts of worship, even when we rationally understand the reasons (*ʿilal*) for some of them, either by legal definition or by inference (*istinbāṭ*) according to the proponents of analogy (*qiyās*). Despite all this, we do not exclude them from being pure devotion from Allah, since the reasons are not effective in bringing about the ruling, even with the existence of the reason and its being intended. This is the strongest form of transcendence (*tanzīh*) in the Divine Presence (*al-janāb al-ilāhī*), if you understand.

(Chapter on the pilgrim washing his head with mallow)

As for the pilgrim washing his head with mallow (*al-khuṭmī*), they agreed on forbidding it. If he washes with it, some said expiation (*al-fidā’*) is due, while others said nothing is due if he washes. I hold the latter view, without forbidding it or anything else.

### [Every cause necessitating cleanliness should be used (كل سبب موجب للنظافة ينبغي استعماله‏)]

Since every cause necessitating cleanliness (*al-naẓāfa*), outwardly and inwardly, should be used in every state. For <<إِنَّ اللهَ جَمِيلٌ يُحِبُّ الْجَمَالَ>> (Indeed, Allah is Beautiful and loves beauty). No Book, Sunnah, or consensus has been transmitted forbidding the pilgrim from washing his head with anything.

### [Among the reality of the form upon which man was created is honor (من حقيقة الصورة التي خلق عليها الإنسان العزة)]

When Allah the Exalted commanded the human being to enter *ihram*, thereby becoming sacred (*ḥarām*) after having been permissible (*ḥalāl*), He described him with the attribute of honor (*al-ʿizza*): that nothing of the things that reached him before he was characterized by this immunity should reach him. For things seek the human being because they were created for his sake, and they seek him through the subjugation (*al-taskhīr*) upon which Allah created them. The human being is created upon the Form (*al-ṣūra*), and among the reality of the Form upon which he was created is honor: that he should not be perceived or attained in most aspects, such as His saying: <<لا تُدْرِكُهُ الْأَبْصارُ>> (Vision does not encompass Him)—meaning in this world—and <<وُجُوهٌ يَوْمَئِذٍ ناضِرَةٌ إِلَى رَبِّها ناظِرَةٌ>> (Faces, that Day, will be radiant, looking at their Lord), despite the affirmation of vision in the Hereafter. This is a relative honor (*ʿizza iḍāfiyya*), because He restricted and then permitted. So He granted honor and restriction to the one who attained the Form through his creation, in acts of worship such as fasting, Hajj, and prayer, preventing some of what was created for his sake from reaching him. Thus, he became honored and immune from some things, yet he was not prevented from being attained by some of them, just as the one created upon His Form was not prevented from being attained by piety (*al-taqwā*) from us, and piety is in the pious among His creation. Thus, He strengthened the ambiguity in the ambiguous matters so that the proofs might be joined to the ambiguities, since all is from Him and to Him; indeed, all is His very Essence (*ʿayn*).

### [Things were not forbidden to man, rather he is forbidden to them (ما حرمت الأشياء على الإنسان بل هو حرام عليها)]

Things were not truly forbidden to him; rather, he is the one forbidden to the things, because he was created only for his Lord, and things were created for him. Thus, they seek him just as he seeks his Lord. Immunity at one time is like immunity, and attainment at one time is like attainment, if you understand. I have clarified your rank (*martaba*) for you. The Exalted said concerning the human being: <<وَسَخَّرَ لَكُمْ ما في السَّماواتِ وما في الْأَرْضِ جَمِيعاً مِنْهُ>> (And He has subjected to you whatever is in the heavens and whatever is on the earth—all from Him). And He said: <<هُوَ الَّذِي خَلَقَ لَكُمْ ما في الْأَرْضِ جَمِيعاً>> (It is He who created for you all of that which is on the earth). And He said: <<وما خَلَقْتُ الْجِنَّ والْإِنْسَ إِلَّا لِيَعْبُدُونِ>> (And I did not create the jinn and mankind except to worship Me). And in the Torah revealed to Moses, peace be upon him: "O Son of Adam, I created things for your sake, and I created you for My sake. So do not violate what I created for My sake by means of what I created for your sake."

Thus, the Exalted clarified your rank for you, so that you may know the locus of your humiliation (*dhilla*) from the locus of your honor (*ʿizza*). You did not become honored or sacred (*ḥarām*) to things by yourself; rather, He made you sacred to things, preventing them from attaining you. He commanded you to enter *ihram*, so you entered *ihram* and became sacred. He only established this for you through His command so that it might be a means of proximity (*qurba*) to Him and an increase in status with Him, the Exalted, and so that you would not forget your servanthood upon which you were created. His making you commanded in this immunity is a beneficial remedy for you, preventing an ailment that might afflict you due to your great status. It is inevitable that your creation upon His Form (*ṣūra*) affects you with honor in your soul. So He legislated it for you in obedience to Him, by commanding you to be sacred—not as a restriction upon you, but as a restriction for you.

### [Man is a servant essentially and by rank, and a master essentially but not by rank (الإنسان عبد عينا ورتبة سيد عينا لا رتبة)]

Do you not see how the one whom Allah abandoned (Pharaoh) claimed honor over his peers by saying: <<أَنَا رَبُّكُمُ الْأَعْلى>> (I am your Lord, the Most High)? Did anything cause him to do this except his knowledge of his rank (*martaba*), not his knowledge of his own essence (*nafs*)? The human being is a servant essentially (*ʿaynan*) and by rank (*rutba*), just as he is a master essentially (*ʿaynan*) but not by rank (*rutba*). Therefore, if he claims the rank, he is broken and forbidden; but if he claims the essence, he is protected and shown mercy. The human being is one in reality, except that he is divided between the one who is cared for and the one who is not cared for. This is the consideration of this chapter. And Allah <<يَقُولُ الْحَقَّ وهُوَ يَهْدِي السَّبِيلَ>> (speaks The Truth and guides to the way). End of the Sixty-Fourth Part.

(In the Name of Allah, the Most Compassionate, the Most Merciful)

(Chapter on the pilgrim entering the bathhouse)

Some people disliked it, and some said there is no harm in it. I hold this view.

### [The bathhouse softens the body, removes dirt, and reminds of the Hereafter (الحمام ينعم البدن ويزيل الدرن ويذكر الآخرة)]

There is nothing in the states of this world that points to the Hereafter, or rather, to Allah the Exalted and to the measure of the human being, like the bathhouse (*al-ḥammām*). Umar ibn al-Khattab, may Allah be pleased with him, said when he entered the bathhouse in Syria: "What an excellent house the bathhouse is: it softens the body, removes dirt (*al-daran*), and reminds one of the Hereafter." Since these are its effects on the servant, its use should not be disliked for him, for it is an excellent companion (*ṣāḥib*). It was named *ḥammām* because it derives from *ḥamīm*, and *ḥamīm* means a compassionate companion (*al-ṣāḥib al-shafīq*). The Exalted said: <<فَما لَنا من شافِعِينَ ولا صَدِيقٍ حَمِيمٍ>> (So we have no intercessors, nor a devoted friend [ḥamīm]), meaning compassionate. It was called *ḥamīm* due to its heat, and water is used in it due to its moisture. The bathhouse is hot and moist, the nature of life, and by it the body is softened. By water, the dirt is removed. By stripping the entrant of his clothes and remaining naked, possessing nothing in his hands of all that he owns, it reminds him of the Hereafter, death, and the rising of people from their graves, naked and barefoot, possessing nothing. Entering the bathhouse is a greater indicator of the Hereafter than death, for the deceased is not turned over to his grave until he is clothed, while the entrant to the bathhouse does not enter until he is stripped. And stripping is a greater indicator. Furthermore, it is part of the Prophet’s supplication, peace and blessings be upon him: "O Allah, purify me from sins and transgressions as a garment is purified from dirt." And the purification of the body from dirt and filth is one of the most specific characteristics of the bathhouse, and it was established for this reason. The consideration of the bathhouse in relation to the states of the Hereafter is a vast field of great benefit, understood only by the Gnostics of Allah (*al-ʿulamā’ bi’llāh*).

(Chapter on the prohibition of land game for the pilgrim in *ihram*)

### [The game of the ascetic and the game of the Gnostic (صيد الزاهد وصيد العارف‏)]

They agreed upon this, and it is also the agreement of the People of Allah (*Ahl Allāh*) regarding its consideration and meaning. Some of them said: The ascetic (*al-zāhid*) is the game of The Real (*ṣayd al-Ḥaqq*) from the world (*al-dunyā*), and the Gnostic (*al-ʿārif*) is the game of The Real from Paradise (*al-janna*). The ascetic inclines toward His saying: <<وما عِنْدَ الله خَيْرٌ وأَبْقى>> (And what is with Allah is better and more lasting), and the Gnostic inclines toward His saying: <<والله خَيْرٌ وأَبْقى>> (And Allah is better and more lasting). Creation (*al-khalq*) is game for The Real; He hunts them from their souls, whether on land or sea. I shall clarify this, if Allah wills.

### [The snares of The Real for hunting stray souls (حبالات الحق لصيد النفوس الشاردة)]

Know that The Real (*al-Ḥaqq*) the Exalted set up snares (*ḥibālāt*) to hunt the souls straying from the worship for which they were created. Then He deceived them with the bait (*al-ḥabb*) He placed for them in those snares, or the lures, or the living beings similar to them in life, which He made confined in the snares without the observers realizing it. Among the game, some were caught in the snare by seeing their own kind, hoping to join them to see what they were experiencing. Thus, they fell into the grasp of the hunter and were bound. This game was the intended target because it was sought for its own sake. Other game was caught by the greed to obtain the bait scattered in the snare. Furthermore, the hunter has whistles with which he imitates the sounds of birds; when the bird hears them, it descends and falls into the snare. This is analogous to one who hears the call of The Real and responds. This one was not hunted by benevolence (*al-iḥsān*). The other was shown benevolence through the bait scattered in the snare; he saw it, and the benevolence led him, so he threw himself upon it, and the hunter caught him. Were it not for the benevolence, he would not have come to it, so his coming is conditional (*maʿlūl*). Righteousness (*al-birr*) is the Benefactor (*al-muḥsin*) and the benevolence (*al-iḥsān*). The Real is jealous (*ghayūr*). He did not intend for this specific group, whom He made sacred (*ḥarām*) to be for Him, to become slaves of benevolence (*ʿabīd iḥsān*), existing for benevolence and not for Him. For this reason, He called them disheveled and dusty (*shuʿath ghubr*), stripped of sewn garments, responding to His call with the *ihlāl* (the loud declaration of *talbiya*), just as the bird resorts to the sound of the hunter. Thus, due to their status, He forbade them land game (*ṣayd al-barr*), which is benevolence (*al-iḥsān*), as long as they are sacred (*ḥuram*), permissible (*ḥalāl*) in the permissible and sacred place, and residents in the sacred place, whether they are permissible or sacred. Wherever the sanctity (*ḥurma*) exists, the hunting of benevolence is prohibited. For jealousy (*al-ghīra*) is one of Allah’s attributes. He did not wish to call this group, characterized by *ihram*, through the door of blessings and benevolence, thereby making them slaves of benevolence and not slaves of Reality (*ʿabīd ḥaqīqa*), for that is a slight against the Divine Presence (*al-janāb al-ilāhī*).

### [Whoever accompanies you for a purpose, his companionship ends when it ends (من صحبك لغرض انقضت صحبته بانقضائه‏)]

So He said: "Whoever accompanies you for a purpose, his companionship ends when that purpose ends." The companionship of the servant with his Lord ought to be essential (*dhātiyya*), just as it is in reality, because the servant cannot escape the grasp of his Master. Even if he flees in his own estimation, he has not left His dominion. He is ignorant of his Master's dominion, for wherever he walks, he walks within His dominion. He has not left the dominion of his Master, nor His ownership. For to Allah belongs the dominion of the heavens and the earth. For this reason, land game was forbidden to the pilgrim, and this is related to his saying, peace and blessings be upon him: "Love Allah for what He nourishes you with of His blessings," which is an an address from Him to the slaves of benevolence, since they were ignorant of their true measure and what is incumbent upon them of submission and obedience to the Majesty of Allah.

### [Water is the element of life from which Allah created every living thing (الماء عنصر الحياة الذي خلق الله منه كل شي‏ء حى‏)]

Sea game was not forbidden to the pilgrim while he is in *ihram* because sea game is the game of water, and water is the element of life (*ʿunṣur al-ḥayāt*) from which Allah created every living thing. The objective of establishing this worship and others is the life of the hearts (*ḥayāt al-qulūb*), as He said: <<أَ ومن كانَ مَيْتاً فَأَحْيَيْناهُ>> (Is he who was dead and We gave him life?) in the context of praising this. Since the objective is the life of the hearts and the limbs through this worship and all acts of worship, both outwardly and inwardly, a correspondence (*munāsaba*) occurred between what was demanded of him and water. Thus, its game was not forbidden for him to consume. For this reason, the word *sea* (*baḥr*) was used due to its vastness, for it is comprehensive. This is also the case in reality, for there is nothing of His creation except that it <<يُسَبِّحُ بِحَمْدِهِ>> (glorifies [Him] with His praise), and nothing glorifies except what is alive. Thus, life spread throughout all existing things, and its ruling became vast, corresponding to the vastness of the sea. Therefore, He attributed it to the sea and did not say "to the water," in consideration of the vastness found in the sea. Sea game is permissible for the non-pilgrim (*al-ḥalāl*) and for the pilgrim (*al-ḥarām*).

(Chapter on whether the pilgrim may eat land game hunted by a non-pilgrim)

Some say it is permissible for him to eat it absolutely. Some say it is absolutely forbidden for him. And some say that if it was not hunted for his sake, nor for the sake of a group of pilgrims in *ihram*, then it is permissible to eat it; but if it was hunted for the sake of a pilgrim, it is forbidden for the pilgrim. As for our doctrine on this, nothing has been clearly revealed to me, nor does any evidence preponderate in my view, except that the sound narration transmitted—that if the pilgrim had no involvement (*taʿammul*) in it, he may eat it—is most likely correct. This favors one of the two possibilities for the word *al-ṣayd al-muḥarram* (forbidden game) in the verse, because the mentioned *ṣayd* may mean the act (hunting) or the hunted animal (the game). I do not know which of these The Real intended, or if He intended both the act and the game. Whoever holds that it means the act, not the game, says it is permissible to eat it absolutely. There is no meaning to the saying of those who stipulate that it was not hunted for his sake, because I am not addressed concerning the intention of another. If I commanded the non-pilgrim, or hinted to him, or alerted him, or gestured to him concerning it, or assisted him in any way, then I have involvement in it, and it becomes forbidden for me, and I am sinful for it. Although I have not seen this specific interpretation attributed to others, it is one of the possibilities of the third opinion, which states: "if it was not hunted for his sake." This might mean by his indication or guidance, or it might mean that the non-pilgrim intended to hunt what the pilgrim would eat.

### [The non-pilgrim has no restriction on his action (الحلال لا تحجير عليه في تصرفه‏)]

The non-pilgrim (*al-ḥalāl*) has no restriction (*taḥjīr*) upon his action, thus resembling The Real (*al-Ḥaqq*) in this attribute. For the removal of restriction is transcendence (*tanzīh*) from limitation, and this is a Divine Attribute. No one has the right to refuse, by his own limitation, the direction (*taṣrīf*) of The Real upon him, since his limitation is part of His direction. Thus, he must accept what He directs him into, just as he accepted his limitation, with no difference. This is pure, unadulterated servanthood (*ʿubūdiyya*). When he saw this in the non-pilgrim—that he is not restricted in the way the pilgrim is restricted—I mean, he saw the Divine Attribute whose nature is not to accept restriction, but rather He is the Doer of what He wills. Just as the Exalted resembled the restricted pilgrim in matters He made incumbent upon Himself for His servants in other places, as He said: <<أَوْفُوا بِعَهْدِي أُوفِ بِعَهْدِكُمْ>> (Fulfill My covenant [with you], and I will fulfill your covenant [with Me]). Thus, He included Himself with us. This is one of the most difficult contradictions to the verse of His saying, the Exalted: <<فَعَّالٌ لِما يُرِيدُ>> (Doer of what He intends). For He is not a locus for His action, and His fulfillment of the covenant for the one who fulfills his covenant is necessary due to the truthfulness of His report. He has indeed done what He wills, yet He is not a locus for the attachment of His Will, because He is existent, and no state that He was not upon returns to His Essence from His action. This is the ultimate difficulty in Divine Knowledge (*al-ʿilm al-ilāhī*), and if people are lax concerning it, it is only due to their ignorance of the object of the Will (*mutaʿallaq al-irāda*).

### [The third opinion is the closest to correctness (القول الثالث أقرب الأقوال إلى الصحة)]

The third opinion is the closest of the opinions to correctness, because it is closer to reconciling the narrations transmitted in this chapter. This consideration of ours on this matter is not a fourth opinion, for we have not definitively ruled on it, but I strongly suspect the preponderance of the third opinion over the other two, even if it is not explicitly stated as such.

(Chapter on whether the compelled pilgrim eats carrion or game)

Some say he eats carrion (*al-mayta*) and pork (*al-khinzīr*) but not game. Others say he hunts and eats, and owes expiation (*al-jazā’*). I hold the first view. If he is compelled (*iḍṭurra*) to hunt, he hunts and owes expiation, because he is acting intentionally (*mutaʿammid*). Allah did not distinguish between the compelled and the non-compelled (in terms of the prohibition of hunting).

### [All movements of the cosmos are essentially compulsory (جميع حركات الكون من جهة الحقيقة اضطرارية)]

Compulsion (*al-iḍṭirār*) constantly accompanies every created being, because it is its reality. Despite his compulsion, he is held responsible (*kullifa*). What is incumbent upon him is to abide by what he is held responsible for, because absolute compulsion (*al-iḍṭirār al-muṭlaq*) is never lifted from him. Rather, a specific compulsion toward a certain thing is lifted. Thus, all movements of the cosmos (*al-kawn*) are essentially compulsory (*iḍṭirāriyya*), and he is compelled in them, even though choice (*al-ikhtiyār*) exists in the cosmos, which we recognize.

### [The chooser is compelled in his choice (المختار مجبور في اختياره‏)]

However, there is another knowledge by which we know that the chooser (*al-mukhtār*) is compelled (*majbūr*) in his choice. Indeed, the Realities (*al-Ḥaqā’iq*) dictate that there is no chooser, because we have seen that choice in the chooser is compulsory (*iḍṭirāriyy*); that is, he must be a chooser. Compulsion (*al-iḍṭirār*) is a fixed, undeniable principle that accompanies choice, and choice does not rule over compulsion. All Existence (*al-wujūd*) is under essential determinism (*al-jabr al-dhātī*), not that he is compelled by the compulsion of another. For the one who compels the compelled—who would have been a chooser were it not for his compulsion—is himself compelled in his choice for this compelled one.

> So creation is compelled, especially since the Origin is compelled, so where is the choice?
> Every created being is upon its form, in the state of determinism and in compulsion.
> The created being is distinguished from its Origin by what it possesses of humiliation and need.
> So be with The Real through His attributes, between perpetual determinism and choice.

And Allah <<يَقُولُ الْحَقَّ وهُوَ يَهْدِي السَّبِيلَ>> (speaks The Truth and guides to the way).

(Chapter on the marriage of the pilgrim)

Some say he may neither contract marriage (*yankih*) nor be contracted in marriage (*yunkah*), and if he does, the marriage is void (*bāṭil*). Others say there is no harm in him contracting marriage or being contracted in marriage. The view I hold is that it is disliked (*makrūh*), but not forbidden. And Allah knows best.

### [Ihram is a contract and marriage is a contract (الإحرام عقد والنكاح عقد)]

*Ihram* is a contract (*ʿaqd*) and marriage (*nikāḥ*) is a contract, so they share the same relationship, thus it is permissible.

### [The grazer around the sanctuary (الراتع حول الحمى‏)]

Sexual intercourse (*al-waṭ’*) is forbidden for the pilgrim, and the contract (marriage) is a cause that permits intercourse. Thus, it was forbidden or disliked, for it is a sanctuary (*ḥimā*), and the one grazing around the sanctuary is likely to fall into it. Ambiguous matters (*al-shubah*) are avoided for fear of falling into the forbidden (*al-maḥẓūr*).

### [We are required to know Unity and affirm the One (نحن مطلوبون بمعرفة الوحدة وإثبات الواحد)]

Marriage and the contract are only valid between two; they are not valid from one. Thus, it was forbidden or disliked, because we are required to know Unity (*al-waḥda*) and affirm the One (*al-wāḥid*) and Oneness (*al-waḥdāniyya*). <<وإِلَهُكُمْ إِلَهٌ وَاحِدٌ>> (And your God is one God). <<فَاعْلَمْ أَنَّهُ لا إِلَهَ إِلَّا الله>> (So know that there is no deity except Allah).

### [Theophany in Absolute Oneness is not valid (التجلي في الأحدية لا يصح‏)]

Theophany (*al-tajallī*) in Absolute Oneness (*al-aḥadiyya*) is not valid, because Theophany requires two. Since Theophany is necessary, the two are necessary. Therefore, the marriage contract for the pilgrim is permissible. The Gnostic (*al-ʿārif*) acts according to the states of witnessing (*aḥwāl al-shuhūd*) established within him.

### [Al-Junayd's answer concerning gnosis and the gnostic (جواب الجنيد عن المعرفة والعارف‏)]

Al-Junayd was asked about gnosis (*al-maʿrifa*) and the Gnostic (*al-ʿārif*), and he replied: "The color of the water is the color of its container." Thus, he affirmed the two. So, there must be you and Him. And distinction is necessary, so the One is necessary. If you say, "There is nothing in Existence (*al-wujūd*) except One," you speak the truth. If you say, "There is nothing in Existence except two," you speak the truth. If you say, "There are only two in bringing into existence (*al-ījād*)," you speak the truth, for it proceeds from a single Essence (*dhāt wāḥida*). And if you say, "There is only one in bringing into existence," you speak the truth, because it is impossible for two powers (*qudratayn*) to relate to one object of power (*maqdūr*). Unification (*al-tawḥīd*) is the Unseen (*ghayb*), and affirmation (*al-ithbāt*) is the Witnessed (*shahāda*). And He, the Exalted, is the Knower of the Unseen and the Witnessed. Thus, He affirmed duality (*al-ithnayniyya*) in relation to the world (*al-ʿālam*). In relation to Allah, He is the Knower of the Witnessed only, since it is impossible for anything to be unseen by Him, contrary to those who make existence the cause of vision.

(Chapter on the pilgrims in *ihram*, who are three)

Either one performing *Qirān* (combining Hajj and Umrah), or one performing *Ifrād* (Hajj only), or one performing *Ifrād* with *Umrah* (Umrah only, who is the *Mutamattiʿ*).

### [The Hadith of the Farewell Pilgrimage (حديث حجة الوداع‏)]

This chapter necessitates the citation of the Farewell Pilgrimage (*Ḥajjat al-Wadāʿ*). After citing it, we will mention the rulings related to the actions of this worship, following the style of what has preceded. So we say:

More than one person narrated to us, by permission and hearing, from Ibn Sa’id al-ʿIrāwī, from ʿAbd al-Ghāfir al-Fārisī, from al-Julūdī, from Ibrāhīm ibn Sufyān al-Marwazī, from Muslim ibn al-Ḥajjāj al-Qushayrī, from Jaʿfar ibn Muḥammad ibn ʿAlī ibn al-Ḥusayn, from his father, from Jābir ibn ʿAbd Allāh, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, remained nine years without performing Hajj. Then, in the tenth year, he announced to the people that the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, was performing Hajj. A large number of people came to Medina, all seeking to follow the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, and learn from his actions. We set out with him until we reached Dhū al-Ḥulayfah. Asmā’ bint ʿUmays gave birth to Muḥammad ibn Abī Bakr there, so she sent word to the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, asking how she should proceed. He said: "Bathe, wrap yourself with a cloth, and enter *ihram*." The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, prayed in the mosque, then mounted *al-Qaṣwā’* (his she-camel). When his she-camel stood upright on *al-Baydā’*, I looked as far as my eye could see in front of him, to his right, to his left, and behind him, of riders and walkers. The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, was among us, and the Quran was being revealed to him, and he knew its interpretation. Whatever he did, we did. He declared *ihram* with the declaration of Unity (*al-tawḥīd*): "Labbayka Allāhumma Labbayk, Labbayka lā sharīka laka Labbayk. Inna al-ḥamda wa’l-niʿmata laka wa’l-mulk, lā sharīka lak" (Here I am, O Allah, here I am. Here I am, You have no partner, here I am. Indeed, all praise, grace, and sovereignty belong to You. You have no partner). The people declared *ihram* with what they declared, but the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, did not reject any of it, and he adhered to his *talbiya*. Jābir said: We did not know anything but Hajj; we did not know *Umrah*. When we reached the House (Kaaba) with him, he touched the Corner (Black Stone), then jogged (*ramal*) three times and walked four times. Then he proceeded to the Station of Abraham (*Maqām Ibrāhīm*) and recited: <<وَاتَّخِذُوا مِنْ مَقَامِ إِبْرَاهِيمَ مُصَلًّى>> (And take from the standing place of Abraham a place of prayer). He placed the Station between himself and the House. My father used to say—and I only know him to have mentioned it from the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him—that he recited *Qul Huwa Allāhu Aḥad* (Chapter 112) and *Qul Yā Ayyuhā al-Kāfirūn* (Chapter 109) in the two cycles of prayer. Then he returned to the Corner and touched it. Then he exited through the gate to *al-Ṣafā*. When he drew near *al-Ṣafā*, he recited: <<إِنَّ الصَّفَا وَالْمَرْوَةَ مِنْ شَعَائِرِ اللَّهِ>> (Indeed, al-Ṣafā and al-Marwah are among the symbols of Allah). [He added:] "I begin with what Allah began with." So he began with *al-Ṣafā* and ascended it until he could see the House. He faced the *Qiblah*, affirmed the Oneness of Allah, and magnified Him, saying: "Lā ilāha illā Allāh waḥdahu lā sharīka lah, lahu al-mulku wa lahu al-ḥamdu wa huwa ʿalā kulli shay’in qadīr. Lā ilāha illā Allāh waḥdahu, anjaza waʿdahu wa naṣara ʿabdahu wa hazama al-aḥzāba waḥdahu" (There is no deity except Allah, alone, without partner. To Him belongs sovereignty, and to Him belongs praise, and He is over all things competent. There is no deity except Allah, alone. He fulfilled His promise, supported His servant, and defeated the confederates alone). Then he supplicated between these phrases. He did this three times. Then he descended toward *al-Marwah*. When his feet descended into the bottom of the valley, he hurried until they ascended, then he walked until he reached *al-Marwah*. He did on *al-Marwah* what he did on *al-Ṣafā*. When it was the last circuit on *al-Marwah*, he said: "If I had known in advance what I know now, I would not have brought the sacrificial animal (*al-hady*) and I would have made it an *Umrah*. So, whoever among you does not have a sacrificial animal with him, let him exit *ihram* and make it an *Umrah*." Surāqah ibn Mālik ibn Juʿshum stood up and said: "O Messenger of Allah, is this for this year of ours, or forever?" The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, interlaced his fingers, one into the other, and said: "The *Umrah* has entered into the Hajj," twice. "No, rather, it is forever, forever." ʿAlī arrived from Yemen with the sacrificial animals of the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, and found Fāṭimah having exited *ihram*, wearing dyed clothes and applying kohl. He disapproved of this. She said: "I was commanded to do this." ʿAlī used to say in Iraq: I went to the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, complaining about Fāṭimah for what she had done, seeking a legal opinion from the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, concerning what she mentioned. I informed him that I had disapproved of it. He said: "She spoke the truth, she spoke the truth. What did you say when you intended Hajj?" ʿAlī said: "I said: O Allah, I enter *ihram* with what the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, entered *ihram* with." He said: "Then you have the sacrificial animal with you, so do not exit *ihram*." The total number of sacrificial animals that ʿAlī brought from Yemen and those the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, brought was one hundred. So all the people exited *ihram* and shortened their hair, except the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, and those who had sacrificial animals with them. When the Day of *Tarwiyah* (8th Dhul-Hijjah) arrived, they proceeded to Minā and entered *ihram* for Hajj. The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, rode and prayed the Noon, Afternoon, Sunset, Evening, and Dawn prayers there. Then he waited a little until the sun rose. He commanded a tent of hair to be pitched for him at Namirah. The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, traveled, and Quraysh had no doubt that he would stand at *al-Mashʿar al-Ḥarām* (Muzdalifah), as Quraysh used to do in the time of ignorance (*Jāhiliyya*). But the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, passed on until he reached Arafat and found the tent pitched for him at Namirah. He descended there. When the sun passed the meridian, he commanded *al-Qaṣwā’* to be saddled for him. He came to the bottom of the valley and addressed the people, saying: "Indeed, your blood and your wealth are sacred to you, like the sanctity of this day of yours, in this month of yours, in this land of yours. Behold, everything from the affairs of the *Jāhiliyya* is placed beneath my feet. The blood feuds of the *Jāhiliyya* are abolished. And the first blood feud I abolish from our blood is the blood of Ibn Rabīʿah ibn al-Ḥārith, who was nursed among Banū Saʿd and was killed by Hudhayl. The usury (*ribā*) of the *Jāhiliyya* is abolished, and the first usury I abolish is the usury of al-ʿAbbās ibn ʿAbd al-Muṭṭalib; all of it is abolished. Fear Allah concerning women, for you have taken them as a trust from Allah, and you have made their private parts lawful by the word of Allah. You have the right over them that they should not allow anyone you dislike to tread upon your bedding. If they do that, strike them with a non-injurious strike. And they have the right over you to their provision and clothing according to what is reasonable (<<رِزْقُهُنَّ وكِسْوَتُهُنَّ بِالْمَعْرُوفِ>>). I have left among you that which, if you hold fast to it, you will never go astray: the Book of Allah. And you are asking me, so what will you say?" They said: "We bear witness that you have conveyed the message, fulfilled the trust, and advised the community." He pointed with his index finger, raising it toward the sky, then lowering it toward the people, saying: "O Allah, bear witness! O Allah, bear witness!" three times. Then he gave the call to prayer (*adhān*) and the call to commence prayer (*iqāma*) and prayed the Noon prayer. Then he gave the *iqāma* and prayed the Afternoon prayer, without praying anything between them. Then the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, rode until he reached the standing place (*al-Mawqif*). He placed the belly of his she-camel *al-Qaṣwā’* toward the rocks and placed the rope of the walkers in front of him, facing the *Qiblah*. He remained standing until the sun set and the yellowness disappeared slightly, until the disk vanished. He took Usāmah behind him (on the mount) and departed. The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, held the halter of *al-Qaṣwā’* tightly, so much so that her head touched the saddle’s pommel, and he gestured with his right hand, saying: "O people, calmness, calmness!" Whenever he came to a hill, he loosened the halter slightly so she could ascend. He continued until he reached Muzdalifah, where he prayed the Sunset and Evening prayers with one *adhān* and two *iqāmas*, without performing any supererogatory prayer between them. Then the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, lay down until the dawn rose. He prayed the Dawn prayer when the morning became clear, with an *adhān* and an *iqāma*. Then he mounted *al-Qaṣwā’* until he reached *al-Mashʿar al-Ḥarām* (the Sacred Monument). He faced the *Qiblah*, supplicated to Allah, magnified Him, declared His Oneness, and affirmed His Unity. He remained standing until it became very bright. He departed before the sun rose, taking al-Faḍl ibn ʿAbbās behind him. Al-Faḍl was a man with beautiful hair, fair-skinned, and handsome. As the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, departed, some women on litters passed by quickly. Al-Faḍl began looking at them. The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, placed his hand on al-Faḍl’s face. Al-Faḍl turned his face to the other side to look, so the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, moved his hand from the other side onto al-Faḍl’s face. He turned his face away from the other side until he reached the valley of Muḥassir. He urged his she-camel slightly, then took the middle road that leads out to the Greater Jamrah. He came to the Jamrah near the tree and threw seven pebbles at it, saying *Allāhu Akbar* with each pebble, pebbles the size of date stones. He threw from the bottom of the valley. Then he proceeded to the place of sacrifice (*al-manḥar*) and slaughtered sixty-three camels. Then he gave ʿAlī the rest to slaughter and made him a partner in his sacrificial offering (*hady*). Then he commanded a piece of meat from each camel to be placed in a pot and cooked. They ate from the meat and drank from the broth. The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, rode and proceeded to the House for *al-Ifāḍa* (the Overflowing Circumambulation). He prayed the Noon prayer in Mecca. He came to Banū ʿAbd al-Muṭṭalib, who were providing water from Zamzam, and said: "Draw water, O Banū ʿAbd al-Muṭṭalib. Were it not that people would overwhelm you in providing water, I would draw water with you." They handed him a bucket, and he drank from it. End of the Hadith of Jābir.

### [The consideration of Qirān and Ifrād from the spiritual perspective (اعتبار القران والإفراد من الوجهة الروحية)]

We return and say: The one performing *Qirān* (conjunction) is he who conjoins the attributes of Lordship (*al-rubūbiyya*) and the attributes of servanthood (*al-ʿubūdiyya*) in one of the actions, such as fasting. Or, he who conjoins the servant and The Real in a matter by virtue of equal participation in it, such that each one of them has a share equal to the other, like the division of the prayer between Allah and His servant. This is also *Qirān*. As for *Ifrād* (singularity), it is like His saying: <<لَيْسَ لَكَ من الْأَمْرِ شَيْءٌ>> (You have no share in the matter), and His saying: <<قُلْ إِنَّ الْأَمْرَ كُلَّهُ لِلَّهِ>> (Say: Indeed, the matter belongs entirely to Allah), and His saying: <<كُلٌّ من عِنْدِ الله>> (All is from Allah), and His saying: <<وإِلَيْهِ يُرْجَعُ الْأَمْرُ كُلُّهُ>> (And to Him the matter will be returned entirely). And whatever comes like this, where a servant is singular without the Lord, or a Lord is singular without the servant. Among what the servant is singular in without the Lord is His saying, the Exalted: <<أَنْتُمُ الْفُقَراءُ إِلَى الله>> (You are the needy ones toward Allah), and His saying to Abu Yazid: "O Abu Yazid, draw near to Me with what is not Mine: humiliation (*al-dhilla*) and need (*al-iftiqār*)." This is the meaning of *Qirān* and *Ifrād* in Hajj. The ruling concerning this will come in detail, if Allah the Exalted wills.

(Chapter on the Mutamattiʿ)

The *Mutamatti'* (one combining 'Umra and Hajj) is of two types: either the *Qarin* (combiner) or the *Mufrid bi-'Umra* (one performing 'Umra separately). Islamic scholars have differed regarding *Tamattu'*. Some said it is when a man enters *ihram* for 'Umra during the Months of Hajj (*Ashhur al-Hajj*) from the *Miqat* (designated boundary), provided his residence is outside the Sacred Precinct (*Al-Haram*). He then completes all the rites of 'Umra, dissolves his *ihram*, and then initiates Hajj in that same year and during those months, without returning to his homeland. Others said—and this is the better view—that he is a *Mutamatti'* even if he returns to his homeland, whether he performs Hajj or not, for he is obligated to offer the *Hady* (sacrificial animal) prescribed in the Almighty’s saying: <<فَمَنْ تَمَتَّعَ بِالْعُمْرَةِ إِلَى الْحَجِّ فَمَا اسْتَيْسَرَ من الْهَدْيِ>> (So whoever performs 'Umra [in the months of Hajj] followed by Hajj, let him offer what can be obtained easily of sacrificial animals). Thus, they said, 'Umra performed in the Months of Hajj is *Mut'a* (enjoyment). Some also said that even if he performed 'Umra outside the Months of Hajj, then stayed until Hajj arrived and performed Hajj in that same year, he is a *Mutamatti'*. Ibn al-Zubayr held that the *Mutamatti'* mentioned by God is the one prevented (*muhsar*) by illness or an enemy—that is, when a man sets out for Hajj but is detained by an enemy or some impediment until the days of Hajj pass. He then comes to the House, performs *Tawaf* (circumambulation) and *Sa'y* (running), dissolves his *ihram*, and then performs *Tamattu'*. He is obligated to perform Hajj the following year, and he must offer the *Hady*. According to Ibn al-Zubayr’s view, the commonly known *Tamattu'* would not be valid by consensus. He also said that if a Meccan performs *Tamattu'* from a place other than Mecca, he must offer the *Hady*. Scholars agreed that anyone whose family is not among the residents of the Sacred Mosque (*hadhiri al-Masjid al-Haram*) is a *Mutamatti'*.

My view is that the Almighty’s saying <<ذلِكَ لِمَنْ لَمْ يَكُنْ أَهْلُهُ حاضِرِي الْمَسْجِدِ الْحَرامِ>> (That is for him whose family is not present at the Sacred Mosque) refers to the permission to fast during the Days of *Tashriq* (the three days following the Day of Sacrifice) because of his return to his homeland, not that the Meccan cannot perform *Tamattu'*. Scholars differed on whether a Meccan can perform *Tamattu'*. Some said he can, and they agreed that he is not obligated to offer blood (*dam*). Their proof is the verse we mentioned, which is open to interpretation. The blood (or its substitute, fasting after the Days of *Tashriq*) may be obligatory upon him, as he is one of the residents of the Sacred Mosque.

Due to this verse, we should mention their disagreement regarding the definition of the residents of the Sacred Mosque (*hadhiri al-Masjid al-Haram*). Some said they are the people of Mecca and Dhi Tuwa and similar areas near Mecca. Others said they are the people of the *Mawaqit* (Miqat boundaries) and those closer to Mecca. Others said they are those who live within a night's journey of Mecca. Some said they are the residents of the Sacred Precinct (*Haram*). Others said they are only the people of Mecca. My view is that they are the residents of the Sacred Precinct, those whose signs point back to the House, for whoever is not within it is undoubtedly not present. If the Almighty had said "present at the Sacred Precinct," we would have included those adjacent to the *Haram*, because the resident of a city includes its surrounding areas, regardless of how far they extend. However, the Glorious One linked what He mentioned to the residents of the Sacred Mosque, who are those dwelling within it.

The meaning of *Tamattu'* is the dissolution of *ihram* between the two rites, 'Umra and Hajj. In my view, this only applies to one who did not bring the *Hady*. If he brought the *Hady* and entered *ihram* as a *Qarin* (combiner), he is a *Mutamatti'* without dissolving *ihram*, for he is not permitted to dissolve it <<حَتَّى يَبْلُغَ الْهَدْيُ مَحِلَّهُ>> (until the sacrificial animal reaches its place of sacrifice).

Having mentioned the ruling on *Tamattu'*, let us return to the subject upon which we based this book concerning these acts of worship, and we say: God speaks the Truth, and He guides to the Way.

### The Months of Hajj are a Divine Presence (حضرة إلهية)

The Months of Hajj are a Divine Presence (*Hadra Ilahiyya*) uniquely distinguished by this ruling. Any servant who is characterized by an attribute of Lordship (*siyada*) through Divine characterization, then returns to the attribute of the reality of servitude (*'ubudiyya*), and then returns to his attribute of Lordship within a single Presence—that is the *Mutamatti'*. If he enters the attribute of servitude with a Lordly attribute while characterized by it, he is the *Qarin* (combiner), and he is also a *Mutamatti'*.

The meaning of *Tamattu'* is that the ruling of the *Hady* (sacrificial offering) is incumbent upon him. If he already has a *Hady* while in this state of performing 'Umra separately or combining, that *Hady* suffices, and he is not obligated to offer another *Hady*, nor does he annul (*faskh*) his intention entirely. If he performs Hajj individually (*Ifrad*) and has a *Hady* with him, there is no annulment. The word *ila* (إلى - to) here means *ma'a* (مع - with). This is why the *Qarin* is included in the saying: <<فَمَنْ تَمَتَّعَ بِالْعُمْرَةِ إِلَى الْحَجِّ>> (So whoever performs 'Umra [in the months of Hajj] followed by Hajj), meaning 'Umra *with* Hajj. This designation thus encompasses both the *Mufrid* and the *Qarin*. 'Umra is a visit (*ziyara*). If it is intended repeatedly, and the minimum repetition is a second time, the visit becomes Hajj. Thus, 'Umra is included in Hajj, meaning one enters *ihram* for it at the same time one enters *ihram* for Hajj. The Messenger of God (peace and blessings be upon him) confirmed this by making the *Qarin* perform only one *Tawaf* and one *Sa'y*.

This is the station of Union (*Ittihad*): the servant being clothed in the attribute of the Lord. If the focus is the servant, it is the Lord being clothed in the attribute of the servant. If the *Mutamatti'* dissolves *ihram* to fulfill his own right, and then initiates Hajj, his *Tamattu'* may be characterized by a Lordly attribute if he is one whom God has made a light, or one whose hearing and sight are The Real's, so that he acts only with a Lordly attribute in whatever he acts upon.

### Attributes of Transcendence and Attributes of Analogy (صفات التنزيه وصفات التشبيه)

The Divine Attributes are of two types: a Divine Attribute that necessitates Transcendence (*Tanzih*), such as The Great (*Al-Kabir*) and The Exalted (*Al-'Ali*); and a Divine Attribute that necessitates Analogy (*Tashbih*), such as The Proud (*Al-Mutakabbir*) and The Supremely Exalted (*Al-Muta'ali*).

Regarding what The Real (*Al-Haqq*) describes Himself with, which the servant also possesses: if one considers this a descent from The Real to us, then the servant is the origin. But if one considers this a Divine Attribute whose relation to Him is incomprehensible due to our ignorance of Him, then the servant, in possessing it, is described by a Lordly attribute while in the state of his servitude. Thus, all the servant's attributes that do not imply *Tanzih* are, in reality, the attributes of God Almighty and none other. However, when the servant is clothed in them, the tongue of entitlement attributes them to the servant, but the reality is contrary to that. This is the view approved by the realized ones (*muhaqqiqun*) among the people of our path, although we have not seen anyone explicitly state, verify, or reveal it as we have done. It is easily understood if one is fair-minded. This is because the servant did not derive these attributes or describe The Real with them initially from himself. Rather, The Real described Himself with them, as conveyed by His messengers and revealed to His saints. We would not have known these attributes except as belonging to us, not to Him, based on rational evidence. But when the revealed laws came with them, and He existed while we did not, we knew that these attributes belong to Him by origin, and their ruling flowed into us from Him. They are truly His, and they are borrowed by us, since He existed and we did not. The matter concerning them is easy to grasp and readily accessible, as we have established. Therefore, do not be alarmed by this, since The Real is speaking with it, and you are the listener. If anything is said to you regarding this, let your answer to the objector be: "I did not say it; He said it about Himself, and He knows best what He attributed to Himself. We believe in Him according to His knowledge of it." This is the safest of beliefs. Whoever has the image of that relation unveiled to him by God Almighty possesses true knowledge of it through direct experience (*dhawq*) and spiritual drinking (*shurb*). Were it not for this blending, it would not be valid for man and animal to originate from a mixed drop (*nutfat amshaj*). Thus, the All manifested by the all, and the All was multiplied into the all, so we appeared by Him, for Him, and for us. We are by Him from one perspective, but He is not by us, because He is The Manifest (*Al-Zahir*), and we remain on our origin, even though we were given, through our preparedness in our fixed entities (*a'yan*), matters that the veiled person calls names belonging to us, such as Throne, Footstool, Intellect, Soul, Nature, Sphere, Body, Earth, Heaven, Water, Air, Fire, Mineral, Plant, Animal, Man, and Jinn—all of which belong to one single Essence, and nothing else.

### Man is Wrongdoing and Ignorant (الإنسان ظلوم جهول)

Glory be to the Most High, specialized by the Most Beautiful Names and the Highest Attributes. He knows who is most worthy of the attribute of the Last and the First. <<هُوَ الْأَوَّلُ والْآخِرُ والظَّاهِرُ والْباطِنُ وهُوَ بِكُلِّ شَيْ‏ءٍ عَلِيمٌ>> (He is the First and the Last, the Manifest and the Hidden, and He is, of all things, Knowing). Man is wrongdoing (*zalum*) by usurping these attributes, claiming them as truly his own, and ignorant (*jahul*) of who they belong to and that they are usurped in his hand. Whoever wishes to remove the description of wrongdoing and ignorance from himself must return the trust to its rightful owner and the usurped matter to its possessor. This matter is very easy, though the common people imagine it to be difficult, which is not the case.

(Section on the Chapter of Annulment/Faskh)

*Faskh* is when one intends Hajj but has no *Hady*, so he changes his intention to 'Umra, performs it, dissolves *ihram*, and then initiates Hajj. Some say it is permissible, some say it is obligatory, and some say it is impermissible. I hold the view that it is obligatory.

### The Gift from the Arriving Guest to the Host (الهدية من القادم للذي قدم عليه)

'Umra is the lesser Hajj, so it is permissible to change the intention to it. How could it not be, when its performance is encompassed by the greater Hajj? The *Tawaf* and *Sa'y* of the greater Hajj stand for the *Tawaf* and *Sa'y* of 'Umra for the *Qarin*, and both are pillars. Thus, 'Umra, which is the lesser Hajj, is subsumed into the greater Hajj, and they become one Essence. Annulment (*Faskh*) is permissible due to the absence of the *Hady*, for the gift (*hadiyya*) from the arriving guest to the host is customary. If he does not bring it, he is required not to approach the one he intended with his first intention until he performs *Tamattu'* and offers a *Hady*—this is necessary. However, he does not offer his *Hady* until he initiates a new intention for the purpose, according to what he intended. When he enters *ihram* for Hajj—meaning he intends the Great One (Glorified is He), not the Proud One (who is analogous to 'Umra, the lesser Hajj)—he offers the *Hady* made obligatory by *Tamattu'*, either a sacrifice (*nasika*) of what is easily obtained, or fasting, for the One he intended with that visit. Fasting is for Him, and He is the One upon whom the pilgrim has arrived. Therefore, fasting is a gift (*hadiyya*) because He deserves it; indeed, it is more fitting for Him than the *Hady*, for He receives nothing from the *Hady* except the piety (*taqwa*) of the one offering it, whereas fasting is entirely for Him. Thus, it is a greater gift.
