God only prescribed it for those who cannot find a *Hady* because the *Hady* provides The Real with piety, and the servant with nourishment and sustenance for his existence. The Glorious One thus considered the servant's benefit alongside The Real's share of piety when the *Hady* is available. If the servant cannot find it, He shows him mercy by obligating fasting, since fasting is for Him, and He did not obligate anything else, because He has nothing from the acts of the servants except fasting. So, He established it in place of the gift, and indeed, it is superior. He was content with three days during Hajj, showing mercy to the servant, so that he may present something to his Lord upon arrival, and the arriving guest rejoices in that offering he presented to his Lord during this arrival. This is one aspect of God's mercy toward His servant. He deferred the seven days until the pilgrim returns to his family, for there He takes it from him, as the pilgrim is also arriving upon Him in his return, for The Real is with His people wherever they are. When he returns to his family, he finds The Real with them, and he fasts the seven days as a gift, which The Real accepts from him among his family or wherever he may be, for God is with His servants wherever they are.

### The Essence is One, even if the Relations Differ (العين واحدة وإن اختلفت النسب)

Whoever perceives that the Essence (*'Ayn*) is one, even if the relations (*nisab*) differ, does not see that he has annulled (*faskh*), even with the existence of annulment, similar to His saying: <<وما رَمَيْتَ إِذْ رَمَيْتَ ولكِنَّ الله رَمى‏>> (And you did not throw when you threw, but Allah threw), where He negated and affirmed simultaneously. Likewise, "You did not annul when you annulled." Whoever's witnessing (*shuhud*) is focused solely on Hajj (the greater) does not dissolve *ihram* for the lesser and the greater, and remains upon his first intention, based on the Almighty's saying: <<وأَتِمُّوا الْحَجَّ>> (And complete the Hajj). This is according to his witnessed state. The first view is more complete, and he who affirms annulment and the transgression of annulment is an annuller, not a non-annuller.

(Sub-section on *Tamattu'*)

Islamic scholars differed concerning one who initiated 'Umra outside the Months of Hajj, then performed Hajj in that same year. Some said his 'Umra is counted in the month in which he dissolved *ihram*. If he dissolved *ihram* in the Months of Hajj, he is undoubtedly a *Mutamatti'* according to them. If he dissolved *ihram* outside the Months of Hajj, he is not a *Mutamatti'*. Some stipulated that his entire *Tawaf* must be in the Months of Hajj. Some said that if he performed three circuits in Ramadan and four in Shawwal, he is a *Mutamatti'*. Others said that if he entered *ihram* for 'Umra outside the Months of Hajj, whether he performed *Tawaf* in the Hajj months or not, nothing is incumbent upon him, for he is not a *Mutamatti'*.

### Names of The Real: Some Allow Sharing, Others Do Not (أسماء الحق منها ما يعطى الاشتراك ومنها لا)

Know that since some of the Names of The Real (*Al-Haqq*) allow sharing and some do not—those that do not allow sharing are like The Giver of Honor (*Al-Mu'izz*) and The Humiliator (*Al-Mudhill*), and those that do allow sharing are like The Knowing (*Al-'Alim*) and The All-Aware (*Al-Khabir*)—if the servant is under the ruling of a Divine Name that allows sharing, it is analogous to one who enters *ihram* for 'Umra outside the Months of Hajj but performs it within them. Does the ruling of the first Name still apply when he moves to the ruling of the other Name? Look: if one encompasses the other in some respect, such as The All-Aware (*Al-Khabir*) and The Knowing (*Al-'Alim*), then his act is under the ruling of the latter, because it is the master of the time, and you are taken by more than what the first time took from you. But if your witnessing is that the initial initiation is the effective cause, and without it the ruling of the latter would not be valid (like the intention for prayer, which is not present during the prayer, yet the prayer is valid due to the ruling and strength of the initial intention), then whoever's witnessing is this negates that this person is a *Mutamatti'*, because the ruling is based on the initiation, not the completion. Know this.

### The Five Conditions of Tamattu' (شروط التمتع الخمسة)

The maximum conditions for *Tamattu'* that make the *Mutamatti'* a *Mutamatti'* are five, according to some: 1. Combining 'Umra and Hajj in one journey. 2. That this occurs in one year. 3. Performing some part of 'Umra in the Months of Hajj. 4. Initiating Hajj after completing 'Umra and dissolving *ihram* from it. 5. That his homeland is not Mecca.

### Combining in One Journey (الجمع في سفر واحد)

As for combining in one journey, this means being called by two Names or more, or one Name encompassing two Names or more, as we presented. He responds in that single journey to both calls according to what they called for, like the rich person (*Al-Mughni*) calling him, which implies the ruling of the Name The Giver of Honor (*Al-Mu'izz*) in the one called, for when he becomes rich, he becomes honored (*'azza*), and honor only comes from the Name *Al-Mu'izz*. He was only honored here by the Name *Al-Mughni* because it enriched him, and the attribute of richness bequeathed him honor. Were it not that *Al-Mughni* encompasses the Name *Al-Mu'izz*, honor would not have appeared in this rich person through what he was enriched with.

### The Perfection of Time by the Manifestation of Eternity (كمال الزمان بظهور الأبد)

As for the single year, it is the perfection of time (*kamal al-zaman*), since the year contains the perfection of time by encompassing the seasons. The perfection of time is through the manifestation of Eternity (*Al-Abad*), by which time (*al-dahr*) is perfected. *Azal* (Pre-eternity) negates firstness, and *Abad* (Post-eternity) negates lastness. Since there are no two extremes remaining, there is only one Time (*Dahr*), as the relation of *Azal* to The Real is like the relation of time to creation generally, and like the relation of past time to us. Therefore, action in it is only expressed in the past tense, so they say, "That was in *Azal*," and "He did that in *Azal*." We have explained the true meaning of this word in this book and in a separate treatise we named *Al-Azal*.

### Man's Intention toward His Lord According to God's Right (قصد الإنسان من ربه من حيث ما يقتضيه حق الله)

As for performing some part of 'Umra in the Months of Hajj, this means that man's intention toward his Lord is according to what God's right requires of him therein, and fulfilling the right of servitude. Thus, the act has one aspect in this and one aspect in that.

### Exiting the Ruling of One Divine Name Opposed to Another (الخروج من حكم اسم إلهى مقابل لاسم إلهى لا يجتمعان)

As for initiating Hajj after completing 'Umra and dissolving *ihram* from it, this is analogous to sincerity (*Ikhlas*) in worship and exiting the ruling of one Divine Name that opposes another and cannot be combined, such as The Harmer (*Al-Darr*) and The Benefactor (*Al-Nafi'*), or The Giver (*Al-Mu'ti*) and The Withholder (*Al-Mani'*).

### The Servant's Homeland is Servitude (العبد موطنه العبودية)

As for the homeland not being Mecca, that is clear, for the servant's homeland is Servitude (*'Ubudiyya*). He cannot leave his homeland unless The Real calls him to it. If He were to include him with a homeland, He would not have called him to it.

(Section on the Chapter of *Qiran*)

*Qiran* (combining) is, in our view, entering *ihram* for both 'Umra and Hajj simultaneously. If he enters *ihram* for 'Umra and then enters *ihram* for Hajj afterward, this is *Irdāf* (adding), and he is also a *Qarin*, but by way of subsequent inclusion. Whoever combines 'Umra and Hajj in one *ihram* is performing *Qiran*, whether he combined them at the initiation or sometime afterward, as long as he has not performed *Tawaf* of the House.

It is also said: as long as he has not performed *Tawaf* and prayed the two *rak'ahs*. It is disliked after *Tawaf* but before the two *rak'ahs*. If he prays the two *rak'ahs*, it becomes binding. Some say he may do so even after the two *rak'ahs* of *Tawaf*, provided nothing remains of the 'Umra rites. However, if nothing remains of the 'Umra rites except shaving, they agree that he is not a *Qarin*. All of this is conditional, according to some, on him having brought the *Hady*, and this is my view. If he did not bring a *Hady* with him, they differed regarding his Hajj, and the same applies to the *Mufrid* (one performing Hajj individually). Some say the Hajj is invalid and *Faskh* (annulment) is obligatory. Some say *Faskh* is permissible but not obligatory. Some forbid it, saying he must complete the Hajj he intended, whether he brought the *Hady* or not. The *Qarin* who is obligated to offer the *Hady* of *Tamattu'* is, according to the majority, one whose family is not among the residents of the Sacred Mosque, except for Ibn al-Majishun, who holds that the *Qarin* from the people of Mecca must offer the *Hady*.

As for *Ifrad* (performing Hajj individually), it is stripped of these attributes, being the entry into *ihram* for Hajj only. Scholars among the Companions differed regarding it if the pilgrim has no *Hady*, as we mentioned earlier in this chapter.

As for those who permitted Hajj for one who did not bring the *Hady*, and regarding the superiority of the original entry into *ihram* for Hajj, even if he brought the *Hady*: some say *Ifrad* is superior, some say *Qiran*, and some say *Tamattu'*.

Know that the one entering *ihram* does not enter *ihram* just as the existent does not exist. The one who adds (*murdif*) entered *ihram* before he added, then he added the Hajj intention to the preceding 'Umra *ihram*, and it sufficed him without dispute. *Ihram* is a pillar in both acts, and its permissibility is agreed upon. Therefore, the view of those who say he performs one *Tawaf*, one *Sa'y*, and one shaving (or shortening) for both is preferable to those who disagree.

### The Power Concurrent with the Act and its Effect on the Object of Power (القدرة المقارنة للفعل وأثرها في المقدور)

You have already been presented with the ruling on the interpenetration of Divine Names in the ruling, and the ruling on the singularity of a Divine Name whose ruling is not interpenetrated by another. Refer to that section.

The *Mufrid* (individual performer) says: All acts belong to God, and the servant is merely the locus of their manifestation. The *Qarin* (combiner) says: The acts belong to God in one respect, and are attributed to the one from whom they appear in another respect, which some speculative theologians call acquisition (*kasb*) and others call creation (*khalq*). All agree that the creation of the power (*qudra*) concurrent with the appearance of the act from the servant belongs to God, and that it is neither the acquisition nor the creation of the servant. They differed on whether this power has an effect on the object of power (*maqdur*). Some said it does have an effect on the *maqdur*, and the *maqdur* only comes into being through it. This is necessary for obligation (*taklif*) to be valid and directed toward the servant, for if he were not capable of the act, he would not be obligated. <<وَلَا يُكَلِّفُ اللَّهُ نَفْسًا إِلَّا وُسْعَهَا>> (And Allah does not charge a soul except [with that within] its capacity), which is what he is able to perform. They interpreted the power that is in the servant as belonging to God, saying: <<لَا يُكَلِّفُ اللَّهُ نَفْسًا إِلَّا مَا آتَاهَا>> (Allah does not charge a soul except [with that within] what He has given it). What He has given it is the power He created within it, enabling it to bring about the obligation requested of it. Others said that the originated power (*al-qudra al-haditha*) has no creative effect on the *maqdur* that originates from the servant. The servant's role in the act issuing from him is only acquisition (*kasb*), which is his choice of that act, since he was neither compelled nor coerced in it.

### Essential Requirements are not Acts, but Rulings (الاقتضاءات الذاتية ليست أفعالا بل أحكاما)

As for the People of God (*Ahl Allah*), the essences of the acts appearing from the essences of creation are merely relations (*nisab*) of The Manifest (*Al-Zahir*) in the essences of these possibilities (*mumkinat*). The preparedness (*isti'dad*) of the possibilities affects The Manifest in the essences of the possibilities, resulting in the acts that appear. The giving that occurs by way of preparedness is not called an act of the prepared one, because he required it by his very essence. Just as the establishment of the ruling of the Knower (*Al-'Alim*) for the one who possesses it—the Knower being a knower—is not an act at all. Thus, the high essential requirements (*al-iqtida'at al-dhatiyya*) are not acts attributed to the one from whom they appear; rather, they are rulings (*ahkam*) belonging to him.

The acts of the obligated ones (*mukallafin*)—whether they are commanded acts or prohibitions—while we know that the manifest existent is The Real and none other, are analogous to what we mentioned regarding the dialogue and interplay of the Divine Names in the arenas of debate, and their direction toward the locus described by a certain attribute with differing rulings, where some overpower others. For example, the doer of an act called a sin or transgression is subject to the Names The Pardoner (*Al-'Afuww*), The Forgiving (*Al-Ghaffar*), The Avenger (*Al-Muntaqim*), and The Punisher (*Al-Mu'aqib*). One of the rulings of these Names must be executed upon him, as it is impossible for all of them to be executed at once, because the locus cannot accept them due to the opposition between these rulings. Thus, the overpowering of some Names over others in the ruling has appeared, even though the Divine Presence (*Hadra Ilahiyya*) is one.

### Attributing Acts to God despite the Oneness of the Essence and Difference in Ruling (نسبة الأفعال إلى الله مع أحدية الذات واختلاف الحكم)

If you know this, it becomes easy for you to attribute all acts to God, just as all the Most Beautiful Names are attributed to God Almighty or The Most Compassionate (*Al-Rahman*), despite the oneness of the Essence (*'Ayn*) and the difference in ruling. Know this and apply it to everything called an act. You will then know who is the obligated one (*mukallaf*) and the obligator (*mukallif*), and you will speak concerning it according to your witnessed state. (End of Part Sixty-Five)

(In the Name of God, the Most Compassionate, the Most Merciful)

(Section on the Chapter of *Ghusl* for *Ihram*)

Some say it is obligatory, some say *Wudu'* (ablution) suffices for it, and some say it is a confirmed Sunna, more emphasized than the *Ghusl* for Friday prayer.

### Inner Purity is Obligatory in Every Worship (الطهارة الباطنة واجبة في كل عبادة)

Know that inner purity (*al-tahara al-batina*) is obligatory in every act of worship according to the People of God (*Ahl Allah*), except for those who hold that the obligated one (*mukallaf*) is merely The Manifest in a locus of manifestation (*mazhar*) among the possible entities. Such a person views it as a Sunna, not an obligation.

### Preparedness is the Essence of the Locus of Manifestation and an Effect in The Manifest (الاستعداد عين المظهر وأثر في الظاهر)

Among the People of God, whoever sees that the preparedness (*isti'dad*) upon which he exists is the very essence of the locus of manifestation (*mazhar*), just as it affects The Manifest (*Al-Zahir*) within it—so that he is distinguished from another manifestation by some matter or Name, such as animal, human, compelled, adult, sane, or insane—that preparedness itself necessitates the ruling upon him by some matter, just as the Name necessitated it for him. Thus, He said to him: "Perform *Ghusl* for your *ihram*," meaning, purify yourself by gathering yourself, so that purity encompasses your essence, because you intend to forbid specific acts upon yourself, acts whose performance is not required by this specific worship called Hajj or 'Umra. Therefore, approaching it with the attribute of sanctification (*taqdis*) is more fitting, because you intend to enter upon the Name The Holy (*Al-Quddus*). You should not enter upon Him except with His attribute, which is purity, just as you do not enter upon Him except by His command, since suitability (*munasaba*) is a condition for connection and companionship. Thus, *Ghusl* is obligatory.

### Only Specific Acts are Forbidden to the Pilgrim, Not All Acts (إنما يحرم على المحرم أفعال مخصوصة لا جميع الأفعال)

Whoever holds that only specific acts are forbidden to the pilgrim, not all acts, says that *Ghusl*, which is general purification, is not obligatory upon him, because not all his acts are forbidden. Therefore, *Wudu'* suffices, as it is the washing of specific limbs of the body, just as only specific acts are forbidden to him. However, if he performs *Ghusl*, it is better. Likewise, if he generalizes inner purity, it is more fitting and better.

(Section on the Chapter of Intention for *Ihram*)

This is a matter agreed upon, except by those who deviate.

### The Intention of Prohibition is the Essence of Your Remaining as You Are (القصد بالمنع عين بقائك على ما أنت عليه)

The intention of prohibition (*al-qasd bi-al-man'*) is the very essence of your remaining upon what you are. This is a ruling attributed to you, for which you are rewarded, but you have not performed any existential act. It is like prohibition in obligation (*taklif*), and it relates to the Name The Withholder (*Al-Mani'*).

### Intention is Always Related to the Non-Existent (القصد أبدا لا يكون متعلقه إلا معدوما)

Intention (*al-qasd*) is always related only to the non-existent (*ma'dum*). In the non-existent, one always intends one of two things: either the creation of an essence (*'ayn*), which is coming into being (*kawn*), or the creation of a ruling (*hukm*), which is the relation (*nisba*). There is no third thing intended. An example of creating an essence is: <<إِنَّما قَوْلُنا لِشَيْ‏ءٍ إِذا أَرَدْناهُ أَنْ نَقُولَ لَهُ كُنْ فَيَكُونُ>> (Our word to a thing when We intend it is only that We say to it, "Be," and it is), and He only intends it when it is non-existent. Thus, the existence of the intended essence appears after it was non-existent. An example of creating a ruling (the relation) is the Almighty's saying: <<إِنْ يَشَأْ يُذْهِبْكُمْ>> (If He wills, He can do away with you). The doing away (*idhhab*) is non-existent, and He wills it if He wills it. If He wills, He makes it non-existent by withholding the condition upon which the ruling of existence depends, so the ruling of the non-existent Name applies to it. The Doer has done nothing, yet the intention relates to annihilation, and the existent is characterized by the ruling of non-existence, not that non-existence itself existed, for non-existence cannot exist alongside the existence of its ruling, which is the relation.

### There is no Existence except God Alone (ما ثم وجود إلا الله خاصة)

If you reflect, there is no existence (*wujud*) except God alone. Everything else described by existence besides God is a specific relation (*nisba*). The Divine Will relates only to manifesting the Theophany (*Tajalli*) in the loci of manifestation (*mazahir*), which is a relation. The Manifest (*Al-Zahir*) has always been described by Existence, and the Locus of Manifestation (*Al-Mazhar*) has always been described by non-existence (*'adam*). When the manifestation occurs, the Locus imparts a ruling upon The Manifest according to its own psychic realities (*haqa'iq nafsiyya*). Thus, a ruling is applied to The Manifest from those realities upon which that non-existent Locus exists, and it is called man, or sphere, or angel, or whatever the created beings may be. Likewise, from that manifestation, a Name returns to The Manifest, by which He is called Creator, Maker, Harmer, Benefactor, and Powerful, and whatever that Theophany bestows of Names. The essences of the possibilities remain in their state of non-existence, just as The Real has always possessed the ruling of Existence. The essence of the possible entity acquired the name Locus of Manifestation (*Mazhar*), and the One manifesting in it acquired the name The Manifest (*Zahir*).

### Every Existent Besides God is a Relation, Not an Essence (كل موجود سوى الله هو نسبة لا عين)

Therefore, we said that every existent besides God is a relation (*nisba*), not an essence (*'ayn*). The preparedness of a certain locus of manifestation grants that The Manifest within it is obligated (*mukallaf*), so He is told, "Do," and "Do not do," and is addressed with "You" and the second-person pronoun.

### All Obligations are Rulings (التكليفات كلها أحكام)

The intention for *Ihram* is the intention for prohibition, to prohibit what might otherwise not be prohibited. Thus, the prohibition becomes a ruling (*hukm*), and all obligations (*taklifat*) are rulings. The intention for *Ihram* is to seek proximity (*qurba*) to God through this prohibition. Proximity is non-existent, and this prohibition becomes the cause of the existence of its ruling. Proximity is thus attained by the servant after it was non-existent, and he becomes a locus of manifestation (*mazhar*) thereby. This is the ultimate proximity: manifestation in a locus, because through that manifestation, the ruling of the Locus appears in the One manifesting in it, just as the ruling of the caller appears in the one called through the response. The Almighty said: <<وَإِذَا سَأَلَكَ عِبَادِي عَنِّي فَإِنِّي قَرِيبٌ أُجِيبُ دَعْوَةَ الدَّاعِ إِذَا دَعَانِ>> (And when My servants ask you concerning Me, indeed I am near. I respond to the invocation of the supplicant when he calls upon Me). Response only occurs after the call. Thus, the caller granted the ruling of response. Similarly, God called him to Hajj to His House in a specific manner called *Ihram*. The servant responded by raising his voice, which is the *Ihlal* (chanting the *Talbiya*), saying: "Labbayka Allahumma Labbayk, Labbayka la sharika laka Labbayk. Inna al-hamda wa al-ni'mata laka wa al-mulk, la sharika lak" (Here I am, O God, here I am. Here I am, You have no partner, here I am. Indeed, all praise, grace, and sovereignty belong to You, You have no partner).

(Section on the Chapter of Whether Intention Suffices for *Talbiya*)

The scholars of external rites differed regarding this. Some said that *Talbiya* in Hajj is like *Takbirat al-Ihram* (the opening *Allahu Akbar*) in prayer. According to this view, any phrase that takes the place of *Talbiya* suffices, just as any phrase that signifies glorification suffices for *Takbir* in prayer. Others said the specific wording of the *Talbiya* is necessary.

The Messenger of God (peace and blessings be upon him) said: "Take your rites from me." The wording of the *Talbiya* is his saying, "Labbayk," just as God prescribed "Allahu Akbar" for *Takbirat al-Ihram* in prayer. Thus, some made the Prophet's *Talbiya* obligatory, in the form: "Labbayka Allahumma Labbayk, Labbayka la sharika laka Labbayk. Inna al-hamda wa al-ni'mata laka wa al-mulk, la sharika lak." In one narration: "Labbayka Ilah al-Haqq" (Here I am, O God of Truth). In another: "Ilah al-Khalq" (O God of Creation). This specific wording is obligatory according to these scholars, but recommended (*mustahabb*) according to the majority, and this is my view, though using the specific wording is preferable. They differed on adding to this wording or changing it. They also differed on raising the voice with the *Talbiya* (*Ihlal*). Some made it obligatory, and this is my view, but I hold that if it is done once, it suffices, and anything more is recommended and preferable. Others said raising the voice with *Talbiya* is recommended, except in congregational mosques, excluding the Sacred Mosque and the mosque of Mina, according to some. They differed on whether *Talbiya* is a pillar (*rukn*). Some said it is a pillar of Hajj, and this is my view, for God says: <<فَلْيَسْتَجِيبُوا لِي>> (So let them respond to Me). He has called us to His House, so we must say "Labbayk," and then proceed with the acts He called us to perform with those attributes. Others said it is not a pillar.

### The Intention toward God through Hajj is a Specific Intention for a Specific Name (القصد إلى الله بالحج قصد خاص لاسم خاص)

Know that the intention toward God Almighty through this specific worship, which combines *ihram* with the permission to engage in most permissible acts, is a specific intention toward a specific Name: the Caller to the House. The intention is not *to* Him, but *for* Him, with an attribute of servitude mixed with an attribute of Lordship. The ruling of Lordship appears in this worship in the sacrifice (*nahr*), because it is the destruction of a form; and in the stoning of the pillars (*jimār*), for it describes a Divine Act, as in His saying: <<وَأَمْطَرْنَا عَلَيْهِمْ حِجَارَةً>> (And We rained down upon them stones). It is narrated that Iblis appeared to Abraham the Friend (*Al-Khalil*) repeatedly at the places of the *Jamarat*, so Abraham pelted him with stones corresponding to the prescribed number and time. Likewise, in removing the matted hair (*ilqā' al-tafath*), for it is a Divine description from His saying: <<سَنَفْرُغُ لَكُمْ>> (We will attend to you), and your Lord attends. Fulfilling the vow is likewise, based on His saying: <<أُوفِ بِعَهْدِكُمْ>> (I will fulfill My covenant with you).

### The Manifestation of the Ruling of Lordship in the Worship of Hajj (ظهور حكم السيادة في عبادة الحج)

The circumambulation (*Tawaf*) of the House is because this act is an encompassing of the House, based on His saying: <<إِنَّهُ بِكُلِّ شَيْ‏ءٍ مُحِيطٌ>> (Indeed, He is encompassing of all things). The remembrance (*dhikr*) therein is from His saying: <<فَاذْكُرُونِي أَذْكُرْكُمْ>> (So remember Me; I will remember you). God's remembrance of us is greater than our remembrance of Him, unless we remember Him *by* Him, not by ourselves. Our remembrance of Him *by* Him is greater in encompassing. For in our remembrance, we are present, and in His remembrance, He is present without us. It was recited to Abu Yazid: <<إِنَّ بَطْشَ رَبِّكَ لَشَدِيدٌ>> (Indeed, the grip of your Lord is severe). He said: "My grip is more severe," meaning when the servant grips *by* Him, not by himself. However, my interpretation of Abu Yazid's saying is different: the servant's grip is stripped of mercy; he has no mercy while gripping. The grip of The Real, in every aspect, contains mercy for the one gripped, from the perspective intended by The Real who grips, for He is the Merciful in His grip. Thus, the servant's grip is more severe because it is not sustained by mercy toward the one gripped. And similar to this are the trotting (*ramal*) and the running (*sa'y*), and every act that has a description in Divinity (*Uluhiyya*).

### Let Your Intention to the House be by Your Lord, Not by Yourself (فليكن قصدك إلى البيت بربك لا بنفسك)

Since you know that the intention toward the House is from God, not *to* Him, let your intention toward the House be *by* your Lord, not by yourself. Thus, you will have a Divine intention, for He Almighty intended this House above all others and asked His servants to intend it with a specific attribute, which is *Ihram* and all the acts of the pilgrim. He made its beginning *Tawaf* and its end *Tawaf*, concluding with what He began with upon reaching the House. He only commanded you to intend the House, not Him, because He made it a sensory intention involving the cutting of a distance, the shortest of which is from your house in Mecca to the House. Yet, He is with you wherever you are, so it is not valid to intend, by physical walking, the One who is with you. Thus, He informed you that He is with you.

### The Indication toward the House is an Indication toward Yourself (الدلالة على البيت دلالة لك على نفسك)

Then, His indication toward the House, which is like you and of your kind—meaning it is created—is His indication toward yourself, as in the saying: "He who knows himself knows his Lord." When you intend the House, you only intend yourself. When you reach yourself, you know who you are. And when you know who you are, you know your Lord. You will then know whether you are He or not He. For there, you attain correct knowledge. The indicator may be different from the indicated, or it may be the very essence of the indicated. Nothing indicates a thing better than itself. Then the indication becomes distant according to the distance of the suitability (*munasaba*). Man is the closest indicator to himself, being created upon the Form. This is why He called you from near, due to the proximity of suitability, saying: <<فَإِنِّي قَرِيبٌ أُجِيبُ دَعْوَةَ الدَّاعِ إِذَا دَعَانِ>> (Indeed, I am near. I respond to the invocation of the supplicant when he calls upon Me), and <<قَدْ سَمِعَ اللَّهُ قَوْلَ الَّتِي تُجَادِلُكَ>> (God has certainly heard the statement of the woman who argues with you).

### The House was only Named 'Bayt' (House) for the Purpose of 'Mabit' (Staying Overnight), and Staying Overnight is only at Night (إنما سمى البيت بيتا للمبيت فيه والمبيت لا يكون إلا ليلا)

We have already presented the secrets that appeared in the consideration of the House at the beginning of the chapter. Then He used the word *Bayt* (House) because of its derivation from *Mabit* (staying overnight). It is as if it was only named *Bayt* for the purpose of staying overnight in it, for that is the greatest pillar in the benefits of the House, just as they say, "Hajj is 'Arafa," meaning its greatest part. He considered the ruling of staying overnight (*Mabit*) because sleep occurs during *Mabit*. The sleeper needs someone to guard his belongings and himself, as he is characterized by guarding his belongings and himself while awake. Since He considered *Mabit*, and *Mabit* only occurs at night, not during the day, this is why Ahmad ibn Hanbal considered the washing of the hand in *Wudu'* before inserting it into the vessel to be specific to one who wakes from night sleep, based on the Prophet's saying (peace and blessings be upon him): "For none of you knows where his hand spent the night." He used the word *Mabit*, making the ruling specific to night sleep.

### God Only Made His Theophany to His Servants in the Temporal Ruling of the Night (ما جعل الحق تجليه لعباده في الحكم الزمانى إلا في الليل)

Since the night is the locus of Theophany (*Tajalli*)—for The Real only made His Theophany to His servants in the temporal ruling of the night—it is during the night that our Lord descends, and it was during the night that the Messenger of God (peace and blessings be upon him) was taken on the Night Journey (*Isra'*), and during the night that souls ascend in sleep to see the signs (*ayat*). When all these matters were realized, the Glorious One specified this place with the word *Bayt* (House). Understand what we have indicated.

Then He, Majestic and Exalted, said: <<وَلِلَّهِ عَلَى النَّاسِ>> (And [due] to God from the people)—an allusion to forgetfulness (*nisyān*), and He did not say "upon the children of Adam"—<<حِجُّ الْبَيْتِ>> (is the pilgrimage to the House), meaning the intention toward this place because it is a *Bayt*, so that one may be alerted by its name to what was intended by it, rather than anything else, <<مَنِ اسْتَطَاعَ إِلَيْهِ سَبِيلًا>> (for whoever is able to find thereto a way), meaning whoever is capable of reaching it. For this reason, He prescribed <<وَإِيَّاكَ نَسْتَعِينُ>> (And You we ask for help) and similar phrases.

### The House is the Veil in the Intended Aspect (البيت هو الحجاب على الوجه المقصود)

The response to God through *Talbiya* and raising the voice with it is due to the House's distance from the One called, for He called him from the House so that he might see Him therein through His manifestation, just as He took His servant on the Night Journey to show him His signs, which are indications of Him. Sometimes the appearance of a thing to the seeker is an indication of himself, so it is one of His signs that He manifests to him and he sees Him, and this becomes an indication of himself. This is the doctrine of Ibn Abbas. Therefore, raising the voice with *Talbiya* (*Ihlal*) is obligatory because of the House's share in this call, for it is the intended object in the wording. Thus, the House is the veil (*hijab*) in the intended aspect.

### God is with the Servant in his Witnessing According to his Knowledge of Him (الله مع العبد في شهوده على قدر علمه به)

If your witnessing is Muhammadan, do not add anything to the *Talbiya* of the Messenger of God (peace and blessings be upon him), and you will see Him with his eye, for nothing will be manifested to you through your *Talbiya* except what was manifested to him, and it is established that he is the most knowledgeable of creation concerning God. Knowledge of God is only attained through Theophany (*Tajalli*). He has manifested to you in this *Talbiya* of yours, and you have seen Him with the eye of Muhammad (peace and blessings be upon him), which is the most perfect of eyes, because he is the most perfect of those who know God. God is with the servant in his witnessing according to his knowledge of Him. If you add to this *Talbiya*, you have committed *shirk* (association) by adding another *Talbiya* to it, and you know that combination yields a ruling that singularity does not. Do not imagine that by completing his *Talbiya* and then adding whatever you wish, you attain what was attained by one who did not add to it. This is ignorance on the part of the one who says it regarding the reality of things. Do you not see that the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) adhered to his *Talbiya* and did not add to it, nor did he deny anyone what they chanted? His adherence to it was not invalid. Therefore, adhere to the following (*ittibā'*) and be a servant, and do not innovate a ruling in servitude, lest you become a lord through that innovation, for He is The Originator (*Al-Badi'*) (Glorified is He).

### Partnership is Not Valid in Existence Because Existence is in the Image of The Real (الشركة لا تصح في الوجود لأن الوجود على صورة الحق)

Adhere to your reality, and you will be favored by Him. If you associate a partner with Him, you will not be favored by Him, for He does not accept partnership, and you will fall into ignorance, because partnership (*shirka*) is not valid in Existence (*Wujud*), for Existence is in the image of The Real (*Al-Haqq*), and there is no partner in The Real; rather, He is The One. Partnership has no source from which it originates. Realize this warning regarding partnership, for it is unlikely that you will hear it from anyone else, even if it is known to them, because they are ruled by the cowardice they were created with, and they fear that The Real established partnership as an attribute in the created being. This observer has not perceived His saying: "I am the most self-sufficient of partners concerning partnership. Whoever performs an act in which he associates another with Me, I am free of him." It is the servant who associated, and there is no partnership in reality, because the matter originates from One.

> This is the Truth which,
> If you speak it, you will not be overcome.
> And anything other than this is not,
> It is merely an example that is struck.

Like the estimation of the existence of the impossible by way of hypothesis.

### The Pillars of the House and the Pillars of Hajj (أركان البيت وأركان الحج)

Since the intention is toward the House, and the House in its form has four corners, and in its original placement had three corners, the intention is upon the form of the House in most schools of thought. The pillars of Hajj are four: *Ihram*, Standing (*Wuqūf*), *Sa'y* (running), and *Tawaf al-Ifada* (the final circumambulation). This is what most people hold. Whoever considered the form of the House in its original placement held it to be threefold, not considering *Tawaf al-Ifada* a pillar. Thus, he established the House in the shape of an isosceles triangle, not an equilateral triangle. It cannot be an equilateral triangle, for if it were, there would be no distinction between the two sides, and distinction between them is necessary, as they are the two hands and the two grips (*qabdāt*). They were only named "sides" (*sāqayn*) because of the reliance (*i'timād*) inherent in the reality of the side. Since reliance is upon the two grips, and the ruling of the matter in the two abodes (Paradise and Hell, and there is nothing else) returns to them, the name "side" is more fitting. <<وَالْتَفَّتِ السَّاقُ بِالسَّاقِ>> (And leg is joined with leg). Equality is necessary so that the wrapping of the whole by the whole is valid. Anything added to these four and made a pillar is based on another perspective, outside the shape and form of the House. This is like one who seeks a thing and sees something resembling it, and says, "It is it," even if the consideration is sound, but it does not have this manifestation in resemblance, because the form—meaning the form of the House, which is the intended object of Hajj and nothing else—does not bear witness to it.

(Section on the Chapter of *Ihram* Following Prayer)

This is recommended according to scholars, whether the prayer is obligatory or supererogatory. However, some recommend performing two supererogatory *rak'ahs* for it, as this is preferable, since the Sunna of the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) was to pray at that time, and the Sunna is most worthy of being followed, for it was legislated for this purpose. He said: "Take your rites from me."

### Prayer, Hajj, and 'Umra are Acts of Worship between Two Extremes of Prohibition and Permissibility (الصلاة والحج والعمرة عبادات بين طرفى تحريم وتحليل)

*Ihram* was only prescribed after prayer because prayer is an act of worship between two extremes of prohibition (*tahrim*) and permissibility (*tahlil*). Its prohibition is the *Takbir* (opening glorification), and its permissibility is the *Taslim* (closing salutation). Thus, it resembles Hajj and 'Umra, which are two acts of worship between two extremes of prohibition and permissibility. Therefore, suitability (*munasaba*) occurred. Also, in prayer, The Real established Himself and His servant equally, making one matter unique to Himself, one share unique to His servant, and a *Barzakh* (Isthmus) where they share. Prayer is built upon sayings and actions, and Hajj is likewise built upon sayings and actions. What is in it of glorification belongs to God, and what is in it of humility, need, and removing matted hair (*tafath*) belongs to the servant. What appears therein as shared is the *Barzakh*. Thus, the suitability in it is greater than in other acts of worship, for fasting, although it is between two extremes of prohibition and permissibility, does not involve sayings or actions.

### The Correspondence between Hajj, Prayer, and Marriage (المناسبة بين الحج والصلاة والنكاح)

Furthermore, if you have your family at the place of your *ihram*, you should have intercourse with your family if you intend to enter *ihram*, for that is part of the Sunna. Then you perform *Ghusl*, pray, and enter *ihram*. The correspondence between Hajj, Prayer, and Marriage (*Nikah*) is that each of these acts of worship is between two extremes of prohibition and permissibility. God considered this suitability in Prayer and Marriage, saying: <<حَافِظُوا عَلَى الصَّلَوَاتِ وَالصَّلَاةِ الْوُسْطَى>> (Maintain the prayers and [especially] the middle prayer), placing this verse between verses concerning marriage and divorce that precede and follow it, and the waiting period for widowhood. On the surface, this is not its place, and there is no apparent aspect of suitability for combining it with what we mentioned, except that they are all between two extremes of prohibition and permissibility, whether preceding or succeeding.

### Man is by His Lord, so He Should be for His Lord in All His Movements and Stillness (الإنسان بربه فينبغي أن يكون لربه في جميع حركاته وسكناته)

Since God desired from the servant, through what He alerted him to, that he should not perform any action outwardly without knowing that God is the Doer of that action, as in His saying: "I was his hearing and his sight, so by Me he hears, and by Me he sees, and by Me he moves."

And He said concerning prayer that God spoke through the tongue of His servant: "God hears the one who praises Him."

He attributed the saying to Himself, not to the servant, and did not say "by the tongue of His servant." For this reason, *Ihram* was prescribed immediately following prayer, so that man may be alerted, as we mentioned, that he is *by* his Lord in all his movements and stillness, despite the difference in their rulings. Thus, he is perpetually in worship through this presence, and he is in it and not in it.

> God manifested Himself by the realities
> Of the cosmos in their essences, so worship Him by Him.
> If you worship Him, you are not the worshipper,
> So look at my saying, perhaps you will be alerted.

### Ihram for the Servant is Analogous to Tanzih for The Real (الإحرام للعبد نظير التنزيه للحق)

Be aware that God did not say to His Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) <<وَمَا رَمَيْتَ إِذْ رَمَيْتَ وَلَكِنَّ اللَّهَ رَمَى>> (And you did not throw when you threw, but Allah threw) in vain. Rather, He said that so that you and those like you may know the reality of the matter. *Ihram* for the servant is analogous to *Tanzih* (Transcendence) for The Real, which is your saying concerning The Real: "He is not such and such," because He said: <<لَيْسَ كَمِثْلِهِ شَيْءٌ>> (There is nothing like unto Him), and <<سُبْحَانَ رَبِّكَ رَبِّ الْعِزَّةِ عَمَّا يَصِفُونَ>> (Exalted is your Lord, the Lord of Might, above what they describe). Might (*'izza*) is refusal, and glorification (*tasbih*) is *Tanzih*. *Tanzih* is distance from what is attributed to Him, such as having a consort or a son, and other things. *Ihram* is prohibition, *Tanzih*, and distance from sexual intercourse and things that the Lawgiver has specified must be avoided. It is the very essence of *Tanzih* and distancing oneself from them, and prohibiting the possessor of this worship from being characterized by them.

(Section on the Chapter of Attributing Place to Hajj from the *Miqat* of *Ihram*)

This concerns the place from which the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) entered *ihram*. Some said it was from the Mosque of Dhu al-Hulayfa. Some said it was when his riding camel stood up with him. Some said it was when he overlooked Al-Bayda'. Each one spoke and reported the time he heard him chanting the *Talbiya*. Some heard him chanting immediately after prayer from the Mosque. Then another heard him chanting when his riding camel stood up with him. Then another heard him chanting when he overlooked Al-Bayda'.

The scholars of external rites said that when a Meccan enters *ihram*, he does not chant the *Talbiya* until he sets out toward Mina. My preferred view is that he should chant the *Talbiya* immediately after prayer when he enters *ihram*, and then continue chanting when he sets out, and he should not cease chanting until the prescribed time when the *Talbiya* is cut off. Since the call was for all the acts of Hajj, the *Talbiya* is the response to that call. As long as there remains an act of Hajj before him that he has not performed, he should not cut off the *Talbiya* until he finishes the acts of Hajj to which he was called. This is what reflection requires, unless a text from the Lawgiver specifies a time for cutting off the *Talbiya*, in which case one must stop there, based on his saying (peace and blessings be upon him): "Take your rites from me."

### Supplication is a Request for Proximity from the Ruling of the Servant (الدعاء طلب للقرب من حكم العبد)

Since supplication (*Du'a'*) is, according to the People of God, a call from the height of distance and a revelation of the essence of the ailment, the response (*Ijaba*) immediately signals distance. Thus, the call is a request for proximity from the ruling of this distance. The response is a preliminary glad tiding from the servant to The Real, informing Him of the response to His call to manifest in a form that grants these relations. Although happiness lies in that response for the servant, God only created Jinn and mankind to worship Him, so He called them to what He created them for. Since both response and non-response were possible, the response was a glad tiding to the Caller that His call was heard and His command obeyed, while others refused and abstained, even though they heard the call.

### Attributing Acts to the Doers and their Annihilation from Seeing Them (نسبة الأعمال إلى العمال وفناؤهم عن رؤيتها)

Perhaps this includes those who permit delay despite ability. The best approach in every respect is to hasten when ability is present and impediments are removed. God made His saying <<يُبَشِّرُهُمْ رَبُّهُمْ بِرَحْمَةٍ مِنْهُ وَرِضْوَانٍ>> (Their Lord gives them good tidings of mercy from Him and approval) a reward corresponding to this glad tiding of response. And He said <<لَهُمُ الْبُشْرَى فِي الْحَيَاةِ الدُّنْيَا وَفِي الْآخِرَةِ>> (For them are glad tidings in the worldly life and in the Hereafter) as a confirmed reward for their glad tidings of responding to the Caller of The Real with acts of worship. They said, "Labbayk" (Here I am), meaning, "A response to You for what You called us to and created us for." Thus, the Caller of The Real did not return disappointed. Then they confirmed the response by performing what they were obligated to do, according to the limits of their obligation, attributing the acts to themselves while being annihilated (*fana'*) from seeing them as originating from themselves, seeing instead the One who causes them to flow through their hands and initiates them within them. They are workers of acts—this is the reality of the matter, whether the servants realize it or not. The knowledgeable one is honored by this realization over the one who does not realize it, and is favored above him. <<يَرْفَعِ اللَّهُ الَّذِينَ آمَنُوا مِنْكُمْ وَالَّذِينَ أُوتُوا الْعِلْمَ دَرَجَاتٍ وَاللَّهُ بِمَا تَعْمَلُونَ خَبِيرٌ وَاللَّهُ يَهْدِي مَنْ يَشَاءُ إِلَى صِرَاطٍ مُسْتَقِيمٍ>> (God will raise those who have believed among you and those who were given knowledge, by degrees. And God is Acquainted with what you do. And God guides whom He wills to a straight path).

(Section on the Chapter of the Meccan Entering *Ihram* for 'Umra without Hajj)

Scholars obligated the Meccan to exit to the *Hill* (unconsecrated area), and I know of no proof for this whatsoever. They differed regarding one who did not exit to the *Hill*: some said he must offer blood (*dam*), and some said his 'Umra is invalid. I examined their evidence for this and did not find it to be proof for their view. My view on this issue is that it is permissible for the Meccan to enter *ihram* for 'Umra from his house, just as he enters *ihram* for Hajj. He performs all the rites of 'Umra—*Tawaf*, *Sa'y*, and shaving or shortening—and dissolves *ihram*, and nothing is incumbent upon him whatsoever.

When the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) set the *Mawaqit* (boundaries) for those intending Hajj and 'Umra, without distinguishing between Hajj and 'Umra, he said: "The *Miqat* for the people of Mecca is from Mecca."

The acts required in the rite of 'Umra are actions, and the acts required in the rite of Hajj are actions. The Messenger of God (peace and blessings be upon him) never specifically prescribed combining the *Hill* and the *Haram* except for the pilgrim from outside Mecca (*āfāqī*). He told Abd al-Rahman ibn Abi Bakr: "Take Aisha out to Al-Tan'im so that she may enter *ihram* for 'Umra in place of the 'Umra she rejected when she menstruated." Aisha was an *āfāqī*. This is the evidence used by the scholars for their view, but it is extremely weak evidence and cannot be used as proof against the Meccan.

### The Meccan is in God's Sacred Precinct, Meaning He Exists in the Essence of Proximity to God (المكي هو في حرم الله أي موجود في عين القرب من الله)

The most appropriate way to implement the Wisdom (الحكمة) concerning the Meccan resident (*Makki*) is that he should not leave for the Non-Sacred Territory (*Hill*) when he enters the state of ritual consecration (*ihram*) for the minor pilgrimage (*Umrah*). For he is already within the Sacred Precinct (*Haram*) of Allah, exalted is He, and is thus in a state of witnessed servitude (عبودية مشاهدة); the location itself prevents him from being anything other than a servant. He then confirms that servitude by entering *ihram*. Thus, *ihram* within the *Haram* is a confirmation of servitude (العبودية) and a glorification of Lordship (الربوبية). If he leaves for the *Hill*, he diminishes this degree, whereas the goal is an increase in merit. Do you not see that when the Outsider (*Afaqi*) went out to the *Hill* there, he entered *ihram*? It was not required of him, in his departure, to remain in a state of ritual deconsecration (*ihlāl*). He then entered the *Haram* consecrated, thereby adding merit upon merit. The increase was the goal. The *Makki* is in the Sacred Precinct of Allah, meaning he exists in the very essence of proximity (قرب) to Allah by virtue of the place. Why, then, should he leave, when proximity is his house and his homeland? Far be it from the Lawgiver (الشارع) to hold this view, nor did He say it, see it, or command it.

### [The Outsider in *Ihram* Must Be Between the *Hill* and the *Haram*]

Since the concern (*himma*) of the Outsider (*Afaqi*) was attached to his homeland outside the *Haram*, his departure to the *Hill* for the sake of *ihram* for *Umrah* was like a punishment for him, because his concern was attached to that place. He is in the intention of separating from the Sacred Precinct of Allah and seeking his homeland outside of it. Thus, he departed from the superior state to one that is lesser. And where is the neighbor of Allah compared to one who is not His neighbor? Allah has commanded kindness to the neighbor, so much so that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Gabriel, peace be upon him, continued to enjoin me concerning the neighbor until I thought he would make him an heir," meaning, he would include him among the relatives who receive shares in the inheritance.

Likewise, in the Hajj, the rite of standing at Arafat is agreed upon, and Arafat is in the *Hill*. It has not been reported from the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, that he legislated the standing at Arafat only because it is in the *Hill*. Nor is it necessary for the consecrated person (*muhrim*) to combine the *Hill* and the *Haram*. The Lawgiver did not address any of this; if it had been His intention, He would have made it clear and not left people in confusion. Rather, peace and blessings be upon him, He clarified what we mentioned regarding the appointed stations (*mawāqīt*). He described the rites (*manāsik*), specified them, their states, their places, and their times. May Allah inspire us with the guidance of our souls and make us among those who follow and emulate. Amen, by His Might. <<وَاللَّهُ يَقُولُ الْحَقَّ وَهُوَ يَهْدِي السَّبِيلَ>> (And Allah speaks the Truth, and He guides to the Way).

(Chapter on When the Pilgrim Interrupts the Talbiyah)

Some say [it is interrupted] when the sun declines on the Day of Arafat, which is at noon. Others say until he stones the entire Jamrat al-Aqaba. And others say when he throws the first pebble at the Jamrat al-Aqaba. Our previous statement on this is that as long as any ritual act of the Hajj remains for him, he should not interrupt the Talbiyah (التلبية) until he completes it. For Allah calls him as long as any act of Hajj remains, and the response (الإجابة) is obligatory. There is no explicit text (*naṣṣ*) from the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, regarding this. The most that has reached us is that one person did not hear him reciting the Talbiyah after the sun declined, another did not hear him reciting it when he threw the first pebble at Jamrat al-Aqaba, and yet another did not hear him reciting it after throwing the last pebble at the last *jamra*. Thus, each of them was truthful in that he did not hear [the Prophet] reciting the Talbiyah as they had heard it at the beginning of the Hajj consecration (*ihlāl*). All of them are trustworthy in what they reported.

For the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, did not legislate the continuous recitation of the Talbiyah throughout the time of Hajj without pause, such that one could not attend to speech or remembrance (*dhikr*). Rather, he recited the Talbiyah at one time, performed *dhikr* at another, rested at another, ate at another, and delivered sermons at another. Therefore, continuous recitation of the Talbiyah is not legislated, even if one recites it frequently; there must be interruptions during the times of Hajj. All of this is not a matter of dispute. Likewise, in our view, the person performing *Umrah* does not interrupt the Talbiyah as long as any ritual act of the *Umrah* remains for him. For those who said that the person consecrated for *Umrah* goes out to the *Hill*, some said he interrupts the Talbiyah when he reaches the *Haram* (meaning the Mosque), and others said when he begins the circumambulation (*tawāf*).

### [No Obligatory Act is More Deserving of Observance Than Another, and Likewise for the Recommended Acts]

Know that there is no act of Hajj or *Umrah* that the consecrated person begins except that The Real (الحق) calls him to perform the remaining acts; this is necessary. Just as he is obligated to respond initially to the act, he is obligated to respond to every act until he performs it. For the consecrated person has entered Hajj from the moment he entered *ihram*, and he did not interrupt the Talbiyah; he circumambulated the House, and he did not interrupt the Talbiyah; he performed the running (*sa'y*), and he did not interrupt the Talbiyah; he went out to Arafat, and he did not interrupt the Talbiyah. No obligatory act is more deserving of observance than another, and likewise, no recommended act is more deserving of observance than another, since no definitive text (*naṣṣ*) from the Lawgiver has been reported on which to rely.

### [The Messenger is a Caller to Allah by Allah's Command, so Allah is the One Responded To]

In the obligatory acts (*farā’iḍ*), the response is to Allah, and in the recommended acts (*sunan*), the response is to the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him. For Allah says: <<يَا أَيُّهَا الَّذِينَ آمَنُوا اسْتَجِيبُوا لِلَّهِ وَلِلرَّسُولِ إِذَا دَعَاكُمْ>> (O you who have believed, respond to Allah and to the Messenger when he calls you). For the Messenger is a caller by the command of Allah, so Allah is the One responded to. The Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, admonished the worshipper whom the Messenger of Allah called, but who did not respond when called, even though he was praying. He said, "O Messenger of Allah, I was in prayer." The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said to him, "Did you not hear the saying of Allah, the Exalted: <<اسْتَجِيبُوا لِلَّهِ وَلِلرَّسُولِ إِذَا دَعَاكُمْ>> (Respond to Allah and to the Messenger when he calls you)?" And the Talbiyah is a response (إجابة).

The acts of Hajj are between obligatory and recommended. If you are fair, the Truth (الحق) has become clear to you, so adhere to it, unless you find an explicit text (*naṣṣ*) from the saying of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, regarding this, in which case the reference is to him.

### [The Gnostics Do Not Interrupt the Talbiyah, Neither in This World Nor in the Hereafter]

As for the Gnostics (*al-Ārifūn*), they do not interrupt the Talbiyah, neither in this world nor in the Hereafter. They continuously hear the call of The Real (الحق) in their hearts (قلوبهم) with their breaths. Thus, they move from state (*ḥāl*) to state according to what The Real calls them to. Likewise, the truthful believers in this world [respond] to what the Law calls them to in all their actions. Their response is what protects them from falling into the prohibited. They also move from state to state due to their Lord calling them, for He is the Caller eternally, and the Gnostic is not veiled in hearing, so he is the Responder eternally.

### [The Theophany is Perpetual, Not Circular; It Neither Ceases Nor Repeats]

May Allah make us among those whose hearing is split open to the call of their Lord and whose sight is split open to witness His Theophany (تجلي). The Theophany (التجلي) is perpetual; it does not cease. The witnessing (شهود) of The Real (الحق) is that which does not lift. Thus, there is permanence for permanence, concern for concern, and transition to a station (*maqām*) that is higher than the station you left, from a perspective that relates to you. But there is nothing higher from a perspective that relates to The Real. For if you relate matters to The Real, they do not differ in honor; but if you relate them to yourself, they differ in respect to you. The one who is perfected (*al-mukammal*) in our view is he for whom matters are in relation to him as they are in relation to Allah, and he is the one who sees the Face of The Real (وجه الحق) in every matter. I have not seen anyone who has tasted this door, in its entirety, among those whose reports have reached us. Yet, there must be men who attain it; this is necessary, but they are few, for the station is immense and the matter is grave. I used to imagine that one of those who followed us had attained it, but one day a reproach came to me from him concerning a matter, and that very address witnessed to me that he had not attained it.

(Chapter on the Circumambulation of the Kaaba)

Its description is that one places the House to his left and begins by kissing the Black Stone (*al-Ḥajar al-Aswad*) if he is able, then prostrates upon it, or points to it if he cannot reach it. He then moves back slightly so that he includes it in the *Tawāf* by passing it, and then walks until he reaches it again. He does this seven times, kissing the Stone each time, and touching the Yemeni Corner (*Rukn al-Yamānī*) that precedes the corner of the Stone with his hand, but not kissing it. If he is performing the Circumambulation of Arrival (*Ṭawāf al-Qudūm*), he performs *Raml* (hastening) for three circuits and walks for four circuits. However, in the circuits of *Raml*, he walks slightly between the two Yemeni Corners and says: <<رَبَّنا آتِنا فِي الدُّنْيا حَسَنَةً وَفِي الْآخِرَةِ حَسَنَةً وَقِنا عَذابَ النَّارِ>> (Our Lord, grant us in this world [that which is] good and in the Hereafter [that which is] good and protect us from the punishment of the Fire), until the seven circuits are completed, all with a heart present with Allah.

### [The Circumambulators Around the House are Like Those Surrounding the Throne]

He should imagine that in this act of worship he is like those surrounding the Throne (*al-Arsh*), <<يُسَبِّحُونَ بِحَمْدِ رَبِّهِمْ>> (glorifying with the praise of their Lord). Thus, he must adhere to glorification (*tasbīḥ*), praise (*taḥmīd*), declaration of oneness (*tahlīl*), and the saying of "There is no might nor power except with Allah, the Exalted, the Magnificent," during his circumambulation. And concerning this, we have:

> A body circumambulates, but a heart is not circumambulating;
> An essence turns away, and an essence has no turning away.

> He is called, even if this state is his adornment,
> This Gnostic (*al-Ārif*), the zealous, resolute Imam.

> Far, far away! The name of falsehood does not please me;
> My heart is fearful of the hidden plots of its deceit.

### [The Kaaba Asks for Circumambulation and Zamzam Asks to Be Drunk to Satiation]

One day I looked at the Kaaba, and it was asking me to circumambulate it, and Zamzam was asking me to drink its water until satiated, desiring connection with the believer—a spoken request audible to the ear. We feared being veiled by them, despite their great status with The Real (الحق), from the state of Divine Proximity (القرب الإلهي) that befits that location in our gnosis (*ma'rifa*). So I recited to them, addressing them and informing them of the true state of affairs, translating the reality of the Perfect Believer (المؤمن الكامل):

> O Kaaba of Allah, and O Zamzam,
> How often you ask me for union! Hush, then be silent!

> If my union with you occurs,
> It is out of mercy, not desire for you.

> The Kaaba of Allah is none other than our Essence (ذاتنا),
> The Essence marked by the veils of piety.

> The Real was not contained by heaven, nor
> Earth, nor the one He spoke to (Moses).

> He appeared to the heart and said, "Be patient,
> For it is our established *Qibla*."

> From you to us, and to your heart
> Is my House, how magnificent it is!

> Love for you is obligatory upon our Kaaba,
> And our love is obligatory upon you. Be silent!

> The House was not magnified over others
> Except by you, My servant, by your adherence to it.

> Your circumambulation has illuminated the Kaaba,
> While the houses of mankind are dark.

> How patient the House is with their polytheism!
> Were it not for you, it would be a misfortune for them.

> But you, in your mutual counsel,
> [Enjoined] patience in realization and mercy.

> How the heart loves My Essence (ذاتي)! How
> Intense is its love, and how knowledgeable it is!

### [Correspondence and Reproach Between the Kaaba and Ibn Arabi]

During my residence near the Kaaba, there was continuous correspondence, supplication, and reproach between us. I mentioned some of the discourses that occurred between us in a volume we named *Tāj al-Rasā’il wa Minhāj al-Wasā’il* (The Crown of Epistles and the Path of Means), which I believe contains seven or eight epistles, corresponding to the seven circuits (*ashwāṭ*), with one epistle from me for each circuit addressed to the Divine Attribute (الصفة الإلهية) that manifested to me in that circuit.

However, I did not compose those epistles or address her with them except due to a specific incident. This was because I used to prefer my own existential origin (*nash’a*) over her, and I placed her station in the manifestation of Realities (مجلى الحقائق) below my own station. I considered her merely as an inanimate origin (*nash’a jamādiyya*), at the lowest degree of generated things, and I disregarded the high degrees with which Allah had distinguished her. This was so that her spiritual concern (*himma*) might ascend and that she might not be veiled by the circumambulation of Messengers and great figures around her essence and the kissing of her Stone. For I am certain of the ascent of the world, high and low, with every breath, due to the impossibility of the Fixed Entities (الأعيان) remaining constant in a single state. For the Origin to which all existing things return, which is Allah, described Himself as <<كُلَّ يَوْمٍ هُوَ فِي شَأْنٍ>> (Every day He is in [new] manifestation). Thus, it is impossible for anything in the world to remain in one state for two moments. Therefore, states change upon it due to the variation of Theophanies (التجليات) through the Divine Affairs (*Shu’ūn*). My attitude towards her was due to the dominance of a spiritual state that overcame me.

There is no doubt that The Real (الحق) intended to alert me to the spiritual intoxication (*sukr al-ḥāl*) I was in. So He roused me from my bed on a cold, moonlit night with a light rain. I performed ablution and went out to circumambulate with intense agitation. There was no one circumambulating except one other person, I believe.

(In the Name of Allah, the Most Merciful, the Grantor of Mercy)

(Chapter) On what happened concerning the Kaaba regarding me on that night

When I descended, I kissed the Stone and began the circumambulation. When I was opposite the water spout (*Mīzāb*) behind the *Ḥijr* (semi-circular wall), I looked at the Kaaba and saw, in what was imagined for me, that she had gathered up her skirts and was preparing, raised above her foundations. She intended, when I reached the Syrian Corner (*Rukn ash-Shāmī*) during the circuit, to push me away and cast me out from circumambulating her. She was threatening me with words that I heard with my ear. I became extremely distressed. Allah revealed to me such distress and rage from her that I could not move from my spot. I shielded myself with the *Ḥijr*, making it like a shield between her and me, so that any blow from her would fall upon it. I swear by Allah, I heard her saying to me: "Come forward so you may see what I will do to you! How often you diminish my worth and elevate the worth of the children of Adam, preferring the Gnostics over me! By the Might of the One to whom Might belongs, I will not let you circumambulate me!"

I turned back to myself and knew that Allah intended to discipline me. I thanked Allah for that, and the distress I felt vanished. I swear by Allah, she appeared to me, raised from the ground upon her foundations, gathering her skirts, just as a person gathers his clothes when he intends to leap from his place. Thus, she was imagined for me, having gathered her coverings upon herself to leap upon me. She was in the form of a maiden; I had never seen a more beautiful form, nor could one be imagined. I immediately improvised verses, addressing her with them and seeking to appease her from the distress I had witnessed. I continued to praise her in those verses, and she began to expand and descend with her foundations back to her place, showing joy at what I recited to her, until she returned to her former state, granted me safety, and signaled me to circumambulate.

### [The Trust Ibn Arabi Deposited with the Kaaba]

I threw myself upon the *Multazam* (the area between the Black Stone and the door), and every joint in my body was trembling from the intensity of the state (*ḥāl*), until it passed from me. I reconciled with her and deposited the testimony of Divine Unity (*Shahādat at-Tawḥīd*) with her when kissing the Stone. As I uttered the testimony, it emerged, and I watched it with my own eyes in the form of a thread. An archway opened in the Black Stone, allowing me to look into the depth of the Stone's length, which I saw was about a cubit. I later asked one of the residents who had seen it when the House burned and was repaired with silver. He told me, "I saw it just as you described, about a cubit long, and I saw the testimony had become like a ball of thread and settled at the bottom of the Stone." The Stone closed upon it, and that archway sealed up while I watched. She said to me, "This is a trust (*amāna*) with me. I will raise it for you until the Day of Resurrection, and I will testify for you with it before Allah." This was the saying of the Stone to me, and I heard it. I thanked Allah, and then I thanked her for that. From that time, reconciliation occurred between us, and I addressed her with those seven epistles, which increased her joy and delight. Until a glad tiding came to me from her, conveyed through a righteous man of the People of Unveiling (*Ahl al-Kashf*), who had no knowledge of what had transpired between us that I mentioned. He said to me, "Last night, in a dream, I saw the Kaaba, and she was saying to me, 'O Abd al-Wahid, Glory be to Allah! There is no one circumambulating me in this Sacred Precinct except so-and-so,' naming you by your name. 'I do not know where the people have gone.'" "Then she stood me up in the dream, and you were circumambulating her alone; I did not see anyone else with you in the *Tawāf*." The seer said, "She then told me, 'Look at him! Do you see any other circumambulator with me?' 'No, by Allah, nor do I see him myself.'" I thanked Allah for this glad tiding from such a man and recalled the saying of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, concerning the righteous vision that the Muslim man sees or that is seen for him.

### [The Verses with which Ibn Arabi Appeased the Kaaba]

As for the verses with which I appeased the Kaaba, they are these:

> My heart sought refuge at the *Multazam*
> When the arrow of enemies came to it.

> O Mercy of Allah for the servants,
> Allah deposited you in the inanimate.

> O House of my Lord, O light of my heart,
> O comfort of the eye, O my core!

> O secret of the heart of Existence (الوجود) truly,
> O my sanctity, O purity of my affection!

> O *Qibla* I have approached,
> From every quarter and every valley.

> And from subsistence (*baqā’*), then from heaven,
> And from annihilation (*fanā’*), then from the cradle.

> O Kaaba of Allah, O my life,
> O path of felicity, O my guidance!

> Allah deposited in you all security
> From the terror of the dread on the Day of Return.

> In you the Noble Station (*Maqām*) shines,
> In you are the felicities for the servants.

> In you is the Right Hand that my sin
> Clothed with the newness of blackness.

> The one who adheres to his passion adheres to you;
> He will be happy on the Day of Calling.

> Souls died of longing for it,
> From the pain of yearning and distance.

> From the grief of what befell them,
> It has worn the garment of mourning.

> For Allah is a light upon its peaks,
> From His light, manifest to the heart.

> And none sees it but a sorrowful one,
> Whose eye is lined with sleeplessness.

> He circumambulates seven times after seven,
> From the beginning of the night until the caller.

> With a tear that has no cessation,
> A captive of ecstasy, sworn to striving.

> I heard him say, seeking aid,
> From the side of the Stone, "Alas, my heart!"

> Our night has swiftly passed,
> But my desire in love has not passed.

### [The Black Stone is the Right Hand of Allah on Earth, that We May Pledge Allegiance to It in Every Circuit]

When Allah related the Throne (*al-Arsh*) to Himself and made it the locus of the Merciful’s Establishment, saying: <<الرَّحْمَنُ عَلَى الْعَرْشِ اسْتَوَى>> (The Most Merciful established Himself upon the Throne), He made the angels surrounding it, circling the Throne, like the guards of a king and those adhering to his gate to execute his commands. Allah made the Kaaba His House and established those who circumambulate it in that same manner. The House is distinguished from the Throne, the *Ḍirāḥ* (the celestial Kaaba), and the rest of the fourteen Houses by a matter that has not been reported to us as existing in the Throne or in any of the other Houses. This is the Black Stone (الحجر الأسود), the Right Hand of Allah on Earth, that we may pledge allegiance (*mubāya’a*) to it in every circuit—a pledge of contentment (*riḍwān*) and a glad tiding of acceptance for what we have done in that circuit, whether it is for us or against us. What is for us is acceptance, and what is against us is forgiveness. I saw in a spiritual vision (*wāqi’a*) people circumambulating it, and sparks of fire were flying from their mouths. I interpreted this as the inappropriate speech of the circumambulators during their *Tawāf*. When we reach the Right Hand, which is the Stone, we perceive acceptance from Allah, the Glorified, so we pledge allegiance to it and kiss His Hand, which is related to Him, with a kiss of joyful and hopeful acceptance. This is done in every circuit. If the crowding around it is great—due to its Theophany (تجلي) in a sensible, delimited form—we point to it, signaling our desire to kiss it and acknowledging our inability to reach it. We do not stop to wait for our turn to reach it and kiss it. For if He had intended that of us, He would not have legislated pointing to it when we are unable to reach it. Thus, we know that He desires us to maintain continuous walking during the seven circuits without interruption, except for the time needed for kissing as we pass, if we find a way to do so. We know that the Right Hand of Allah is Absolute (مطلقة), and we are in its grasp, with no veil between us and it. However, when it appeared in the manifestation of a delimited entity (عين محصورة) referred to as the Stone, the preparedness of this entity, called the Stone of Relation, restricted the manifestation of the Hand through it. Thus, the restriction and delimitation were established, even though it is undoubtedly the Hand of Allah, but in the manner that He, the Glorified, knows concerning it. Thus, the relation is sound.

### [There is Nothing in Existence Except Allah, and the Possible Entities Remain on Their Origin of Non-Existence]

From this, our saying is understood: that there is nothing in Existence (الوجود) except Allah, and the Possible Entities (الأعيان الإمكانية) remain upon their origin of non-existence, distinguished for Allah in their essences (أعيانها) according to their realities (حقائقها). And that The Real (الحق) is the One who manifests in them, without any conceivable containment. He manifests in the form of that entity, which, if it were truly to exist, would be in this sensible form. Look at how wondrous the matter of Existence (الوجود) is! The entity that benefits from Existence is the very entity that benefits [Existence]. If the benefit is other than Existence—namely, the form—then the Beneficiary is the Manifest One (الظاهر), and the Benefactor is the Entity (العين). This is because the form in which the Manifest One appeared is truly the form of the manifesting entity. Thus, every ruling attributed to the Manifest One originates from that entity. And the Manifest One benefited the entity by His manifestation with the ruling of influence upon it, for the entity did not possess that ruling when it existed without manifestation or Theophany (تجلي) in its form. We have only clarified this for you so that you may know who is the circumambulator, who is the circumambulated, who is the Stone, and who is the Kisser. Thus, you will be according to what you have known of this, and your knowledge is the very essence of your form. In it, your spirit will be gathered on the Day of Resurrection, and by it, you will be distinguished in the Greatest Assembly (*az-Zawr al-A'ẓam*). Therefore, do not let the knowledge I have alerted you to escape you. Peace.

(Chapter on the Ruling of Running (*Raml*) in the Circumambulation)

Some say it is a *Sunnah* (recommended practice), making a compensatory sacrifice (*dam*) obligatory upon whoever omits it. Others say it is a merit (*faḍīla*), so nothing is obligatory for its omission. I mean this concerning the Circumambulation of Arrival (*Ṭawāf al-Qudūm*).

### [Raml is Hastening in the Essence of Goodness Towards Goodness]

*Raml* (hastening) is hastening in the very essence of goodness toward goodness; thus, it is goodness within goodness. This is due to the wisdom of seeking to quickly grasp the knowledge of the Divine Command. For Allah, the Exalted, says: <<وَمَا أَمْرُنَا إِلَّا وَاحِدَةٌ كَلَمْحٍ بِالْبَصَرِ>> (And Our command is but one [word], like the twinkling of an eye). Nothing is faster than the eye. The time of its twinkling is the very time of its connection to the object seen, no matter how far away it is. The farthest sensible objects are the fixed stars in the sphere of the mansions. When you look at them, the glance connects to them. This is the speed of the sense. What, then, do you think of the meanings abstracted from restriction, regarding the speed of their penetration? Speed has a ruling concerning things that does not belong to anything else. From this, the saying of The Real to a thing, "Be (Kun)," and it "is (Fayakūn)," is understood. The state of the Divine "Be" is the state of the created thing that "is." This is why the fastest letter used in this context is the *fā’* of immediate sequence, which is why it appears in the response to the command.

### [The Image of the World's Origin, Its Manifestation, and the Penetration of the Divine Command Within It]

If you wish to know the image of the world's origin (*nash’*), its manifestation, the speed of the penetration of the Divine Command within it, and what eyes and insights perceive of it, look at what happens in the air due to the speed of movement of a firebrand in the hand of the one moving it, if he intends it. It creates a circle in the eye of the beholder, or an elongated line if the movement is lengthwise, or any shape he wishes. Do not doubt that you saw a circle of fire, yet do not doubt that there is no circle there. Rather, the speed of the movement created that in your sight. This is His saying: <<وَمَا أَمْرُنَا>> (And Our command), and His saying "Be," <<إِلَّا وَاحِدَةٌ>> (is but one), like the firebrand, <<كَلَمْحٍ بِالْبَصَرِ>> (like the twinkling of an eye)—the perception of the circle, which is not a circle. That is the very created form that appears to the perception of the eye. Thus, you judge, based on your sight, insight, and thought, that it is creation. But based on your knowledge and Unveiling (كشف), you know that it is The Real (حق) by which what appeared to your eye—which is not *it*—was created. This is non-existence in the very essence of existence. Look at how subtle this perception is, despite the sense being the locus of its manifestation, with all its restriction, density, and deficiency. What, then, do you think of the true state of affairs concerning the Divine Presence (جناب الحق)? Glory be to the One who speaks to Himself through Himself in the entities (أعيان) of His creation, as He said: <<فَأَجِرْهُ حَتَّى يَسْمَعَ كَلَامَ اللَّهِ>> (Grant him protection until he hears the Word of Allah). And indeed, Allah said upon the tongue of His servant: "Allah hears the one who praises Him." He is the Speaker and the One who says: <<لَا إِلَٰهَ إِلَّا هُوَ الْعَزِيزُ الْحَكِيمُ>> (There is no deity except Him, the Exalted in Might, the Wise).

### [The Time of the Lightning's Illumination is the Very Time the Air is Colored by It]

My brother, verify your observation regarding the speed of lightning when it flashes. When the lightning flashes, the flash is the cause of the air being colored by it. The coloring of the air by it is the cause of the manifestation of the sensible entities (أعيان المحسوسات) through it. The manifestation of the sensible entities through it is the cause of the perception of the eyes connecting to them. And the time for all of this is one, despite your rational understanding of the precedence of every cause over its effect. The time of the lightning's illumination is the very time the air is colored by it, which is the very time the sensible things manifest through it, which is the very time the eyes perceive what manifested from them. Glory be to the One who sets forth parables and establishes forms, so that the speaker may say, "There is," and "There is not," or "There is not." By the Might of the One to whom Might, Majesty, and Grandeur belong, there is nothing there except Allah, the Necessary Existent (الواجب الوجود), the One in His Essence (ذاته), the Many in His Names (أسمائه) and Rulings (أحكامه), the One capable of the impossible—so what of possibility and the possible, which are among His rulings? By Allah, it is none other than Allah. From Him and to Him all matters return. This is why *Raml* was legislated three times—no more, no less.
