The One is for Him, the Third is for what manifested, and the Second is between the First and the Third, being the cause for the manifestation of what manifested from Him. This is necessary.

### [If You Verify What You Saw, You Will See That There Is What You Saw]

If you verify what you saw, you will see that there is what you saw. Thus, the intellect's perception of intelligible matters emerges in this triangular form: the premises composed of three parts to produce the desired conclusion. Likewise, in the sense: sense, sensible object, and the connection of the sense to the sensible object. One does not know whether the sense connected to the sensible object or the sensible object was imprinted upon the sense. By Allah, the intellect falls short, thought retreats, imagination is bewildered, and understanding is obscured. The matter is immense, the affair is grave. The Law (*Shar’*) descends, the intellect receives, the Command penetrates, events occur, the powers are established, the balances are set, the Words do not cease, and the created things are not distant. Yet, there is nothing alongside this manifold known thing, for the Entity (العين) is one, and the Command is one. Bewilderment (*al-Ḥayra*) became bewildered in itself, finding no one to contend with it. The bewilderment that one imagines the world is described by is not as imagined; rather, that is the bewilderment of bewilderment. There is nothing there except Him. By Allah, tongues are exhausted from expressing what hearts have known of that, and by Allah, hearts are exhausted from grasping the true state of affairs, so they do not know whether they are bewildered or not. Yet, bewilderment exists, and its locus of subsistence is unknown. For whom does it exist? And in whom did its ruling manifest? There is nothing there except Allah.

> There is nothing there except Allah, nothing other than Him,
> And there is no "there" when the Entity (العين) is one.

> Therefore, we said concerning the Essences (الذوات) that they,
> Even if they are not prostrating to Allah, they are prostrating by Allah.

(A Chapter from It)

Scholars differed regarding whether the residents of Mecca (*Ahl Makkah*) must perform *Raml* when they perform Hajj. Some said that every circumambulation before Arafat that is followed by *Sa'y* (running) requires *Raml*. Others said it is recommended. Some did not see *Raml* as obligatory for them when they circumambulated the House, which is the doctrine of Ibn Umar, as narrated by Malik.

### [The Human is Under the Ruling of Every Breath]

If the reason (*‘illa*) is what we mentioned previously concerning *Raml*, then *Raml* is incumbent upon the residents of Mecca and others. Especially since the matter itself is that the human is under the ruling of every breath (*nafas*), and every breath is an arrival (*qādim*), and every arrival is a circumambulation (*ṭā’if*), and every Circumambulation of Arrival (*Ṭawāf Qudūm*) includes *Raml*. This is the *Sunnah* concerning it for whoever wishes to follow it. But whoever is ignorant of the arrival of his own soul, and that the human is created in every state—arriving upon Existence (الوجود) from non-existence—does not see circumambulation as incumbent upon him. For he belongs to the people of this description, just as the residents of Mecca are from Mecca.

(Chapter on Touching the Corners)

Some scholars, who are the majority, said that only two corners should be touched. Jabir said, "We used to hold that when we circumambulated, we should touch all the corners." Some of the early scholars (*Ahl as-Salaf*) said it is recommended to touch the two corners in every odd circuit: the first, third, fifth, and seventh. They agreed that kissing the Black Stone is specifically among the *Sunan* of *Tawāf*, but they differed regarding kissing the second Yemeni Corner.

### [Touching, which is Touching the Corner with the Hand with the Intention of the Pledge of Allegiance]

As for touching (*istilām*), which is touching the corner with the hand with the intention of the pledge of allegiance (*bay’a*), it occurs only at the corner of the Stone, specifically in the Stone, because The Real (الحق) made it His Right Hand. Thus, touching it is by way of the pledge of allegiance. Whoever does not view the touching as a pledge of allegiance but views it as a blessing (*baraka*) touches all the corners, for touching them and being near them is all blessing. The corner of the Stone is distinguished only by the pledge of allegiance and the handshake (*muṣāfaḥa*). It shares in the blessing with the other corners, possessing both the status of a corner and an addition. Whoever observes its status as a corner includes the Yemeni Corner with it in the touching. The third corner is in the *Ḥijr* (semi-circular wall) but is not specified, as it has no form in the House. The Syrian and Iraqi Corners are not corners of the House as originally established. Since they were not established by the first Divine establishment, they are not [true] corners, and their ruling differs from the ruling of the two [true] corners. However, whoever holds that all actions are from Allah sees that the One who specified the two corners and the third corner in the *Ḥijr* by the first establishment is the same One who specified the four corners by the second establishment, since there is no Establisher but Allah. Thus, he touches all the corners, considering them corners established by a Divine establishment, which Allah enabled whichever of His creatures He willed to manifest through their hands. However, their status as corners does not include them in the kissing and the handshake. Therefore, the circumambulator, after kissing the Stone, prostrating upon it with his forehead as the *Sunnah* dictates, and shaking hands with it by touching it with his hand, should touch its corner so that he has touched all the corners. If he does not do this, he has not touched [all of them], unless he holds that the Black Stone is part of the stones of the corner, in which case his handshake is itself the touching.

(Chapter on the Prostration after Circumambulation)

> I circumambulated the House seven times and prayed two cycles,
> At the Station of the Intimate Friend (Abraham), then I returned.

> To my circumambulation, and I circumambulated seven times, and we returned
> To the Station of the Intimate Friend, then I prayed two cycles.

> I did not cease calling between this and that,
> "O Beloved of Hearts," until I heard:

> "O My servants!" So I said, "Here I am, my Lord!
> Here I am, I have responded, and then I have obeyed."

> "So command whatever you wish of Me,
> For the door of acceptance has been opened by Me."

Scholars agreed that two cycles of prayer (*rak’atayn*) after the completion of the *Tawāf* are among the *Sunan* of *Tawāf*. The majority hold that one performs them after the completion of every seven circuits (*usbū’*) if he performs more than one *usbū’*. Some permitted not separating the *usbū’s* or interposing a prayer between them, and then praying two *rak’at* for every *usbū’*. What I maintain is that it is better to pray at the completion of every *usbū’*. If one combines *usbū’s*, he should only conclude with an odd number (*witr*). For the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, never concluded the *Tawāf* except with an odd number. He concluded after seven circuits, or one *Tawāf*. If he adds more, he should conclude after three *usbū’s*, which is twenty-one circuits. He should not conclude after two *usbū’s*, for that is an even number (*shaf’*), and in terms of circuits, it is fourteen circuits, which is an even number. In that case, he would have acted contrary to the *Sunnah* in his *Tawāf* in every respect.

### [The Circumambulation is a Prayer in Which Speech is Permitted]

Know that it has been narrated that the *Tawāf* is a prayer (*ṣalāh*) in which speech is permitted, even though it contains neither bowing (*rukū’*) nor prostration (*sujūd*), just as the funeral prayer (*ṣalāt al-janā’iz*) is legally called a prayer, though it contains neither bowing nor prostration. The minimum to which the name prayer applies is one *rak’a*, which is the *Witr*. When two *rak’at* are added to the *Tawāf*, it becomes an odd number (*witr*), like the Maghrib prayer which makes the daytime prayers odd. Thus, the *Tawāf* with the two *rak’at* resembles the Maghrib prayer, which is obligatory. The Real (الحق) thus makes the evenness (*shaf’iyya*) of the servant odd.

### [Every Composite Thing is Poor and Needs an Odd Number to Rely Upon]

It should not be said concerning the fourth of four that it has made the servant's oddness even, for the servant does not possess oddness (*witrīyya*) in his essence; he is composite (*murakkab*). Every composite thing is poor (*faqīr*) and needs an odd number (*witr*) to rely upon. He is not singular in his own evenness (*shaf’iyya*). He is never anything but an odd number: three, five, or seven, up to the infinite odd numbers. If he is a fourth or a sixth, he is the fourth of three, not the fourth of four; and the sixth of five, not the sixth of six. He is the original One, added to an odd number. His relation is only to his essence, for he is the essence of every odd number, because by his manifestation, he preserves the name of oddness for the one to whom he is added. Thus, it is said, "the fourth of three," not "the fourth of four," and the fourth of three can only be one.

### [His Absolute Oneness—Exalted is He—in the State of the World's Existence and in the State of Its Non-Existence]

Whether it occurs in an odd number (*witr*) or an even number (*shaf’*), the ruling concerning it is one. You say concerning it, "the fifth of four," just as you say, "the fourth of three." Thus, Absolute Oneness (الأحدية) accompanies Him in every state. This is like the saying: "Allah was, and there was nothing with Him, and He is now as He was." So, He established the "now" in the place of numbers, and numbers include even and odd. If you relate The Real (الحق) to them, you do not make Him one of them. You say, "the third of two," and "the fourth of three," up to the infinite. Thus, He is distinguished by His Essence (ذاته). The ruling established for Him is not established for the world, even though the world exists. That is His Absolute Oneness (الأحدية المطلقة) in the state of the world's existence and in the state of its non-existence.

### [The Circumambulator is an Odd Number, Whether He Performs Tawaf Alone or Adds Two Rak'at to It]

The circumambulator, if he performs the *Tawāf* alone, is an odd number (*witr*). If he adds the two *rak’at* to it, he is an odd number, in that the prayer stands in the place of the single *rak’a*. And whoever completes his *Tawāf* resembles the four-cycle prayer (*ṣalāh rubā’iyya*) due to the existence of the eight prostrations (*sajadāt*) contained within the *usbū’* (seven circuits), which are the sensible prostrations upon the Stone when kissing it. These are eight kisses in every *usbū’*: one at the beginning of the *usbū’* and one at the end of every circuit. Whoever establishes the *Tawāf* according to this consideration, following both paths, will be rewarded with the reward of the obligatory four-cycle and three-cycle prayers, which combine the obligatory and the odd number (*witr*), which is *Sunnah* or obligatory. Therefore, it is better not to delay the two *rak’at* beyond their *usbū’*, but to pray them upon the completion of the *usbū’*. If one recites [the Quran] during the *Tawāf*, he is like one who recites in prayer. If one does not recite, he is like one who holds that the prayer is valid without recitation.

### [The Seven Circuits of Tawaf and the Seven Celestial Spheres]

Know that these two *rak’at* following the *Tawāf* were only generated within you by the *Tawāf*. For the *Tawāf* stood for you in the place of the celestial spheres (*aflāk*), which are the seven heavens, because it is a circular, spherical shape, just like the sphere. When you established seven circuits in the *Tawāf*, you established seven spheres, and Allah revealed in every heaven its command, a fact known only to a Gnostic of Allah. If Allah informs you of what is deposited in these spherical circuits, you are truly a circumambulator.

### [The Movements of the Seven Circuits and the Seven Effects of the Prayer]

Furthermore, He made the movements of the heavens, which are the spheres, influential upon the four corners [of the world] to bring forth what is generated from them. You are the four corners, because you are composed of four humors (*akhlāṭ*), and their totality is the very essence of your sensible self (ذاتك الحسية), which is the body. Thus, the movements of these seven circuits established the Prayer (*Ṣalāh*) within you, which is generated from your corners by them. And it was two *rak’at* because the generated origin (*nash’a*) is composed of two things: body and rational soul (*nafs nāṭiqa*), which is the rational animal. One *rak’a* is for your animality, and the second is for the rational soul. This is why Allah made the Prayer into two halves: one half for Him and one half for the servant. Allah made an effect in the Prayer for every circular movement of this *usbū’*, so that it might be known that the Prayer is generated from it. Thus, seven physical effects and seven spiritual effects appeared in the Prayer, one effect corresponding to the movement of each circuit of the *Tawāf* *usbū’*. For it is a subsisting form and a spiritual sphere (*falak ma’nawī*), seen only by those who perceive the creation of existing things from actions as distinct entities (أعيانا). The seven existing physical effects in the origin of the Prayer are: the first standing, the bowing (*rukū’*), the second standing (rising from bowing), the prostration (*sujūd*), the sitting between the two prostrations, the second prostration, and the sitting for the *tashahhud*. The seven remembrances (*adhkār*) within these physical movements are their spirits. Thus, the origin of the Prayer is established as complete.

### [The Highest Thing in the Human Origin and the Highest Thing in the Origin of the Prayer]

Since there is a matter in the human origin (*nash’a insāniyya*) that Allah singled out and preferred over the rest of the human origin, making it the Imam within it—which is the Heart (القلب)—likewise, He placed a matter in the origin of the Prayer that is the highest thing in the Prayer: the movement in which one says, "Allah hears the one who praises Him." For the worshipper in this position is a deputy of Allah, just as the Heart is a deputy of Allah in the governance of the body. It is the noblest posture of the Prayer, being a standing that follows submission, in which you magnify your Lord in an Isthmus Presence (حضرة برزخية). It is the most complete of origins because it is between prostration and standing, combining the two extremes and the two realities. Thus, it has the ruling of the standing person and the ruling of the prostrating person, combining the two rulings.

### [The Authority of the Opening Chapter of the Book]

Its effect in the recitation during the Prayer is also septenary, corresponding to the effect of each circuit in the *Tawāf*. This is the recitation of the Seven Oft-Repeated Verses (*as-Sab’ al-Mathānī*), meaning the Opening Chapter of the Book (*Fātiḥat al-Kitāb*). Its authority (*sulṭān*) is <<إِيَّاكَ نَعْبُدُ وَإِيَّاكَ نَسْتَعِينُ>> (You alone we worship, and You alone we ask for help). For it is an Isthmus (برزخية) between Allah and His servant. It is comprehensive, and the authority is comprehensive. What precedes it is purely for Allah, and what follows it is purely for the servant. The highest of stations is the affirmation of a Deity and a worshipped one, a Lord and a creature under Lordship. This is the perfection of the Divine Presence (الحضرة الإلهية). He is only praised through us, and we are only honored through Him. We are by Him and for Him. It consists of seven verses, no more, and it is the sufficient recitation in the Prayer.

### [The Manifestation of The Real in the Existential Entities]

Just as the servant is the one who established within his own essence the seven circular, spherical circuits, and within his essence the creation of the Prayer took effect, and within his essence the Prayer manifested in its completeness—so that nothing of all this departed from his essence—likewise is the matter concerning the manifestation of The Real (الحق) in the Entities (الأعيان). He acquired from the preparedness of every entity in which He manifested the ruling that was imposed upon the Manifest One within it. The Entity is one. So it is said of Him, "a circumambulator," which this Name granted Him—this form that He established, which is the *Tawāf*. And it is said of Him, "a worshipper," which this ruling granted Him—the form of the Prayer that He established in His Essence (ذاته) from His *Tawāf*. He is He, and there is nothing else there.

> If you saw what we saw,
> You would describe it with what we described:

> That He is One, yet Many.
> By this we knew Him when we knew.

> So we are not, and He is the Possessor of Manifestation;
> The Entity (العين) is from Him, and the Attribute (النعت) is from us.

### [The True House of Allah, Which Has No Custodians Over It]

We have mentioned at the beginning of this book what remains of the House within the *Ḥijr* (semi-circular wall) and why Allah left it there. We clarified the Divine Wisdom (الحكمة الإلهية) in this: the removal of restriction and the Divine Theophany (التجلي الإلهي) in the open door for whoever wishes to enter it. That is the True House of Allah. What remains of it in the hands of the custodians, Banu Shayba, has restriction (*taḥjīr*) placed upon its interior, because it is in the possession of a created thing (*muḥdath*), which is the restricted existent. It must necessarily act according to what its essence dictates. The Prophetic narration concerning this is well-known. The Caliphs and rulers were heedless of the implication of the meaning of the saying of the Exalted when the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, held the key to the House, which he had taken from Banu Shayba. Then Allah, the Exalted, revealed: <<إِنَّ اللَّهَ يَأْمُرُكُمْ أَن تُؤَدُّوا الْأَمَانَاتِ إِلَىٰ أَهْلِهَا>> (Indeed, Allah commands you to render trusts to whom they are due). People imagined that the trust (*amāna*) was the custodianship of the House, but the trust was only the key to the House, which belonged to Banu Shayba. He returned their key to them, peace and blessings be upon him, and left the authority of custodianship with them. Had He willed, He would have placed others in that rank. The Imam has the right to do so if he sees benefit in the action. However, the Caliphs did not wish to remove from this rank those whom the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, had confirmed in it. They are like all other holders of office: if they uphold The Real (الحق) in it, it is for them; if they act unjustly, it is against them. The Imam has the right to review this. Thus, the House of Allah, according to the Gnostics of Allah, has no ruling for Banu Shayba or anyone else concerning what remains of it in the *Ḥijr*. "Whoever enters it has entered the House, and whoever prays in it has prayed in the House," as the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said to Aisha, the Mother of the Believers, may Allah be pleased with her. The Gnostics (*al-Ārifūn*) do not need the favor of Banu Shayba, for Allah has sufficed them with what He brought forth for them from it in the *Ḥijr*. The Divine Presence (جناب الله) is too vast to have custodians from His creation over it, especially from souls naturally inclined to stinginess, love of leadership, and precedence. Allah granted Al-Hajjaj, may Allah have mercy on him, success in restoring the House to what it was during the time of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, and the Rightly Guided Caliphs. For Abdullah ibn az-Zubayr changed it and included it in the House, but Allah refused anything but the true state of affairs, and they were ignorant of Allah's Wisdom (حكمة الله) in it. Ali ibn al-Jahm says:

> The doors of kings are veiled,
> But the Door of Allah is open to the courtyard.

(Chapter on the Time When Circumambulation is Permitted)

Some permit *Tawāf* after the Fajr and Asr prayers, and this is what I maintain. The reason for this is that I saw the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, in a dream, facing the Kaaba and saying, "O My Owner," or he said, "O My Resident" (the doubt is mine), "of this House, do not prevent anyone from circumambulating it and praying at any time he wishes, by night or by day. For Allah creates for him from his prayer an angel who seeks forgiveness for him until the Day of Resurrection." From that time, I maintained the permissibility of *Tawāf* during these two times. Before this vision, I had reservations about it. For I saw that they hesitated to accept the *Hadith* of An-Nasa'i, which resembles our *Hadith*. When I saw this glad tiding, the difficulty was removed from me, and the *Hadith* of An-Nasa'i and the *Hadith* of Abu Dharr al-Ghifari were confirmed for me. Praise be to Allah. Some maintain prohibition specifically at the time of sunrise and sunset. Some maintain dislike (*karāha*) after Asr and Fajr, and prohibition at sunrise and sunset. And some maintain its permissibility at all times, which is our view, except that I dislike entering the prayer during the time of sunrise and sunset, unless one has already entered *ihram* for it before the time of sunrise or sunset.

(Clarification of That)

The worshipper must either have his *Qibla* at the place of sunrise or sunset, such that he faces it—in which case I dislike that for him—or if it is not in his *Qibla*, there is no harm. As for the Kaaba, the ruling for him revolves around wherever he wishes; he does not face the sun rising or setting. He has separated himself from the disbelievers who prostrate to it in the apparent form of facing it, and he is separated from them inwardly without doubt or uncertainty.

### [The Text of the Two Hadiths of An-Nasa'i and Abu Dharr]

The Hadith of An-Nasa'i: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "O Banu Abd Manaf, do not prevent anyone from circumambulating this House and praying at any time he wishes, by night or by day." He did not specify the time of sunrise or sunset, because the servant, by witnessing the House, is able not to intend facing the setting or rising [sun]. This is not the case in the outlying regions (*al-Āfāq*). How excellent was his caution, peace and blessings be upon him, regarding the worshipper facing a barrier (*sutra*): that he should not face it directly, but should incline slightly to the right or the left.

The Hadith of Abu Dharr: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "There is no prayer after Asr until the sun sets, nor after Fajr until the sun rises, except in Mecca, except in Mecca, except in Mecca."

These *Hadiths* support our vision.

### [Allah is Manifesting Perpetually; Times Do Not Restrict His Theophany]

Know that Allah is manifesting (متجل) perpetually; times do not restrict His Theophany (تجلي). The veils are only lifted from our sights. The Exalted says: <<فَكَشَفْنَا عَنكَ غِطَاءَكَ>> (We have removed from you your cover). And He says: <<وَنَحْنُ أَقْرَبُ إِلَيْهِ مِنْكُمْ وَلَكِن لَّا تُبْصِرُونَ>> (And We are nearer to him than you, but you do not see), referring to the dying person (*al-muḥtaḍir*). Abraham the Intimate Friend said: <<لَا أُحِبُّ الْآفِلِينَ>> (I do not love those that set). He undoubtedly loves Allah, so Allah is not one who sets. His Theophany (تجلي) is perpetual, and His drawing near (*tadlīh*) is necessary. The difference between this and that is that you are asleep today. Thus, there is no prohibition for one whose witnessed object (*mashhad*) is The Real (الحق). This is why remembrance of Allah (*dhikr*), sitting before Him awaiting prayer, and supplication are not prohibited in that state. Only prostration (*sujūd*) is specifically prohibited because the disbelievers prostrate to [the sun] at that time.

### [It is Impossible for the Effect of Disbelief to Be Stronger Than the Effect of Faith]

Here is an alert to an intelligible secret: it is impossible for the effect of disbelief (*kufr*) to be stronger than the effect of faith (*īmān*), either in our view or theirs, such that it prevents the manifestation of faith and its ruling. This appears in the matter of the disbelievers' prostration to the sun, which is disbelief, preventing the believer from prostrating to Allah, and the prohibitor substituting strength for it. Know that the matter in this is subtle, concealed by Allah except from the Gnostics (*al-Ārifūn*). By this prohibition, Allah preserved for the disbelievers a certain Divine right. To that extent, the prohibition occurred, and strength appeared in the ruling by preventing the believer from prostrating at that time due to the disbelievers' prostration to the sun. This is because Allah says: <<وَقَضَىٰ رَبُّكَ أَلَّا تَعْبُدُوا إِلَّا إِيَّاهُ>> (And your Lord has decreed that you worship none but Him). And this is what they did, for they only worshipped the sun because they imagined it to be a deity. Thus, they only prostrated to Allah, not to the essence of the sun, but to the essence of their judgment concerning it, that it was Allah. One of their scholars hosted me, and I discussed with him their worship of the sun and their prostration to it. He said to me, "There is nothing there except Allah. And this sun is the closest thing related to Allah because of the light and benefits Allah placed in it. We magnify it because Allah magnified it by what He placed in it." Then we return and say: Since The Real (الحق) knew that they worshipped none but Him, even if they erred in the relation, and the believer worships none but Allah, the disbeliever resembled the believer in his faith in Allah. Thus, the matter was like the Divine Law (*Shar’*) abrogating parts of itself. So, disbelief did not affect faith here, nor was it stronger than it. Rather, since the matter was as we mentioned—that the disbeliever, in his belief in the Deity, possessed a truth, but in relating divinity to the sun, he was a disbeliever—The Real (الحق) observed the meaning they intended. From that perspective, the specification of prostration was established for them, excluding the believers, and the abrogation of the believers' prostration to Allah at that time occurred. Thus, it is an effect of faith upon faith, not an effect of disbelief upon faith.

(Chapter on Circumambulation Without Ritual Purity)

Some say that *Tawāf* without ritual purity (*ṭahāra*) is not permissible, neither intentionally nor forgetfully. Others say it is sufficient, but it is recommended for him to repeat it, and he owes a compensatory sacrifice (*dam*), because they agreed that purity is among the *Sunan* of *Tawāf*. Others say that if he circumambulates without ablution (*wuḍū’*), his *Tawāf* is sufficient if he did not know, but insufficient if he knew. Some stipulate the purity of the garment for the circumambulator, just as they stipulate it for the worshipper. What I maintain is that *Tawāf* is permissible without ablution for both men and women, unless the woman is menstruating, in which case she should not circumambulate. If she does, it is insufficient, and she is disobedient, due to the explicit text (*naṣṣ*) regarding that. No law concerning purity for *Tawāf* has been reported except what relates specifically to the menstruating woman. Not every act of worship requires this apparent purity.

### [There is Nothing in Existence, by the Ruling of Reality, Except What is Pure]

Know that there is no state in Existence (الوجود) in which Allah does not have a Face that preserves its existence. The purity of everything subsisting by itself is due to that Divine Face. Thus, there is nothing in Existence, by the ruling of Reality (الحقيقة), except what is pure (*ṭāhir*). For the Name *al-Quddūs* (The Holy) accompanies existing things, and by it, His saying is established: <<وَإِلَيْهِ يُرْجَعُ الْأَمْرُ كُلُّهُ فَاعْبُدْهُ وَتَوَكَّلْ عَلَيْهِ وَمَا رَبُّكَ بِغَافِلٍ عَمَّا تَعْمَلُونَ>> (And to Him all matters are returned, so worship Him and rely upon Him. And your Lord is not unaware of what you do)—[referring to] your distinguishing between Allah and His servants. It is not fitting that a barrier be placed between the servant and his Master, nor should anyone intervene between the servant and the Master except with goodness. I met one of the travelers (*suyyāḥ*) on the seashore between Marsā Laqīṭ and the Lighthouse. He told me, "I met one of the Substitutes (*al-Abdāl*) by chance in this place, and he was walking upon the waves of the sea. I greeted him, and he returned the greeting. There was great oppression and injustice in the land, so I said to him, 'O man, do you not see the injustice in the land?' He looked at me angrily and said, 'What concern is that of yours with the servants of Allah? Speak nothing but good.'" This is why Allah legislated intercession (*shafā’a*) and accepted excuses. There is no doubt that impurity (*najāsa*) is an accidental matter specified by a legal ruling, while purity (*ṭahāra*) is an essential matter (*amr dhātī*). If the ruling of the accident manifests at a certain time, such as the prohibition of *Tawāf* due to menstruation, the ultimate reference is to the purity required by the Essence (الذات).

### [The Leadership of the Transgressor is Not Permissible While He is in a State of Transgression]

Does the believer lie? He said, "No, [this is] sound information, for the liar cannot be truthful in that wherein he is lying, so understand." And menstruation (الحيض) is, by consensus, the lying of the soul (النفس). The circumambulation (الطواف) is a state of faith (إيمان), so the menstruating woman does not circumambulate. Just as we say concerning the imamate (إمامة) of the transgressor (الفاسق), that his leadership is not permissible during his state of transgression (فسقه) without dispute. For whoever was a transgressor in his state of transgression, then performed ritual ablution (توضأ) according to the Law (شرعا) and entered the state of consecration (أحرم) for prayer as an Imam, he is in obedience (طاعة) to Allah, and it is not permissible for us to call him a transgressor (فاسقا) in that state. Thus, we have not prayed behind a transgressor Imam. And likewise is the action of Abdullah ibn Umar, which they use as proof for praying behind a transgressor, but they erred, for Al-Hajjaj is not a transgressor (فاسق) while performing the obedience (طاعته) in prayer that Allah has made obligatory upon him.

### [There is no disobedience (معصية) for the believer except that faith (إيمان) accompanies it]

This is an issue that the jurists (الفقهاء) have neglected and in which they flounder, achieving nothing of substance. We have already shown that no act of disobedience (معصية) ever issues from a believer that is not fundamentally mixed with obedience (طاعة). Whereas obedience may be pure and not mixed with disobedience. For there is no disobedience except that faith accompanies it from the believer—[faith] that it is an act of disobedience forbidden for him to commit. And the belief (الإيمان) that it is disobedience is itself obedience to Allah. Thus, Al-Hajjaj or anyone else, in his state of transgression (فسقه), is a believer (مؤمن) who is obedient through his faith, so his disobedience is too weak to resist his obedience. And in the state of his prayer or his obedience in performing any of his acts, he is not a transgressor (فاسق); rather, he is obedient. So, he whose heart Allah has sealed prefers transgression (الفسق) over faith and obedience, despite the weakness of the transgression compared to the obedience, due to the faith mixed within it that the act is transgression (فسوقا). So they said, "The imamate of the transgressor is not permissible," but not according to the meaning we have mentioned. If the Messenger of Allah (may Allah bless him and grant him peace) or Allah Almighty had said it, the correct interpretation would be what we have stated. The utmost degree of the Muslim transgressor in his state of transgression is that he is one of those who <<mixed a righteous deed with another that was bad.>> And in his state of obedience, he is not a transgressor.

### [We are commanded to have good opinion (حسن الظن) of people]

The most astonishing thing about this issue is that we are commanded to have a good opinion (حسن الظن) of people and forbidden from having a bad opinion (سوء الظن) of My servants. We have seen someone whom we know committed transgression (فسق) perform ablution and pray. Why then do we pronounce the name of transgression (الفسوق) upon him during his worship? Where is the good opinion compared to the bad opinion of him? We have no knowledge of his future, and we do not know what Allah did concerning his past. The judgment belongs to the time of obedience in which he is engaged. Therefore, good opinion is more appropriate for the servant, if there must be interference [in judgment]. Indeed, someone whose religion I trust informed me about a jurist (فقيه), an Imam, a theologian (متكلم), who was excessive against his own soul. He told me: "I entered a gathering where wine was being circulated, and he was drinking with the group. When the wine ran out, he was told, 'Send someone to so-and-so to bring us more wine.' He replied, 'I will not do that, for I have never insisted upon an act of disobedience (معصية). I have repentance (توبة) between the two cups, and I will not wait for it. When [the next cup] is in my hand, I will see whether my Lord grants me success (يوفقني) to leave it, or abandons me (يخذلني) so I drink it.'" Such are the scholars, may Allah have mercy on him. This scholar died with regret in his heart that he had not met me, though I had met him, and he did not recognize me, but he asked about me and longed for me, may Allah have mercy on him. That was in Murcia in the year 595 AH.

### [The good deed (الحسنة) is multiplied tenfold up to seven hundred times, and the bad deed (السيئة) is equal to it]

The Real (الحق) made me witness in my secret heart (سرى) during a spiritual event (واقعة), and He said to me: "Inform My servants of the generosity (كرمي) I have shown to the believer: the good deed (الحسنة) is multiplied tenfold up to seven hundred times, and the bad deed (السيئة) is equal to it." And the act of the bad deed cannot withstand the faith (الإيمان) that it is a bad deed. Why then do My servants despair of My Mercy? <<And My Mercy encompasses all things.>> And I am as My servant thinks of Me, so let him think good of Me.

(Section concerning the chapter on the number of circumambulations (الطواف), which are three: Arrival, Overflowing, and Farewell)

### [The symbol/mystery (رمز) of the number of circumambulations]

The Circumambulation of Arrival (طواف القدوم) corresponds to the Circumambulation of Farewell (طواف الوداع); thus, it is like the Name, the First and the Last. <<Indeed, the example of Jesus in the sight of Allah is like the example of Adam.>> And the cycle of dominion (الملك) is completed. And the Circumambulation of Overflowing (طواف الإفاضة) is <<a Barzakh (Isthmus) between them; they do not transgress. So which of the favors of your Lord would you deny?>> From the Circumambulation of Arrival emerges the pearl of gnosis (لؤلؤ المعارف) in the rites (المناسك), and from the Circumambulation of Farewell emerges <<the coral. So which of the favors of your Lord would you deny?>> The Circumambulation of Visit (طواف الزيارة) has a face toward the Circumambulation of Arrival, so it may suffice for it, and a face toward the Circumambulation of Farewell, so it may suffice for it. And the scholars have stated both opinions, and mention of this will come in this chapter, if Allah wills.

### [The secrets (أسرار) of the number of circumambulations]

The consideration (الاعتبار) regarding the circumambulation and what arises from it has already been presented. The circumambulation of the arrival is like the Intellect (العقل) when it approaches Allah seeking benefit (الاستفادة), and the circumambulation of farewell is when it desires to go out to the soul (النفس) to give benefit (الإفادة). Like the Messenger (may Allah bless him and grant him peace) approaching the Trustworthy Spirit [Gabriel] when he conveys the Divine Revelation (الوحي الإلهي) to him, and then the Messenger conveys [the message] to creation (الخلق) upon the departure of the Spirit, in order to deliver the message. Thus, the Messenger is between the circumambulation of arrival and farewell, and between them is the circumambulation of visit. There are three circumambulations because, as we established, the manifestation of sciences (العلوم) only occurs through three levels (مراتب), whether intellectual (فكرية) or gifted (وهبية). We have shown you that the Barzakh (البرزخ) is always the strongest in judgment because it combines both extremes. Thus, it can take any form it wishes, stand in the judgment of either extreme it desires, and suffice for both. Therefore, it possesses complete power (الاقتدار التام), and the secret of what we have said becomes apparent in the ruling of the exoteric Law (ظاهر الشرع) concerning it.

### [Rulings (أحكام) concerning the number of circumambulations]

Among these [rulings] is that they have agreed that the obligatory circumambulation (الواجب) among these three, the omission of which invalidates the Hajj, is the Circumambulation of Overflowing (طواف الإفاضة). For if the one who has attained gnosis (المعرف) arrives in Mecca after the stoning (الرمي) and the Circumambulation of Overflowing, it suffices him for the Circumambulation of Arrival, and his Hajj is valid. And if the one departing circumambulates, believing it to be the Circumambulation of Farewell, but has not performed the Circumambulation of Overflowing, that circumambulation becomes the Circumambulation of Overflowing and suffices for the Circumambulation of Farewell. This is because it is a circumambulation of the House performed during the time of the obligatory circumambulation, which is the Overflowing. So Allah accepts it as the Circumambulation of Overflowing and it suffices for the Circumambulation of Farewell, just as we mentioned concerning one who fasts voluntarily during Ramadan, the obligation of Ramadan converts it into an obligatory fast due to the ruling of the time, and the intention (النية) does not affect it. The majority of scholars hold that the Circumambulation of Arrival in Mecca does not suffice for the Circumambulation of Overflowing. It is as if they saw that the obligatory act is only one circumambulation. Some said they agreed that the Circumambulations of Arrival and Farewell are part of the Sunnah (سنة) of the pilgrim, except for one who fears missing the Hajj, in which case the Circumambulation of Overflowing suffices for him. Some scholars recommended that whoever considers the Circumambulation of Overflowing sufficient for the Circumambulation of Arrival should perform the quick pace (رمل) during it. As for the Meccan, he has only one circumambulation. As for the one performing *Tamattu'* (المتمتع), if he is not performing *Qiran* (قارنا), he has two circumambulations. If he is performing *Qiran*, he has one circumambulation—this is my view. Others say the *Qarin* has two circumambulations. End of the Sixty-Seventh Part.

(In the Name of Allah, the Most Compassionate, the Most Merciful)
(Section concerning the chapter on the ruling of the running/Sa'y)

Some say it is obligatory (واجب); if one does not perform the running (السعي), his Hajj is invalid. Others say it is Sunnah; if he returns to his country without performing the running, he owes a sacrifice (دم). And others say it is voluntary (تطوع), and there is nothing upon the one who omits it.

### [Perfection (الكمال) is not restricted to women, and they have a foundation in the Law (التشريع)]

Since perfection (الكمال) is not restricted to women, even if the woman is of a lesser degree than the man—that is the degree of origination (الإيجاد) because she originated from him—this does not detract from perfection. For the man, Adam, his relation to that from which he was created, which is dust (التراب), is the same as the relation of Eve to him. And this earthy relation did not prevent Adam from the perfection (الكمال) that was witnessed for him. The Messenger of Allah (may Allah bless him and grant him peace) testified to the perfection of Mary and Asiya. When Allah considered this in woman, He established a foundation for her in the Law (التشريع) from a place she did not intend. Hagar, the mother of Ishmael (peace be upon him), ran between Safa and Marwa and hurried in the valley floor seven times, looking for someone approaching, seeking water because of the thirst that afflicted her son Ishmael, fearing his destruction. The narration is well-known. So Allah made it—meaning, He made Hagar's act of running (السعي) between Safa and Marwa—and established it legally as one of the rites (مناسك) of Hajj.

### [The psychic thoughts (الخواطر النفسية) when they influence compassion and effort on behalf of others]

Whoever considers it obligatory (واجب) magnifies its sanctity (الحرمة) and does not believe the Hajj is valid if it is omitted. Likewise, when psychic thoughts (الخواطر النفسية) influence compassion (الشفقة) and effort (السعي) on behalf of others, they effect acceptance in the Divine Presence (الجناب الإلهي). Thus He said: <<O tranquil soul (النفس المطمئنة), return to your Lord,>> the One from whom you departed to manage this body through the Divine Breath (النفخ الإلهي). For returning (الرجوع) only occurs to a state from which one departed; otherwise, it is not a return. He did not say to it, "Approach," but rather, "Return." And the matter must be so, for their return is their perfection (كمالها).

### [The running (السعي) during the Overflowing (الإفاضة) from Arafat must be with tranquility (السكينة) and solemnity (الوقار)]

When Allah Almighty said: <<O you who have believed, when [the adhan] is called for the prayer on the day of Friday, then proceed (فَاسْعَوْا) to the remembrance of Allah,>> the running (السعي) became obligatory due to the call of the Real (الحق) through an intermediary. How much more so when the Real called His servants in His Book revealed to us, saying: <<And [due] to Allah from the people is a pilgrimage (حج) to the House,>> so the running became obligatory. However, the Law (الشريعة) that Allah legislated for the running to the Friday prayer is that it must be with tranquility (السكينة) and solemnity (الوقار), just like the running during the Overflowing (الإفاضة) from Arafat to Muzdalifah, which is done with tranquility.

For the Prophet (may Allah bless him and grant him peace) used to say to the people when he saw them rushing during the Overflowing from Arafat, which is the station (موقف) of attaining Gnosis (المعرفة) of Allah. When they overflowed by His command to Muzdalifah, which is the station of proximity (القربة) and gathering with the Known (المعروف) therein—which is a special Theophany (تجلي خاص) from Him to the hearts of His servants, and for this reason it is called *Jam'* (Gathering) and *Muzdalifah* (from *Zulfa*, meaning proximity)—the Messenger of Allah said to them, "Tranquility! Tranquility!"

He said concerning the running to the Friday prayer: "Do not come to it while you are running," meaning rushing in your running, "but come to it, and upon you is tranquility (السكينة) in your running and solemnity (الوقار)." Thus, *Jumu'ah* (Friday) and *Jam'* (Muzdalifah) met in this reality of gathering (الحقيقة الجمعية) with Him Almighty in both stations. And His saying, "and solemnity (الوقار)," means running with stillness and the measured pace of the burdened person, because *waqar* (وقر) is from *wiqr* (وقر), meaning heaviness/burden. For Gnosis (المعرفة) of Allah grants that. Whoever knows Him witnesses Him, and whoever witnesses Him is not absent. So, if He calls him from one station to another, he only hastens for His sake, and he is witnessing Him, for it is through Him that he runs. Thus, he walks with the measured pace of the burdened person. This is the meaning of solemnity (الوقار), for stillness in things only arises from awe (هيبة) and veneration (تعظيم), not from exhaustion and fatigue, since running by Allah (السعي بالله) contains neither fatigue nor hardship.

(Section concerning the chapter on the description of the running/Sa'y)

The majority of scholars of the Law (الشريعة) said that it is part of the Sunnah of the running between Safa and Marwa that one supplicates when ascending Safa, facing the House, then descends. When he reaches the green marker (الميل الأخضر), which is the valley floor, he runs quickly (رمل) until he reaches the second green marker. That was the boundary for ascending Marwa and the boundary of the valley's width. Today, however, it has been filled in by what the floods brought. For this reason, those who established the two markers made them a sign for the valley floor, to mark the boundary of the quick pace legislated in the running. Then he runs without rushing when he passes the second marker, in the manner he descended from Safa. When he reaches Marwa, he does on Marwa what he did on Safa. Then he returns, seeking Safa from Marwa, and his state is like the first state in quick pacing and calmness, until he completes seven times.

### [Starting the running with Safa because Allah gave it importance in the Remembrance (الذكر)]

He only begins with Safa because Allah gave it importance in the Remembrance (الذكر) and began with it. The Messenger of Allah (may Allah bless him and grant him peace) said, "Begin with what Allah began with." So he began with Safa, recited the verse, then supplicated afterward, and concluded with Marwa. Since the first is the counterpart of the last, and their ruling is equal, he concluded with it because the seven are completed by it. This is because the corresponding thing is on the line of equality with its counterpart, just as the Prophet (may Allah bless him and grant him peace) said, "Do not face the Qibla, nor turn your backs to it." Because facing something and turning one's back to it are on a single line. Likewise, when Iblis was silent regarding approaching the servant for temptation from above (الفوقية), he was silent regarding below (التحت), because it is on the line of equality with above. Because, may Allah curse him, he saw the descent of the Lights (الأنوار) upon the servant from above, so he feared being burned and did not expose himself to the above in his approach. And he saw the below on the line of equality with the above, and that the Light connects to the below due to this equality, so he did not come from below, and the reason is the same. Ata' said that if one ignorantly begins with Marwa, it suffices him. Others said that if one begins with Marwa, that circuit is cancelled. We have already mentioned in the preceding Hadith of Jabir what the Prophet (may Allah bless him and grant him peace) used to supplicate with when ascending Safa and Marwa.

### [The consideration (اعتبار) of Isaf and Na'ilah]

Isaf was upon Safa and Na'ilah was upon Marwa, so the runner (الساعي) between Safa and Marwa should not neglect them. When he ascends Safa, he considers its name, which is derived from *al-asaf* (الأسف), meaning sorrow, which is his sorrow over what he missed by neglecting the rights of Allah Almighty upon him. For this reason, he faces the House with supplication and remembrance (الذكر), so that this reminds him and sorrow appears upon him. When he reaches Marwa, which is the place of Na'ilah, he takes it from *al-nayl* (النيل), meaning the gift or attainment, thus achieving the attainment (*Na'ilah*) of the sorrow (*Asaf*), meaning his reward (أجره). He does this in the seven circuits because Allah favored him with seven Attributes (صفات) so that he might act through them and direct them toward fulfilling the rights of Allah, not wasting anything of them. Thus, he sorrows over that, and Allah grants him his reward by considering Na'ilah at Marwa until he finishes.

### [The valley floors (بطون الأودية) are the dwellings of the devils (الشياطين)]

Then he runs quickly (يرمل) between the two markers, which is the valley floor. The valley floors are the dwellings of the devils (الشياطين), and for this reason, prayer is disliked in them. It is reported from the Prophet (may Allah bless him and grant him peace) that when he slept in the valley floor past the time for the Dawn Prayer, he said, "Ascend, for it is a valley in which there is a devil." For therein they are afflicted by temptation (الفتنة). So he runs quickly in the valley floor to swiftly escape the satanic quality (الصفة الشيطانية) and to be free from its company, since it is its abode. Just as one does in the valley floor of Muhassir in Mina, where one hastens to leave it because it is a valley from the valleys of the Fire (النار) from which the devil was created. Likewise, the hastening in the valley floor of Urana, which is the valley of Arafat, and it is the place where Iblis stands on the Day of Arafat, due to what Allah described him with on that day: humiliation (الذلة), abasement (الصغار), and weeping, because of what he sees of Allah's Mercy, His pardon, and the removal of the sins of His servants who are pilgrims.

### [The runner (الساعي) between Safa and Marwa is from Allah, to Allah, with Allah, by Allah]

Furthermore, the running (السعي) in this place combines the three states: descent (الانحدار), ascent (الترقي), and equilibrium (الاستواء). There is no fourth, so he attains the degree of perfection (الكمال) in this worship. That place grants this, and in every state, he is a traveler (سالك): his descent is to Allah, his ascent is to Allah, and his equilibrium is with Allah. And in all of that, he is *by Allah* (بالله), because it is by the command of Allah, *in Allah* (في الله). Thus, the runner between Safa and Marwa is from Allah, to Allah, with Allah, by Allah, in Allah, by the command of Allah. So, in every state, he is with Allah, for Allah.

### [There is nothing higher in the human than the mineral quality (الصفة الجمادية)]

Safa and Marwa possess a mineral quality (صفة جمادية) appropriate to the stones (الحجارة) whose arrangement manifested the specific form of the House. For by that form, they gave the name of the House, and without that, the name of the House would not exist. We have shown you that minerals (الجمادات) are more knowledgeable of Allah and more devoted in worship to Allah than all other generated things (المولدات). They were created in gnosis (المعرفة); they have no intellect (عقل), no desire (شهوة), and no self-direction, except if they are directed. They are directed by others, not by themselves, and there is no Director but Allah, so they are directed by the direction of Allah. Although plants (النبات) were created in gnosis like them, the plant descends from the mineral's degree through growth (النمو) and seeking elevation by itself, as it belongs to those that seek nourishment. It grants growth and the seeking of height, but the mineral is not like that. It does not possess height in its natural movement, but if it is raised to height and left to its nature, it seeks the low, which is the reality of servitude (العبودية). And height (العلو) is a Divine Attribute (نعت إلهي), for He is the Exalted (العلي). Thus, the stone flees from competing with Lordship (الربوبية) in height, so it descends out of awe (خشية) of Allah. Allah informed us of this, saying, when mentioning the stones: <<And indeed, among them are those that fall down from fear (خشية) of Allah.>> So He made the natural descent arise from awe (خشية). Thus, it originates from awe of Allah, and the witnessing (الشهود) of Him is intrinsic. <<Only those fear (يخشى) Allah, from among His servants, who have knowledge (العلماء) [of Him].>> So whoever fears has known the One he fears. This is the doctrine of Sahl ibn Abdullah al-Tustari. Therefore, there is nothing higher in the human than the mineral quality (الصفة الجمادية), then the vegetative, then the animal, which has greater directionality (تصريف) than the plant, and then the human who claimed divinity (الألوهة). To the extent that he rose above the degree of the mineral, he acquired a Divine Form (صورة إلهية) from that elevation, by which he departed from his origin. The stones are verified servants (عبيد محققون) who have not departed from their origins in their creation.

### [Stones (الأحجار) are the place for the manifestation of waters, which are the sources of life]

Furthermore, Allah made these stones the place for the manifestation of waters, which are the origin of life for every living thing in the natural world (العالم الطبيعي), and they are the sources of life. And by Knowledge (العلم), the human who is dead by ignorance is brought to life. Thus, the stones combine awe (الخشية) and the gushing forth of rivers from them, linking Knowledge and Life. Allah Almighty said: <<And indeed, there are stones from which rivers burst forth,>> despite their characteristic hardness (القساوة). This is due to their strength in the station of servitude (مقام العبودية). They do not waver from their essence (ذاتها) because they do not love to leave their abode, due to the Knowledge (العلم) and Life (الحياة) they possess therein, which are among the noblest Attributes (الصفات).

### [What the runner (الساعي) attains from Safa to Marwa]

Thus, the runner (الساعي) attains from Safa to Marwa—which are stones—what the reality of stones grants: awe (الخشية), life (الحياة), gnosis (العلم بالله), and steadfastness (الثبات) in that station of theirs. So, whoever runs and finds such qualities in himself during his running has truly run and achieved the result of his running. He departs from his place of running with a heart alive by Allah, possessing awe of Allah, knowing his own worth and what belongs to him and to Allah. If he is not like that, then he has not truly run between Safa and Marwa.

(Section concerning the chapter on its conditions)

The scholars agreed that one of its conditions is purity from menstruation (الحيض). As for purity from ritual impurity (الحدث), all of them said that purity from ritual impurity is not a condition, except for Al-Hasan.

### [Were it not for the servant's ritual impurity (حدث), his servitude (عبوديته) would not be valid]

Know that, based on what we established in the chapter on the running and the consideration of stones in the ruling of Safa and Marwa, they agreed that purity from ritual impurity (الحدث) is not a condition for this rite (النسك). This is because he is a pure servant (عبد محض) in it, and this servitude (العبودة) is only valid for him through his ritual impurity. Were it not for his ritual impurity, his servitude would not be valid. If he purifies himself from his ritual impurity, he departs from his reality (حقيقته) and claims participation in Lordship (الربوبية) to the extent of his departure. If the purification is general, like the major ablution (الغسل), it distances him further from his reality. If it is a specific purification, like the minor ablution (الوضوء), it is closer. And adopting what is appropriate is more complete in the Realities (الحقائق).

### [Every living existent (موجود حي) must have an act attributed to it]

As for those who hold purification (الطهارة) is necessary for this rite, they say that every living existent must have an act attributed to it, in whatever manner. No created thing (محدث) that remains upon its origin is more complete than stones. Yet, Allah described them with awe (الخشية), which is an act attributed to them—meaning, it is said they fear. Therefore, one should purify oneself from this attribution, not from the awe itself, so that the awe of Allah remains within it. Likewise, splitting (التشقق) is attributed to them due to the emergence of waters. Thus, purification from these attributions is necessary. For this reason, Al-Hasan inclined toward stipulating purity in this rite, and it is *hasan* (good), like his name—meaning, it is a good doctrine. For the Prophet (may Allah bless him and grant him peace) disliked mentioning Allah except in a state of purity (طهر) or, as he said, purification (طهارة). And the running necessarily involves the remembrance of Allah (ذكر الله). Thus, the opinion of purity is more appropriate. Al-Hasan, in our view, is one of the Imams of the Path of Allah (طريق الله), majestic is His glory, and one of the People of Secrets and Allusions (أهل الأسرار والإشارات).

(Section concerning the chapter on its sequence)

The scholars agreed that the running (السعي) only occurs after the circumambulation (الطواف) of the House, and that whoever runs before the circumambulation must return and circumambulate, even if he has left Mecca. If he was ignorant of this until he had intercourse with women during the Umrah or Hajj, he must perform Hajj the following year and offer a sacrifice (الهدى), or perform another Umrah. Some said there is nothing upon him. Others said that if he leaves Mecca, he is not required to return, but he owes a sacrifice (دم). This is the view I hold.

### [The servitude (عبودية) of necessity (الاضطرار) and fulfilling its station]

Know that when Allah called us, He only called us to intend the House. Therefore, when we reach it, we should not begin with anything other than what He called us to, nor do anything until we circumambulate it. When we intend it with the quality He commanded us, then we act afterward according to what was prescribed for us in the rest of the rites (المناسك), if we are servants of necessity (عبيد اضطرار) and fulfill our station of servitude (العبودية). This is what the Legislator (المشرع), may Allah bless him and grant him peace, did, who said to us: "Take your rites from me." And Allah said: <<There has certainly been for you in the Messenger of Allah an excellent pattern.>> And He said: <<Say, [O Muhammad], 'If you should love Allah, then follow me, [so] Allah will love you.'>> And He said: "Whoever turns away from my Sunnah is not of me." Thus, by his action (may Allah bless him and grant him peace), he made clear Allah's intent for us in this worship. This is the verification (التحقيق).

### [Presumption (الإدلال) is a departure from abasement (الإذلال)]

If the servant expands into presumption (*idalal* with the hard *dal*), which in our view is a departure from abasement (*idhlal* with the dotted *dhal*) derived from lowliness (*dhilla*), because Allah created him upon the Form (الصورة), and this Form necessitates might (*izza*), he desires to have choice (اختيار) in the act. By this will, he was charged [with responsibility] so that his manifestation through the Form would be valid when he chooses, because it is known that the Form must have a ruling in some station. So he performed the running (السعي) first and said: "Even if He called us to His House, we must reach it and circumambulate it. He did not restrict us from passing by anything other than the House on our way. If He had restricted us, we would have stopped at His restriction. His silence on this indicates that He gave us a choice, since circumambulation of the House is necessary because He commanded us with it, saying: <<And let them circumambulate the Ancient House.>>" Thus, we made the ruling regarding the precedence of the running due to our creation upon the Form (الصورة), so that it may have the ruling of choice (الاختيار) and testing (الاختبار), fulfilling and observing its station. For He says of Himself: <<And your Lord creates what He wills and chooses.>> And since we are upon the Form, this reality must have an effect. Despite this, it is more appropriate that we direct the choice of the Form away from this station, due to the preceding clarification by the Legislator, who is the verified servant (العبد المحقق), Muhammad (may Allah bless him and grant him peace). He did not precede the circumambulation with the running, nor Marwa with Safa in the running. And Allah said: <<There has certainly been for you in the Messenger of Allah an excellent pattern for anyone whose hope is in Allah and the Last Day... And whoever turns away—then indeed, Allah is the Free of need, the Praiseworthy (الحميد).>> He did not condemn, out of courtesy to us so that we may learn, but rather exalted Himself by being Free of need (الغنى) of what He called them to, and that if they respond to it, the good contained therein returns to them, and Allah is Free of need of it. By this, a concession (رخصة) was found for the one who performed the running first, followed by [the mention of] the Praiseworthy (الحميد)—meaning, He is worthy of praise in the first and the last, so praise belongs to Him in every state. Whether you, O seeker, acted by the Form and chose due to the power the Form grants, or you acted as a servant compelled by necessity (مضطرا), praise belongs to Allah in all of that. Allah says through the state: "Were it not for My Form, you would not have chosen, nor would you have been a chooser. My Form is the one that had the choice, not you." This is establishing an excuse for the servant, and this is from Allah's generosity, so there is no blame. For this reason, He did not attach condemnation to it, nor did He mention it in the context of failing to follow and emulate His Messenger (may Allah bless him and grant him peace), for He did not restrict, as we said. This is a strange Divine notification (تنبيه) in this context, where He neither condemned nor praised, but left it unspoken.

(Section concerning the chapter on what the pilgrim does on the Day of Tarwiyah if his route passes through Mina)

The Day of Tarwiyah (يوم التروية) is the day of departure to Mina, the eighth day of Dhu al-Hijjah, and spending the night there. One prays the Dhuhr, Asr, Maghrib, Isha, and Fajr of the ninth day—the Day of Arafat—there, in emulation of the Messenger of Allah (may Allah bless him and grant him peace). The scholars agreed that this is not a condition for the validity of the Hajj. When the morning of Arafat arrives, he proceeds to Arafat and stands there.

### [The pilgrim between the knowledge (علم) of the Sanctuary (الحرم) and the gnosis (معرفة) of the Non-Sanctuary (الحل)]

When the pilgrim reached the House and attained the Knowledge (العلم بالله) he attained, and attained through the pledge (المبايعة) and shaking the Hand of Allah Almighty what the People of Allah (أهل الله) find therein, and acquired Divine Gnosis (المعارف الإلهية) through his circumambulation of the House, his running, and his prayers in Mina, Allah desired to distinguish for him between the Knowledge he acquired in the consecrated place (الموضع المحرم) and the Divine Gnosis (المعرفة الإلهية) that Allah grants him in the non-sanctuary (الحل), which is Arafat. For the gnosis of the non-sanctuary grants the removal of restriction from the servant, who is restricted during his state of consecration (إحرامه) because he is consecrated for Hajj. Thus, in Arafat, he combines his gnosis of Allah from the perspective of his being consecrated (محرم) and his gnosis of Allah from the perspective of his being in the non-sanctuary (الحل). Because the gnosis of Allah in the Sanctuary (الحرم) while he is consecrated is a gnosis appropriate to the counterpart, for by consecration he is restricted, and by the Sanctuary he is restricted. This is contrary to the ruling of Arafat, for he is consecrated in a non-sanctuary. Thus, in Arafat, the appropriateness is more distant and the difficulty is greater, because it is the confrontation of opposites and distinction. For the non-sanctuary was not consecrated by the pilgrim's consecration, nor was the pilgrim released from consecration by the non-sanctuary status of the place. Neither affected the other. The servant is distinguished by restriction due to his remaining in his state of consecration, having nothing of the chosen Real (الحق المختار). The Real is distinguished by the non-sanctuary status, meaning He is not restricted. He does what He wills, according to what imagination (الوهم) conjectures, based on the evidence of the intellect (العقل), that the Real judges the act based on His prior knowledge of it, and it does not change. This is the opposite of choice (الاختيار). Thus, He resembles the restricted one. In Arafat, in the non-sanctuary, he attains the gnosis that removes this restriction established by imagination based on the evidence of the intellect. For in this station of Knowledge of Allah, imagination equaled the intellect, and they restricted Allah, placing Him under the ruling of His Knowledge concerning the thing, according to the doctrine of those who hold that Knowledge (العلم) is an attribute (صفة) added to His Essence (ذاته), subsisting in Him, which rules over His Essence according to what it relates to. But whoever says that His Knowledge is His Essence (ذاته) is not bound by this. This is a subtle and wondrous gnosis (معرفة بالله) of Allah, whose value is known only by those who have attained it.

### [The Day of the Greater Hajj (الحج الأكبر) is the day of attaining the daytime command (الأمر النهارى) and the nighttime Theophany (التجلي الليلى)]

When the pilgrim desired to attain this gnosis, he passed through Mina on his way, which is the place of the Greater Hajj (الحج الأكبر). He wished to taste its flavor before the standing at Arafat, since his return is to it on the Day of Sacrifice (يوم النحر), which is the Day of the Greater Hajj. For in that first time, those who stood at Arafat and those who stood at Muzdalifah gather there, so the majority of pilgrims were in Mina. He prayed there and spent the night to taste that in the ruling of the day and the ruling of the night. Thus, he attains the daytime command (الأمر النهاري) and the nighttime Theophany (التجلي الليلي), and what occurs during the prayer times of the specific command in this station, so that when he returns to it after the standing, he may see whether the taste (الذوق) remains the same or if the state has changed due to the influence of Arafat and Muzdalifah upon him. Thus, his spending the night and staying in Mina was a state of choice (اختيار) and testing (تمحيص), so that he might have knowledge of the outcome. This is unlike the one who has attained gnosis (المعرف), for he does not attain that, so he does not know whether the ruling of Mina changes after Arafat from its ruling before Arafat or not. This was the reason for that.

(Section concerning the chapter on the Standing at Arafat)

As for the Standing at Arafat (الوقوف بعرفة), they agreed that it is a pillar (ركن) of the Hajj, and whoever misses it must perform Hajj the following year and offer a sacrifice (الهدى), according to most of them. We do not hold that a sacrifice is due for the one who misses it, for he is not performing *Tamattu'* (المتمتع), since he did not perform Hajj with his Umrah in the same year. The Sunnah on the Day of Arafat is to enter it before the sun declines (الزوال). When the sun declines, the Imam addresses the people, then combines the Dhuhr and Asr prayers at the beginning of the Dhuhr time, and then stands until the sun sets. This is what the Messenger of Allah (may Allah bless him and grant him peace) did.

### [The imamate (إمامة) of the Hajj belongs to the Greatest Sultan (السلطان الأعظم)]

The imamate of the Hajj belongs to the Greatest Sultan (السلطان الأعظم); there is no disagreement among them on this. And one prays behind him, whether he is righteous or wicked. We have already established that he is righteous during the time of his prayer. Thus, you have only prayed behind a righteous person, and your Imam was only righteous. Therefore, there is no benefit in discussing the wickedness and transgression (الفسق) mentioned by the scholars of external forms (علماء الرسوم) regarding this issue, and we have already discussed it.

### [It is from the Sunnah on the Day of Arafat that we come to the mosque with the Imam]

And it is from the Sunnah upon us on that day that we come to the mosque with the Imam for prayer. In this, one considers the walking *by Allah* (بالله), *with Allah* (مع الله), *to Allah* (إلى الله) in the House of Gnosis (بيت المعرفة), because it is a mosque in Arafat, and it is a mosque of servitude (مسجد عبودية). A mosque is only valid as a place of servitude, because prostration (السجود) is bending low, which is a descent from high to low. By this, the prostrator is named a prostrator, due to his descent from his standing position.

### [The mosque of Arafat is the House of Gnosis (المعرفة) of Allah and of the soul (النفس)]

The mosque of Arafat grants him gnosis of his own soul (نفسه), so that this becomes a ladder for him to the gnosis of his Lord, for <<Whoever knows his soul knows his Lord.>> The One to whom he prostrated, and Gnosis (المعرفة) seeks one single thing in its transitive nature: that is, the attachment of the servant's knowledge and gnosis specifically to the Oneness (أحدية) of Allah. If He had not said *Arafat* (from *arafa*, to know) but had said something else indicating knowledge, as *Arafat* indicates knowledge, we would not have made its attachment to Oneness (الأحدية), but would have made it attached to another matter.

### [In knowing his soul, the human seeks its duality (شفعيتها) from the perspective of its Oneness (أحديتها)]

We thus know that in knowing his soul, the human seeks its duality (شفعيتها) from the perspective of its Oneness (أحديتها), by which the gnosis of the Oneness of the Real (أحدية الحق) is distinguished, for the One is only known by that which is one. So, by your oneness in your duality, you knew His Oneness Almighty. Thus, [the place] came in the name of *Arafat* (Gnosis) for the purpose of intending the gnosis of the Oneness of the Creator (أحدية الخالق), because He has no oneness in relations other than the Essence (الذات) except the Oneness of the Creator, meaning the Originator. For this reason, He praised Himself with it and made it a criterion (فرقانا) between one who claimed divinity (الألوهية) or in whom it was claimed, saying: <<Then is He who creates like one who does not create? Then will you not remember?>> If participation in creation had occurred, it would not be valid for Him to take it as self-praise or as a proof, given the shared indication. This is invalid. Thus, it is known definitively that the Creator (الخالق) is an Attribute of Oneness (صفة أحدية) belonging to Allah alone, which is not valid for anyone else. Therefore, the gnosis of Allah in Arafat is a gnosis of Oneness (معرفة أحدية), since the gnosis of this is what He described in the language with which Allah addressed us. If you have known this, then you have attained gnosis.

(Section concerning the chapter on the Call to Prayer/Adhan)

Know that the scholars differed regarding the time for the caller (المؤذن) to give the call to prayer (أذان) for Dhuhr and Asr in Arafat. Some said the Imam delivers the sermon until a portion or most of it has passed, then the caller gives the call while he is delivering the sermon. Others said the call is given when he begins the second sermon. Others said that when the Imam ascends the pulpit, he commands the caller to give the call, so he gives it, like the Friday prayer (الجمعة). When the caller finishes, the Imam stands to deliver the sermon. I have seen the practice today follow this last opinion, which is the doctrine of Abu Hanifa. The first is the doctrine of Malik, and the second is said to be the doctrine of Al-Shafi'i. It is also reported from Malik that he said what Abu Hanifa said, as narrated by Ibn Nafi' from Malik. The Hadith states that the Prophet (may Allah bless him and grant him peace) delivered the sermon to the people, then Bilal gave the call, then the call to stand (إقام), and he combined Dhuhr and Asr without moving between them.

### [The reality of the Call to Prayer (الأذان) is notification (الإعلام), not remembrance (الذكر)]

The reality of the Call to Prayer (الأذان) is notification (الإعلام), not remembrance (الذكر). It may also be a notification by means of remembrance, for the sake of remembrance. Thus, all of it is remembrance, except for the two *Hay'alatayn* ("Hasten to the prayer," "Hasten to success"), for they are a call by command to a specific worship. Whoever observes the gathering (الجمع) within the essence of distinction (الفرق) made one call for them and two calls to stand (إقامتين). Whoever observes the distinction between Dhuhr and Asr applied the ruling of separation to the combination, thus holding two calls and two calls to stand. For this reason, the disagreement occurred. So some held two calls and two calls to stand, and others held one call and two calls to stand. Whoever observed the prayer placed the call after the sermon, and whoever observed the hearing of the sermon placed it before the sermon. Whoever observed its being the remembrance of Allah (ذكر الله) in the form of the call—like the one commanded to repeat what the caller says, on the basis that he is remembering Allah, not calling to prayer, for the one who repeats the caller is not called a caller, but rather a rememberer in the form of the call—this person holds the call should be during the sermon itself, and suffices with the contextual evidence that the people intending Arafat on that day have no occupation other than focusing on the acts required of them that day, including listening to the sermon and the prayer. This makes the call, which is notification, unnecessary, unless the intention is to notify those who are ignorant of the entry of the prayer time, in which case it is a call by means of remembrance.

### [The remembrance (ذكر) of those scholars of Allah who are granted success]

For remembrance (الذكر) on the Path of Allah (طريق الله) is not restricted to speech alone. Rather, the conduct of the servant, if he is granted success (التوفيق), in all his movements, is that he moves only in obedience to Allah Almighty, whether obligatory or recommended. This is called the remembrance of Allah (ذكر الله)—meaning, because his remembrance in that act is that it is for Allah, by way of proximity (القربة), it is called remembrance. Aisha said concerning the Messenger of Allah (may Allah bless him and grant him peace) that <<He used to remember Allah in all his states.>> This encompasses all his states, in wakefulness and sleep, movement and stillness. She meant that he did not act, nor was he in any state, except in a matter that brought him near to Allah, because he is the companion of those who remember Him. Thus, all acts of obedience, whether action or omission, if performed or omitted for the sake of Allah, are part of the remembrance of Allah—meaning, Allah is remembered therein, and for His sake they were performed or omitted, according to the ruling legislated for them. This is the remembrance of those scholars of Allah who are granted success.

### [The difference between the Friday Prayer (صلاة الجمعة) and the prayer in Arafat]

The scholars agreed that if the Imam does not deliver the sermon on the Day of Arafat before the prayer, his prayer is valid, unlike the Friday prayer. This is a difference between the Friday prayer and the prayer in Arafat. This is what the Prophet (may Allah bless him and grant him peace) did, and he only delivered the sermon before the prayer, just as they agreed that the recitation in this prayer is silent (سر), not audible (جهر), unlike the Friday prayer.

### [The preacher (الخطيب) on the Day of Arafat is the reminder of the Real (الحق) in the servant's heart]

The preacher (الخطيب) on this day is the reminder of the Real (الحق) in the servant's heart, and his admonisher, and his limbs are like the congregation present listening to that sermon. He encourages them to obey Allah and informs them that Allah only called them to this station to stand before Him as a reminder of the standing of people on the Day of Resurrection before the Lord of the Worlds. He informs them that Allah comes to them on this day, unlike His coming on the Day of Resurrection, for that coming is only for separation and judgment, and distinguishing groups from one another by their marks. But today, His coming to those standing in this station is a coming with forgiveness (مغفرة), mercy (رحمة), grace (فضل), and favor (إنعام). That Divine grace is attained on this day by those who are worthy of it—meaning, those consecrated for Hajj—and by those who are not worthy of it, who merely share in the standing and presence on that day but are not pilgrims. Their ruling is like the companion among a people whose companion is not wretched. Allah Almighty said to the angels concerning the people of the gatherings of remembrance (مجالس الذكر), regarding one who came for a need and not for remembrance: "They are the people whose companion is not wretched." Thus, Allah's forgiveness and pleasure encompassed them, and Allah multiplied for those consecrated, based on their worthiness for that station, what that worthiness deserves. All this and its like, the servant senses in his soul, just as the preacher should remind the people of such Divine grace, so that their worship on that day is gratitude to Allah Almighty, and they forget the dishevelment and fatigue they are in, compared to what they have attained from Allah.

### [The combined prayer of the Gnostics (العارفين) in Arafat]

Then they stand for prayer after finishing the sermon, and they pray in that station the prayer of one who is in Arafat, while they are disheveled, dusty, stripped of sewn garments, bareheaded, standing on their feet before a Mighty Lord. On that day, they pray the combined prayer (جمعا)—the prayer of the Gnostics (العارفين)—as we said:

> The prayer of the Gnostics has awe (خشوع),
> Lowliness, humility, and destitution (افتقار).
> And its performer is alone in witnessing (شهود),
> Upon him in his witnessing is necessity (اضطرار).

### [Inner remembrance (الذكر النفسي) is a notification of the rememberer's verification (تحقيق) by the Real (الحق)]

Since his state on this day is specific to him, between him and his Lord in his prayer, it is incumbent upon him that his recitation be silent (سرا), which is inner remembrance (الذكر النفسي), as a notification of his verification (تحققه) by the Real (الحق) in that station. For if he remembers Him in his soul—and the Quran is remembrance—the Real remembers him in His Essence (نفسه), without the servant perceiving that Allah has remembered him. For when Allah remembers him in His Essence, His remembrance is in an eternal Presence (حضرة أزلية) where there is no origination (حدوث). Thus, the servant gains a footing in eternity (الأزل) through this remembrance, as the Real makes him present in His Essence through remembrance. If He remembers him in a gathering, He remembers him in a Presence of origination (حضرة حدوث), and origination is the attribute of the servant. He only increases in rank by this by virtue of its being a specific remembrance. The station of Arafat is mighty, so the recitation therein during prayer was inner (نفسية) so that this rank might be attained on that day.

(Section concerning the chapter) If the Imam is a Meccan
