They differed as to whether he shortens the prayer (يقصر) or not, here, in Mina, and in Muzdalifah. Some said shortening is necessary in these places, whether he is a Meccan or not, and whether he is a resident of the place or not. Others said he only shortens if he is a traveler.

### [The secret (سر) of completing (الإتمام) and shortening (القصر) the prayer on the Day of Arafat]

Whoever observes the travel (السفر) intends to commune secretly (يناجي) with the Real Almighty in this prayer in the station of Oneness (مقام الوحدانية). He assigns to the Real the first *rak'ah* (ركعة) in which he communes with Him from the perspective of His Oneness (أحديته), and he assigns to himself the second *rak'ah* in which he communes with Him from the perspective of the servant's oneness (أحدية العبد), by which he knew the Oneness of the Real on the Day of Arafat, due to the transitive nature of this act toward a single matter. Whoever observes the completion (الإتمام) assigns two *rak'ahs* to the Real: the first from the perspective of His Essence (ذاته تعالى), and the second from the perspective of His being known to us through a specific relation (نسبة خاصة) that necessitates His being described as known to us, since He was previously not described as known, as we had no existence in our Fixed Entities (أعياننا), and thus there was no one to ask Him to be known by. And he assigns the other two *rak'ahs*: one for the essence (ذات) of the servant from the perspective of his entity (عينه), and the second from the perspective of his possibility (إمكانه), which grants him the need (الافتقار) for his preponderant cause (مرجحه) in his relation to Him. This is gnosis (معرفة) for the sake of proof and witnessing (المشاهدة), for witnessing is also a proof. Witnessing is a path leading to the Knowledge of the witnessed, and reflection (الفكر) is also a path leading to the Knowledge of Allah, from the perspective of the intellect's independence concerning Him, even if it does not witness. This is the secret of completing and shortening the prayer, due to what the place of Arafat grants of Gnosis of Allah in the prayer in this location.

(Section concerning the chapter on the Friday Prayer in Arafat)

The scholars differed regarding the obligation of the Friday prayer (الجمعة) and when it becomes obligatory. Some said the Friday prayer is not obligatory in Arafat. Others who held this view stipulated that for the Friday prayer to be obligatory, there must be forty men from the residents of Arafat. Others said that if the Amir of the Hajj is one who does not abandon prayer in Mina or Arafat, he leads them in the Friday prayer in both places if it coincides. Some said that if the governor of Mecca is present, he leads them in the combined prayer. What I hold is that he leads them in the combined prayer, whether he is a traveler or a resident, and whether they are many or few, provided the term "congregation" (جماعة) applies to them linguistically.

### [A spiritual event (واقعة) that occurred to Ibn Arabi on the night of writing this section of Al-Futuhat al-Makkiyya]

A spiritual event (واقعة) occurred to me on the night I wrote this section, and it is relevant to this chapter. I saw, in what the sleeper sees, a person from the angels handing me a piece of earth, tightly compacted, without dust, a span wide, a span long, and of infinite depth. When it came into my hand, I found it to be the saying of Allah Almighty: <<And wherever you are, turn your faces toward it [the Kaaba], so that the people will not have a case against you,>> up to His saying: <<And be grateful to Me and do not deny Me.>> I was astonished. I could neither deny that it was the very essence of these verses nor deny that it was a piece of earth. And it was said to me: "Thus was the Quran revealed," or "Thus was it revealed to Muhammad (may Allah bless him and grant him peace)." I saw the Messenger of Allah (may Allah bless him and grant him peace), and he said to me: "Thus was it revealed to me, so take it as a direct taste (ذوقا). This is the matter. Can you deny what you find of that?" I said, "No." I was perplexed by the matter until, due to the overwhelming nature of the state upon me, I said:

> There is nothing there but perplexity (حيرة) that encompassed
> My whole and my part, and it is from my totality.
> By Allah, there is no discourse there except
> This which my eye has witnessed.
> So I see none other than myself, yet it is not me,
> And that is His manifestation (مجلاه), and this is my totality.

Then I said: This is an unveiling (كشف) corresponding to the Friday prayer (الجمعة) that Gabriel (peace be upon him) brought to the Messenger of Allah (may Allah bless him and grant him peace) in the form of a polished mirror, containing a point (*nukta*), and he said to him: "O Messenger of Allah, this is the Friday prayer, and this point is the Hour (الساعة) within it." The Hadith is well-known. Look at the wondrous nature of Divine matters and their Theophany (تجليها) in sensory molds (القوالب الحسية). This is proof of the connection of the matter between us and the Real (الحق).

> The All is the Real, and the All is creation,
> And all that you witness is the Real.
> It contains the command from near,
> And it has no utterance in the tongue.
> And all of it is as you see it,
> And all of it in Existence (الوجود) is truth.

The supply of the comprehensive spiritual event has ended. Let us return and say: <<And Allah speaks the truth, and He guides to the way.>>

### [No existent (كون) was found except through an intelligible gathering (جمع معقول), nor did it manifest except as a composite of realities]

The Hajj is a Divine call: <<And proclaim to the people the Hajj.>> And the Friday prayer is a Divine call: <<When [the adhan] is called for the prayer on the day of Friday.>> Thus, the appropriateness occurred. The congregation (الجماعة) is present, so its establishment in Arafat is obligatory, and there is no way to abandon it, especially since the Realities (الحقائق) support this. No existent (كون) among the existents was found except through an intelligible gathering (جمع معقول), nor did an existent manifest in an entity (عين) except as a composite of realities (حقائق) that manifest that. The existence of a contingent thing (حادث) is not valid, legally or intellectually, and everything other than Allah is contingent, except through an Essence (ذات) possessing Will, Knowledge, Power, and Life, intellectually; and an Essence possessing Will and a commanding Word (قول أمري), legally.

### [The Oneness (أحدية) of the Level (المرتبة) is the Oneness of Multiplicity (الكثرة)]

Then the other aspect of the comprehensive nature (الجمعية) is that the contingent thing (الحادث) arises from Divine Power (اقتدار إلهي) and potential acceptance (قبول إمكاني). Both are necessary, and one of their conditions is the existence of Life, legally, when He says to the thing, "Be!" Thus, the comprehensive nature is established legally in the origination of existents, and it is established intellectually, as we determined. Thus, Unity (الوحدة) in origination, Existence (الوجود), and the existent is not intelligible or transmitted except in "There is no god but He." This is the Oneness of the Level (أحدية المرتبة), and it is the Oneness of Multiplicity (أحدية الكثرة), so understand. Therefore, when Oneness (الأحدية) is mentioned, it is not mentioned, intellectually or textually, except in relation to the Oneness of the Composite (أحدية المجموع)—a composite of relations (نسب) or Attributes (صفات), or whatever you wish, according to what your proof grants. And every relation or attribute has a oneness by which it is distinguished from others in reality. Whoever wishes to distinguish this for the listener or learner cannot do so except through a composite of realities, each reality being known to the listener. There is nothing more wondrous in the sciences than this knowledge, where Oneness is intelligible in every existent, yet the existence of a contingent existent is only valid through a composite of composites. This is a tremendous perplexity (حيرة عظيمة).

> The perplexity of the matter is perplexity,
> And it is jealousy (غيرة) in the other.

### [What is required of us is the unification (توحيد) of the God (الإله) specifically]

For this reason, the Real Almighty did not demand from us in faith (الإيمان) anything but the unification of the God (الإله) specifically: that you know that there is only <<One God (إِلَهٌ وَاحِدٌ); there is no god except Him.>> Then He said: <<The Most Compassionate, the Most Merciful.>> There was no gathering (جمع) that necessitated this ruling—that He be a God—except this One named by these Beautiful Names (الأسماء الحسنى) of differing meanings, which the possible existent (الممكن) needed for the existence of its entity (عينه).

### [The obligation of establishing the Friday prayer in Arafat at its time and with its condition]

If the matter is as we have established, then there is no obligation more incumbent than establishing the Friday prayer in Arafat when its time and condition arrive.

### [I know of no one more ignorant than him who said: Only one proceeds from the One]

I do not know of anyone more ignorant in the world than him who said, "Only one proceeds from the One," despite the proponent of this saying holding to causality (العلية). The intelligibility of a thing being a cause for something is contrary to the intelligibility of its thingness. And relations (النسب) are among the aspects of gathering (الجمع). How far is the proponent of this saying from the Realities (الحقائق) and from the gnosis of the One who possesses the Beautiful Names (الأسماء الحسنى)! Do you not see that the People of the Laws (أهل الشرائع), who are the People of the Real (أهل الحق), affirm the attribution of Divinity (الألوهة) to this Originator of the possible existent who is worshipped? And the intelligible concept of Divinity is not the intelligible concept of the Essence (الذات). Thus, Oneness (الأحدية) is intelligible, but expression cannot encompass it except through a composite, even though the intellect grasps it—and it is the oneness of the composite and its units.

### [The Divine Theophany (التجلي الإلهي) is fundamentally invalid in Oneness (الأحدية)]

Do you not see that the Divine Theophany (التجلي الإلهي) is fundamentally invalid in Oneness (الأحدية)? Yet there is nothing there but Oneness. And no effect is intelligible from a One that has no comprehensive nature (جمعية). I wish I knew how intellects could be ignorant of what is clearer than the sun! He says, "Only one proceeds from the One," and he says, "The Real is One from all aspects," yet he knows that relations (النسب) are from some aspects, and Attributes (الصفات), in the doctrine of the other, are from some aspects. Where then is the One from all aspects?

### [The Oneness of Divinity (أحدية الألوهية) and the Oneness of the Composite (أحدية المجموع)]

I know of no one who knows Allah better than Allah, since He did not stipulate Unity (الوحدة) except as the Oneness of the Composite (أحدية المجموع), which is the Oneness of Divinity (أحدية الألوهة) belonging to Him Almighty. Thus, He said: <<He is Allah, other than whom there is no god, Knower of the unseen and the witnessed. He is the Most Compassionate, the Most Merciful. He is Allah, other than whom there is no god, the Sovereign, the Holy, the Source of Peace, the Giver of Security, the Overseer, the Exalted in Might, the Compeller, the Superior. Exalted is Allah above whatever they associate with Him. He is Allah, the Creator, the Inventor, the Fashioner; to Him belong the Beautiful Names (الأسماء الحسنى).>> And they are ninety-nine Names, one hundred minus one. And the referent of every single Name is not the referent of the very essence of the other Name, even though the One named by all of them is One. Thus, none knows Allah except Allah.

> None knows Allah except Allah, so acknowledge!
> The Entity (العين) is one, but the ruling (الحكم) is diverse.
> So say to a people who refused all but their intellects:
> This is the flowing river, so scoop from it!
> And do not say that the intellect has nothing
> But its proofs in what has appeared, so stop!
> Here, and do not depart until
> Unveiling (كشف) passes you to Him, and there is no turning away in the Unveiling.

### [Whoever seeks the One in its entity (عينه) attains nothing but perplexity (الحيرة)]

Whoever seeks the One in its entity (عينه) attains nothing but perplexity (الحيرة), for he cannot detach himself from the gathering (الجمع) and multiplicity (الكثرة) in the seeker and the sought. And how can he negate multiplicity when he judges himself to be the seeker and his object to be the sought?

### [The Day of Arafat is a day for which people are gathered, and that is a witnessed day]

The Day of Arafah is a day for which people are gathered, and that is a day witnessed (يَوْمٌ مَشْهُودٌ). The Real (الحق) only hastened its appointed time in this world for His servants because of the expiration of its limited term, just as He, the Exalted, said concerning the Hereafter: <<إِنَّهُ يَوْمٌ مَجْمُوعٌ لَهُ النَّاسُ وَذَلِكَ يَوْمٌ مَشْهُودٌ وَمَا نُؤَخِّرُهُ إِلَّا لِأَجَلٍ مَعْدُودٍ>> (Indeed, it is a Day for which mankind will be gathered, and that is a Day witnessed. And We do not delay it except for a term counted).

The Day of Arafah is a day of general and comprehensive forgiveness. If it happens to coincide with a Friday (يوم جمعة), then it is grace upon grace, forgiveness upon forgiveness, and a festival upon a festival. The Imam is therefore the most deserving and entitled to establish the Friday Prayer (الجمعة) on that day, for it is the most excellent prescribed prayer and holds the position of primacy. It possesses a priority that has no second. Thus, it should be established by one whose divine forgiveness (المغفرة الإلهية) has been legally confirmed, who has purified himself with outward and inward purity, and who is thus sanctified from every sin that acts as a veil from Allah. Furthermore, it is a station of dustiness, dishevelment (الشعث), humility, supplication (الابتهال), prayer, and earnest entreaty (التضرع). Therefore, the Friday Prayer is obligatory therein if its day is present, making it a day of two festivals: the festival of Arafah and the festival of Friday. If the Imam does not establish it, the people only attain one festival, and that day is not considered a Friday at all; rather, that ruling is stripped from it due to the absence of the Friday Prayer. Its original name, *al-Uruba* (العروبة), is also removed. Thus, there is neither *Jumu'ah* nor *Uruba*. However, if the inward rank (الرتبة الباطنة) is considered, its original name, *al-Uruba*, may return to it, and nothing else. Reflect deeply upon what I have mentioned to you concerning the removal of the name *Jumu'ah* from it, for it was only named thus because of the gathering of people upon a single Imam, just as we are gathered in our Existence (وجودنا) upon a single God. And Allah is the Guide. End of the Sixty-Eighth Part.

***

(In the Name of Allah, the Most Compassionate, the Most Merciful)

(Chapter concerning the timing of the Standing at Arafah during its day and night)

Scholars have not differed that the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) only stood (وقف) after the sun had passed the meridian (الزوال) and after he had prayed the Dhuhr and Asr prayers. He ascended from his prayer place and stood supplicating until sunset. When the sun set, he proceeded (دفع) to Muzdalifah.

They agreed unanimously that whoever stands at Arafah before the meridian, his standing is not counted if he leaves Arafah. If he does not return and stand after the meridian or stand during that night before the rising of the dawn, his Hajj has been missed.

### [The Arabic Time System Precedes Its Day with Its Night]

Know that the Arabs and the Arabic time system, in their terminology and convention, precede the day with the night, following the fundamental principle (الأصل). For the Originator of Time, who is Allah the Exalted, says: <<وَآيَةٌ لَهُمُ اللَّيْلُ نَسْلَخُ مِنْهُ النَّهارَ>> (And a sign for them is the night; We withdraw from it the day). Thus, He made the night the origin and withdrew the day from it, just as a sheep is skinned from its hide. The manifestation belonged to the night, and the day was concealed within it, like the sheep's hide, which is outwardly a covering until it is stripped off. Thus, He stripped the realm of witnessing (الشهادة) from the Unseen (الغيب), and our Existence (وجودنا) from non-Existence (العدم).

### [The Non-Arabs Precede the Night with the Day]

Thus, the knowledge of the Arabs became manifest over that of the non-Arabs (العجم). For the non-Arabs, whose calculation is based on the sun, precede the night with the day. They have a basis for this in the verse: <<فَإِذا هُمْ مُظْلِمُونَ>> (And behold, they are in darkness). The particle *idha* (إذا) indicates the time of the present or the future state. The description of being "in darkness" (مظلم) only occurs with the existence of the night in this verse. Thus, the day was a covering over it, then it was stripped away—that is, removed—so <<فَإِذا هُمْ مُظْلِمُونَ>> (and behold, they are in darkness), meaning the night, whose ruling is darkness, has appeared, and behold, the people are in darkness.

### [The Contingent, even if Existing, is in the Ruling of Non-Existence]

The contingent (الممكن), even if it exists, is in the ruling of non-existence (المعدوم). The truest line of poetry spoken by the Arabs is the saying of Labid:

> ألا كل شي‏ء ما خلا الله باطل‏
> Behold, everything besides Allah is vain (or false).

And *al-batil* (vain/false) is non-existence.

### [The Appearance of the Non-Arabic Ruling in the Arabic Law on the Day of Arafah]

This non-Arabic ruling (الحكم الأعجمى) appeared in the Arabic Law (الشرع العربي) on the Day of Arafah. For the Arabs and the Law delayed the Night of Arafah (ليلة عرفة) from its day, just as the non-Arabs (الأعاجم), the people of solar calculation, do. The Arabic Law made the Night of Arafah the night following the Day of Arafah, which is the morning of the Day of Sacrifice (يوم النحر), the tenth day. In all other times according to them [the Arabs], the night belongs to the day whose morning follows it. Whereas, according to the non-Arabs, the night of Friday, for example, is the one whose morning is Saturday. Thus, the Arabs and the non-Arabs converged in delaying this night from its day. This was granted to the station (مقام) of Muzdalifah, which is called *Jam'* (Gathering), because the Arabs and non-Arabs were gathered there upon a single ruling. They made the Night of Arafah belong to the preceding Day of Arafah because the Lawgiver (الشارع) legislated that whoever attains the Standing (الوقوف) at Arafah on that night before dawn has attained the Hajj, and Hajj is Arafah.

### [Every Day is Complete with Its Night Except the Day of Arafah]

Every day is complete with its night—from sunset to sunset according to the Arabs, and from sunrise to sunrise according to the non-Arabs—except the Day of Arafah. The Day of Arafah is three-quarters of the known day, minus one hour and five-sixths of an hour. This is because it is specifically from the passing of the sun (زوال الشمس) until the rising of the dawn (طلوع الفجر). Thus, the time of the Day of Arafah is deficient compared to the known day (from dawn until the meridian). The reason for this is that since Arafah is considered the station of Gnosis (المعرفة بالله) of Allah, which He has made obligatory upon us, we should not be called Gnostics (عارفين بالله) until we know His Essence (ذاته) and what is necessarily due to it by virtue of its being God (إلها). If we know Him according to this limit, then we have known Him.

### [Gnosis of Allah from the Perspective of His Essence and from the Perspective of His Being God]

Gnosis (المعرفة) is thus divided into two halves: one half is the Gnosis of the Essence (معرفة الذات), and the other half is the Gnosis of His being God (الألوهة). When we investigated with rational proofs (الأدلة العقلية) and listened to the legal proofs (الأدلة الشرعية), we affirmed the Existence (وجود) of the Essence but remained ignorant of its Reality (حقيقتها). We affirmed Divinity (الألوهة) for it, which constitutes half of the complete Gnosis. The quarter is its Existence—meaning the Existence of the Essence to which Divinity is attributed. The fourth quarter is the Gnosis of its Reality, which we have not attained, and it is impossible to attain it. The excess over the quarter that we are also ignorant of is our ignorance concerning the specific nature of the rulings (الأحكام) we attribute to it. Even though we know the attribution as an attribution, we may be ignorant of the specific attribution due to our ignorance of the entity to which it is attributed (المنسوب إليه). Thus, Gnosis was attained from the passing of the sun until the rising of the dawn. From the rising of the dawn until sunrise, we are ignorant of the attribution. From sunrise until the meridian, which is a quarter of the day, we are ignorant of the Essence (الذات). Arafah was only granted the measure of Gnosis of Allah that its time granted it. Know this. Thus, the knowledge of Him falls short of the degree of knowledge of every known thing. Whoever we do not know in his Reality, we have not truly known him. We know the Existence of the Essence due to reliance (الاستناد), not by the Essence itself. We know the attribution of Divinity to it, but not the modality of the attribution. This is half of Gnosis. This half comprises two quarters: one quarter is the knowledge of the Attributes of Transcendence and Negation (صفات التنزيه والسلوب), and the other quarter is the Gnosis of the Attributes of Acts and Relations (صفات الأفعال والنسب). What we possess, therefore, is three-quarters of Gnosis, minus the one quarter that we shall never know. The aspect of Gnosis corresponding to the excess over the quarter (from dawn until sunrise) is analogous to our ignorance concerning the attribution of a descriptive quality (صفة التشبيه) with which the Real described Himself. We do not know how to attribute it to Him, despite our belief in it and our affirmation of this ruling, coupled with our ignorance—but based on what Allah knows of it. This corresponds to the excess over the quarter of the day. This is why the Day of Arafah is deficient compared to the other temporal days. Therefore, verify the correctness of the Day of Arafah: it is from the meridian until the rising of the dawn of the Night of Arafah.

(Chapter concerning one who proceeds from Arafah before the Imam)

Scholars of Islam differed concerning one who stood at Arafah after the meridian and then proceeded (دفع) from it before the Imam and after sunset. Some said his Hajj is sufficient (أجزأه) because he combined night and day at Arafah. If he proceeded before sunset, some said he owes a sacrifice (عليه دم), and others said he owes nothing and his Hajj is complete. What I hold is that he owes nothing, and his Hajj is complete in its pillars (الأركان), but incomplete in its rites (المناسك), because he abandoned the more excellent path (الأفضل).

### [The Ruling on one who abandons something of the Prophet's emulation according to the People of Allah's Path]

There is no doubt that whoever abandons something of the emulation (اتباع) of the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) that was not obligatory upon him, his love for Allah decreases in proportion to the deficiency in his emulation of the Messenger. He has belied himself in his claim of love for Allah due to the failure to complete the emulation. According to the People of Allah's Path (أهل طريق الله), even if he emulated him in all his affairs but failed in emulation in a single matter that was not obligatory upon him—rather, he contravened a Sunnah of emulation in something permissible for him to emulate—then he has not emulated him at all. Rather, he followed his own desire (هوى نفسه), not the Prophet, provided there were no compelling excuses (الأعذار الموجبة) for the lack of emulation. This is established with us. Allah the Exalted said to Muhammad (peace and blessings be upon him): Say, O Muhammad, to your community: <<إِنْ كُنْتُمْ تُحِبُّونَ اللهَ فَاتَّبِعُونِي>> (If you love Allah, then follow me). He made emulation the proof (دليلا). He did not say concerning one thing rather than another: <<يُحْبِبْكُمُ اللهُ>> (Allah will love you). Allah says: <<لَقَدْ كَانَ لَكُمْ فِي رَسُولِ اللهِ أُسْوَةٌ حَسَنَةٌ>> (There has certainly been for you in the Messenger of Allah an excellent pattern), which is emulation. And He said: <<وَأَوْفُوا بِعَهْدِي>> (And fulfill My covenant) in your claim of loving Me, <<أُوفِ بِعَهْدِكُمْ>> (I will fulfill My covenant with you), which is that I will love you if you are truthful in your love for Me. He made the proof of their truthfulness the attainment of Allah's love for them, and the attainment of Allah's love for them is the proof of emulation. The decrease is proportional to the deficiency. According to the People of Allah, this is a matter that does not accept deficiency, and even an excuse does not diminish it. If he is prevented by Allah from emulation in a certain matter, then the Real (الحق) acts on his behalf, in my view.

### [When Abu Yazid held himself accountable regarding the sincerity of love]

*A story:* Abu Yazid said concerning this matter: I used to think, regarding my dutifulness to my mother, that I was not performing it out of my own desire (هوى نفسي), but out of reverence for the Sacred Law (الشريعة) which commanded me to honor her. I found great pleasure in myself, which I imagined came from my reverence for the Real (الحق), not from the agreement of my ego (موافقة نفسي). One cold night, she said to me, "Give me water, O Abu Yazid." I felt heavy about moving to do so. I said, "By Allah, nothing made what she asked me to do easy except the agreement [of my ego] that was in my soul without my realizing it." So, his action was invalidated, and he did not achieve sincerity. Abu Yazid said: I rose with spiritual struggle (بمجاهدة) and brought the pitcher to her. I found that sleep had quickly overtaken her, and she was asleep. I stood with the pitcher above her head until she woke up. I handed her the pitcher, and a piece of the skin of my finger had broken off on the handle of the pitcher due to the severity of the cold. My mother was pained by this. Abu Yazid said: I returned to my soul and said to it, "Your action is nullified (حبط عملك) because you claimed enthusiasm in your worship and emulation, saying it was from your love for Allah. Yet, He only obligated and recommended to you what is beloved to Him. Everything commanded by the Beloved is beloved to the lover. And among what Allah commanded you, O my soul, is dutifulness to your mother and kindness to her. The lover rejoices and rushes to what his Beloved loves. But I saw you become lazy, heavy, and the command of your mother was difficult for you when she asked for water. You rose with laziness and reluctance. So I knew that all the acts of righteousness (أعمال البر) in which you were active, performing them without laziness or heaviness, but with joy and pleasure, were only for a desire (هوى) you had in them, not for the sake of Allah. For if it were for Allah, kindness to your mother—an act Allah loves from you and commanded you to do—would not have been difficult for you, while you claim His love, and that His love instilled in you enthusiasm and pleasure in His worship." Thus, he did not concede even this much to his soul.

### [And thus did the People of Allah hold themselves accountable]

Similarly, others among the People of Allah besides Abu Yazid used to maintain the first row (الصف الأول) always for seventy years, claiming that he did so out of desire for what Allah desired, in conformity with Allah. Then an obstacle prevented him from walking to the first row. A thought occurred to him: "The congregation praying in the first row, if they do not see me, will say, 'Where is so-and-so?'" He wept and said to his soul, "You have deceived me for seventy years! I imagined I was acting for Allah, but I was following your desire! What does it matter to you if they miss you?" He repented and was never seen after that adhering to a single, specific place in the mosque, nor a specific mosque. This is how the People held their souls accountable. One whose state is this is not equal to one who lacks this quality. Likewise, one who stands with the Imam, because it is an act of worship (عبادة) where the Imam is a condition until one proceeds with him, is not equal in emulation to one who proceeded before him.

(Chapter concerning one who stood at Urana of Arafah, for it is part of it)

Scholars differed concerning one who stood at Urana (عرنة) of Arafah, for it is part of Arafah. Some said his Hajj is complete (تام) but he owes a sacrifice (عليه دم). Others said he has no Hajj.

### [Urana of Arafah is the standing place of Iblis]

Urana of Arafah is the standing place of Iblis. Iblis performs Hajj every year, and that is his station where he weeps over the obedience he missed to his Lord. He is compelled in misguidance (الإغواء), even though his fulfilling the oath to his Lord was by his own choice. Even though wretchedness (الشقاء) was predetermined for him, he has a pretext (شبهة) upon which he relies in obeying the command of his Master after the word of punishment (كلمة العذاب) was decreed against him by His saying, the Exalted: <<قَالَ اذْهَبْ وَاسْتَفْزِزْ وَأَجْلِبْ وَعِدْهُمْ>> (He said, "Go, and incite [with] your voice and gather [against] them and promise them"). He finds relief (تنفيسا) in this. Despite this, he grieves when he sees the forgiveness that has been granted to the People of Arafah, which encompasses them. Since he is in it—meaning in Arafah—he must, in his own estimation, receive a portion of the divine favor (المنة الإلهية), even if after a time. This is his good assumption concerning his Lord. As for his exit from Hell (جهنم), there is no way for that, because he and his followers, the polytheists (المشركين) who are the inhabitants of the Fire, Allah will fill Hell with them, and there will be no deficiency in it after it is filled. Thus, there is no exit.

### [Allah commanded the pilgrim to ascend above the standing place of Iblis]

Allah commanded the pilgrim to ascend above the standing place of Iblis, for it is the station of remoteness (البعد). Iblis is under the ruling of the Name *al-Ba'id* (The Remote), while the People of Arafah are under the ruling of the Name *al-Qarib* (The Near). They have not departed from the ruling of the Names (الأسماء). The Hajj of one who stood at Urana is complete, since it is part of Arafat, but it is deficient in virtue (ناقص الفضيلة), as we explained regarding proceeding before the Imam. Urana is a disliked place (موضع مكروه) for standing due to the participation of Satan. Do you not see that the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) ascended above the bottom of the valley (بطن الوادي) where he missed the Fajr prayer? He gave the reason, saying, "It is a valley, and a devil disciplined him," because it was the devil who calmed Bilal until he slept and failed to watch for the dawn. It is reported in the Hadith that Satan ties three knots on the nape of the head of one of you when he sleeps, striking the place of each knot, saying, "You have a long night, so sleep." The Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) only intended by ascending above the bottom of Urana to distance himself from the neighborhood of Satan. If he had prayed in that place, it would have been sufficient for him—meaning the place where the temptation (الفتنة) afflicted him. So he departed the place as an act of purification (تنزيه), not as an act of prohibition (تحريم). Since Iblis has a portion of Gnosis (المعرفة), the angels did not expel him from Urana. Rather, he stood there, except that the people isolated themselves from him in one side of it, due to the isolation of their Imam. All of Arafat is a standing place, and Urana is part of Arafat. We were commanded to ascend above the bottom of Urana for the reason we mentioned.

### [The pilgrim's departure must be from the bottom of Arafah]

Whoever interprets this command as obligatory invalidates the Hajj. The pilgrim's departure (الإفاضة) must be from the bottom of Urana, for the boundary of Muzdalifah is the edge of the valley, which is Urana. Allah the Exalted said: <<فَإِذَا أَفَضْتُمْ مِنْ عَرَفَاتٍ>> (Then when you depart from Arafat), and He did not specify one place over another, but rather the complete departure from it to Muzdalifah. We know that Allah forgives the People of the Standing, both pilgrims and others, and the Mercy of Allah <<وَسِعَتْ كُلَّ شَيْءٍ>> (encompasses all things). Restriction (التقييد) is not a characteristic of the One who possesses Absolute Existence (الوجود المطلق). By Allah's Mercy, every existent thing besides Allah lives and is provided for. Mercy is comprehensive, and in every station (موطن), it grants according to that station. Thus, its effect in the Fire is different from its effect in Paradise. And Allah is the Granter of Success; there is no Lord but Him.

(Chapter concerning Muzdalifah)

Scholars agreed that whoever spends the night (بات) in Muzdalifah, prays Maghrib and Isha there, prays Fajr on the Day of Sacrifice, and stands after the prayer until it brightens (أسفر), then proceeds to Mina, his Hajj is complete. They differed as to whether standing there after the Fajr prayer and spending the night there are Sunnahs (recommended acts) of Hajj or obligatory duties (فروضه). A group said it is among the obligatory duties of Hajj, and whoever misses it must perform Hajj the following year and offer a sacrifice (الهدى). Some said whoever misses standing there and spending the night owes a sacrifice (دم). Others said if he does not pray Fajr there, he owes a sacrifice.

### [Pillars in Acts of Worship and Essential Attributes in Entities]

Muzdalifah (المزدلفة) is a name for proximity (قرب), and the action performed there is an act of proximity (قربة). Whoever misses the quality of proximity (صفة القرب) in the place of proximity has not performed Hajj, for Hajj is a complete formation (نشأة كاملة) composed of all these actions. These actions are to Hajj like the essential attributes (الصفات النفسية) are to the described entity: if one of them is removed, the existence of that described entity is nullified. Similarly, every act of worship (عبادة) composed of different elements is validated by their totality. These are called its pillars (أركان). They are called a pillar in worship, and an essential attribute in essences and entities (الذوات والأعيان). However, formations (النشآت), even though they have essential attributes that preserve the identity of that thing, also have necessary concomitants (لوازم), which are found in formal definitions (الحدود الرسمية) and are inseparable from the entity described by them. Whoever views the described entity as inseparable from these concomitants, like laughter for a human, which resembles an essential attribute, says that the necessary entity (الملزوم) is nullified by the absence of the concomitant. Whoever says that the definition of the essential thing (الشيء الذاتي) is valid without this concomitant says that the thing is not subject to the ruling of nullification (البطلان) with the removal of the concomitant in the mind, even if it is not removed in Existence (الوجود).

### [The Remembrance of Allah at al-Mash'ar al-Haram]

When Allah named it *al-Mash'ar al-Haram* (The Sacred Monument), it is so that we may perceive (نشعر) acceptance from Allah in this act of worship through divine care (العناية), forgiveness, and the guarantee of responsibilities (ضمان التبعات). He described it as sacred (الحرمة) because it is within the Sanctuary (الحرم), so what is prohibited in the entire Sanctuary is prohibited there, as it is part of it. He commanded the remembrance of Allah (ذكر الله) therein—meaning by what we have mentioned. For a thing is not remembered merely by being named, but rather by the praiseworthy attributes (صفات المحمدة) it possesses. Names, in their original designation, are merely markers (أعلام) for the named entity, not descriptions (نعوت). Thus, one only remembers by the proper name (الاسم العلم) for the purpose of identification, so that one may know who is being mentioned by the praises or other qualities you mention.

(Chapter concerning the Stoning of the Pillars (Ramy al-Jimar))

Regarding the Pillar of Aqabah (جمرة العقبة), the point of agreement is that it is stoned with seven pebbles (حصيات) on the Day of Sacrifice (يوم النحر), from after sunrise until close to the meridian (الاستواء). No other pillar is stoned on that day. They differed concerning stoning it before dawn. Some said it is not permissible and requires repetition (الإعادة) of the stoning. Others said it is permissible, but the recommended time is after sunrise. I hold the former opinion. Some said that if one stones it before sunset on the Day of Sacrifice, it is sufficient (أجزأه) and he owes nothing. Others said it is recommended for one who stones it before sunset on the Day of Sacrifice to offer a sacrifice (أن يريق دما). They differed concerning one who did not stone until sunset and stoned it during the night or the following day. Some said he owes a sacrifice. Others said he owes nothing if he stoned it during the night, but if he delayed it until the next day, he owes a sacrifice. A group said he owes nothing, even if he delayed it until the next day. As for the shepherds (الرعاء), the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) granted them a concession (رخص لهم). Some said the meaning of the concession for the shepherds is only that after the Day of Sacrifice has passed and they have stoned the Pillar of Aqabah, on the third day, which is the first of the Days of Departure (أيام النفر), the Messenger of Allah granted them permission to stone on that day for themselves and for the day after. If they depart (نفروا), they are finished. If they remain until the next day, they stone with the people on the last Day of Departure and then depart. Others said the meaning of the concession, according to the scholars, is combining two days into one day. However, Malik only combines what is obligatory according to him, so he combines on the third day, stoning for the second and third days, because no one disobeys him except in what is obligatory. Many scholars permitted combining two days into one, whether the day to which the other is added precedes or follows. They differed concerning one who performed some of these actions earlier than the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) did by his action, or one who delayed what the Prophet performed earlier. Some said whoever shaves (حلق) before stoning the Pillar of Aqabah owes a ransom (الفدية). Others said he owes nothing. We will present the prophetic narrations concerning Hajj, God willing, after this, upon which you may reflect, and attention will be drawn to each narration according to what it contains. Some said if he shaves before stoning or sacrificing (ينحر), he owes a sacrifice. If he is performing *Qiran* (combining Hajj and Umrah), he owes two sacrifices. Others said he owes three sacrifices: two for *Qiran* and one for shaving before sacrificing. They agreed unanimously that whoever sacrifices before stoning owes nothing. They agreed that whoever performs the *Ifadah* (departure/circumambulation) before stoning and shaving must repeat the circumambulation (الطواف). Some said he does not need to repeat it. Al-Awza'i said if one performs the *Tawaf al-Ifadah* before stoning the Pillar of Aqabah and then has intercourse with his wife, he owes a sacrifice. They agreed that the total number of pebbles the pilgrim throws is seventy, seven of which are on the Day of Sacrifice. They agreed that stoning this pillar—meaning the Pillar of Aqabah—from below it, above it, or from its middle, is all permissible. The preferred method is the action of the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him), which is the bottom of the valley (بطن الوادي). They agreed that one must repeat the stoning if the pebble does not fall into the pillar (العقبة). They agreed that one stones three pillars on each of the Days of Tashriq (أيام التشريق) with twenty-one pebbles, seven for each pillar. They agreed that it is permissible to stone for two days and depart on the third. They estimated the size of the pebbles to be like the pebbles used for flicking (*hasy al-khadhf*). The Sunnah for stoning the pillars during the Days of Tashriq is to stone the first one, then stand by it and supplicate, and likewise the second one, prolonging the stay, then stone the third one without standing by it. The *Takbir* (saying Allahu Akbar) upon stoning each pillar is considered good. The stoning during the Days of Tashriq should be after the meridian. They differed if one stones before the meridian during the Days of Tashriq. The majority of scholars said he must repeat the stoning after the meridian. It was narrated from some scholars of the Prophet's Household (أهل البيت) that stoning the pillars is from sunrise until sunset. They agreed unanimously that whoever does not stone the pillars during the Days of Tashriq until the sun sets on the last of them should not stone them afterward. They differed concerning the obligation resulting from this, between a sacrifice (دم) and an expiation (كفارة). Some said if he abandons all the stoning, or part of it, or even one pillar, he owes a sacrifice. Others said if he abandons all of it, he owes a sacrifice. If he abandons one pillar or more, he owes for each pillar the feeding of a poor person half a *sa'* of wheat, up until the point where he has abandoned all except the Pillar of Aqabah, in which case he owes a sacrifice. Others said for one pebble, he owes a *mudd* of food, for two pebbles, two *mudds*, and for three, a sacrifice. Al-Thawri said the same, except he said for the fourth, a sacrifice. A group of the Successors (التابعين) granted a concession regarding a single pebble, saying there is nothing due for it. The literalists (أهل الظاهر) said there is nothing due for any of it. I shall present the narrations concerning what we have mentioned, God willing. The majority of scholars hold that the Pillar of Aqabah is not among the pillars (أركان) of Hajj. As for exiting the state of *ihram* (التحلل), there are two exits: the greater exit (*tahallul akbar*), which is the *Tawaf al-Ifadah*, and the lesser exit (*tahallul asghar*), which is the stoning of the Pillar of Aqabah.

(The Esoteric Consideration of this Chapter)

The *Jimar* (Pillars) are congregations (الجماعات). Every *Jamrah* is a congregation, whatever congregation it may be. From this comes *istijmar* (purification with stones) in ritual purity. This is why it is recommended that it be more than one [stone] so that the meaning of congregation (الجماعة) is found in it. There is no meaning for one who holds *istijmar* with a single stone, even if it has three sides (حروف). For the Arabs do not call a single stone a *Jamrah*. It is recommended that it be an odd number, starting from three and upwards, with a maximum of seven in the act of worship, not in the linguistic sense. For the single *Jamrah* is seven pebbles. Likewise, the temporal *Jamrah* (الجمرة الزمانية) that indicates the end of the season of severe cold: every *Jamrah* in February (شباط) is seven days, and they are three consecutive *Jimar*, each seven days. Thus, the *Jimar* conclude with the passing of twenty-one days of February, just like the stoning of the pillars (رمى الجمار) is twenty-one pebbles, which are three *Jimar*. Similarly, the Divine Presence (الحضرة الإلهية) is expressed by three meanings: the Essence (الذات), the Attributes (الصفات), and the Acts (الأفعال). The stoning of the pillars is like the proofs and evidences (الأدلة والبراهين) for negation (سلب), such as the Presence of the Essence (حضرة الذات), or affirmation (إثبات), such as the Presence of the Conceptual Attributes (الصفات المعنوية), or relations/additions (نسب أو إضافة), such as the Presence of the Acts (حضرة الأفعال).

### [The Proofs of the First Pillar for the Gnosis of the Presence of the Essence]

The proofs of the First Pillar (الجمرة الأولى) are for the Gnosis of the Essence (معرفة الذات). This is why we stand by it (نقِف عندها) due to its obscurity (غموضها), indicating firmness (الثبات) in it. This relates to the negations (السلوب) concerning it, since it is not correct to know it through the affirmation of a specific attribute, nor is it correct for it to have multiple essential attributes (صفات نفسية متعددة). Rather, its essential attribute is its very identity (عينه), not another thing. Thus, its affirmative essential attribute must be one, and it is its very identity, nothing else. Therefore, He is unknown in His identity (مجهول العين) but known through the need for Him (الافتقار إليه). This is the Gnosis of His Absolute Oneness (أحديته). Then the thought (خاطر) of contingency (الإمكان) comes to this Essence. The pilgrim stones it with the pebble of need for the Determiner (المرجح), who is the Necessary Existent by Himself (واجب الوجود لنفسه). He presents the form of the proof based on what its structure yields in the scales of the intellects. This is one pebble of the First Pillar. When he stones it, saying *Allahu Akbar* (magnifying Him), meaning He is greater than this attribution of contingency to Him, the thought comes to him a second time that He is a substance (جوهر). He stones it with the second pebble, which is the proof of the need for spatial limitation (التحيز) or for Existence through another. Then the thought of corporeality (الجسمية) comes to him. He stones it with the pebble of need for tools, composition, and dimensions (الأبعاد). Then the thought of accidentality (العرضية) comes to him. He stones it with the pebble of need for a locus (المحل) and origination (الحدوث) after not having been. Then the thought of causality (العلية) comes to him. He stones it with the fifth pebble, which is the proof of the effect (المعلول) being co-existent with the cause in Existence, whereas He was, and nothing was with Him. Then the thought of Nature (الطبيعة) comes to him. He stones it with the sixth pebble, which is the proof of attributing multiplicity to Him and the need of every individual unit of Nature for another thing in order to combine and produce natural bodies. For Nature is a composite of active and passive principles: heat, cold, moisture, and dryness. Their combination is not valid by themselves, nor is their separation by themselves, and they have no existence except in the very identity of the hot, the cold, the moist, and the dry. Then the thought of non-existence (العدم) comes to him, saying, "If this and that are not [and he enumerates what preceded], then there is nothing." He stones it with the seventh pebble, which is the proof of His effects in the contingent (الممكن), and non-existence has no effect. It has been established by the proof of the contingent's need for a Determiner in its existence, and the existence of a Necessary Existent by Himself, who is the One we have established as the Determiner. And thus, the First Pillar is concluded.

### [The Proofs of the Second Pillar for the Gnosis of the Presence of the Attributes]

Then we come to the Second Pillar, which is the Presence of the Conceptual Attributes (حضرة الصفات المعنوية). The thought says to you, "We grant that there is an Essence that determines the contingent. But who says that this Essence is Knowing (عالمة) of what appeared from it?" We stone it with the first pebble if this is the first thought that occurs to this spiritual pilgrim (الحاج المعنوي). Or, the attack might first occur concerning another attribute. He stones it according to the thought that occurs to him, up to seven attributes: Life, Power, Will, Knowledge, Hearing, Sight, and Speech. Some of our companions do not stipulate these three—Hearing, Sight, and Speech—in the rational proofs (الأدلة العقلية) but receive them through transmitted texts (السمع) if established, and they replace them with three others: Knowledge of what is necessary for Him, what is permissible for Him, and what is impossible for Him, along with the four: Power, Will, Knowledge, and Life. These are seven types of knowledge. The Satanic thought (الخاطر الشيطاني) presents a doubt for each type of knowledge. This pilgrim stones it with the pebble of every rational proof (دليل عقلي) according to the correct scale in the structure of proofs as required. He prolongs his verification (التثبت) in this, which is the standing (الوقوف) at the Middle Pillar and supplicating there.

### [The Proofs of the Third Pillar for the Gnosis of the Presence of the Acts]

Then comes the Third Pillar, which is the Presence of the Acts (حضرة الأفعال). These are also seven. First, the thought arises in his mind that the generated things (المولدات) arose by themselves. He stones it with the pebble of their need, from the specific aspect (الوجه الخاص), for the Real, the Mighty and Majestic. When the Satanic thought knows that the pilgrim will not turn back from his knowledge of need, it suggests to him that their need is for another cause besides the Real, namely the elements (العناصر). We have seen those who worship them in Mosul. If that thought occurs to him, either it takes hold of him by negating the effect of the Real (أثر الحق) in them, or, if it cannot, its utmost is to establish them as partners (شركا). He stones it with the second pebble, showing him in its proof that the elements are like the generated things in their need for something other than Allah the Exalted. This is because the Gnostic (العارف) always looks at the specific aspect (الوجه الخاص) in every contingent thing that comes from Allah to it. He does not look at the cause upon which Allah made its existence dependent, or to which He linked it by way of causality or condition. This is the perspective of the People of Allah's Path among our companions. I have not seen anyone among our predecessors or contemporaries in my knowledge draw attention to the affirmation of this specific aspect in every contingent thing, even though they are not ignorant of it. But Allah spoke the truth in His saying: <<وَنَحْنُ أَقْرَبُ إِلَيْهِ مِنْكُمْ>> (And We are nearer to him than you are)—meaning the causes—<<وَلَكِنْ لَا تُبْصِرُونَ>> (but you do not see)—meaning His relation to us, not to the cause. Praise be to Allah who opened our eyes to the realization of this aspect in every contingent thing. When he stones it with the second pebble, as we mentioned, the thought suggests the cause upon which the existence of the pillars (الأركان) depends, which is the celestial sphere (الفلك). It says that the originator of these pillars is the celestial sphere, and you spoke truly in what you said. He stones it with the third pebble, which is the need of the celestial sphere—which is the form (الشكل)—for Allah from the specific aspect, as we mentioned. The thought agrees with him on the need but says, "You are mistaken. The need of the form was only for the body (الجسم) without which the form would not have appeared." He stones it with the fourth pebble, which is the need of the body for Allah from the specific aspect. The thought agrees with him and says, "What you said about the existing need is correct, but it is for the essence of the primordial dust (جوهر الهباء), which the speculative thinkers call the Universal Hyle (الهيولى الكل), in which alone the form of the body appeared." He stones it with the fifth pebble, which is the proof of the need of the primordial dust for Allah, as we mentioned before. The thought says, "No, rather its need is for the Universal Soul (النفس الكلية), expressed in the Law as the Preserved Tablet (اللوح المحفوظ)." He stones it with the sixth pebble, which is the proof of the need of the Universal Soul for Allah, also from the specific aspect. The thought agrees with him on the need but says, "Rather, its need is for the First Intellect (العقل الأول), which is the Supreme Pen (القلم الأعلى), from which this Soul emanated." He stones it with the seventh pebble, which is the proof of the need of the First Intellect for Allah. There is no target beyond Allah (ليس وراء الله مرمى). Therefore, he finds nothing to say after Allah. That is why he does not stand (يقف) at the Pillar of Aqabah, which is the last of the pillars, because, as we said, there is no target beyond Allah.

### [Mina is the place of wishing and attaining the wish]

This is the detailed explanation of the stoning of the pillars of the Gnostics (جمرات العارفين) at Mina (منى), the place of wishing (*tamanni*) and attaining the wish (*bulugh al-umniyya*). For these are days of eating, drinking, enjoyment, and bliss; they are a hastened Paradise (جنة معجلة). In it is the casting off of dirt and filth (إلقاء التفث والوسخ) and the removal of dishevelment (إزالة الشعث) from the pilgrim. Such is the power of the wishing (التمني) from which Mina is named, that it brings the one who is destitute (معدوم) of what he wished for to the level of one who actually possesses what the wisher wished for, in the most complete manner. For example, the wealthy man who performs various acts of goodness and spends them in paths of righteousness seeking Allah's favor. The destitute man wishes he had the same wealth to do the same actions. They are equal in reward (الأجر). Indeed, the destitute man's reward is more complete, for he obtains the full reward in the most perfect way without being questioned. The doer of the action is questioned about where he gathered it and whether he was sincere in spending it. After this toil and hardship, he obtains his reward, while the wisher obtains it without questioning or hardship.

### [After stoning the pillars, the pilgrim shaves his head]

After stoning the pillars—meaning the Pillar of Aqabah on the Day of Sacrifice—the pilgrim shaves his head, which is preferable to shortening the hair. I called it *Jimar* (plural) even though it is a single pillar on that day, because every single pebble, when added to the others, is called a congregation (جماعة), so they are *Jimar* from this perspective. Just as you say, when two substances (جوهران) combine, they are two bodies (جسمين)—meaning the term 'body' applies to each one by virtue of its combination with the other. Thus, they are two bodies from this perspective, as He said: <<وَمِنْ كُلِّ شَيْءٍ خَلَقْنَا زَوْجَيْنِ>> (And of everything We created pairs). He only created one pair of everything, such as male and female. He called them a pair (*zawjayn*) based on the consideration we mentioned, because neither one, when viewed by itself without the other joining it, is a pair. When another is joined to it, the name 'pair' applies to each one. Thus, they are called two pairs. Since Allah considered this by mentioning it, we said, "Then after stoning the *Jimar*," and we called the Pillar of Aqabah *Jimar* because it consists of several pebbles. There is no redundancy (*hashw*) in our speech, because there is no repetition in Existence due to the Divine Vastness (الاتساع الإلهي).

### [Shaving the head after stoning the Pillar of Aqabah is preferable to shortening the hair]

When he stones the Pillar of Aqabah, he shaves his head, which is preferable to shortening the hair. The perception (الشعور) of a matter is not the same as the attainment of complete knowledge of it in detail. The servant only perceives that there is *something* (أمرا ما). When he attains it, the perception ceases and becomes complete knowledge (علما تاما) with the details of what he perceived, like one who perceives the details in the general before attaining knowledge that specifies those details. The casting off of the hair (إلقاء الشعور) is the removal of the perception (الشعور) with the existence of knowledge, because the hair (الشعر) is a veil over the head.

### [Then the pilgrim perfumes himself so that the scent of what he has transitioned to may be found from him]

Then he perfumes himself (يتطيب) so that the scent of what he has transitioned to—the permissibility of what was restricted to him—may be found from him. Just as he perfumed himself for his *ihram* when he entered it, so that the scent of what he transitioned to might be found from him. He made it perfume because the transition in both states is toward a prescribed good (خير مشروع) that brings one closer to Allah the Exalted. For Allah is Good (*Tayyib*) and accepts only what is good, <<لِيَمِيزَ اللهُ الْخَبِيثَ مِنَ الطَّيِّبِ>> (so that Allah may distinguish the wicked from the good). He made perfume in both states a notification of the goodness of the actions.

### [Then the pilgrim slaughters his sacrifice, freeing the animal's spirit from the prison of its natural structure]

Then he slaughters or sacrifices his offering (قربانه), intending thereby to release the spirit (روح) of this animal from the prison of this dark natural structure (الهيكل الطبيعي المظلم) to the Higher World, the world of expansion and goodness. For all animals, in our view, possess spirits and intellects (عقول) that understand from Allah. That is why He, the Exalted, said concerning them: <<كُلٌّ قَدْ عَلِمَ صَلَاتَهُ وَتَسْبِيحَهُ>> (Each [creature] has known its prayer and its glorification). We release the spirits of these animals on this day as thanks to Allah, just as we ourselves emerged on this day from the state of restriction (التحجير)—the *ihram* we were in—to the state of permissibility (الإحلال) and the disposal of permissible things that bring one closer to Allah by way of choice. Then we eat from it so that a part of it may be with us, allowing us to witness the specific remembrance (الذكر المخصوص) that belongs to it, by way of tasting (*dhawq*), and to make it an aid for us in our intended movement in obedience to Allah the Exalted, since nourishment is necessary. Thus, taking this type of nourishment was preferable.

### [Then the pilgrim descends to the House, remembering and praying behind the Station of Abraham]

Then we descend to the House (البيت), visiting our Lord the Exalted, so that He may see us in a state of permissibility (محلين) just as He saw us in a state of *ihram*, as an act of gratitude to Him for releasing our entities (أعياننا) and permitting us to dispose of what He had restricted to us. We kiss His Right Hand (يمينه) upon that, as a pledge of allegiance and a greeting. Then we circumambulate it seven circuits and pray behind the Station of Abraham (مقام إبراهيم).

### [Drawing attention to taking the Station of Abraham as a place of prayer]

We previously discussed the meaning of the circumambulation and prayer during the Arrival Circumambulation (*Tawaf al-Qudum*), but we did not draw attention to taking the Station of Abraham as a place of prayer (مصلى) so that we may attain the Intimate Friendship (*Khullah*) that he attained, according to what our state grants. For Allah commanded us to take it as a place of prayer and drew our attention to what we interpreted as the description of the prayer upon the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him). He told us to say: "O Allah, bless Muhammad and the family of Muhammad"—and the believers are his family—"as You blessed Abraham." Abraham was distinguished only by the Intimate Friendship (*Khullah*). When we supplicated with this for the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him), Allah answered our prayer concerning him so that we might establish a favor with Him thereby. Allah then blessed us tenfold for that, on behalf of His Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him). The Exalted acted on behalf of His Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) by way of recompense, out of His care for him and honoring us, since the recompense was not completed for an angel or anyone else. The Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) then said, when the answer from Allah was attained concerning what we supplicated for his Prophet: "If I were to take an intimate friend (*khalil*), I would take Abu Bakr as an intimate friend, but your companion"—meaning himself—"is the Intimate Friend of Allah (خليل الله)." If this Intimate Friendship had been confirmed for him prior to the supplication of his community for him, then our prayer upon him—meaning our supplication for him—would have been pointless. If it is said that the Intimate Friendship was attained first through the supplication of the Companions, then what is the benefit of our supplication, since we are commanded at this time to pray upon him despite the attainment of the Intimate Friendship? We say that the ruling of *Khullah* does not manifest here; rather, it manifests in the Hereafter. The ruling for a meaning (المعنى) only occurs after the meaning is attained. Whenever the meaning is established in a locus, its ruling becomes obligatory for that locus. In the Hereafter, *Khullah* will be attained due to the manifestation of its ruling there. As for what manifests here, they are flashes (لوامع) that appear and announce that he has become worthy of it and has been cared for. This is the correct view. The first answer is that every soul among us has a share of Muhammad (peace and blessings be upon him), which is the form (الصورة) within its inward being. He is in every soul in the form that each person believes concerning him. That soul supplicates for him with the mentioned prayer upon him, and that Muhammadan form (الصورة المحمدية) within him attains that state (*hal*) supplicated for by his prayer upon him. Thus, he only attained *Khullah* from this perspective after the supplication of every soul. This is how the People of Allah find it in their unveiling (كشفهم). Know this.

### (An Event) [of Ibn Arabi at the Station of Abraham]

Know, may Allah grant you success, that while I was writing this discourse at the Station of Abraham the Intimate Friend (الخليل), and his station (مقامه) is His saying, the Exalted, concerning him: <<وَإِبْرَاهِيمَ الَّذِي وَفَّى>> (And Abraham, who fulfilled [his obligations]), because he fulfilled what he saw in the dream of sacrificing his son—I was overcome by a light sleep (*sinnah*). Suddenly, a speaker from the spirits of the Highest Assembly (أرواح الملإ الأعلى) said to me, on behalf of Allah the Exalted: "Enter the Station of Abraham, which is that he was *Awwah* (oft-returning) and *Halim* (forbearing)." Then he recited to me: <<إِنَّ إِبْرَاهِيمَ لَأَوَّاهٌ حَلِيمٌ>> (Indeed, Abraham was oft-returning [to Allah] and forbearing). I knew that Allah the Exalted must grant me a measure of power (الاقتدار) with which forbearance (الحلم) exists, since there is no forbearance without power over the one toward whom one is forbearing. I knew that Allah the Exalted must test me with people speaking ill of my honor (كلام في عرضي), and I must treat them with forbearance, despite having power over them. This will involve much harm, for the word *Halim* (forbearing) came in the intensive form (*fa'il*). Then he was described as *Awwah*, which is one who frequently sighs (يتأوه) due to what he witnesses of Allah's Majesty (جلال الله) and the fact that he lacks the power to treat that Divine Majesty with the reverence it deserves, since the created being (المحدث) lacks the capacity to match Allah's Majesty with magnification and reverence. This is also part of our intention in seeking the Station of Abraham, to take it as a place of prayer (مصلى)—meaning a place of supplication in prayer or after prayer—so that we may attain this station and the quality that is the description and state of Abraham, the Intimate Friend of Allah. We hope that we may have a share of the Intimate Friendship (*Khullah*), just as we have obtained a generous share of the degree of perfection, conclusion, and elevation that flows through all things in this community, by the glad tidings concerning this.

### [Among the Stations of Abraham the Intimate Friend]

Among the stations of Abraham is also that he <<كَانَ أُمَّةً قَانِتاً لِلَّهِ حَنِيفاً وَلَمْ يَكُ مِنَ الْمُشْرِكِينَ شَاكِراً لِأَنْعُمِهِ اجْتَبَاهُ وَهَدَاهُ إِلَى صِرَاطٍ مُسْتَقِيمٍ>> (was a nation [unto himself], obedient to Allah, inclining toward truth, and he was not of the polytheists, grateful for His favors. He chose him and guided him to a straight path). This refers to absolute polytheism (الشرك المطلق), the one that is unforgivable, and the one that is condemned in what was attributed to him when he said concerning the star, "This is my Lord." Among the stations of Abraham is also that he was given the argument (الحجة) against his people regarding the Oneness of Allah, and that he was grateful for His favors. He chose him (اجتباه) and guided him—meaning He granted him success by clarifying for him—to a straight path, which is the path of the Lord mentioned in the saying of Hud: <<إِنَّ رَبِّي عَلَى صِرَاطٍ مُسْتَقِيمٍ>> (Indeed, my Lord is on a straight path). Among his stations is also that he was *Hanif* (inclining toward truth), turning in all his states from Allah to Allah, based on witnessing and direct vision (*shuhud wa 'iyan*), and turning from his own self to Allah based on Allah's command and preference for the Divine Presence, according to the station in which he is placed and the vision he witnesses, and turning away from everything that should be turned away from, by Allah's command. Among his stations is also that he was *Muslim* (submissive), yielding to Allah upon every call He called him to, without hesitation. *Al-Ummah* (nation) means a teacher of goodness. We hope that the knowledge we present to people will be my share of teaching goodness, and that we may stand and be distinguished by a single matter from the side of Allah—meaning from the knowledge of Him—in which we have no partner, standing in the position of a nation due to my singularity in it. *Al-Qanit* (obedient) is one who is obedient to Allah. I hope that I am among those who obey Allah in secret and in public. Obedience only occurs in accordance with the Divine Rites (المراسم الإلهية) and commands dependent on direct address (الخطاب). I hope that I am among those whom Allah commands in their secret being, and they comply with His rites without intermediary. Among his stations is also righteousness (*Salah*). Righteousness, in our view, is the most noble station (أشرف مقام) a servant can reach and be described by in this world and the Hereafter. For righteousness is an attribute with which Allah favored those of His elect whom He described with it. It is an attribute that every prophet and messenger asks to attain. We possess a great spiritual tasting (*dhawq*) of the knowledge of it, inherited from the prophets (peace be upon them), which I have not seen possessed by others. Righteousness is a kingly, spiritual attribute. The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) said concerning it, when the servant says in the *Tashahhud*: "Peace be upon us and upon the righteous servants of Allah (عباد الله الصالحين)," it reaches every righteous servant of Allah in the heavens and the earth. Among the stations of Abraham is that Allah gave him his reward (أجره) in this world, which is the reward for conveying the message, as every prophet said: <<إِنْ أَجْرِيَ إِلَّا عَلَى اللهِ>> (My reward is only upon Allah). His reward was that Allah saved him from the Fire, making it <<بَرْداً وَسَلَاماً>> (coolness and peace) upon him. I hope from Allah that every transgression and disobedience that originated from me will have the same ruling as the Fire had for Abraham when he was thrown into it, by Allah's care, not by my action. And <<وَإِنَّهُ فِي الْآخِرَةِ لَمِنَ الصَّالِحِينَ>> (And indeed, in the Hereafter he will be among the righteous)—meaning that reward is not diminished by his having attained something of it in this world. Among the stations of Abraham is fulfillment (*Wafa'*), for he is <<الَّذِي وَفَّى>> (the one who fulfilled). I hope to be among <<الَّذِينَ يُوفُونَ بِعَهْدِ اللهِ وَلَا يَنْقُضُونَ الْمِيثَاقَ>> (those who fulfill the covenant of Allah and do not break the compact), and <<الَّذِينَ يَصِلُونَ مَا أَمَرَ اللهُ بِهِ أَنْ يُوصَلَ وَيَخْشَوْنَ رَبَّهُمْ وَيَخَافُونَ سُوءَ الْحِسَابِ>> (those who join what Allah has commanded to be joined, and fear their Lord and dread the evil of the reckoning). I always guide people to this and raise my companions upon it. I do not allow anyone who has made a covenant with Allah, while hearing me, to break it, no matter how small or great the good deed is. I do not let him abandon it based on a concession (رخصة) that appears to him, which might remove the sin, but rather he must fulfill the covenant of Allah and not break it, in order to complete the highest and most perfect station. For if the soul becomes accustomed to breaking covenants and deems it permissible, nothing good will ever come from it. All of this is part of the Station of Abraham that we were commanded to take as a place of prayer. He said: <<وَاتَّخِذُوا مِنْ مَقَامِ إِبْرَاهِيمَ مُصَلًّى>> (And take from the Station of Abraham a place of prayer)—meaning a place of supplication when you pray there, that we may supplicate for the attainment of these stations that Abraham the Intimate Friend attained, as we have established.

### (An Event of Ibn Arabi at the Station of Abraham the Intimate Friend)

In this event, I was also told: "Say to your companions: 'Seize the opportunity of my existence before my departure.'" I composed this and included this phrase, saying after I awoke:

> A discourse has come to me *** from my desired object,
> That I should speak a word *** to the people of my creed:
> "Seize the opportunity of my existence *** before my departure,"
> So that I may see with my eye *** the one who was my direction [of prayer],
> And in my existence also *** the one who was my cause,
> For I am poor *** to fill my need.
> My love is my station *** and the state is my intimate friendship.
> So His very identity is my existence *** and Gnosis is my adornment.
> I called my very self *** when it turned away,
> From the remembrance of what came to it *** and what it deemed insufficient.
> And when He disclosed Himself (تجلى) *** with the crescents,
> To the witnessing of my eye *** from behind every veil,
> He extended His Right Hand to me *** for the sake of my direction [of prayer],
> And I saw none other than myself *** since He was my totality.

I saw in this event many kinds of divine glad tidings (مبشرات إلهية) of divine proximity and indications of care and attention. I hope from Allah that He realizes this in the witnessed realm. For proper conduct (الأدب) dictates that I should say in such a case what the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) said: "If it is from Allah, He will confirm it," even though I know it is from Allah. I have never said such a thing concerning an event except that it came out clear as the morning light. In this saying, I am following and emulating the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him). This is because when he saw in a dream that Gabriel (peace be upon him) brought him Aisha wrapped in a piece of red silk and said to him, "This is your wife," when he related it to his companions, he said, "If it is from Allah, He will confirm it." He used the conditional particle due to the authority of possibility (سلطان الاحتمال) granted by the state of sleep and the Presence of Imagination (حضرة الخيال). It happened just as he saw and as he was told, and he married her afterward. I have adopted this practice for every glad tiding I see, and I have benefited from following it. I have only mentioned all this in compliance with Allah's command in His saying: <<وَأَمَّا بِنِعْمَةِ رَبِّكَ فَحَدِّثْ>> (But as for the favor of your Lord, report [it]). And what favor is greater than these divine favors that conform to the Book and the Sunnah?

### [The Water of Zamzam is a Hidden Gnosis in an Elemental Natural Form]

Then we return and say: When he finishes the *Tawaf al-Ifadah*, if he has the *Sa'y* (running), he goes out to perform the *Sa'y* as we established previously when discussing it. Otherwise, he comes to Zamzam and drinks until his ribs are full (تضلع من مائها). It is a well, and it is a hidden Gnosis (علم خفي) in an elemental natural form (صورة طبيعية عنصرية) that has been incorporated into it, by which souls are revived. It indicates pure servitude (العبودية المحضة). For the ruling of Allah the Exalted in Nature is greater than His ruling in the heavens and the earth, because both are, in our view, part of the world of Nature. From Nature appeared every body, physical structure, and corporeal entity in the upper and lower worlds of bodies.

(Chapter)

Concerning His saying, the Exalted: <<يَسْأَلُونَكَ عَنِ الْأَهِلَّةِ قُلْ هِيَ مَوَاقِيتُ لِلنَّاسِ وَالْحَجِّ>> (They ask you about the new moons. Say, "They are fixed times for the people and [for] the Hajj"). He did not say "for the pilgrim" but placed Hajj in the verse on the same level as people, not on the level of debts and sales, even though the meaning requires it. Thus, we know that the ruling of Hajj, in the sight of Allah, is not the ruling of things for which the new moons are considered—meaning the fixed times of the new moons.

### [Most of the actions of Hajj are pure devotion]

The Hajj is a specific, designated act attributed [to the human] which a person performs, like all their other acts in their sales and debts. He (Allah) took care to mention these specific acts because they are acts specifically intended for Allah, the Mighty and Majestic, in which the servant has no worldly benefit except a small amount of physical exertion. For this reason, the ruling concerning the Hajj is distinguished from other acts of worship in most of its states and actions regarding their rationale. Most of it is pure devotion (تعبد محض) for which the jurists (الفقهاء) cannot rationally grasp a meaning. Thus, in its very Essence (بذاته), it is the Reality of Wisdom (عين الحكمة), not established for a compelling rational purpose. In it is a reward (أجر) that is not found in other acts of worship, and a Divine Theophany (تجلي إلهي) that is not found in other deeds.

### [The Crescent Moon at the Beginning of the Month of Standing is Equivalent to the Number One]

The crescent moon (الهلال) at the beginning of the month of the Standing [at Arafat] (الوقوف) is equivalent to the number One (الواحد من العدد). The Theophany (تجلي) of the crescent moon on the first night is the Self-disclosure of The Real (تجلى الحق) in the servant through faith (الإيمان), which is the first thing required by the Law (الشرع) from the responsible human being (الإنسان المكلف). Faith is a spirit, and its body is the form of uttering "There is no god but Allah," which is the testimony of Unity (التوحيد). Similarly, we witness the crescent moon on the first night, and the Theophany continues to increase in the simple numbers (بسائط العدد) until it reaches the ninth night, which is the last night of the simple numbers, which are its units (آحاده). Thus, His Self-disclosure is perfected in the units of the simple numbers, and the Standing at Arafat (الوقوف بعرفة) occurs on the ninth day. Thereby, the servant attains Gnosis of Allah (معرفة الله تعالى) through the perfection of the simple numbers (البسائط). For this reason, he faces it and enters into it by stripping away sewn garments (التجريد عن المخيط), which represents composition (التركيب). Do you not see that he wears sewn garments on the tenth day, because he has moved from the units (الآحاد) to the beginning of the tens (أول العقد), which is Ten?

### [The Slipknot and the Non-Slipknot]

The knot (العقد) only occurs between two things by joining one to the other in the form of conjunction and wrapping. It is of two types, meaning the knot: the slipknot (أنشوطة) and the non-slipknot (غير أنشوطة). The slipknot quickly unravels concerning what one has been entrusted with and what one has covenanted with Allah. The non-slipknot does not quickly unravel.

### [The Twelve Levels in the Perfective Theophanies in Hajj]

After the Nine, three actions of the Hajj remain: the act of Muzdalifah, Mina, and the Circumambulation of Overflowing (طواف الإفاضة). The act specific to Muzdalifah is only from the beginning of dawn until sunrise. The staying overnight (المبيت) in Muzdalifah is not specific to it, because it is the Night of Arafat. Muzdalifah has no night of its own, but it has the staying overnight, not the night itself—like the night of Sawdah bint Zam'ah: the night belongs to her, but the staying overnight belongs to Aisha. So, Sawdah has a night without staying overnight, and Aisha has the staying overnight of Sawdah's night, not her own night. For this reason, that night is attributed to Sawdah in mention.

Similarly, three levels (مراتب) of number remain after the Ninth: Ten, One Hundred, and One Thousand. No level remains for the number beyond what I have mentioned. Likewise, after the Circumambulation of Overflowing, there is no action remaining for the pilgrim in the Hajj by which something lawful to him becomes forbidden. For by it, he has made all lawful things permissible. Nothing remains after it for the non-Meccan except the Farewell Circumambulation (طواف الوداع), because he has bid farewell to the levels of number, and composition (التركيب) remains in it infinitely. These are twelve levels that the servant has attained in the numerical perfection Theophanies (التجليات الكمالية العددية). And on the thirteenth night, the crescent moon enters into perfection. This is one of the White Nights (الليالي البيض) recommended for fasting, just as the Days of Tashriq (أيام التشريق) are recommended for breaking the fast, which the non-Meccan performing *tamattu'* (Muta'ammiq al-Afaqi) fasts.

### [The Journey from Him, Almighty, by His Emergence to Us, and the Journey to Him from Us]

The half of the month that encompasses the journey (السلوك) *from Him* by His emergence toward us has ended, and it is Him, Glory be to Him, Whom we seek. Then, in the second half of the month, we begin the journey *to Him* from us, until it ends on the Night of Concealment (ليلة السرار), which is the unseen perfection (الكمال الغيبي). Just as the first half contained the witnessed perfection (الكمال الشهادي), so [the month] is perfected in the unseen and the witnessed. The cycle turns with a second crescent moon and a different ruling, both worldly and otherworldly. For He said, describing Paradise: <<لَهُمْ رِزْقُهُمْ فِيها بُكْرَةً وعَشِيًّا>> (They will have their provision therein morning and evening), making it a locus for time (الزمان) known to the Arabs, just like the world (الدنيا).

### [The Pilgrim in Hajj Reaps the Fruits of Time and Number]

The pilgrim (الحاج) in the Hajj reaps the fruit of Time (الزمان) and the Divine Gnosis (المعارف الإلهية) contained within it, specific to the month of Dhul-Hijjah. And he reaps the fruit of Number (العدد) in the Divine Gnosis, because Number has a ruling (حكم) within it. Do you not see that He said: <<واذْكُرُوا الله في أَيَّامٍ مَعْدُوداتٍ>> (And remember Allah during a number of days)? And He said: "Indeed, Allah has ninety-nine Names, one hundred minus one." Thus, He entered under the ruling of Number through specific Names. And He said: "Indeed, Allah has three hundred dispositions (خلق)."
