Constriction is the opposite of Allah’s Mercy, even though Mercy encompassed him by bringing his entity into existence and giving him a ruling in the souls of the world, sensually and spiritually. The Exalted says: "<<وإِذا أُلْقُوا مِنْها مَكاناً ضَيِّقاً>>" (And when they are thrown into a narrow place therein). The newborn is the opposite of The Real in this matter. For The Real, when He possessed the attribute that nothing exists but Him, there was no rival, no claimant to partnership in any matter, no cause for wrath, and no need for supplication. He was independent of the worlds, existing by Himself, for Himself, in the joy of pre-eternity and the delight of perfection through Self-Sufficiency (الغنى الذاتي). Thus, Allah was, and there was nothing with Him, and He is as He ever was.

[The Example of One Who Moves from Spaciousness to Constriction]

When He brought the world into existence, this state occurred for this newborn, but in reverse. The world rivaled Him in existential entity (الوجود العيني). It was not content with that until it rivaled Him in Unity (الوحدة). It was not content with that until it attributed to Him what is unfitting for Him. Because of all this, He described Himself with Wrath toward whoever rivaled Him in everything we mentioned. Thus, He was like one who moved from spaciousness to constriction, and from joy to grief. He took retribution and punished with the attribute of Wrath, and He pardoned and overlooked with the attribute of Generosity (الكرم), and He preserved and protected with the attribute of Mercy. Thus, the reliance of existing things upon multiplicity appeared within the single entity. One relied upon something other than what another relied upon. The joy of Unity (التوحيد) and Absolute Oneness (الأحدية) vanished due to the Beautiful Names and the multiple aspects of rulings attributed to Him. The single Name no longer retained its joy. The matter returned to the Oneness of Divinity (أحدية الألوهية), which is the Oneness of Multiplicity, due to the Names it requires for the subsistence of the designation of Oneness. So He said: "<<وإِلهُكُمْ إِلهٌ واحِدٌ>>" (And your God is one God). He did not mention the relationships, the Names, or the aspects, for the seeking of Unity contradicts the seeking of Multiplicity. This matter must be so.

[The One Intending the House of Allah for Allah’s Sake]

Thus, the one intending His House for Hajj or Umrah for the sake of Allah is placed in the state of one whose mother gave birth to him, meaning he has emerged from constriction to spaciousness. He is likened to his counterpart, the newborn, and not to the description of the Exalted that we mentioned just now. However, He stipulated that he must not engage in *rafath* (foul talk/sexual intimacy), for if he engages in intercourse, he begets a child, and thus does not resemble the newborn. For when the newborn is born, he moves from spaciousness to constriction, as he acquires a partner in his wealth through the child, and his ruling becomes more determined by the child than by himself. The matter becomes constricted for him, especially if his child acts in a way that displeases him, causing him distress and tightness of the chest due to the rivalry of the second party. For this reason, it was stipulated for the visitor to the House that he should not engage in *rafath* nor commit *fusūq* (transgression), meaning he should not rebel against his Master by claiming His attributes or rivaling Him in His qualities, since *fusūq* means departure/exit.

[Being with Allah in the Thingness of Existence as in the Thingness of Establishment]

Whoever remains in the state of his existence with Allah as he was in the state of his non-existence, that is the one who has given Allah His due right. For this chronic disease, He referred him to the use of a medicine: "<<أَوَلا يَذْكُرُ الْإِنْسانُ أَنَّا خَلَقْناهُ من قَبْلُ ولَمْ يَكُ شَيْئاً>>" (Does man not remember that We created him before, when he was nothing?). He says to him: Be with Me in the *thingness* (شيئية) of your existence, just as you were when you were not existing, so that I may be as I am, and you may be as you are. Whoever uses this medicine knows the right of Allah and gives Him what is due. Whoever does not know and does not use this medicine, and mixes things up, his diseases and pains multiply within the very entity of his joys, and he incurs the wrath of The Real concerning that in which he is joyful and happy. Thus, in some of your joys lies His wrath. Be alert to the secrets in this Hadith according to this style and its likes, for it contains knowledge that would make the book too long to detail and specify.

(A Fourth Hadith on the Chapter of Arafah and Emancipation Therein)

Muslim recorded from ‘Ā’ishah, may Allah be pleased with her, that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "There is no day on which Allah emancipates more servants from the Fire than the Day of Arafah. He draws near, then boasts of them to the angels, saying: 'What did these desire?' until they say: 'Your forgiveness and Your pleasure with them.'"

[The Day of Arafah is an Intercessor with Allah for the Servants of Desires]

The Real intended to boast of them to the angels, and His question to them, "What did these desire?" is a thin veil over the intention of boasting, meant to comfort the hearts of the angels. When desertion (*ibāq*) appeared among the servants of Allah, and desires (*ahwā’*) and lusts (*shahawāt*) enslaved them, making them slaves to these things, Allah created the Fire out of Divine Jealousy (الغيرة الإلهية). The Fire became jealous for Allah and sought retribution from the servants who deserted. The report came that when a servant deserts, he has committed disbelief (*kufr*).

Disbelief is the cause of enslavement. Thus, they became slaves to desires through disbelief. The Fire sought a way to take them from the hands of desires for retribution. When the Fire deserved them and intended to inflict punishment upon them, it happened to coincide with the Day of Arafah. So the Day came as an intercessor (شفيع) with Allah for these servants, asking that they be emancipated from the ownership of the Fire, since the Fire is one of Allah’s obedient servants. Allah bestowed His generosity upon them through the intercession of that Day, and Allah emancipated their necks from the Fire, so the Fire had no power over them.

[The Purification of Hearts from Destructive Desires]

Thus, the goodness of Allah multiplied and became pure. Allah purified their hearts from *destructive* desires (الشهوات المردية), not from the *entities* of desires (أعيان الشهوات). He left the entities of desires upon them but removed their attachment to what displeases Allah. When He made them stand at Arafat, He displayed the entities of desires upon them for the angels to see. Since the angels have no desire, they are inherently obedient, and no hindrance of desire arises in them to divert them from the obedience of their Lord. Thus, the authority of the angels’ power did not appear to them, as they have no rival. They were intellects without rivalry. When the angels perceived the intellects of these servants, despite the multitude of rivals from desires, and saw the human presence filled with them, they knew that were it not for the Divine Power (القوة الإلهية) Allah granted them to repel the ruling of those destructive desires within them, they would not have been able to endure. They realized that perhaps if Allah had tested them with the desires He tested humans with, they would not have been able to repel them. Thus, their souls felt inadequate compared to them and the worship they were engaged in, and they knew that "<<أَنَّ الْقُوَّةَ لِلَّهِ جَمِيعاً>>" (Indeed, all power belongs to Allah) and that Allah has great and mighty care for them. This was Allah’s intention in boasting in this state. For this reason, The Real described Himself as drawing near (الدنو) to them, so that they might seek aid in His proximity to repel the destructive desires, without the angels perceiving it. Then Allah says to the angels—though He knows best—"What did these desire?" so that they might look at the authority of their intellects over their desires, and the refuge, supplication, and earnest prayer they were engaged in, forgetting everything besides Allah in the presence of Allah.

(A Fifth Hadith on the Pilgrim Being the Delegation of Allah)

Al-Nasā’ī recorded from Abu Hurayrah that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "The delegations (وفد) of Allah are three: the warrior, the pilgrim (الحاج), and the one performing Umrah (المعتمر)."

[Allah Has Relationships and Attributions with His Servants]

He meant the delegation that seeks Him at His House, and nowhere else, for Allah is with them wherever they are. One does not delegate to the one with whom one already is. However, Allah the Exalted has relationships (نسب) and attributions (إضافات) with His servants, as He said: "<<يَوْمَ نَحْشُرُ الْمُتَّقِينَ إِلَى الرَّحْمنِ وَفْداً>>" (The Day We will gather the righteous to the Most Merciful as a delegation). He made them the delegations of *Al-Raḥmān* (The Most Merciful), because *Al-Raḥmān* is not feared. When they were righteous, they were under the ruling of a Divine Name in which The Real manifested to them, so they feared Him. When He desired to grant them security from the state of fear they were in, He gathered them to *Al-Raḥmān*. When they arrived as a delegation to Him, He granted them security.

[The Meaning of Allah’s Delegation, If You Understand]

Similarly, their attribution to the Lord of the House occurs when they leave The Real as a successor (*khalīfa*) over their family and wealth, as established by the Sunnah regarding the traveler’s supplication. They departed from that state and adopted a Divine Name, making it their companion in their journey, as established by the Sunnah. The entity is one in all this. For this reason,

It was reported: "You are the Companion (الصاحب) in the journey and the Successor (الخليفة) over the family."

When they arrive at the House, which is the King’s palace and Presence, the Divine Name that accompanied them on the journey is veiled for them by the Name that remained with the family, which is the Name *Al-Ḥafīẓ* (The Preserver). The Lord of the House receives them and reveals His Hand to them, which they accept, and they circumambulate His House until they complete their Hajj and Umrah. In every ritual, a Divine Name receives them and hands them over from the hand of the Divine Name that accompanies them from ritual to ritual, until they return to their homes and fall under the grasp of the One they left behind with their family. This is the meaning of Allah’s delegation, if you understand.

(A Sixth Hadith: Hajj to the Kaaba is a Specific Characteristic of This Nation, the People of the Quran)

Al-Tirmidhī mentioned from Ali ibn Abi Ṭālib that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Whoever possesses provisions and a mount that can convey him to the House of Allah, yet does not perform Hajj, then it does not matter if he dies a Jew or a Christian." This is because Allah the Exalted says in His Glorious Book: "<<ولِلَّهِ عَلَى النَّاسِ حِجُّ الْبَيْتِ من اسْتَطاعَ إِلَيْهِ سَبِيلًا>>" (And [due] to Allah from the people is a pilgrimage to the House—for whoever can find thereto a way).

He said: This is a strange Hadith, and there is discussion regarding its chain of transmission.

[The People of the Book are Not Addressed by the Obligation of Hajj to the House]

Know that if the People of the Torah and the Gospel were addressed by the obligation of Hajj to this House, He would not have said to him, "it does not matter if he dies a Jew or a Christian," meaning that Allah did not call them to it. That is, whoever is in this position is not among the People of the Quran.

[The Agent Owns the Disposal of the Principal’s Wealth, Not the Wealth Itself]

The agent (*wakīl*) owns the disposal of the principal’s wealth but does not own the wealth itself. "<<وَأَنفِقُوا مِمَّا جَعَلَكُم مُّسْتَخْلَفِينَ فِيهِ>>" (And spend from that over which He has made you successors). He commanded him to spend in what He defined for him to spend in, and among what was defined for him is spending on Hajj.

[The Agent is The Real, and the Principal is the Servant]

The Agent here is The Real, and the principal is the servant. The Agent is more knowledgeable of the interests than the principal. The interest in Hajj has become manifest to him. The wealth is in the hand of the agent, and he is an agent who does not withdraw his hand from the wealth. If he gives him what he needs to perform Hajj, but he does not perform Hajj, the foolishness (*safah*) of the principal is proven. The judge then rules against him with interdiction (*ḥajr*). Thus, Islam places an interdiction upon him and joins him with the foolish. "<<أَلا إِنَّهُمْ هُمُ السُّفَهاءُ ولكِنْ لا يَعْلَمُونَ>>" (Unquestionably, they are the foolish, but they know not). If He wills, He judges him by the ruling of the Jews or the ruling of the Christians, who were not addressed by this interest. He has no share in Islam because Hajj is one of its pillars, and he was able but did not perform it. If he separates from Islam, it does not matter to which religion he returns.

(A Seventh Hadith on the Obligation of Hajj)

Muslim recorded from Abu Hurayrah that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, addressed us and said: "O people, Allah has obligated Hajj upon you, so perform Hajj." A man asked, "Is it every year, O Messenger of Allah?" He remained silent until the man repeated it three times. Then the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "If I had said yes, it would have become obligatory, and you would not have been able to do it. Leave me alone as long as I leave you alone. Those before you were destroyed only by their excessive questioning and their disagreement with their prophets. When I command you to do something, do as much of it as you can, and when I forbid you from something, abandon it."

Al-Nasā’ī recorded from the Hadith of Ibn ‘Abbās: "If I had said yes, it would have become obligatory, and then you would not have listened or obeyed. But it is only one Hajj."

[Hajj is Unique in its Oneness, so its Obligation is Not Repeated Daily or Annually]

Since it is established that the One Who obligates is One in His Divinity, and He said: "<<وإِلهُكُمْ إِلهٌ واحِدٌ>>" (And your God is one God), then He commanded the intention toward Him at His House and limited the intention, making it a single Hajj (حجة واحدة) in suitability with Oneness (الأحدية). Thus, He concluded the pillars with that with which He began, which is Oneness. He began with *Lā ilāha illā Allāh* (There is no god but Allah) and concluded with Hajj, making it singular in a lifetime. Its obligation is not repeated daily, like the repetition of the obligation of prayers, nor annually, like the repetition of the obligation of Zakat by the year and the obligation of fasting by the entry of Ramadan every year. Hajj is not like that; it is unique in its Oneness, because the Last (الآخر) in Divine matters is the very entity of the First (الأول), so it is ruled by His ruling. The text of this narration contains many rulings that would take too long to mention if we were to embark upon them. The traditions in this chapter are numerous, so let us take a portion from each Hadith according to what the Spirit (الروح) casts upon my heart by His command, or as you wish.

(An Eighth Hadith on the *Ṣarūra*)

Abu Dāwūd recorded from Ibn ‘Abbās that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "There is no *ṣarūra* (صرورة) in Islam."

In the Hadith recorded by Al-Dāraquṭnī from him, the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, forbade calling a Muslim a *ṣarūra*.

Both Hadiths are subject to discussion regarding their chain of transmission.

[A Person is in Hajj as long as He Awaits the Means Leading to Hajj]

The *ṣarūra* is one who has never performed Hajj. The Muslim is one whose Islam is established, and the Muslim’s intention must include Hajj. A person is in prayer as long as he awaits the prayer, just as he is in Hajj as long as he awaits the means leading to Hajj. Thus, he is not called a *ṣarūra*, for he is inevitably a pilgrim. If he dies, he has the reward of one who performed Hajj due to his anticipation, just as one who dies awaiting prayer is recorded as having prayed. Thus, there is no *ṣarūra* in Islam.

(A Ninth Hadith on a Woman Seeking Her Husband’s Permission for Hajj)

Al-Dāraquṭnī recorded from Ibn ‘Umar that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said concerning a woman who has a husband and wealth, and he does not permit her to perform Hajj: "It is not for her to set out except with her husband’s permission."

In the chain of this Hadith is an unknown man called Muḥammad ibn Abī Ya‘qūb al-Kirmānī, who narrated it from Ḥassān ibn Ibrāhīm al-Kirmānī. If her husband prevents her, he is among "<<الَّذِينَ يَصُدُّونَ عَنْ سَبِيلِ الله>>" (those who avert [people] from the path of Allah), provided she has a *maḥram* (unmarriageable relative) to travel with, according to us in this matter, if she is from outside Mecca. However, if she is from the people of Mecca, she does not need his permission, for she is in the place of Hajj, just as she does not seek his permission for prayer, or for fasting Ramadan, or for Islam, or for paying Zakat.

[Intending the House for Hajj and the Soul’s Intention for Gnosis of Allah]

Since Hajj is the intention toward the House as an obligation for one who has not performed Hajj, similarly, the soul’s (النفس) intention toward the Gnosis of Allah (معرفة الله) is not something it can determine by itself. For it is inherently disposed in its original creation to repel sensible and psychological harms and to attract benefits. It does not know whether engaging in the contemplation of the Gnosis of Allah brings it closer to Allah or not. In fact, it is currently harmed by engaging in this contemplation, due to the abandonment of sensual pleasures that results. Therefore, there must be someone who rules over it in this matter and permits it to contemplate, similar to the husband’s permission for the wife.

[Is the Gnosis of Allah Obligatory by Law or by Intellect?]

Some of us said that the Intellect (العقل) permits her. If the Intellect permits her to contemplate Allah based on what rational proofs provide, then knowledge of a thing, whatever it may be, is better than ignorance of it, according to every rational person. For the soul is honored by the knowledge of things over other souls, especially when it witnesses ignorant souls (in crafts and other sciences) being needy of knowledgeable souls. Thus, the rank of the honor of knowledge becomes clear to it. This is if it does not know that delving into this brings one closer to Allah and attains favor with Him. Others among us said that the husband in this matter is the Law (الشرع). If the Law permits her to delve into this, she engages in it until she attains it. She then learns from it the Oneness of her Creator, what is obligatory for Him, what is impossible for Him, and what He may do. By contemplating this, she learns that the sending of Messengers from Allah to His servants is to clarify for them what contains their salvation and felicity if they practice it or avoid it. Thus, the obligation of contemplation becomes a legal obligation (شرعا) because the Law obligated them to contemplate for the sake of its inherent establishment. This is a point of dispute among the theologians: whether the Gnosis of Allah is obligatory upon people by the Intellect or by the Law.

[Is the Husband of the Soul the Law or the Intellect?]

In any case, the husband of the soul here is either the Law, according to the Ash‘arī school, or the Intellect, according to the Mu‘tazilī school. The soul has no ruling or view in this specific disposition by way of obligation, unless it finds pleasure in it due to a love of leadership, in that it sees other souls needing what it knows and they are ignorant of. In that case, it is like the woman who has a husband but is in the place of Hajj during the time of Hajj, according to us, especially if her companion is also performing Hajj, which confirms the matter.

(A Tenth Hadith: A Woman Traveling with a Slave is a Loss)

Al-Bazzār mentioned from Ibn ‘Umar that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "A woman’s travel with her slave is a loss (ضيعة)."

There is discussion regarding its chain of transmission.

[The Soul’s Journey in Gnosis of Allah with Faith is the Height of Praise]

The soul’s (النفس) journey in the Gnosis of Allah (معرفة الله) accompanied by faith in the Law (الإيمان بالشرع) is the height of praiseworthiness and felicity. In that state, the Intellect (العقل) is among her slaves, because she is the one who rules it, commanding it to accept from the Lawgiver everything He brought concerning the Gnosis of Allah. If she travels only with her Intellect in knowing what this Lawgiver brought concerning the attributes of The Real—which her rational proof deems impossible—and she isolates herself with it without Faith, she is lost from the path of guidance and salvation. If the first journey occurred before the establishment of the Law, then the slave there is Caprice (الهوى), not the Intellect. If the soul travels in the company of her caprice, it misguides her from the path of guidance, salvation, and what contains her felicity. The Exalted said: "<<أَ فَرَأَيْتَ من اتَّخَذَ إِلهَهُ هَواهُ>>" (Have you seen he who has taken his desire as his god?). And He said: "<<وأَمَّا من خافَ مَقامَ رَبِّهِ ونَهَى النَّفْسَ عَنِ الْهَوى‏>>" (But as for he who feared the standing before his Lord and restrained the soul from [following] caprice), meaning from traveling with it. For caprice is truly her slave, as it is one of her descriptions that has no entity except through her existence. She is its owner. If she follows it, it becomes her owner, and it has neither intellect nor faith, so it throws her into destruction, and she is lost. The Lawgiver considered this in the sensible journey of the woman with her slave, making it an alert to what we have mentioned.

(An Eleventh Hadith on Matting the Hair with Honey During Iḥrām)

Abu Dāwūd recorded from Ibn ‘Umar that the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, matted his head with honey.

[Reducing the Multiplicity of Attributes and Meanings to a Single Entity]

Since hair (*sha‘r*) comes from perception (*shu‘ūr*), and matting (*talbīd*) is to stick some of it to others until it becomes like a single piece of felt, this symbolizes the human being reducing the multiplicity of attributes, Divine relationships (المناسبة الإلهية) (legally and rationally), and Beautiful Names—like the meanings established by theoretical proofs—to a single entity. As the Exalted said: "<<قُلِ ادْعُوا الله أَوِ ادْعُوا الرَّحْمنَ أَيًّا ما تَدْعُوا فَلَهُ الْأَسْماءُ الْحُسْنى‏>>" (Say, "Call upon Allah or call upon the Most Merciful. Whichever [Name] you call—to Him belong the Beautiful Names"). And He said: "<<وإِلهُكُمْ إِلهٌ واحِدٌ>>" (And your God is one God).

[The Symbolism of Honey from Among the Sciences]

Furthermore, he matted it with honey (عسل) rather than other substances like mallow, which are used for matting. This is because honey is produced by a species of animal that has a share in Revelation (الوحي), establishing a suitable connection (*munāsaba*) between it and the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, for he is one to whom revelation is sent, and the bee is one to which revelation is sent. Thus, the honey from the bee is analogous to the sciences brought by the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, from the Quran and the narrations. The Exalted said: "<<وأَوْحى‏ رَبُّكَ إِلَى النَّحْلِ>>" (And your Lord inspired the bee). Thus, the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, informed us that our reduction of the multiplicity of rulings to a single entity is not achieved through rational speculation (*naẓar ‘aqlī*), but through a Divine Gift (وهب إلهي) and a Lordly Unveiling (كشف رباني) that no doubt can penetrate. This is the meaning of matting the head with honey rather than other matting agents.

(A Twelfth Hadith: The Muhrim Does Not Circumambulate After the Arrival Tawaf Except the Farewell Tawaf)

Al-Bukhārī recorded from Ibn ‘Abbās that the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, departed from Medina—meaning during the Farewell Pilgrimage—and in the Hadith: "He did not approach the Kaaba after his circumambulation of it until he returned from Arafah."

Meaning the Arrival Tawaf (طواف القدوم).

[The Basis of Acts of Worship is Divine Stipulation]

The basis of acts of worship (العبادات) is built upon Divine Stipulation (التوقيف). Nothing should be added to them or subtracted from them. The one in the state of *iḥrām* for Hajj is like one in the state of *iḥrām* for prayer. He should only perform what has been legislated to be performed therein. Among the actions in worship, some are permissible for him to do or leave, some are encouraged, some detract from its perfection, and some invalidate it, even if it is an act of worship—like one who is required to speak while in prayer; if he speaks, the prayer is invalidated, or if he performs an action that is obligatory upon him, the performance of which invalidates the prayer. There is no disagreement among scholars that if he performs circumambulation, it does not affect his Hajj with corruption or invalidation.

[The Resemblance Between The Real and the Servant Regarding the Permissible]

Realities do not change. Supererogatory acts (التطوع) do not become obligatory. The supererogatory act is that in which the obligated person is given a choice: if he wills, he performs it, and if he wills, he leaves it. He has the choice to act or refrain. Whoever sees the refraining does not find it affecting the ruling of the supererogatory act with prohibition or dislike. Whoever sees the action does not find it affecting its ruling with obligation. This applies to all five rulings of the Law (الشرائع الخمسة). The relationship of the supererogatory act to the servant is like the relationship of Allah’s Acts to Allah: He is neither obligated to perform them nor to refrain from them. For this reason, He placed the Will (المشيئة) in that. The servant is most perfect in his description with the attribute of The Real in his disposition of the Permissible (المباح). For Lordship (الربوبية) is manifest in it, and permissibility is the station and entity of the soul (النفس) and its inclination among the five legal rulings, because Allah created it upon the form, so its ruling must be this. As for the resemblance of obligation, that only occurs in the vow (النذر) and nothing else. For The Real obligated matters upon Himself, which He mentioned to us in His Book. The one who makes a vow obligates upon himself what Allah did not obligate upon him initially. Allah only obligated the fulfillment of the vow upon the servant in proportion to the obligation He placed upon Himself. Thus, the resemblance is strong in the obligation of the vow, just as it is strong in the supererogatory act.

[The Resemblance Between The Real and the Servant Regarding Prohibition and Obligation]

As for prohibition (التحريم), the resemblance therein is the restriction of likeness. He said: "<<لَيْسَ كَمِثْلِهِ شَيْءٌ>>" (There is nothing like unto Him). Thus, He restricted the cosmos from being like Him or like His supposed likeness. This restriction itself means that He manifests in a form that accepts comparison. If the reality of the matter necessitates the negation of comparison, then we share in that, for He does not accept comparison to us, nor do we accept comparison to Him. If the reality of the matter is not so, but He chose that—meaning He stood in this station for His servants—then He has ruled upon Himself with restriction in what He has the power to do otherwise, just as He restricted us. In both cases, a type of resemblance has occurred. As for obligation (الوجوب), the image of resemblance is that He is upon what is obligatory for Him, and we are upon what is obligatory for us. He said to Abū Yazīd: "Approach Me with what is not Mine: lowliness (الذلة) and neediness (الافتقار)." For Him, Self-Sufficiency (الغني) and Might (العزة) are obligatory by virtue of His Essence (ذاته). For us, lowliness and neediness are obligatory by virtue of our essence. This is essential obligation (الوجوب الذاتي). As for obligation by a necessitating cause (الوجوب بالموجب), He obligated matters upon us initially that we did not obligate upon ourselves. He also obligated upon us by our obligating them upon ourselves, such as the vow. He obligated upon Himself to create creation initially. This was necessitated by the demand for the perfection of Knowledge and the perfection of Existence. These two demanded the creation of creation from Him, because He possessed perfection, and He saw no ruling for His perfection unless it had an attachment. So, the demand obligated upon Him that He bring into existence a form in which He could see Himself, because the thing does not see itself in itself, according to the realized ones (المحققين). Rather, it sees itself in another by itself. For this reason, Allah created the mirror (المرآة) and polished bodies so that we may see our forms in them. Every matter in which you see your form is a mirror for you.

The Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "The believer is the mirror of his brother."

So He created creation, and Existence was perfected by it, and Knowledge was perfected by it. Thus, The Real witnessed His own perfection in the perfection of Existence. This is an obligation by a necessitating cause. Thus, the resemblance occurred through obligation by a necessitating cause, just as it occurred in the other rulings.

[The Resemblance Between The Real and the Servant Regarding the Recommended and the Disliked]

The rulings of the Recommended (الندب) and the Disliked (الكراهة) are attached to the Permissible, even though there is a degree between them. The Recommended is that for which the doer is praised, but the one who leaves the action is not blamed. Its resemblance in the Divine Presence is what He bestows of favors upon His servants beyond what necessity calls for. He is praised for this, but if He does not do it, no blame is attached to Him, because necessity does not demand it, having already fulfilled its right. This is the resemblance of the Recommended. As for the resemblance of the Disliked, Allah speaks of Himself as disliking, for He

Said: "And I dislike His offense."

And He said: "<<ولا يَرْضى‏ لِعِبادِهِ الْكُفْرَ>>" (And He is not pleased with disbelief for His servants). The legislated Disliked act is that for which the one who leaves it is praised, but the one who does it is not blamed. Thus, it resembles the Recommended, but in the opposite sense. If the servant has a purpose that entails harm for him—which is most common among people—and he asks Allah to attain that purpose, but Allah does not do it for him, the servant dislikes that refusal from Allah and says, "Perhaps Allah has placed good for me in that, without my knowing it." This is His saying: "<<وعَسى‏ أَنْ تَكْرَهُوا شَيْئاً وهُوَ خَيْرٌ لَكُمْ>>" (And perhaps you dislike a thing and it is good for you). This is what does not agree with the purpose, yet it is good for you. If He did it for him, He would not blame him for it, for he would excuse himself and say, "I asked for it." This is the very resemblance between the servant and the Lord from the perspective of the Disliked.

[The World Emerged Upon the Form of The Real]

The categories of the rulings of the Law are confined within the Divine Presence and within the servant. For this reason, the Sufis say that the world (العالم) emerged upon the form of The Real (صورة الحق) in all its existential rulings. Thus, obligation (التكليف) encompassed both Presences and was directed toward both forms. If you say, "Where is the resemblance in the ignorance of some things, when there is no ignorance there?" We have already said concerning that:

> If you say, "I am none other than God, *** and He is I," then He is ignorant.
> Because I am ignorant of who I am, *** and He is I, so what shall we do?

Whoever says that He is the Manifest in the manifestations, and the manifestations are as they are, and the Manifest therein is described by knowledge of some matters and ignorance of others, this is granted to Him by the preparedness of the manifestation (المظهر) for what it is colored by. Thus, the resemblance is valid on this basis. Rather, He is He. Al-Junayd said concerning this: "The color of the water is the color of its container." End of Part Seventy-One.

<<بسم الله الرحمن الرحيم>>

(A Thirteenth Hadith: The Persistence of Scent on the Muhrim After His Iḥrām)

Muslim recorded from ‘Ā’ishah that she said: "It is as if I can see the glistening of the perfume (الطيب) in the parting of the hair of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, while he was in *iḥrām*." Al-Nasā’ī added: "After three [days], while he was in *iḥrām*."

Meaning after three nights from the start of his *iḥrām*.

[The Persistence of Scent on the Muhrim is the Persistence of the Attribute of The Real Upon Him]

Allah the Exalted is named *Al-Ṭayyib* (The Good/Pure). He, Glory be to Him, established that in certain matters and stations, one should approach Him by means of the attributes by which He named Himself. Generosity (الكرم) is one of His attributes, and He made it an attribute of proximity to Him for us. Likewise, all that The Real described Himself with. The persistence of scent (*ṭīb*) on the *muḥrim* is the persistence of the attribute of The Real upon him, since he adopted it and characterized himself with it at a time when it was permissible for him to do so. For the attributes of The Real are not adopted absolutely; rather, specific states and stations are designated for them. Understand this.

(A Fourteenth Hadith on the Muhrim Oiling Himself with Unscented Oil)

Al-Tirmidhī recorded from Farqad al-Sabakhī, from Sa‘īd ibn Jubayr, from Ibn ‘Umar, that the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, used to oil himself with oil (*zayt*) while in *iḥrām*, provided it was not scented (*al-muftat*).

Abū ‘Īsā said: *Al-Muftat* means scented. There is discussion regarding its chain of transmission because of Farqad.

[Oil is the Substance of Lights]

Oil (*Al-Zayt*) is the substance of lights (مادة الأنوار). The *muḥrim* is more deserving of it than anyone else engaged in worship, due to the multitude of rituals in Hajj. If his light (نوره) is not strong and extended by the Divine Light (النور الإلهي) that Allah deposited in oil and similar unguents for the persistence of light, he will miss much of the perception of the meanings of the rituals. Thus, oiling with oil is an alert to the Divine Sustenance (الإمداد الإلهي) for the light. The Exalted said: "<<يَكادُ زَيْتُها يُضِي‏ءُ ولَوْ لَمْ تَمْسَسْهُ نارٌ نُورٌ عَلى‏ نُورٍ>>" (Its oil would almost illuminate even if not touched by fire. Light upon Light). Thus, He made it a light: "<<يَهْدِي الله لِنُورِهِ من يَشاءُ>>" (Allah guides to His light whom He wills). Guidance only occurs through a guide, and here the guide is nothing but the oil. "<<ومَنْ لَمْ يَجْعَلِ الله لَهُ نُوراً فَما لَهُ من نُورٍ>>" (And he for whom Allah has not made light—for him there is no light). Everything that preserves the existence of light upon you, that light is made for him, and observing the origins is part of being established in knowledge and wisdom.

(A Fifteenth Hadith on a Woman Dyeing with Henna on the Night of Her Iḥrām)

Al-Dāraquṭnī mentioned from Ibn ‘Umar that he used to say: "It is from the Sunnah that a woman should rub herself with some henna on the evening of *iḥrām* and cover her head with a wash that contains no scent, and she should not enter *iḥrām* while *‘aṭl*." *Al-‘Aṭl* means devoid of adornment.

[The Real is the Most Worthy of Adornment]

In the *Ṣaḥīḥ*: "Indeed, Allah is Beautiful and loves beauty." The Real is the most worthy of adornment.

"<<خُذُوا زِينَتَكُمْ عِنْدَ كُلِّ مَسْجِدٍ>>" (Take your adornment at every masjid). He intended here to attach her to the Night of Decree (Laylat al-Qadr) among the nights, for all other nights are devoid of the adornment of the Night of Decree. Likewise, the woman when she enters *iḥrām* without adornment. Since she is commanded to cover, and in *iḥrām* she is commanded to uncover, He desired that a form of the ruling of concealment (*sitr*) remain for her during her *iḥrām*. So she dyed with henna, concealing her whiteness with the redness of the henna. Thus, it was both adornment and concealment. In this Hadith, He permitted the woman to adorn herself with the adornment of Allah, and the adornment of Allah is His Names. The woman, in consideration, is the human soul (نفس الإنسان). Whoever characterizes himself with the Names and Attributes of Allah has adorned himself with the adornment of Allah "<<الَّتِي أَخْرَجَ لِعِبادِهِ>>" (which He has produced for His servants) in His Book and upon the tongues of His Messengers, especially in the Sacred Months, and especially the month of Dhū al-Ḥijjah. By Sacred Months, I mean those in which the pilgrim may enter *iḥrām*. *Iḥrām* is entirely a state of fame/exposure, for there is no concealment in it. The reason for removing concealment and stripping oneself is that he has been made a *muḥrim* (one in *iḥrām*), forbidden from many things he used to do in his state of non-consecration. So He compensated him by removing the concealment that necessitates restriction, so that restriction is not combined with restriction (concealment and *iḥrām*).

(A Sixteenth Hadith: A Woman’s Iḥrām is in Her Face)

Al-Dāraquṭnī mentioned from Ibn ‘Umar that the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "A woman’s *iḥrām* is only in her face."

[The Origin is No Veiling and No Concealment]

This is a return to the origin (الأصل), for the origin is no veiling and no concealment. The origin is the establishment of the entity (*‘ayn*), not its existence. She has always been described by this attribute and by her acceptance of hearing the address when addressed. She is ready to accept the attribute of Existence, hastening to witness the Worshipped One (المعبود). When He said to her in her state of non-existence, "Be," she was, and she appeared by herself, and she was found unveiled in the form of her Creator, lowly in the glory of her witnessing, knowing nothing of the veil and not recognizing it.

[Man is the Most Jealous of Animals]

When the Levels (المراتب) became manifest to the Fixed Entities (الأعيان الثابتة), and Nature (الطبيعة) instilled stinginess (الشح) in the animal, and made it abundant in the reality of the human soul—due to the abundance of Intellect (*al-Aql*) and the governance of spiritual and sensory powers with which God composed him in his origination—the zealous protection (*al-Ghīra*) accompanying natural stinginess was drawn forth. Thus, the human became the most zealous of animals, because the dominion of stinginess and illusion (*al-Wahm*) is stronger in him than in others. The Intellect has, in reality, no affinity with zealous protection. This is why God created it in the human, to repel the dominion of lust (*al-Shahwa*) and caprice (*al-Hawa*), which necessitate the rule of zealous protection within him. For zealous protection arises from witnessing a similar rival who competes with him for things he seeks to acquire or already possesses—matters which, if one person obtains them, cannot be held by another. God molded him upon eagerness (*al-Ḥirṣ*) and greed (*al-Ṭamaʿ*) that everything should belong to him and be under his rule, in order to manifest the dominion of the Form (*al-Ṣūra*) upon which he was created. For it is of the nature of this Form that everything should be under its dominion. This even leads some people to unleash the rule of their zealous protection where it ought not to be unleashed, so they become zealous *over* God, His creation, and His commands. Yet, one is only commanded to be zealous *for* God, not *over* God. By this, the dominion of zealous protection reaches its full strength in the human, and it consigns him to the ignorant.

### The Perfect Intellect is created for its Lord, not for others

The Perfect Intellect (العقل الكامل) knows that it was created for its Lord, not for others. It knows by its very Essence (الذات) that the One who created it cannot be rivaled in any matter, nor opposed in any decree. Thus, it says: He is He, according to what He is in Himself, <<لَيْسَ كَمِثْلِهِ شَيْ‏ءٌ>> (There is nothing whatever like unto Him). And I am I, according to what I am in myself, and I have peers of my own kind. He has no claim upon my state except governance, and I have no claim upon His state except the acceptance of His decree. Therefore, there is neither rivalry nor zealous protection.

The human, insofar as he is rational, if he is under the dominion of his Intellect, does not feel zealous protection, because he was created only for God, and God does not feel zealous protection *over* him. If the rational person does feel zealous protection, it is only from the perspective of his faith (*Iman*), so he is zealous *for* God. This zealous protection has a specific, prescribed domain that he must not transgress.

Any zealous protection that exceeds that limit is outside the rule of the Intellect, stemming from the stinginess of Nature and the rule of caprice (*al-Hawa*). This is to the extent that some people, seeing matters permitted by the Divine Law (*al-Shar'*) find within themselves that if the authority were theirs, they would restrict and prohibit them. They thus prefer their own judgment in such matters over what God has permitted, believing their opinion to be weightier in the balance than God’s and His Messenger’s (peace and blessings be upon him) regarding this thought that occurred to them. They may even become enraged, saying, "What can I do? This is something God has permitted, so let us endure it." Thus, they endure it with aversion and resentment in their souls toward their Lord. This is a truce built upon smoke (a false peace), and it is the greatest possible lack of proper conduct (*Sū’ al-Adab*) with God. Such a person is among those whom <<أَضَلَّهُ اللهُ عَلَى عِلْمٍ>> (God has led astray knowingly). This phenomenon appeared among isolated individuals in earlier times, but today it is widespread among all people.

### The Lawgiver is God, and the Messenger is a conveyor from God

We know that the Lawgiver (*al-Shāriʿ*) is God, and that the Messenger is a person conveying God’s decree concerning what God showed him; he does not speak from his own caprice. <<إِنْ هُوَ إِلَّا وَحْيٌ يُوحَى>> (It is nothing but a revelation revealed). God says of Himself, <<وَمَا كَانَ رَبُّكَ نَسِيًّا>> (And your Lord is never forgetful), and the proof of the Intellect confirms this. God is more zealous (*ghayūr*) than His servants. He has established the Divine Laws (*al-Sharā’iʿ*) only for the realization of benefit (*al-Maṣlaḥa*) in the World (العالم). Nothing should be added to them or subtracted from them. Whenever anything is added to them, subtracted from them, or when what He established is not acted upon, the system of benefit intended by God in the Laws He revealed and the decrees He established is disrupted.

### God permitted His female servants to attend the mosques

God permitted His female servants to attend the mosques. Some people held the view that if the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) had seen the innovations introduced by women after him, he would have prevented women from the mosques, just as the women of the Children of Israel were prevented. They thus implicitly believed that God did not know that such things would occur among His servants, since He, glory be to Him, is the sole Lawgiver. They preferred their own judgment over God’s decree. This went so far that some men felt zealous protection (*ghīra*) over their wives attending the mosque. Such a man might be strong in the application of his faith (*Iman*), and his wife might love attending the mosque for prayer and possess outstanding beauty. The established report prohibiting the prevention of women from attending mosques would restrain him, causing him great distress. If you were to suppose that God referred the ruling in this matter back to this person, he would prefer his own judgment over God’s decree and prevent women from the mosques. What is permissible is like what is actual. He continued to devise stratagems against her until she voluntarily refrained from attending the mosque, and he was pleased by this. If the dominion of the Intellect (*al-Aql*) had been firmly established in this man, he would not have felt zealous protection. If the dominion of Faith (*al-Iman*) had been firmly established in him, he would have found no distress in his heart but would have patiently accepted what God decreed in the matter. The Exalted says: <<فَلَا وَرَبِّكَ لَا يُؤْمِنُونَ حَتَّى يُحَكِّمُوكَ فِيمَا شَجَرَ بَيْنَهُمْ ثُمَّ لَا يَجِدُوا فِي أَنْفُسِهِمْ حَرَجًا مِمَّا قَضَيْتَ وَيُسَلِّمُوا تَسْلِيمًا>> (But no, by your Lord, they will not believe until they make you judge concerning that which is in dispute between them, and thereafter find no distress in their souls concerning that which you decide, and submit with full submission).

### I do not feel zealous protection over God

We only presented this example in this context by specifying this report concerning women because we are discussing the issue of a woman not covering her face during the state of ritual consecration (*Iḥrām*), whereas zealous protection (*al-Ghīra*) dictates covering. It is established in the *Ṣaḥīḥ* collection that "No one is more zealous than God." The Messenger of God (peace and blessings be upon him) said concerning Saʿd, "Saʿd is zealous, and I am more zealous than Saʿd, and God is more zealous than me. And out of His zealous protection, He prohibited indecencies (*al-Fawāḥish*)."

Whoever exceeds God’s zealous protection is, in his own estimation and view, more zealous than God. Furthermore, that matter which is not an indecency (*fāḥisha*) in God’s sight—for if it were an indecency in God’s sight, He would have prohibited it, as God prohibited <<الْفَوَاحِشَ مَا ظَهَرَ مِنْهَا وَمَا بَطَنَ>> (indecencies, both open and secret)—the ruling is thus comprehensive. This person has made an indecency out of what is not an indecency in God’s sight, and has implicitly contradicted God in what He stated, claiming through the zealous protection he feels that he is wiser than God in establishing this decree. A person in this state remains tormented within himself. How excellent is the saying: <<ثُمَّ لَا يَجِدُوا فِي أَنْفُسِهِمْ حَرَجًا مِمَّا قَضَيْتَ وَيُسَلِّمُوا تَسْلِيمًا>> (and thereafter find no distress in their souls concerning that which you decide, and submit with full submission).

### The Divine Decree revealed initially and the Divine Decree requested by some of God’s servants

If a person were to examine himself and place himself in this balance, he would see himself as an unbeliever, far removed from faith (*Iman*). For God negated faith from anyone possessing this characteristic, swearing by Himself that such a person is not a believer. This is a Divine decree confirmed by an oath, as He said: <<فَلَا وَرَبِّكَ لَا يُؤْمِنُونَ>> (But no, by your Lord, they will not believe). If covering had been fundamental for her, she would not have been told during *Iḥrām* not to cover her face. Do you not see that the verse of the veil (*Ḥijāb*) was not revealed initially, but was revealed, along with others, due to the request of some creatures? Many rulings of the Divine Law were revealed due to circumstantial causes (*asbāb kawniyya*); were it not for those causes, God would not have revealed what He revealed concerning them. For this reason, the People of God (*Ahl Allāh*) distinguish between the Divine Decree revealed initially and the Divine Decree that was requested by some of God’s servants, where that request became the cause for the revelation of the decree. Thus, the Real (*al-Ḥaqq*) was, as it were, obligated in its revelation, for otherwise He would not have revealed it, unlike what He revealed initially. The realized one (*al-Muḥaqqiq*) accepts the Divine Decree revealed initially differently from the way he accepts the Divine Decree that was not revealed initially. Therefore, O seeker, do not be deceived by the fact that the Real revealed things based on the questions of the questioners. Hasten to accept His decree, whatever its nature, with an open heart and a good soul, if you wish to be a believer. As for the rational person of abundant Intellect, he is at ease with God, and the Divine Decree is at ease with him.

The Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) used to say: "Leave me alone as long as I leave you alone."

Concerning the obligation of Hajj every year, he said: "If I had said yes, it would have become obligatory, but it is only one Hajj."

He disliked and criticized excessive questioning. May God grant us and you understanding of the objectives (*Maqāṣid*) of the Divine Law, so that what is manifest of it does not veil us from what is hidden.

### The ritual of Hajj resembles people on the Day of Resurrection in their states

The ritual of Hajj resembles people on the Day of Resurrection (*Yawm al-Qiyāma*) in their states: disheveled, dusty, supplicating, hastening toward the Caller, abandoning adornment, and casting stones—the occupation of the estranged. They are engaged in a worship such that if they knew what it contained, their minds would be stunned, and they would be like madmen casting stones. God made the stoning of the pillars (*Jamārāt*) a warning to them that the scene is immense, capable of driving minds from their places. There is no worship that is pure devotion (*taʿabbud maḥḍ*) in most of its actions except Hajj. Similarly, women in the Hereafter, on the Day of Resurrection, will have uncovered faces, just as they are in the state of *Iḥrām*. Were it not for the attachment of egoistic purposes (*al-Aghrāḍ al-Nafsiyya*) in the revelation of the veil, the verse of the veil would not have been revealed. God only delayed it and other similar contingent rulings for this reason, as a reserve for the reckoning of the person who was the cause for obligating people with it. That person will wish on the Day of Resurrection that he had not been the cause of it, due to the severity placed upon him, yet people are heedless of this.

### The strict Mujtahid and the Mujtahid who prioritizes lifting hardship from the Community

Likewise, the people of independent legal reasoning (*Ijtihād*) on the Day of Resurrection will be of two types: one who prioritizes prohibition (*al-Ḥurma*), and the other who prioritizes lifting hardship (*rafʿ al-ḥaraj*) from this Community, adhering to the verse and returning to the fundamental principle (*al-Aṣl*). The latter is closer to God and holds a greater rank than the one who prioritizes prohibition, because prohibition is an accidental matter that occurred to the fundamental principle, while the one who lifts hardship is aligned with the fundamental principle. The state of people in the Gardens (of Paradise) returns to this, where they will settle in Paradise wherever they wish. How heedless are the people of caprice (*Ahl al-Ahwā’*), even if they are believers, concerning this matter! They will surely regret it. <<وَاللَّهُ يَقُولُ الْحَقَّ وَهُوَ يَهْدِي السَّبِيلَ>> (And God speaks the Truth, and He guides to the Way).

### Remedies for the disease of natural zealous protection

Existence (الوجود) is a single abode, and the Lord of the abode is One. Creation (الخلق) is God’s family, and this abode encompasses them all. Where is the veil? Is anything seen other than God? Is anything seen other than God? Does a thing veil itself from its own reality? The part of the Whole is created from its very eye. Eve was created from Adam. Women are the sisters of men. These are remedies: whoever uses them against the disease of zealous protection (*al-Ghīra*) will have his illness removed, leaving only the zealous protection of Faith (*Ghīrat al-Iman*), which is a zealous protection that does not vanish in this worldly life in the domain where its ruling is effective. Beware, O my brother, of the obsession of Nature, for the servant is being subtly deceived by it without realizing it, and how quickly disgrace comes upon him before God.

### Zealous Protection of Faith and Zealous Protection of Nature

The Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) said: "God would not forbid you from usury (*al-Ribā*) and then take it from you."

Whoever claims to feel the zealous protection of Faith (*al-Ghīra al-Īmāniyya*), the rule for him is that the matter over which he felt zealous protection when he saw it in others should not appear from him or be performed by him. If he performs it, then that is not the zealous protection of Faith, but the zealous protection of Nature and its stinginess, from which God did not protect him.

He is not successful in his zealous protection. How often this occurs! And how much we have suffered in this chapter from the veiled ones (*al-Maḥjūbīn*) when their caprices (*Ahwā’*) overcame their intellects. We are grasping their waistbands to keep them from the Fire, yet they plunge into it.

> The one who unleashes zealous protection in its proper place / Is a singular, unique, chosen individual.

> But the one who unleashes it absolutely / Is a house whose trace has been erased from him.

> The disease of zealous protection is a chronic ailment / And what God has legislated is the cure.

> So whoever uses it, or rather, whoever / Deviates from it, remains astray.

> The least of the matter is that he sees himself / Described by it and acknowledges it.

### The Messenger of God is an excellent example

One of the Companions of the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) invited the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) to a meal. The Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) said to him, "I and this one," pointing to Aisha. The man said, "No." The Prophet refused to accept his invitation until the man agreed that she could come with him. So, the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) and Aisha proceeded together, jostling playfully, toward the man’s house.

The Exalted God says: <<لَقَدْ كَانَ لَكُمْ فِي رَسُولِ اللَّهِ أُسْوَةٌ حَسَنَةٌ>> (Indeed, in the Messenger of God you have an excellent example). Where is your faith if you were to see a person of high office today—a judge, a preacher, a minister, or a ruler—doing something similar in imitation? Would you not attribute it to base morals? Yet, if this characteristic were not among the noble morals (*Makārim al-Akhlāq*), the Messenger of God (peace and blessings be upon him), who was sent to perfect noble morals, would not have done it.

The Messenger of God (peace and blessings be upon him), while delivering the Friday sermon on the pulpit, saw Al-Hasan and Al-Husayn approaching, stumbling over their garments. He could not restrain himself, so he descended from the pulpit, picked them up, brought them back up, ascended the pulpit, and resumed his sermon.

Do you think that was a deficiency in his state? No, by God, rather it was from the perfection of his Gnosis (*Maʿrifa*). For he saw with which eye he looked and upon whom he looked—a vision hidden from the blind who cannot see. These are the ones who say concerning such actions, "Did he not have an occupation with God that prevented him from such things?" Yet, by God, he (peace and blessings be upon him) was occupied with nothing but God.

### From God’s subtle deception of the Gnostics

Just as the one who lacked Gnosis said—would that she had remained silent when she heard the reciter read: <<إِنَّ أَصْحَابَ الْجَنَّةِ الْيَوْمَ فِي شُغُلٍ فَاكِهُونَ>> (Indeed, the companions of Paradise, that Day, will be busy in joyful occupation). [She said:] "Poor people of Paradise, busy in occupation, <<هُمْ وَأَزْوَاجُهُمْ>> (they and their spouses)!" O poor woman, the mention of occupation is exalted far above these people! And what has informed you of whom, or with whom, they are joyfully occupied, that you judge them to be occupied away from God? If this speaker were occupied with God, she would not have uttered this statement, because she would not attribute to them an occupation other than God until she first conceived this state in herself that she imagined in them. And when she conceived it, her witnessed reality (*Mashhūd*) at that time was nothing but that image. Thus, she is the poor one, for we realize from her words that her time was an occupation away from God, while the companions of Paradise are in the realm of possibility. She has borne witness against herself, by way of verification (*Shuhūd Taḥqīq*), that she is occupied with other than God. This is part of God’s subtle deception (*Makr Allāh al-Khafī*) of the Gnostics (*al-ʿĀrifīn*): criticizing others based on initial judgment, while implying that their own souls are purified from such things. Thus, the person of absolute zealous protection (*al-Ghīra al-Muṭlaqa*) remains perpetually in its torment, troubled in mind, and is, in God’s sight, in the very essence of remoteness, without realizing it.

(Hadith 17: The persistence of perfume on the woman in Iḥrām)

Abū Dāwūd mentioned, based on the *ḥadīth* of ʿUmar ibn Suwayd, who said: ʿĀ’isha bint Ṭalḥa narrated to me that ʿĀ’isha, the Mother of the Believers, narrated to her, saying: We used to go out with the Messenger of God (peace and blessings be upon him) to Mecca, and we would apply musk perfume to our foreheads when entering *Iḥrām*. If one of us sweated, it would run down her face, and the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) would see it and not forbid us.

### God named Himself the Good and made the good beloved to His Prophet

God named Himself the Good (*al-Ṭayyib*) and made the good (*al-Ṭayyib*) beloved to His Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him). The person in *Iḥrām* is only prevented from *newly* applying it during the rites of Hajj until the time of the Farewell Circumambulation (*Ṭawāf al-Ifāḍa*), when he uses it for exiting the state of *Iḥrām* before he is fully released, just as he used it for entering *Iḥrām* before he was consecrated. Thus, it resembles the intention (*al-Niyya*) in the act, because entering *Iḥrām* is a prescribed act, and exiting it is a prescribed act. It therefore holds the status of that without which the act is not accepted. This is a great Level (مرتبة). It is stronger than the intention in accompanying the obligated person, for the obligated person may forget the intention during the act, which impairs the form of the act, though not its essence. The act is thus deprived of what the presence of the intention completes. But the perfume (*al-Ṭayyib*), by its very nature, remains without effort, so the reward for it continues as long as it is present in him. Thus, its dominion is stronger than the intention.

The perfume (*al-Ṭayyib*) is among the perceptions of the Merciful Breaths (*al-Anfās al-Raḥmāniyya*). It repels distress, lifts worries, removes constraint and hardship, and leads to spaciousness, ease, and wandering in the Divine Gnosis (*al-Maʿārif al-Ilāhiyya*), because God is Good (*Ṭayyib*) and accepts only what is good. The good is beloved for its own sake, thus resembling Perfection (*al-Kamāl*). In a woman, it is a cause necessitating looking at her, yet the Lawgiver did not prevent her from this during her state of *Iḥrām*, despite her face being uncovered. This is the opposite of the zealous protection found among the common people, with which we have not been addressed. Therefore, adhere to the zealous protection of Faith (*al-Ghīra al-Īmāniyya*) that is prescribed by the Law, and do not exceed it, lest you suffer in this world and the Hereafter. As for this world, you will remain troubled in soul. As for the Hereafter, it leads to the Real questioning you about it, due to the resulting ill-opinion, the objection to God’s state, and the presence of aversion in the soul toward what God has permitted.

(Hadith 18: Hastening to clarify when needed and the belt of the person in Iḥrām)

Abū Dāwūd narrated from Ṣāliḥ ibn Ḥassān that the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) saw a man in *Iḥrām* wearing a belt made of a striped rope (*ḥabl abraq*). He said, "O owner of the rope, cast it off."

They use this *ḥadīth* as an argument that the person in *Iḥrām* should not wear a belt. However, the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) did not say, "Cast it off because you are in *Iḥrām*." He did not give any reason for casting it off. It is possible that it was because the man was a criminal, or it could be for another reason, such as the rope being either usurped property or resembling the *Zunnār* (belt) designated as a mark for Christians.

### Wearing a belt is derived from prudence

Know that wearing a belt (*al-Iḥtizām*) is derived from prudence (*al-Ḥazm*), which is caution in undertaking matters that lead to human happiness and the Lord’s pleasure, provided that the prudence is applied in the prescribed manner and context. If the rope is the Rope of God (*Ḥabl Allāh*), which is the means leading to the attainment of happiness, and the person wearing the belt was girding himself with the Rope of God, signifying the undertaking of difficulties and important matters, and the Prophet told him to cast it off, then that is similar to his saying: "Whoever makes this religion difficult will be overcome by it," and his saying: "Indeed, this religion is firm, so proceed gently therein."

He (peace and blessings be upon him) often commanded gentleness (*al-Rifq*) and said: "Indeed, God loves gentleness in all matters."

Prudence (*al-Ḥazm*) is the opposite of gentleness, for prudence is based on ill-opinion (*Sū’ al-Ẓann*), and we have been forbidden from ill-opinion. The matter is easier than the prudent person imagines. Prudence contradicts Gnosis (*al-Maʿrifa*), for it does not affect the decreed destiny (*al-Qadar al-Kā’in*). A difficult matter for one person becomes easy when divided among a group. Some have said:

> When the heavy burden is divided / Among the necks of creation, it becomes light upon the necks.

### The Rope of God is His Covenant and His Religion

Do you not see that the Exalted God says: <<وَاعْتَصِمُوا بِحَبْلِ اللَّهِ جَمِيعًا>> (And hold fast, all of you together, to the Rope of God)? And concerning the individual, He said: <<وَمَنْ يَعْتَصِمْ بِاللَّهِ>> (And whoever holds fast to God). And He said: <<تَعَاوَنُوا عَلَى الْبِرِّ وَالتَّقْوَى>> (Cooperate in righteousness and piety). Thus, both the individual and the group hold fast to it. When He mentioned the Rope, He commanded the group to hold fast to it so that it might be easy for them. Yet, even as a group, it might be difficult for them due to its severity, and the group might weaken before it. So, He assisted them Himself, and He mentioned nothing of Himself except what is known to be described by His Power.

The Messenger of God (peace and blessings be upon him) said: "The Hand of God is with the group."

They seek help from Him, and He helps them by having the Hand of God with them in holding fast to the Rope of God, which is His covenant and the religion legislated among us, which none of us can fulfill individually. It is achieved collectively due to the varying states of those addressed, and it must be so. For this reason, the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) considered this, as a warning to the man, and told him to cast it off. This is the consideration needed, especially for the person in *Iḥrām*, who is already restricted. By wearing the rope, he added a restriction upon a restriction. It is as if the Prophet told him: "What you are already under in terms of restriction is sufficient for you, so do not add more." How gentle he (peace and blessings be upon him) was with his Community!

### It is prudent for a man’s provision to be with him

The Messenger of God (peace and blessings be upon him) only permitted the money belt (*al-Himyan*) for the person in *Iḥrām* because it contains his provision, which God commanded him to take when intending Hajj, saying: <<وَتَزَوَّدُوا فَإِنَّ خَيْرَ الزَّادِ التَّقْوَى>> (And take provision, but the best provision is piety/fear of God). Piety (*al-Taqwā*) here refers to the provision the pilgrim takes to protect his face from begging and to dedicate himself to the worship of his Lord. This is not the commonly known piety. For this reason, He followed it immediately with His saying: <<وَاتَّقُونِ يَا أُولِي الْأَلْبَابِ>> (And fear Me, O people of understanding). Thus, He also commanded piety concerning the provision itself, alongside the piety of taking provision, which means that the provision must only come from a good source. Since the money belt is the place, container, and vessel for this provision, and he is commanded to carry it with him, he was permitted to wear it as a belt. For it is prudent (*al-Ḥazm*) that a man’s provision be with him, as that is further removed from the calamities that might befall him and destroy it.

Abū Aḥmad ibn ʿAdī al-Jurjānī mentioned, based on the *ḥadīth* of Ibn ʿAbbās, who said: The Messenger of God (peace and blessings be upon him) permitted the money belt (*al-Himyan*) for the person in *Iḥrām*. Although this *ḥadīth* is not considered sound by the People of *Ḥadīth*, it is sound according to the People of Unveiling (*Ahl al-Kashf*).

(Hadith 19: Entering Iḥrām from Al-Aqsa Mosque)

Abū Dāwūd narrated from the *ḥadīth* of Umm Salama that she heard the Messenger of God (peace and blessings be upon him) say: "Whoever enters *Iḥrām* for Hajj or ʿUmra from Al-Aqsa Mosque to the Sacred Mosque (*al-Masjid al-Ḥarām*), his past and future sins will be forgiven, and Paradise will be guaranteed for him."

There is discussion concerning its chain of transmission.

### The Level of Priority belonging to the Sacred Mosque

The mosque (*al-Masjid*) contradicts elevation (*al-Rifʿa*); it is far from it, yet it is the cause of its attainment. He (peace and blessings be upon him) said: "Whoever humbles himself for God, God elevates him."

*Al-Aqṣā* means the distant, and *al-Ḥarām* means the restricted. Thus, it is distance within proximity for the one who is in it. *Al-Aqṣā* (the Distant) relative to the Mosque is far from what those in the Sacred Mosque (al-Masjid al-Ḥarām)—the people of Mecca—are addressed with. Yet, it is not distant from its own people; rather, it is the closest. It is also distant from the Level of Priority (*al-Awaliyya*), because the House, which is the Kaaba, attained Priority. There are forty years between Al-Aqsa and the Kaaba, which is the limit of the period of wandering (*al-Tīh*) for the people of Moses, who were prevented from entering Al-Aqsa Mosque when it was in the very essence of proximity, which is the Level of Priority belonging to the Sacred Mosque. They refused to support their Prophet Moses and said to him: <<فَاذْهَبْ أَنْتَ وَرَبُّكَ فَقَاتِلَا إِنَّا هَاهُنَا قَاعِدُونَ>> (Go, you and your Lord, and fight; we will remain seated here). So, he said to them: "I am leaving you to wander in this sitting for forty years, unable to enter Jerusalem (*Bayt al-Maqdis*)." Similarly, its manifestation for worship after the Sacred Mosque did not occur until after forty years. Moses (peace be upon him) only remained with them in the wandering because he was a Messenger to them. They remained bewildered, neither in the essence of proximity to Priority nor having achieved their goal of entering Jerusalem. God only seized them based on the apparent meaning of their saying: <<إِنَّا هَاهُنَا قَاعِدُونَ>> (We will remain seated here). Beware of being among the people of Moses whose characteristic is this. Rather, be among the people of Moses who are a community that judges by the Truth and acts justly by it. Likewise, the station of Prophethood (*Maqām al-Nubuwwa*) and the station of birth (*Maqām al-Wilāda*) are separated by a temporal interval of forty years. No prophet was sent except at forty years of age, for this is the culmination of the Intellect’s firmness and the strength of its dominion, and the beginning of the weakening of Nature. He then proceeds by the rule of his Intellect for the remainder of his life, with an abundance of Intellect and a deficiency in Nature.

Thus, whoever enters *Iḥrām* from the more distant station, seeking the closer station—both of which are places of worship—the person in *Iḥrām* becomes an Isthmus (*Barzakh*) between them, and the two places of worship are its two ends. What he has not yet reached is his future sin, and what he has left behind is his past sin. Thus, what is between the two mosques is forgiven for him. *Al-Ghafr* (forgiveness) is concealment. Paradise (*al-Janna*) is guaranteed for him because it is a veil from the Fire for whoever enters it, and its essence is a veil over the fire of his desires (*Shahawāt*). The inner reality of Paradise is a burning fire, because human desire is dominant within it, and that is undoubtedly the fire of his nature. The fortunate servant remains enveloped in concealment: in the future, so that the punishment for sin does not befall him; and in the past, enveloped by the concealment of preservation and infallibility (*al-ʿIṣma*), so that sin does not befall him. He is among those for whom Paradise is guaranteed; if this is his state, he is concealed in God’s protection, and he is in Paradise even while in this world.

(Hadith 20: Al-Tanʿīm is the *Mīqāt* for the people of Mecca)

It is narrated in the *Marāsīl* of Abū Dāwūd from Ibn ʿAbbās, who said: The Messenger of God (peace and blessings be upon him) designated Al-Tanʿīm as the *Mīqāt* (point of ritual entry) for the people of Mecca.

### The people of Mecca are the closest of creation to the Priority of places of worship

How could Al-Tanʿīm not be their *Mīqāt* when they are the neighbors of God and the people of His House? They are the closest of creation to the Priority (*al-Awaliyya*) of places of worship. Thus, the Real (*al-Ḥaqq*) manifests Himself to them through His Name, the First (*al-Awwal*). This Theophany (*al-Tajallī*) occurs only for the people of the Sacred Precinct (*al-Ḥaram*), and within it, they differ according to their eligibility, being either *ʿAṣaba* (agnates) or shareholders. This Theophany does not occur for others who neighbor other houses attributed to God. Anyone who was in it and then departed is subject to the ruling of the traveler and is attributed to it, not to anything else—like the emigration (*Hijra*) of the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) and those who emigrated from it to Medina before the Conquest. God established their neighborhood status when they acquired the name of *Muhājirūn* (Emigrants). This name, however, arose due to accidental matters. The House belongs to God, based on its fundamental principle of sanctity and prohibition, according to both parties. The people of Mecca are, by fundamental principle, Meccans, the neighbors of God in His Sacred Precinct. They are Arabs who uphold the protection of the neighbor and the observance of neighborhood rights. The Real treats His servants according to the morals they have agreed upon.

> (To them creation makes pilgrimage from every side) / They say, "The servant performed Hajj," but the servant did not perform Hajj.

> None performed Hajj except the One to whom belongs the Act and the Command / And there is nothing there but God; there is none other there.

> From Him comes the abundant gift and the overflowing bounty.

### Observing the fundamental principles is the point of return

If a Meccan is outside Mecca, the designation of "people of the House" (*Ahliyya*) does not leave him, just as the designation of "neighbor" (*Jār*) does not leave the person from the horizons (*Āfāqī*) when he is in Mecca. Similarly, even though we have acquired the Divine Form (*al-Ṣūra al-Rabbāniyya*) through our creation, we are, by fundamental principle (*al-Aṣl*), servants of servitude (*ʿUbūdiyya*) in which there is no freedom; we are neither masters nor lords. Thus, observing the fundamental principles is the point of return, and to Him returns the whole affair, for He is the Origin (*al-Aṣl*). Understand this verse with a deep and informed understanding. Accidental matters that might impair the fundamental principle have no effect, for that does not impair the reality of the matter itself.

(Hadith 21: Changing the garments of Iḥrām)

Abū Dāwūd narrated from ʿIkrima that the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) changed his two garments at Al-Tanʿīm while he was in *Iḥrām*.

This is from the *Marāsīl* (reports with a missing link).

### Its consideration: Changing the state of hardship with ease

Changing the state of hardship (*al-Shidda*) with ease (*al-Rakhā’*). This refers to the one whose state is affliction (*al-Balā’*), which necessitates patience (*al-Ṣabr*) and contentment (*al-Riḍā*) from the believer because it comes from God the Exalted. Yet, you find him grateful (*shākir*) during this affliction, having treated the affliction in a way it does not deserve. (This is an issue) that our companions have also overlooked and erred in verifying and expressing, arguing for it based on what Abū Yazīd al-Bisṭāmī the Elder said:

> I desire You, not desiring You for reward / But I desire You for punishment.

> And all my aims I have attained from them / Except the delightful ecstasy of my finding in torment.

### Affliction is the presence of pain in the soul of the afflicted

Know that verified affliction (*al-Balā’ al-Muḥaqqaq*) is only the presence and existence of pain (*al-Alam*) in the soul of the afflicted person, regardless of the cause usually associated with it—such as being struck by a whip, burned by fire, wounded by iron, and similar sensory effects that cause sensory pains. Likewise, the loss of wealth, calamity concerning family and children, severe threats, and all external causes that usually necessitate psychological pains when they occur to this person—such as the two garments of *Iḥrām*, for *Iḥrām* prevents him from comfort and enjoyment. Such matters usually cause pain, so patience (*al-Ṣabr*), contentment (*al-Riḍā*), and submission (*al-Taslīm*) are legally incumbent upon the afflicted person due to the running of the Divine Decrees (*al-Aqdār*) upon him. These causes are called torment (*ʿAdhāb*), but they are not truly torment. Torment is only the existence of pain accompanying these causes, not the causes themselves.

### Delight is bliss and enjoyment

Similarly, delight (*al-Ladhdha*), which is the opposite of pain, is an attribute by which the delighted person is described, and it is bliss (*al-Naʿīm*) and enjoyment (*al-Tanaʿʿum*). It has manifest causes, which are the attainment of one's aims, whatever they may be. He enjoys their existence when they are achieved, so he is a person of enjoyment in a station of enjoyment. Such a person worships through gratitude (*al-Shukr*), not patience. The causes for the existence of delight in the delighted person are called bliss, but bliss is, in reality, only the delight existing in the soul. This includes sensory and psychological delights, and causes, like the causes of pain, that are external and established by his senses. As for the person experiencing the causes of pain, if he finds delight and enjoyment in his soul despite the presence of these causes that usually necessitate pain, patience is not incumbent upon him, for he is not a person of pain; rather, he is a person of delight, turning over in God’s blessings. Thus, gratitude is incumbent upon him for the enjoyment established within him. Conversely, when the causes of bliss are present, he may find pain accompanying them, in which case patience is incumbent upon him.

### In every calamity, there are three blessings from God upon the afflicted servant

ʿUmar ibn al-Khaṭṭāb (may God be pleased with him) said: "God never afflicted me with a calamity—meaning, a calamity befell him, i.e., a cause usually necessitating pain—such that I established myself as afflicted by it, without seeing that God had three blessings upon me in that calamity: the first blessing, that it was not in my religion; the second blessing, that it was not greater than it was; and the third blessing, the reward God promised for it, which I look forward to." Such a person is not called patient (*ṣābir*), for he is a person of multiple blessings; he is delighted by what he witnesses, so gratitude to the Benefactor is incumbent upon him. The converse is the existence of causes of delight: God blesses him with wealth, health, the birth of a child, or a new position of authority where he holds leadership, command, and prohibition. All these are causes by which souls find delight. If they are delicious foods, soft luxurious garments, and fragrant scents, he is a person of sensory delight.

### Patience with affliction and gratitude with blessing

The person experiencing these causes reflects upon the rights the Real (*al-Ḥaqq*) has over him concerning them, such as gratitude to the Benefactor and the Divine obligation therein, and what is incumbent upon him regarding wealth, children, and authority: managing all of it in the prescribed manner that brings him closer to God, and establishing balance in all of it. When this thought occurs to him—which is what God obligates him to consider—these causes, which usually bring delight, are followed by this thought that necessitates pain. Thus, pain arises in him, and he is a person of affliction (*balā’*) because he experiences pain arising from the manifestation of causes of bliss. Patience (*al-Ṣabr*) is then incumbent upon him regarding that pain, and he strives to fulfill the rights incumbent upon him in that matter, or he renounces it if the pain becomes excessive. Thus, patience only occurs in its proper place, despite the existence of its opposite causes, and gratitude only occurs in its proper place, despite the existence of its opposite causes. This is why Abū Yazīd said: "Except the delightful ecstasy of my finding in torment."

He did not intend by "torment" (*ʿAdhāb*) here the existence of pain, for pain concerning a thing is antithetical to finding delight in it, and they never coexist in one place. Rather, it is the seeking of delight when the cause of pain exists, which is a breach of custom, like the fire of Abraham (peace be upon him). It was outwardly fire, but it did not cause burning in Abraham’s body, nor did he feel pain from it; rather, it was <<بَرْدًا وَسَلَامًا>> (coolness and safety) for him. Gratitude was incumbent upon him because there was no pain requiring patience. Patience is always only with affliction (*al-Balā’*), and affliction is the existence of pain. Gratitude is always only with blessing (*al-Naʿmā’*), and bliss (*al-Naʿīm*) is the existence of delight in the locus. Gratitude from the servant only occurs concerning the designation of blessing, and patience from the servant only occurs concerning the designation of pain, which is affliction.
