### The reward of the truthful patient ones and the reward of the truthful grateful ones

Do you not see that the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) only changed his two garments of *Iḥrām* in a place called Al-Tanʿīm (The Place of Bliss)? By this, he alerted his Companions and his brethren who would come after him that when the hardship of *Iḥrām* in Hajj and the painful, harmful causes it entails reach you, look at the countless blessings of God contained within it. The sight of this will result in enjoyment (*tanʿīm*) and delight in the path you are on, because it is a cause necessitating the attainment of those noble witnessed realities (*Mashāhid*) and immense blessings. Thus, the difficulty of your path will be eased for you, and you will be among the grateful ones (*al-Shākirīn*). You will then be rewarded on the Day of Resurrection with the reward of the truthful patient ones (*al-Ṣiddīqīn al-Ṣābirīn*) and the reward of the truthful grateful ones (*al-Ṣiddīqīn al-Shākirīn*). Likewise, concerning the causes of blessing, if you view them as affliction and trial, and you fulfill their rights, you will have both rewards: the reward of the grateful and the reward of the patient. This is the meaning of the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) changing his two garments at Al-Tanʿīm while in *Iḥrām*. If he wished, he said, "Praise be to God, the Benefactor, the Favorable," and if he wished, he said, "Praise be to God in every state," due to the existence of both states with him. Know this. Do you not see his *Talbiya* (chant of Hajj): "Here I am, O God, here I am. Indeed, praise..." thus encompassing both states. Then he said, "...and the blessing is Yours," but he did not say, "and the affliction is from You," despite the apparent state of hardship and restriction, the greatest of which is his abstention from what was beloved to him, which is enjoying women.

(Hadith 22: No Hajj for one who does not speak)

Ibn al-Aʿrābī narrated from Zaynab bint Jābir al-Aḥmasiyya that the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) said to her concerning a woman who performed Hajj with her while remaining silent: "Tell her to speak, for there is no Hajj for one who does not speak." Ibn Ḥazm mentioned this *ḥadīth* with a connected chain to Zaynab in his book *Al-Muḥallā*.

### Prescribed worship requires speech with remembrance

The Exalted said: <<إِنَّا نَحْنُ نَزَّلْنَا الذِّكْرَ>> (Indeed, it is We who sent down the Remembrance), and this is speech (*Kalām*), which is a Divine Attribute (*Ṣifa Ilāhiyya*). Since you are engaged in prescribed worship, speech with remembrance (*Dhikr*) is appropriate, indeed obligatory, therein. The *ḥadīth* states that the rites of Hajj were established only for the establishment of the remembrance of God. We originated from speech, which is His saying "Be," and we were. Silence (*al-Ṣamt*) is a state of non-existence (*ʿadamiyya*), and speech is a state of existence (*wujūdiyya*). Speech has an effect, and it is called *Kalām* because it derives from *Kalm*, meaning a wound, and a wound is an effect on the body. The human is an existent being, so he should only be described by an attribute of existence, which is speech, not by an attribute of non-existence, which is silence. For the reality of the human is articulation (*al-Nuṭq*). If he remains silent, he contradicts his own state. However, God has designated a domain for silence, which is relative silence: abandoning speech concerning what does not concern one, or what is against one rather than for one.

(Hadith 23: Raising the voice with the *Talbiya* which is the proclamation of Hajj)

Al-Nasā’ī narrated from Al-Sā’ib ibn Khallād that the Messenger of God (peace and blessings be upon him) said: Gabriel (peace be upon him) came to me and said, "O Muhammad, command your Companions to raise their voices with the *Talbiya*."

### God boasts of the pilgrim to His angels

It is established by rational and transmitted proof that <<أَنَّ اللَّهَ بِكُلِّ شَيْءٍ عَلِيمٌ>> (Indeed, God is Knower of all things) and <<إِنَّهُ سَمِيعٌ قَرِيبٌ>> (Indeed, He is Hearing, Near). The Divine Law (*al-Shar'*) has confirmed this, so the believer and the Gnostic (*al-ʿĀlim*) are equal. Therefore, raising the voice with the *Talbiya* to the Divine Presence has no purpose other than that the Exalted informed us that He boasts of the pilgrim to His angels. When they raise their voices and clamor with the *Talbiya*—disheveled, dusty, hastening toward God the Exalted, for He is the Caller to them—it is greater in the sight of the angels for the boasting intended by the Real (*al-Ḥaqq*) in that matter.

### O Abraham, upon you is the call, and upon Us is the conveyance

Furthermore, it is from the souls that have departed the state of the world through death, among those who called us to the Real through the act of Hajj. It is narrated concerning Abraham the Intimate Friend (peace be upon him) that when he built the House, his Lord commanded him to ascend it and proclaim the Hajj to the people. He said, "O Lord, how far can my voice reach?" So, He revealed to him: "Upon you is the call, and upon Us is the conveyance (*al-Balāgh*)." So, Abraham (peace be upon him) called out: "O people, God has a House, so perform Hajj to it." God caused that call to be heard by His servants. Some of them responded, and some did not.

Their response was like their saying <<بَلَى>> (Yes) when He made them testify concerning themselves: <<أَلَسْتُ بِرَبِّكُمْ>> (Am I not your Lord?). They responded with a response heard by those whom the Real caused to hear it. Among them were those who hastened to respond to the Real, and they are those who <<يُسَارِعُونَ فِي الْخَيْرَاتِ>> (hasten to good deeds), and who say that Hajj is immediately obligatory for the one who is able. And among them were those who delayed their response, not hastening until after a time. These are the ones who say that Hajj, with ability, is obligatory at leisure. From that primordial moment, they decreed in this present time what they decreed concerning this, without realizing it, because the Exalted God did not inform them of that witnessed reality (*Mashhad*) when He brought them forth into the worldly life. Thus, <<هُمْ عَنِ الْآخِرَةِ هُمْ غَافِلُونَ>> (they are, concerning the Hereafter, heedless).

Furthermore, among those who responded, some repeated the response, and some did not. Whoever did not repeat it performed Hajj only once, and whoever repeated it performed Hajj according to the number of repetitions, and he has the reward of the obligatory duty for every Hajj. The Lawgiver drew attention to this by repeating the *Talbiya* in Hajj, saying: "Here I am, O God, here I am. Here I am, You have no partner, here I am. Indeed, praise and blessing are Yours, and sovereignty, You have no partner. Here I am, O God of Truth." He came with five repetitions for the proclamation of Hajj, in resemblance to the call (*Nidā’*) for the five prayers. He responds to every call because the coolness of his eye was in the prayer. What supports our view is that the proclamation of Hajj (*al-Ihlāl*) was only legislated following a prayer that is indispensable.

I saw a man in Mecca, one of its people, whose age exceeded thirty years, who had never performed Hajj, ʿUmra, or circumambulated the House. His first ʿUmra was with me, and I had instructed him on how to perform it. I was also informed of a man in Jeddah, a night’s journey from Mecca, who was over eighty years old and had never performed Hajj. I was also informed of a wealthy man from Egypt who had never even considered Hajj. He was arrested by order of the ruler of Mecca due to an incident in which it was imagined that he was the perpetrator. They brought him to the ruler of Mecca, bound in iron, to be executed. This coincided with the Day of Standing at ʿArafa. When the informer saw him, he said, "O Prince, this is not the man." So, the ruler released him and apologized. The man then performed the ritual bath and proclaimed Hajj. Thus is Divine Providence (*al-ʿInāya*).

### Those who did not respond to the Abrahamic call

As for those who did not respond to that Abrahamic call (*al-Nidā’ al-Ibrāhīmī*), they are those for whom God did not allot a share in Hajj, despite having heard. And whoever God made deaf to that call is the one who does not believe in Hajj. As for those on whose behalf Hajj is performed when they have not performed it themselves, the one who performs Hajj on their behalf receives the complete Hajj with its reward, while the one on whose behalf it is performed receives the reward of Hajj, but not the Hajj itself. He will be resurrected among the pilgrims but is not a pilgrim. This is what Unveiling (*al-Kashf*) granted.

### Raising the voice with the *Talbiya* to show the strength of the dominion of the Distant Name

For this reason, we mentioned that raising the voice with the *Talbiya* was only for boasting. As for the other meaning, concerning the rule of the Divine Names (*al-Asmā’ al-Ilāhiyya*), it relates to His Name, the Distant (*al-Baʿīd*), which is the wandering one mentioned in the Quran wherever it occurs. Only the Distant Name is called upon from the state in which the servant is called, so that he may respond to the call of the Real to the state He invites him to. Distance requires raising the voice with the *Talbiya* to demonstrate the strength of the dominion of the Distant Name, showing that it has influence over what is distant, just as the Near Name has influence, for there is no preference among the Divine Names, as we have established repeatedly. Know this. End of the Seventy-Second Part.

(In the Name of God, the Most Compassionate, the Most Merciful)

(Hadith 24: Concerning the remembrance of God before the proclamation of Hajj)

Al-Bukhārī narrated from Anas that when the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) was settled upon his riding beast at Al-Baydā’, he praised God, glorified Him, and magnified Him, then he proclaimed Hajj and ʿUmra.

### Combining the two praises is combining the two degrees

He praised God, but the form of the praise was not mentioned. This should be understood as praising God in a manner necessitated by the state of the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) in that station. For in it, he was between what pleased him and what was restricted from him, the performance of which he desired if it were permissible. From the perspective of being a person of joy due to creation responding to God’s call, he says, "Praise be to God, the Benefactor, the Favorable." And from the perspective of what was restricted and prevented from him, which he desired, he says, "Praise be to God in every state." Thus, he combined the two praises so that God might combine the two degrees (*al-Darajatayn*) for him, because he is perfect, and his reward is made complete. Similarly, the pilgrim should bring to mind both states when praising his Lord at that time, so that he combines the two praises both internally and verbally, thereby attaining both rewards. For this reason, the Companion said, "He praised God," without specifying the form.

### The Real is exalted above restriction in His disposal of His creation

As for glorification (*al-Tasbīḥ*) in that station, it is a station of restriction (*al-Taḥjīr*) and *Iḥrām*. The Real (*al-Ḥaqq*) is exalted above restriction in His disposal of His creation; He disposes of them as He wills, with no preventer or restriction upon Him. Thus, glorification was obligatory, as necessitated by the station. And whoever is due glorification is the Great One (*al-Kabīr*), exalted above being described by the state in which people find themselves at that time. Therefore, magnification (*al-Takbīr*) is indispensable. When he has given God what is due to Him, he then turns to his objective for which he was called—Hajj and ʿUmra—and proclaims Hajj and ʿUmra, as reported.

(Hadith 25: Prohibition of ʿUmra before Hajj)

Abū Dāwūd narrated from Saʿīd ibn al-Musayyab that a man from the Companions of the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) came to ʿUmar ibn al-Khaṭṭāb (may God be pleased with him) and testified that he heard the Messenger of God (peace and blessings be upon him), during the illness in which he died, forbidding ʿUmra before Hajj.

This is a *Mursal* (report with a missing link) and very weak, for the sound *aḥādīth* contradict it.

### The prohibition is that the act precedes the intention

Thus, the meaning of the word Hajj in this *ḥadīth* becomes the intention (*al-Qaṣd*), which is the *Niyya*. It is a prohibition against the act preceding the intention therein, for the intention is only legislated at the commencement of the act. ʿUmra is the visitation of the Real (*al-Ḥaqq*) in His House attributed to Him, to which He invited people to come. Whoever visits it without intention—which is called Hajj linguistically, but not legally—has not truly visited it. So, the prohibition is against the visitation before the intention, meaning the intention of visitation as an act of proximity (*Qurba*). The *ḥadīth* is sound based on this meaning.

(Hadith 26: What the pilgrim begins with upon arriving in Mecca)

Muslim narrated from ʿUrwa ibn al-Zubayr, who said: The Messenger of God (peace and blessings be upon him) performed Hajj. ʿĀ’isha (may God be pleased with her) informed me that the first thing he began with upon arriving in Mecca was performing ablution (*wuḍū’*) and then circumambulating the House.

### Circumambulation of the House is the comprehensiveness of the visitation to it

When the Exalted God invited His servants to this worship, He invited them only to His House, not to anything else, saying: <<وَلِلَّهِ عَلَى النَّاسِ حِجُّ الْبَيْتِ>> (And pilgrimage to the House is a duty owed to God by mankind). He commanded His Intimate Friend Abraham (peace be upon him) to ascend the roof of the House when he completed its construction and proclaim: "God has a House, so perform Hajj to it." When they reached the House, it was only possible to begin with circumambulation (*Ṭawāf*) around it, so as to encompass it from all its sides. Circumambulation is not performed around the mere spot unless it is restricted by a form to which the name "House" applies. Do you not see that when a part of the spot remained outside—because their funds fell short on the side of the *Ḥijr* (semi-circular wall)—they erected the wall of the *Ḥijr* for that remaining part, so that the circumambulation would only occur around a form that exceeds the mere spot? All this is so that it is not imagined that the spot itself is the objective. God the Exalted informed them that the objective is the form of the House upon this spot. Thus, the intention (*al-Qaṣd*) is directed toward the composite (*al-Majmūʿ*), not the individual part. Whenever the composite is absent, neither the intention nor the worship is valid.

### The Origin of Reliance in Existence

This is because the origin of our reliance (*Istinād*) in our Existence (وجود) is not upon the Self-Sufficient Essence (*al-Dhāt al-Ghaniyya*) merely as an Essence (الذات), but rather upon this Essence being a God (*Ilāh*). Thus, the reliance is upon the composite. For this reason, deities (*Āliha*) multiplied in the World (العالم) in different essences, according to the claim of those who made them deities, just as houses multiplied in different spots. Yet, only this specific House, for this specific gathering, is valid to be the House for this worship, even though all of them are houses on a spot. Then, when the Exalted God was characterized by zealous protection (*al-Ghīra*), and saw that the Level (*al-Martaba*) due to Him was being contested, and saw that those to whom this description and this Name were attributed—such as the celestial sphere, the angel, the mineral, the plant, the animal, and the star—had no intention or will in it, and that they will disown them on the Day of Resurrection, God fulfilled the needs of those who worshipped them, out of zealous protection, so that the dominion of this attribution might be manifest. For they did not worship them because they were stone or tree, but because they were, in their claim, a God (*Ilāh*). Thus, they worshipped the God. He saw no object of worship (*Maʿbūd*) except Himself. For this reason, on the Day of Resurrection, He only seizes them at the request of the worshipped objects, for that is among the injustices against the servants. From that perspective, God rewards them with wretchedness (*al-Shaqā’*), not from the perspective of their worship. The worship is accepted. For this reason, the ultimate outcome is mercy, despite eternal residence in Hell, for they are its people. Be aware of this.

### The fortunate Gnostics and the wretched ignorant ones

They agree with us in that we did not worship this Essence (*al-Dhāt*) because it is an Essence, but because it is a God (*Ilāh*). We truly applied the Name to its Named, so He is truly God, there is no god but He. When we attributed what is appropriate to whom it is appropriate, we were called fortunate Gnostics (*ʿUlamā’ Suʿadā’*). And those are wretched ignorant ones (*Juhalā’ Ashqiyā’*) because they applied the Name to other than the Named, and thus erred. They are worshippers of the Name, and the Named is concealed. Thus, the distinction between us and them occurred in the Abode. We inhabit an abode called Paradise (*Janna*) which has eight gates. The eighth gate is the true application of the Name to its Named. The Fire has seven gates because the eighth gate is the application of the Name to its Named, and the people of Hell did not apply it to its Named, so they were ignorant. The veil (*al-Ḥijāb*) appeared, and they saw nothing but their named object, and the Name departed from them, seeking its Named, which was taken by the One who deserved it, who is God. Thus, they knew in the Hereafter what they were ignorant of in the world, but their knowledge did not benefit them.

### The truly worshipped is God

However, the Exalted Real (*al-Ḥaqq*) observed their intention, in that they worshipped only God, not the Fixed Entities (الأعيان الثابتة). Thus, He will ultimately lead them to the comprehensiveness of Mercy, after the rights of the worshipped objects have been fulfilled from them. For this reason, He made it one of the major sins that are not forgiven. But not every polytheist (*mushrik*) [is excluded], but rather the polytheists to whom Messengers were sent, or those who did not give contemplation its due right, nor exerted independent reasoning (*Ijtihād*). For the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) informed us that the one who exerts independent reasoning, even if he errs, is rewarded. He did not specify a branch from a root, but generalized, confirming His saying: <<وَرَحْمَتِي وَسِعَتْ كُلَّ شَيْءٍ>> (And My Mercy encompasses all things), and His saying: "My Mercy preceded My Wrath."

The Balance (*al-Mīzān*) is not based on equality between the two Hands (of God), but rather on equality between the deed and the recompense. For this reason, the Balance was established. A group of the People of God (*Ahl Allāh*) erred concerning this issue of the Balance, among them Abū al-Qāsim ibn Qasī, the author of *Khalʿ al-Naʿlayn*, and those who followed him. <<وَاللَّهُ يَقُولُ الْحَقَّ وَهُوَ يَهْدِي السَّبِيلَ>> (And God speaks the Truth, and He guides to the Way).

(Hadith 27: Where the House is located relative to the circumambulator)

Al-Tirmidhī narrated from Jābir, who said: When the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) arrived in Mecca, he entered and kissed the Black Stone, then proceeded to his right, jogging three times and walking four times.

### Satan has no path on the right side

Since the Stone is the Right Hand of Allah, and the human created upon the Form (الصورة) was given a right hand, it was legislated for him that in his circumambulation (طواف) he should be between the Right Hand of Allah and his own right hand. Thus, he is supported by both powers together, and Satan finds no entry to him, because Satan has no path over the right side. He only casts [suggestions] into the heart of the servant when the servant is inclined toward the left side. Thus, the Right Hand of the Real (الحق) in the circumambulation protects the circumambulator, and since he possesses a right hand from his very creation, he remains protected. If he moves away from its alignment—which is from the boundary of the Iraqi Corner to the Yemeni Corner—the care of the House attributed to Allah protects him.

If you say: 'Allah the Exalted informed us that Iblis comes to us from the right side,' we reply: The right side that Satan intended here is not the right hand of the limb, for he does not cast [suggestions] upon the limbs, nor upon what is the left side of the limbs, nor in front of the human, nor behind him. The place of his casting is only the heart. Sometimes he casts into the heart that which corrupts the actions related to his right, his left, his back, or his front. We only mean by the right side here this specific direction. If you say: 'Does the polytheist also have this right side?' We reply: What occurred, occurred by the totality, and the totality is only for the believer. This is the meaning of His saying, the Exalted: <<وَأَمَّا إِنْ كَانَ مِنْ أَصْحَابِ الْيَمِينِ>> (But if he is of the Companions of the Right Hand), meaning the right hand of the covenant (مبايعة) which holds the pact (ميثاق), not the right hand of the limb.

(The Twenty-Eighth Hadith: Concerning Seeing Riding During the Circumambulation and the Running)

Muslim transmitted from Jabir, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, circumambulated the House and ran between Safa and Marwa on his riding beast during the Farewell Pilgrimage. The Hadith continues: Likewise, he stood at Arafat and at Muzdalifah, and he threw the pebbles, all while riding.

### The Messenger is Carried in All His States by Another, Not by Himself

This is an announcement from him, peace and blessings be upon him, that he is carried in all his states of obedience to his Lord, and that he is by another, not by himself. And whoever carried him was like a limb of his limbs in relation to him. Just as his limbs are carried for himself, limb by limb, the whole carries the part. Likewise, the human in his totality is for the one who carries him. Thus, he is a circumambulator who is not a circumambulator, a runner who is not a runner, and a stander who is not a stander. He is only named a pilgrim (حاج) by these actions, yet he is carried through them by the effort and standing of his carrier, and despite this, the action is attributed to him.

### The Real is the Agent Acting Through You, Not You

He alerts you to the reality of the matter, saying to you: even if He tells you to act, He is the Agent acting through you, not you. Then He attributes the action to you and makes the recompense for the action, not for you. However, the action is not a locus for enjoying or suffering the recompense; it must have a subject (قائم) to perform it. So let its locus be the one to whom the action is physically attributed, who is the responsible agent (مكلف). And the carrier becomes like an instrument for him. But if the carrier is Allah, the carried one, due to the manifestation of that action in him, is like an instrument for Him. This is the reverse of the first case. For this reason, he circumambulated, ran, stood, and threw [stones] while riding, so that people might see him and follow his example, and so that the People of Allah might reflect, due to their knowledge of what the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, intended by that state, despite his ability to perform these actions without riding.

(The Twenty-Ninth Hadith: Joining the Hands to the Feet in the Circumambulation)

Al-Daraqutni mentioned from Umm Kabsha that she said: "O Messenger of Allah, I vowed to circumambulate the House crawling." The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said to her: "Circumambulate on your riding beast seven times for your hands and seven times for your feet."

### The Hands for the Human are Like Wings for the Bird

The hands for the human are like wings for the bird. Just as he swims (or moves swiftly) on the earth with his feet when he walks, so too does he swim in the water with his hands if he walks in it. And despite the human walking on his feet, he seeks assistance from the movement of his hands when he walks.

### The Inner Aspect of the Human—Which is His Spirit—is an Angel of the Third Type

Since the inner aspect of the human, which is his spirit, is truly an angel from the angels of governance (تدبير)—who are the third type of angels—and Allah the Exalted informed us that the angels are possessors of wings, and He did not specify one angel over another, we know with certainty that our souls, insofar as they are angels whose station is the governance of these elemental bodies, are possessors of wings. And these natural bodies were made a veil (hijab) preventing us from perceiving them.

### Gabriel Has Six Hundred Wings

Do you not see that when Gabriel, peace be upon him, embodied himself in the form of Dihya or in the form of the Bedouin, his wings did not appear to the eye all at once? The appearance of the physical body, which is not naturally meant to have wings, ruled over the concealment of his wings, despite Gabriel having six hundred wings.

### Angels Have Wings with Which They Walk in the Air

Since they have swimming (or swift movement) by means of wings, with which they walk in the air—which is one of the four elements—just as the feet are for striving in the element of earth, He joined the hand to the feet, saying to her in this statement: "Circumambulate seven times for your spirit, because its walking is by wings"—which is his saying "for your hands"—"and seven times for your feet," because walking in the circumambulation and elsewhere is done by them. Thus, He doubled the obligation upon her because she made the walking occur with an instrument other than its proper one. Understand this.

(The Thirtieth Hadith: Concerning *Idtiba’* in the Circumambulation)

Al-Tirmidhi mentioned from Ya’la ibn Umayya that the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, circumambulated the House performing *Idtiba’* while wearing a cloak.

Abu Isa said: This is a sound and good Hadith.

### *Idtiba’* Linguistically and Symbolically

*Idtiba’* is when one end of the cloak is on your left shoulder, and the remainder is tucked under your right armpit, then passed across your chest to your left shoulder, covering it with the end. Thus, the right shoulder is uncovered and the left is covered. This is to combine the two states of concealment and Theophany (التجلي), the Unseen (الغيب) and the Witnessing (الشهود), the secret and the public.

### The Heart is the Locus of the Unseen in the Human

The concealment occurred on the side of the heart because it is the locus of the Unseen (الغيب) in the human, and from it actions appear in the world of Witnessing (عالم الشهادة), which are the limbs. Were it not for the heart’s intention to move them, no movement would appear on them. That is the effect of the Unseen upon the Witnessing, and the origin of that is from the Divine Knowledge (العلم الإلهي).

Allah’s saying in the Sacred Hadith: "If he remembers Me in himself, I remember him in Myself. If he remembers Me in a gathering, I remember him in a better gathering than theirs."

### The Hidden Divine Remembrance and the Public Remembrance

Know that He has a hidden remembrance (ذكر) which He attributes to Himself, and a public remembrance. The Essence (عين) is one, having no two faces, despite the difference in ruling. And from this Divine attribution, the World (العالم) appeared in the station of duality, so He said: <<وَمِنْ كُلِّ شَيْءٍ خَلَقْنَا زَوْجَيْنِ>> (And of every thing We created pairs). And even though He is One, He has two attributions: apparent and hidden, since He is the Manifest (الظاهر) and the Hidden (الباطن). How difficult is the Gnosis (معرفة) of Allah for the people of intellectual speculation, and how close it is for the People of Allah! May Allah make us among His People.

(The Thirty-First Hadith: Prostrating on the Stone When Kissing It)

Al-Bazzar mentioned from Ja’far ibn Abdullah ibn Uthman al-Makhzumi, who said: I saw Muhammad ibn Abbad ibn Ja’far kiss the Stone, then prostrate upon it. I asked: "What is this?" He said: "I saw your maternal uncle Ibn Abbas kiss the Stone, then prostrate upon it." And he said: "I saw Umar kiss it and prostrate upon it." And he said: "I saw the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, kiss it and prostrate upon it."

### The Reason for Kissing the Stone and Prostrating Upon It

Since the Stone is earthly, and Allah made the earth submissive (ذلول)—which is a word of exaggeration in submission, for *fa’ūl* is one of the forms of exaggeration in the Arabic language, as the poet said:

*A striker with the sword’s blade of their fat shanks*

The exaggeration in submission was granted because the submissive ones, who are the servants of Allah, were commanded to walk upon <<مَنَاكِبِهَا>> (its shoulders), meaning upon it. So, that which the submissive one treads upon is described with greater exaggeration in submission than that which treads upon it. Just as Allah mended the brokenness of the earth resulting from this submission by legislating prostration upon it with the faces, which are the noblest part of the human exterior, and the Stone is from the earth, it was accompanied by that brokenness because it separated from the earth, which is the locus of prostration for foreheads and faces, by which its brokenness is mended. So, prostration upon the Stone was legislated, despite its separation from the earth, in a state of brokenness. Thus, it received its share of mending through this prostration, because it is a stone that is cared for and kissed because it is a Right Hand attributed to Allah. Its kissing is for the covenant (mubaya'a): <<إِنَّ الَّذِينَ يُبَايِعُونَكَ إِنَّمَا يُبَايِعُونَ اللَّهَ>> (Indeed, those who pledge allegiance to you are actually pledging allegiance to Allah). This is the reason for prostrating upon it.

(The Thirty-Second Hadith: The Blackness of the Black Stone)

Al-Tirmidhi mentioned from Ibn Abbas that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "The Black Stone descended from Paradise, and it was whiter than milk, but the errors of the Children of Adam blackened it."

Abu Isa said: This is a sound and good Hadith.

### Were it not for his error, his Lordship would not have appeared

Were it not for the error of Adam, peace be upon him, his lordship (سيادة) in the world would not have appeared. It is that which blackened him and bequeathed him the Election (الاجتباء). He did not leave Paradise because of his error except for his lordship to appear. Likewise, when the Black Stone emerged, it was white, so there must be an effect that appears upon it when it returns to Paradise, distinguishing it from its peers, so that the robe of Divine Proximity (تقريب) appears upon it. So Allah caused it to descend to the level of the Divine Right Hand, with which Allah kneaded the clay of Adam when He created him. So the errors of the Children of Adam blackened it, meaning they made it a lord (sayyid) by their kissing it, for there is no color that indicates lordship except the black color. So Allah clothed it in the color of blackness so that it might be known that His son had made it a lord by this descent into the world, just as Adam was made a lord. Thus, his descent was a descent of vicegerency (خلافة), not a descent of distance. Its blackness was attributed to the errors of the Children of Adam, just as election and lordship were attained by Adam through his error. That is, because of the errors of the Children of Adam, they were commanded to prostrate upon this Stone, kiss it, and seek blessing from it, so that this might be an expiation for their errors. Thus, its lordship appeared because of that. This is the meaning of "the errors of the Children of Adam blackened it"—meaning they made it a lord—and the black color was made an indication of this meaning. Thus, it is praise, not blame, regarding the Children of Adam. Do you not see that Allah first mentioned to the angels only Adam’s vicegerency (خلافة) on earth, and He did not expose the angels? But when what appeared from the angels regarding Adam appeared, that preference for themselves and their being more worthy than Adam of that position arose from them, and they preferred their own view over Allah’s Knowledge (علم). This stood for them in the place of the errors of the Children of Adam, and it became the cause of Adam’s lordship over the angels, so they were commanded to prostrate to him so that his lordship over them might be established.

### The Rational Person Does Not Object to Allah in What He Executes Through His Servants

The fortunate one is he who is admonished by others. The rational person among us does not object to Allah in what He executes through His servants, such as appointing one who rules by his own desires and does not act among his subjects according to what was legislated for him. For Allah has wisdom and governance in that. Indeed, Allah commanded hearing and obedience, and that we should not dispute the authority with those who possess it, since Allah has appointed him for that authority. If he is just, it is for us and for him; if he is tyrannical, it is for us and against him. In both states, it is for us, so we are the fortunate ones. We do not care after that what He does with His creation, if Allah has established fortune for us. If we speak against our rulers and kings concerning their tyranny, what is for us in their tyranny is forfeited, and we show ill manners toward Allah, since we preferred our own view over His Act in that. For what is for us in their tyranny is undoubtedly a share in the Hereafter, and we have deprived ourselves of it. Whoever deprives himself of the reward of the Hereafter is among the losers. And what is for us when they are just is a worldly share, and the world is perishable. We rejoiced and preferred the worldly share over the share of the Hereafter without realizing it, due to the dominance of heedlessness over us. By this action, we were among those who desired the harvest of the world. Likewise, His saying that if they are just, they have a share in the Hereafter, but they renounce it through their tyranny, so the consequence of that tyranny returns upon them. The Muslim is he who submits, entrusts, and sees that all affairs are in the Hand of Allah. He does not object except in what he is commanded to object to, so his objection is an act of worship. If he remains silent in a place of objection, his ruling is like that of one who objects in a place of silence. May Allah make us among the well-mannered and refined ones who judge <<بِالْحَقِّ وَبِهِ يَعْدِلُونَ>> (with the truth and by it they are just).

### Incidents of Ibn Arabi and Communications in His Secret

An incident occurred in which it was said to me—and it has a relevance to this Hadith—what is known of Allah and what is unknown. So I said:

> Knowledge of Allah is my religion, by which I profess faith,
> And ignorance of the Essence (عين) is my faith and my affirmation of Unity (توحيد).

I was told: "You have spoken truly. This is His saying, the Exalted: <<وَيُحَذِّرُكُمُ اللَّهُ نَفْسَهُ>> (And Allah warns you of Himself). So what do you have concerning His Theophany (تجلي)?" I replied:

> In every Theophany (تجلي) I see Him when I witness Him,
> Between the form of transcendence (تنزيه) and limitation (تحديد).

I was told: "Glory be to Him who transcends transcendence by similitude (تشبيه) and transcends similitude by transcendence." Abu Sa'id al-Kharraz was asked: "By what did you know Allah?" He replied: "By His combining the two opposites," meaning in His description. Then he recited: <<هُوَ الْأَوَّلُ وَالْآخِرُ وَالظَّاهِرُ وَالْبَاطِنُ>> (He is the First and the Last, the Manifest and the Hidden).

I had a boil on my leg from which I was suffering intense pain. In that state, the witnessing (شهود) of the Exalted overcame me, so I said:

> I saw Him in my boil,
> So I said: 'A chronic disease.'
> No rest is hoped for, nor
> Harm. Say, what should I do?

I was told: "Submit." So I said: "What an excellent Teacher." And I submitted and did not speak.

> I saw this incident,
> Comprehensive of all knowledge.
> I have not seen its like,
> Among beneficial knowledge.

And I was addressed in my secret concerning matters that I cannot disclose, nor is their nature confusing to me. However, the Theophany (التجلي) to humankind occurs only through forms, and the Divine Act in the sight occurs when the gaze is fixed. You have known, so adhere to it.

(The Thirty-Third Hadith: The Stone’s Testimony on the Day of Resurrection)

Al-Tirmidhi mentioned from Ibn Abbas that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said concerning the Stone: "By Allah, Allah will raise it on the Day of Resurrection, and it will have two eyes with which it sees and a tongue with which it speaks, testifying against whoever received it rightfully."

### One of the Most Astonishing Things in the Quran is for *‘Ala* [على] to Mean *Lām* [ل]

This is one of the most astonishing things in the Quran: for *‘ala* (على) to mean *lām* (ل). Allah the Exalted said: <<وَمَا ذُبِحَ عَلَى النُّصُبِ>> (And what was sacrificed upon the stone altars), meaning *for* the altars. This is because the testimony *against* you is only concerning what you do not approve of, for if the one testified against confessed, no testimony would be given against him, and he only denies what he expects harm from confessing. Thus, *‘ala* here, in our view, retains its original meaning. Likewise, every particle retains its original meaning and is not diverted to a meaning other than its primary one except by contextual evidence. Similarly, those who diverted *‘ala* here from its original meaning and made it mean *lām* used the contextual evidence that the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, only intended by this saying to magnify the act of receiving it for our benefit, and that there is great good for us in doing so with faith. This is His saying "rightfully" (بحق) in their view, meaning by a legislated right, because it is the Right Hand of Allah appointed for kissing and receiving. In the receiving of every nation that possesses this faith, it is done rightfully. For this reason, He made His saying "rightfully" indefinite (نكر) and did not bring it as definite. Allah the Exalted said: <<لِكُلٍّ جَعَلْنَا مِنْكُمْ شِرْعَةً وَمِنْهَاجًا>> (For each of you We prescribed a law and a method). So, it came indefinitely. All laws (shara’i’) are truth (haqq). So, whoever receives it rightfully, whatever right it may be, in whatever religion it may be, falls under this ruling of the Stone’s testimony by faith.

### There is Nothing Existing Except that the Real Accompanies It

As for retaining *‘ala* in its original meaning, which is preferable, the Real (الحق) here, even though it is indefinite, is definite in meaning. It was made indefinite only because of its permeation (سريان) in everything. There is nothing existing or qualified by Existence (الوجود) except that the Real accompanies it, as He said: <<وَهُوَ مَعَكُمْ أَيْنَ مَا كُنْتُمْ>> (And He is with you wherever you are). So, wherever we are, the Real is with us, a transcendent existential being (كينونية وجودية) as befits Him, and we are an existential matter. Falsehood (الباطل) is non-existence, and the Real is Existence.

### It is Proper for Us to Kiss the Stone with Our Servitude

Since the Stone was made the Right Hand of Allah and the locus of receiving and kissing, it is proper for us to kiss it with our servitude (عبودية), and we should not bring to mind during the kissing that the Real is our hearing, our sight, and the Agent acting through us. For if this is our witnessing (مشهد), then the Real is receiving His own Right Hand, and He only receives by the Right Hand, and the Right Hand is the Stone, and a thing does not receive itself. Adam, peace be upon him, chose the Right Hand of his Lord, despite knowing that both Hands of his Lord are blessed Right Hands, yet he inclined toward choosing the Right Hand. When the servant wishes to reap the fruit of the planting of the receiving on the Day of Resurrection, it will be said to him: "You did not receive it; rather, the Real received His Hand with His Hand." Then the Stone will be brought, and it will be said to it: "Do you know this one?" It will say: "Yes." It will be asked: "What do you testify concerning his receiving you?" It will say: "He received me by You, not by his servitude." Then it will be said to the servant: "You have learned by this testimony that the receiving was not by you, but by the Real." At that point, the testimony will be against the human, not for the human, so he will not attain what he seeks. Thus, the Lawgiver informed us of the reality of the matter so that we might receive it out of servitude and necessity, being obligated to do so as pure devotion, just as Umar ibn al-Khattab did.

### The Prophet Pledged Allegiance to Himself in the Pledge of Ridwan

If you say: "The Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, pledged allegiance to himself in the Pledge of Ridwan (بيعة الرضوان), placing his hand upon his hand and taking his hand with his hand, saying: 'This is on behalf of Uthman,' since Uthman was absent from that pledge. Likewise, when the servant receives it rightfully, the Real receives His Right Hand with His Hand, and that receiving is on behalf of this servant who received it rightfully, so he reaps its fruit, just as he said: 'This is on behalf of Uthman.' And the excuse for this servant is that the witnessing of the state (مشهد الحال) overcame him, such that he witnessed only Allah in the essences (أعيان) of all existing things."

We reply: The difference between the two cases is that the suitability between the two examples is sound, and the common factor between the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, and Uthman is humanity, which is the reality of creation and servitude (عبودية). Thus, representation (niyaba) was permissible, and each could stand in the place of the other. The second difference is that the Hand to which they pledged allegiance was the Hand of Allah, and they pledged allegiance to it with their hands. Here, the received object is the Right Hand of Allah, and the receiver is also the Hand of Allah, and there is no suitability between Allah and His creation. But there, the suitability exists.

### The Great Ones Receive the Stone in Two Ways: By the Real and By Their Servitude

If it is said: "The suitability here is His creation upon the Form (الصورة), and for this reason, it is valid for him to be characterized by the Divine Names," we reply: We do not deny the Form, nor do we deny the characterization. However, He attributed the receiving here to the servant and made his receiving rightful (بحق), and there is nothing there but the receiving, and it is rightful. So, he received nothing but the Real. And the Form here is certainly not the Essence (عين) of the Real, for if it were the Essence of the Real, He would not have said, "He created Adam upon His Form." And here, the Real was his hearing, his sight, and his hand. So here, He is the very Essence (عين) of the Real in terms of being the hearer, the seer, and the agent of whatever action occurred. He is the very Essence of the Attribute that has the ruling, the effect, and the state in the cosmos. So choose by which state you receive it when you receive it. Despite this, all states are good, but there is a clear difference between them. Diverting *‘ala* from its original meaning in this context is more appropriate for generality, and retaining it in its original meaning is more appropriate for specificity. The great ones among us receive it in both ways: they receive it rightfully (بحق) and they receive it by servitude (عبودية). Thus, they combine the two attributes and receive two rewards, so it is for them and against them, just as the path leads from Him and to Him.

(The Thirty-Fourth Hadith: Praying Behind the Station)

Abu Dawud transmitted from Abdullah ibn Abi Awfa that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, performed *Umrah*, circumambulated the House, and prayed behind the Station (Maqam).

### Taking the Station of Abraham as a Place of Prayer

Since Allah commanded us to take the Station of Abraham (مقام إبراهيم) as a place of prayer, and its symbolic consideration has passed, we placed it before us so that we might witness it and not be heedless of it during our prayer. Its witnessing reminds us to ask Allah to attain this station if we are not in it, and if we are in it, its witnessing reminds us to ask Allah for its permanence upon us and our subsistence (بقاء) within it. In both cases, we must be behind it, lest we be among those who cast it behind their backs and did not remember it due to not witnessing it.

(The Thirty-Fifth Hadith: Marking the Camels and Garlanding Them with Sandals and Wool)

Muslim transmitted from Ibn Abbas, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, prayed the noon prayer at Dhul Hulaifah, then called for his she-camel, marked her on the right side of her hump, wiped the blood from her, garlanded her with two sandals, and then mounted his riding beast.

### Devilry is a Quality of Distance from Allah’s Mercy

Know that the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, mentioned that camels are devils, and he made this the reason for prohibiting prayer in their resting places. Devilry (شيطنة) is a quality of distance from Allah’s Mercy, not from Allah, for everything is in the grasp of Allah and under the Eye of Allah. Marking (*ish’ar*) is an announcement. The righteous have no path against them. Rather, the call to Allah is directed toward those who are not with Him in the quality to which they are called. Intercession (shafa’a) only occurs for those who have committed a major sin that stands between them and their happiness. And there is nothing more distant than the devils among humans and jinn. The sacrificial gift (*hady*) is distant from the one to whom it is gifted because it is in the ownership of the one who gifts it, so it is described by distance.

### Returning the One Who Has Fled from Allah’s Door to Allah

The one who seeks proximity to Allah among the people who call to Allah does not do so with anything more worthy than returning the one who has fled from Allah’s door and become distant, back to Allah, so that he may attain Allah’s Mercy. For the Messengers were only sent with the affirmation of Unity (توحيد) to the polytheists, who are the most distant of creation from Allah, in order to return them to Allah and drive them to the locus of Proximity (قرب) and the Presence of Mercy. For this reason, the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, offered the camels as sacrificial gifts, despite mentioning that they are devils, so that it might be established among those who know him that his station, peace and blessings be upon him, is the returning of those distant from Allah to the state of Proximity.

### The Abode of the Hereafter is for Those Who Do Not Desire Exaltation on Earth

Then he marked them on their right hump, and the hump is the highest part of them. This represents the arrogance (كبرياء) that they possessed in their souls. This was an announcement from the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, to us that he came upon them in this state so that we might avoid it, for Allah only made the Abode of the Hereafter <<لِلَّذِينَ لَا يُرِيدُونَ عُلُوًّا فِي الْأَرْضِ>> (for those who do not desire exaltation on the earth). And the hump is exaltation. The marking occurred on the right side of the hump, for the right side is the locus of power and strength, and the side (*safha*) is from the word *safh* (forgiveness), announcing that Allah forgives the one who possesses this quality if he seeks proximity to Allah and removes himself from the arrogance that caused his distance, because he <<أَبَى وَاسْتَكْبَرَ>> (refused and was arrogant).

### The Indication of Removing Arrogance in the Devilry of the Camels

The Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, made the indication of removing arrogance in the devilry of the camels by placing sandals around their necks, since only people of humiliation and lowliness are struck with sandals. When one is in this state, no perceptible arrogance remains in him. He hung the sandals in garlands of wool (*‘ihn*) so that one might remember what Allah intended by His saying: <<وَتَكُونُ الْجِبَالُ كَالْعِهْنِ>> (And the mountains will be like carded wool). If this is its quality, it becomes an offering (قربان) of proximity to Allah. Thus, it attained proximity after being described by distance, since it was a devil. If even the devils have attained mercy, what do you think of the People of Islam?

### The Prophet Was Sent to the Monotheists and the Polytheists in Two Ways

Furthermore, the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, was also sent to the monotheists (موحدين) so that they might testify to their affirmation of Unity (توحيد) in a manner of proximity that the intellect cannot grasp—I mean, cannot grasp this proximity except through the Law (Shar’). Thus, his mission to the polytheist and the monotheist is realized in two ways. The polytheist, who is the arrogant devil, was called to the very Essence of Proximity, as we mentioned, and he accepted the offering. And the quality of distance that was in him was removed by the marking and the garlanding of sandals, as we mentioned.

### The Example of Bringing the Monotheists Near

Then the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, drew attention to the station of his call to the monotheists, where he called them to utter it as an act of proximity, though they had no knowledge of that. He once offered sheep to the House, and sheep are among the pure animals in whose resting places we are permitted to pray. This was the example of bringing the monotheists near.

Muslim transmitted from Aisha, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, offered sheep to the House and garlanded them.

The garlanding of the sheep means: this is the quality that necessitated proximity for them, that they should be an offering (قربان).

(The Thirty-Sixth Hadith: The Day of Sacrifice is the Day of the Greater Pilgrimage)

Abu Dawud mentioned from Ibn Umar that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, stood on the Day of Sacrifice between the Jamarat during the Pilgrimage he performed, and he asked: "What day is this?" They replied: "This is the Day of Sacrifice." He said: "This is the Day of the Greater Pilgrimage (الحج الأكبر)."

Meaning the day that Allah named in His saying: <<وَأَذَانٌ مِنَ اللَّهِ وَرَسُولِهِ إِلَى النَّاسِ يَوْمَ الْحَجِّ الْأَكْبَرِ>> (And an announcement from Allah and His Messenger to the people on the Day of the Greater Pilgrimage).

### The Day of the Greater Pilgrimage is the Day the Entire Assembly of Pilgrims Gathers

It was named the Day of the Greater Pilgrimage at that time because it was the day the entire assembly of pilgrims gathered. For some people stood at Arafat, and the Hums stood at Muzdalifah, so they were separated. But when the Day of Mina came, the people who stood at Muzdalifah and Arafat gathered in it, so it was the Day of the Greater Pilgrimage due to the gathering of all in it. When this name was retained for it after all standing (wuqūf) became restricted to Arafat, a new meaning arose for it in Islam, to which the Lawgiver drew attention. For this reason, the circumambulation of departure (*Tawaf al-Ifadah*) was legislated on this day. On this day, he exited his state of ritual consecration (ihram), even though he was still engaged in the Pilgrimage until he finished the Days of Mina. When he exited his state of ihram on this day, the restriction (tahjir) he had been bound by in this worship was removed, and everything that had been forbidden to him was made permissible.

### The Day of the Greater Pilgrimage: His Exiting Ihram is Worship, and His Entering Ihram is Worship

He exited the state of complete permissibility (al-hill al-kull) on this day, and his exiting ihram was worship, just as his entering ihram was worship. The name of Pilgrimage (Hajj) did not leave him because of the remaining ritual of throwing the pebbles. Thus, it was the Day of the Greater Pilgrimage for this release and permissibility. The Days of Mina were days of eating, drinking, and marital relations. Whoever desires the virtue of this day should perform the *Tawaf al-Ifadah* in it and exit the state of complete permissibility. If he does not do so, he is not among the people of the Greater Pilgrimage. So, let Satan not overcome you concerning the virtue of this day, by which you are distinguished among its people. It is the Day of Sacrifice, the slaughtering of the camels, their acceptance as offerings, and the return of their benefit to us through eating their meat, the great reward for slaughtering them, and giving their meat in charity.

(The Thirty-Seventh Hadith: Slaughtering the Camels Standing)

Abu Dawud transmitted from Abu al-Zubayr, from Jabir, from Abd al-Rahman ibn Sabit, that the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, and his Companions used to slaughter the camel with its left foreleg tied, standing on the rest of its legs.

### Witnessing the One Who Stands Over Every Soul for What It Has Earned

As a sign, since sacrificing them is an offering (قربة), He intended suitability in the manner of their sacrifice in oddness (وترية), so He made them stand on three legs, for Allah is Odd (وتر) and loves the Odd. Three is the first of the odd numbers, so it holds the first of the Levels (المراتب) in that, and the Primordiality is also odd. He made it standing because Sustaining (قيومية), like oddness, is a Divine Attribute. He is the Sustainer, the Exalted: <<عَلَى كُلِّ نَفْسٍ بِمَا كَسَبَتْ>> (Over every soul for what it has earned). Thus, the one who slaughters it remembers by its standing that the slaughtering is an earning for him, and he witnesses the One Who Stands Over every soul for what it has earned.

### The Rites Were Legislated Only for Establishing the Remembrance of Allah

It is confirmed that the rites (مناسك) were legislated only for establishing the remembrance of Allah. This is one of the rites of the Pilgrimage—I mean the manner of slaughtering—so one remembers Allah by this attribute. He paired the two legs because of His saying: <<الْتَفَّتِ السَّاقُ بِالسَّاقِ>> (The leg is joined with the leg), which is the meeting of the affairs of the world and the Hereafter. He made the right hand of the camel singular so that it relies only on the oddness of Power (اقتدار). The pair (shaf’) and the odd (witr): the camel stands rightfully due to its creation with the pairing of its two legs and the oddness of its hand. Thus, one remembers Allah by this attribute, and that standing is only valid for things upon an odd state that combines pairing and oddness, and this is the first state in which this combination appears, and it is only the number three. And the camel cannot stand except on three legs.

### All Acts of Pilgrimage Are Valid Only from One Who is Standing

The tying was on the left hand because it is devoid of the strength that the right hand possesses, and standing is only achieved by the strongest part for reliance. He said concerning the prayer: "Establish the prayer," and He said: "The prayer has been established," informing of the past before the servant stands for it. He intended the standing of Allah’s prayer upon the servant so that the servant might stand for the prayer and establish its creation by his standing. The Exalted said: <<هُوَ الَّذِي يُصَلِّي عَلَيْكُمْ>> (It is He who confers blessing upon you). This is what is referred to by the saying: "The prayer has been established." Standing is considered in acts of worship, including the standing on the Day of Arafat, at Muzdalifah, and when throwing the pebbles. All acts of Pilgrimage are valid only from one who is standing.

(The Thirty-Eighth Hadith: All of Mina is a Place of Sacrifice)

Muslim transmitted in the Hadith of Jabir that the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "All of Mina is a place of sacrifice."

### Whoever Reaches the Legislated Wish [Munā] Has Reached the Goal

We have said that Mina (منى) comes from reaching the wish (أمنية). Whoever reaches the legislated wish has reached the goal. He made it a locus for offerings (قرابين), which is the destruction of spirits governing animal bodies so that human bodies may be nourished by them. Their spirits look upon them in the state of their separation, and they are governed by a human spirit after having been governed by a camel, cow, or sheep spirit. This is a subtle matter that only those whose insight Allah has illuminated among the People of Allah have grasped. It is contained in His saying, the Exalted: <<وَإِذْ أَخَذَ رَبُّكَ مِنْ بَنِي آدَمَ مِنْ ظُهُورِهِمْ ذُرِّيَّتَهُمْ وَأَشْهَدَهُمْ عَلَى أَنْفُسِهِمْ>> (And [mention] when your Lord took from the children of Adam—from their loins—their descendants and made them testify concerning themselves). They were in a state of separation in the stages of creation. Allah distinguishes the parts of every totality, and they are specified in the view of their governing spirits in every state they are in, whether of gathering or separation. The names change upon them according to their specific temperament in that gathering.

### Those Who Affirm Transmigration [Tanasukh] Slipped, Went Astray, and Led Others Astray

From this point, a breath (نفحة) blew upon those who affirm transmigration (تناسخ), but they did not realize its true meaning, so they slipped, went astray, and led others astray. This is because they looked at it from the perspective of their thoughts, so they missed the path and erred. They are mistaken, not disbelievers, except for those among them who deny the Resurrection, which is the creation of the Hereafter; such a one is joined with the disbelievers. The governing spirits do not change as the forms change, because they do not accept change due to their oneness (أحدية). Rather, what accepts change is the compound of bodies and physical forms, whether sensory or in the Isthmus (برزخ).

### Joining the Lower to the Higher and the Union of the Distant with the Near

Part of reaching the wish (منى) is joining the lower to the higher and the union of the distant with the near.

> Some of them embodied themselves for me on earth,
> And some of them embodied themselves in the air.
> Some of them embodied themselves where we were,
> And some of them embodied themselves in the heaven.
> They inform us, and we inform them with knowledge,
> But we are not equal.
> For I am fixed in every Essence (عين),
> While they are unable to subsist (بقاء).
> So they take form in every shape,
> Like the color of water from the color of the vessel.

### The Governing Spirits Seek Bodies by an Essential Seeking

I composed these verses concerning the embodiment of the separated spirits due to the gathering of their bodies in the worldly life called death. We saw a group of them embodied—from the Prophets, angels, and righteous Companions and others—and they embody themselves in the forms of meanings that are embodied in the forms of sensibles. When the meaning is revealed and appears in a sensory form, the spirit follows it in the form of that body, whatever it may be, because the governing spirits seek bodies by an essential seeking. So, wherever a body or physical form appears, whether sensory or meaningful—like a righteous deed in the form of a handsome young man with a good face, constitution, and scent—the spirit adheres to it forever: <<فِي أَيِّ صُورَةٍ مَا شَاءَ رَكَّبَكَ>> (In whatever form He willed, He put you together), since it was not.

(The Thirty-Ninth Hadith: Raising the Hands in Seven Places)

Al-Bazzar mentioned from Ibn Umar, from the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, who said: "The hands are raised in seven places: the commencement of prayer, facing the House, Safa and Marwa, the two standing places [Arafat and Muzdalifah], and at the Stone."

### Raising the Hands is Only for Disavowing Ownership

Raising the hands in all these places is for disavowing the ownership (ملك) attributed to the hands. One raises them empty, devoid of anything, for all ownership belongs to Allah. All these places are loci of asking, and asking from a rich owner is inconceivable. Asking is only done out of need, which is the quality of the poor person who does not own what he asks for. So, when he asks the Rich One, he realizes from which quality he asks, and how he asks. Does he ask for what is with Him or what is not with Him? Let the ruling in that be according to what I have drawn your attention to.

### Allah’s Care for the Poor

Allah has cared for the poor by making their asking of the rich a Divine request, in His saying: <<وَآتُوا الزَّكَاةَ>> (And give the Zakat), and in His saying: <<وَأَقْرِضُوا اللَّهَ قَرْضًا حَسَنًا>> (And lend to Allah a good loan), and in His saying: "I was hungry, and you did not feed Me."

If you understand the quality that necessitated the asking, you will know how to ask, whom to ask, what to ask, and in whose hand the gifts fall and what is done with them. You will also know the raising of the hands during asking, both outwardly and inwardly, and the difference in their states.

(The Fortieth Hadith: The Hadith of Seeking Forgiveness for the Shavers and the Trimmers)

Muslim transmitted from Abu Hurayrah that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "O Allah, forgive the shavers (محلقين)." They said: "O Messenger of Allah, and the trimmers (مقصرين)?" He said: "O Allah, forgive the shavers." They said: "O Messenger of Allah, and the trimmers?" He said: "And the trimmers."

### The Lawgiver’s Intention in Seeking Forgiveness

Since they did not understand the Lawgiver’s intention in seeking forgiveness (غفر), which is the covering (ستر), for the shavers—who are those who removed the hair from their heads, so their heads were uncovered—He sought Allah’s covering for them as a reward for their uncovering, but the trimmers do not have that. Since they did not understand him, he said: "And the trimmers," addressing them, for the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Address people according to the measure of their intellects," meaning according to what they can comprehend of the address, so that they do not reject it.

(The Forty-First Hadith: The Farewell Circumambulation)

Muslim transmitted from Ibn Abbas, who said: People used to depart in every direction. The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Let no one depart until the last of his covenant is with the House."

### The First Seeks the Last in the World of Separation

Since this House is the primary objective of the pilgrim, for he was only commanded to perform the Pilgrimage to the House, and the First seeks the Last in the world of separation (عالم المفارقة)—and the condition of the First is not required in everything attributed to it, unlike the Last, which necessarily seeks the First by its Essence (ذات)—understand this, so that you know how to attribute Primordiality (Awwaliyya) to yourself and how to attribute Finality (Akhiriyya) to yourself. Since you know that the Last seeks the First in the world of separation, and you are from the world whose state is separation, because you are from the horizons (āfāqī), it is incumbent upon you that your last covenant be the circumambulation of the House.

(Section on the Expiation for *Tamattu’*)

Allah the Exalted said: <<فَمَنْ تَمَتَّعَ بِالْعُمْرَةِ إِلَى الْحَجِّ فَمَا اسْتَيْسَرَ مِنَ الْهَدْيِ>> (Whoever performs Umrah [Lesser Pilgrimage] in combination with Hajj [Greater Pilgrimage], then [he must offer] what is easy of the sacrificial animal [Hady]). There is no disagreement regarding its obligation. They differed concerning what is obligatory. The majority of scholars hold that <<فَمَا اسْتَيْسَرَ مِنَ الْهَدْيِ>> (what is easy of the sacrificial animal) is a sheep. Ibn Umar said that the name *Hady* (sacrificial animal) only applies to camels and cows, and that the meaning of His saying, the Exalted: <<فَمَا اسْتَيْسَرَ مِنَ الْهَدْيِ>> is a cow less than a cow, or a camel less than a camel. What I hold is that if he offered a chicken, it would suffice him. They agreed that this expiation is sequential, so fasting is only required after one cannot find a sacrificial animal.

### The Time Limit for the Obligation to Shift from Sacrifice to Fasting

Scholars differed concerning the time limit upon the expiration of which the obligation shifts from the sacrificial animal to fasting. One group says that if he begins the fasting, his obligation has shifted to fasting, even if he finds the sacrificial animal during the fast. Another group says that if he finds the sacrificial animal during the three days of fasting, it is incumbent upon him, but if he finds it during the seven days, it is not incumbent upon him. I hold the first opinion. As for the fasting of the three days during the Pilgrimage, they differed concerning one who fasts them during the days of performing *Umrah* or fasts them during the Days of Mina. Some permitted them during the Days of Mina, while others prohibited it, saying that if the first days are missed, the sacrificial animal becomes a debt upon him. Malik prohibited it before commencing the acts of Pilgrimage, while Abu Hanifa permitted it. In our view, one fasts the three days as long as the month of Dhul Hijjah has not ended. As for the seven days, they agreed that if he fasts them with his family, it suffices him. They differed if he fasts them on the road. One group says it suffices him, and I hold this opinion, and another group says it does not suffice him.

### The Sacrificial Animal is More Appropriate in Suitability for the Expiation of the *Mutamatti’*

The sacrificial animal (Hady) is more appropriate in suitability for the expiation of the *Mutamatti’* (one who combines Umrah and Hajj), for it is a substitute for his enjoyment (*tamattu’*), and through the sacrificial animal, the one to whom it is given in charity enjoys the benefit. Fasting is the opposite of enjoyment. As for the suitability of fasting in it, it is because he enjoyed the state of exiting ihram, so he was recompensed with the opposite of enjoyment, which is fasting. Thus, the Real preferred enjoyment through the sacrificial animal for the benefit of the one to whom it is given in charity. If he cannot find it, then he is countered with the opposite of enjoyment, which is fasting.

End of the Seventy-Third Part.

((In the Name of Allah, the Most Compassionate, the Most Merciful))

(Hadiths of Mecca and Medina, May Allah Honor Them)

### Hadiths of Mecca

(The First Hadith: Entering and Exiting Mecca in Accordance with the Sunnah)

Muslim transmitted from Ibn Umar that when the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, entered Mecca, he entered through the Upper Pass (Thaniyyah al-Ulya) and exited through the Lower Pass (Thaniyyah al-Sufla).

The Upper Pass is called Kadā’ (كداء) with the lengthening and opening of the Kâf and the hamza, and the Lower Pass is called Kudā (كدى) with the joining of the Kâf and the shortening.

### Mecca is the Noblest Place on Earth

Since Mecca is the noblest place on earth, the locus for the manifestation of the Right Hand of the Real (الحق), and the Presence of the Covenant (مبايعة), it resembles the white dune of musk in the Garden of Eden, the locus of the Greatest Visit and the general Vision. The dune is the noblest place in the Garden of Eden, and Eden is the noblest of the Gardens because it is the capital of the Garden, and the capital is where the King’s abode is. It is an abode that bequeaths Divine Extension (إمداد) and Opening (فتح) in the Divine Knowledge (العلم الإلهي) to whoever seeks it, which is the noblest gift given to one who seeks Him.

### The Symbolic Meaning in Kadā’

For this reason, entry into Mecca was legislated from Kadā’ (كداء) with the opening of the Kâf, signifying the Divine Opening (فتح) in the Kâf of Creation (تكوين) from His saying 'Be' (كُنْ), and the lengthening (مد) signifies the Divine Extension (إمداد) with the gift of Knowledge (العلم) of Him, which is the noblest gift given to one who seeks Him. The lengthening in these words is an addition, and Mecca is the place of addition (mazīd) in every good, because it is a branch of the origin. The origin in the cosmos is poverty, deficiency, and inability. For this reason, in poetic necessity, the lengthened vowel may be shortened, because it is a return to the origin, but the shortened vowel may not be lengthened, because it is an exit from the origin, and one does not exit except by a compelling reason, and there is none there.

### The Compelling Reason for the Added Lengthening in the Letter of the Word

The compelling reason for the added lengthening in the letter of the word is either the hamza at the beginning, like *āmana*, or at the end, like *jā’a*, or the doubled letter, like *al-Tāmma*, *al-Sākhkha*, and *al-Dābba*. Doubling is the multiplication of the letter, and multiplication is an addition, because it is the entry of one letter into another, which is assimilation (*idghām*). Thus, it is the manifestation of a servant with the attribute of a Lord, so he received the addition and took the lengthening, since he did not possess it originally. Likewise, the manifestation of a Lord with the attribute of a servant in a Divine descent (تنزل إلهي) is from the category of assimilation, an honoring of the servant from Allah. And everyone strives for himself.

### The Servant’s Striving and the Lord’s Hurrying

As for the striving (*sa’y*) regarding the servant, it is known and confirmed due to his need. As for the hurrying (*harwala*) in the striving attributed to Allah, it is an attribute that seeks greater intensity in the seeking than the seeking of the one who strives without the attribute of hurrying. This indicates that the seeking there is more intense due to the nullification of the ruling necessitated by the Divine Names. For this reason, He says in His Theophany (تجلي): "Is there any penitent that I may turn to him?" This is a question from the Name *al-Tawwāb* (The Acceptor of Repentance). "Is there any supplicant that I may answer him?" This is the tongue of the Name *al-Mujīb* (The Responder). "Is there any seeker of forgiveness that I may forgive him?" This is the tongue of the Name *al-Ghafūr* (The Forgiving). For if there were no one in the cosmos to call upon this Name, its ruling would remain nullified. For this reason, His striving is hurrying, and His seeking is more intense, because deficiency is not appropriate for Him. The servant is entirely deficiency and weakness, so due to his weakness, he does not possess the intensity of speed in striving, because he is in need of the Helper, by His saying: <<وَإِيَّاكَ نَسْتَعِينُ>> (And You alone we ask for help).

### The Vicegerents of the Real Among the Servants Possess Command and Prohibition

But when he exits, he exits from Kudā (كدى) with the joining of the Kâf and the shortening (قصر), which is what he acquired in the Divine Presence (حضرة الحق) of elevation, and what flowed into the Kâf of Creation (تكوين), which we call the Act by Spiritual Resolve (همة). For this reason, the Kâf was raised. The Real said to Abu Yazid: "Go out to My creation with My attribute, so whoever sees you sees Me." This is the manifestation of the attributes of Lordship upon him. Do you not see that the vicegerents of the Real (خلفاء الحق) among the servants possess command and prohibition, ruling and control? These are the attributes of the Deity. And the common people are commanded to hear and obey. He gave him the shortening (قصر) in Kudā to alert him that even though you have exited with My attribute, let it not veil you from your servitude (عبودية). For shortening and inability will never leave you, and whenever that leaves you, you will be broken. So, when he exited, he exited from Mecca, the Presence of Allah, to his subjects, elevated by the honor of the Presence, witnessing his servitude by the shortening. For this reason, he would enter through Kadā’ and exit through Kudā. This much is sufficient concerning the Pilgrimage, for its branches would be too long to enumerate, and life would not suffice for them. What remains is the virtue of Mecca and Medina, and the visit will be the conclusion of this chapter.

(The Second Hadith: The Land of Mecca is the Best Land of Allah)

Al-Nasa’i transmitted from Abdullah ibn Adi ibn al-Hamra’ that he heard the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, while standing on his riding beast at Hazwarah in Mecca, saying to Mecca: "By Allah, you are the best land of Allah and the most beloved land of Allah to Allah. Were it not that I was expelled from you, I would not have left."

### Whoever is Valid for Precedence is Followed

The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "The people should be led in prayer by the one among them who is best at reciting the Quran. If they are equal in recitation, then the one most knowledgeable of the Sunnah. If they are equal in the Sunnah, then the one who emigrated earliest. If they are equal in emigration, then the one who embraced Islam earliest. If they are equal in embracing Islam, then the oldest among them."

Whoever possesses such qualities is valid for precedence, and whoever is valid for precedence is followed, and is more worthy of Allah than the follower.

### The Meccan House is the First House Established for People as a Place of Worship

The Meccan House is <<أَوَّلَ بَيْتٍ وُضِعَ لِلنَّاسِ>> (the first House established for people) as a place of worship, and prayer in it is better than prayer in any other place. Thus, it has precedence in time, which is the consideration of age. So, it has the precedence of age, and only that which encompasses all virtues is given precedence in age, for it came last. If we were to suffice with this, it would be sufficient without mentioning anything else. If we look at emigration, it is a sought-after House to which emigration is proper. The Black Stone is one of its stones, and it is the oldest of the stones in emigration from all other stones, having emigrated from Paradise to it. Allah honored it with the Right Hand and made it for the covenant (مبايعة). As for being the most Quranic, it is the most comprehensive of good things among all houses, due to the clear signs within it: the Stone, the Multazam, the Mustajār, the Station of Abraham, and Zamzam, among others. As for its knowledge of the Sunnah, the Sunnahs in it are more numerous due to the multitude of its rites and its encompassing of actions and abstentions that are not found in other acts of worship or in any other house, for it is the locus of the Pilgrimage. As for Islam (سلم), it is the oldest sanctuary (haram), so it is entirely peace. Whoever enters it is safe. Thus, it is valid for precedence in every respect over every land and every house.

(The Third Hadith: The Sanctity of Mecca)

Muslim transmitted from Abu Hurayrah that Khuzā’ah killed a man from Banu Layth in the year of the Conquest of Mecca in retaliation for one of their own whom they had killed. The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, was informed of this, so he mounted his riding beast and delivered a sermon, saying: "Indeed, Allah withheld the elephant from Mecca and gave authority over it to His Messenger and the believers. Behold, it was not made lawful for anyone before me, nor will it be made lawful for anyone after me. Behold, it was made lawful for me for an hour of a day. Behold, it is now forbidden. Its thorns shall not be cut, its trees shall not be felled, and its fallen items shall not be picked up except by one who announces it. And whoever has a relative killed is free to choose one of two options: either he is given the blood money (diyah), or the family of the slain is granted retaliation."

### There is No Sanctuary or Protected Area Greater Than the Sanctuary and Protected Area of Allah

This is the protected area (*himā*) and sanctuary (*haram*) of Allah. There is nothing existing greater than Allah, so there is no sanctuary or protected area greater than the Sanctuary and protected area of Allah in possibility. For Allah sanctified Mecca, and people did not sanctify it. Thus said the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him. He also said in a Hadith in Muslim that this land was sanctified by Allah <<يَوْمَ خَلَقَ السَّمَاوَاتِ وَالْأَرْضَ>> (the day He created the heavens and the earth), and it is forbidden by the sanctity of Allah until the Day of Resurrection.

The Hadith is His saying, the Exalted: <<إِنَّمَا أُمِرْتُ أَنْ أَعْبُدَ رَبَّ هَذِهِ الْبَلْدَةِ الَّذِي حَرَّمَهَا>> (I have only been commanded to worship the Lord of this city, who has sanctified it).

(The Fourth Hadith: Prohibition of Carrying Weapons in Mecca)

Muslim transmitted from Jabir ibn Abdullah, who said: I heard the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, saying: "It is not lawful for anyone to carry weapons in Mecca."

### Weapons are the Equipment of the Fearful or the One Expecting Fear

Since weapons are the equipment of the fearful, or the one expecting fear, or the one seeking revenge, or the aggressor who defends himself if he is disputed in his purpose, and Allah the Exalted has made it a <<حَرَمًا آمِنًا>> (safe sanctuary), there was no meaning in carrying weapons within it.

(The Fifth Hadith: Concerning Zamzam)

Abu Dawud al-Tayalisi transmitted from Abu Dharr, from the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, concerning Zamzam: "It is blessed, a food that satisfies, and a cure for sickness."

(The Sixth Hadith: Concerning It)

Al-Daraqutni transmitted from the Hadith of Jabir that the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "The water of Zamzam is for whatever it is drunk for."

This report is confirmed for me by taste, for I drank it for a certain matter, and it was granted to me.

(The Seventh Hadith: Concerning Taking Zamzam Water Away Due to Its Virtue)

Al-Tirmidhi mentioned from Aisha that she used to carry Zamzam water and informed that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, used to carry it.

This is a good and rare Hadith.

(The Eighth Hadith: Entering Mecca in a State of Ihram)

Abu Ahmad ibn Adi al-Jurjani mentioned from the Hadith of Ibn Abbas that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "No one shall enter Mecca except in a state of ihram, whether from its people or from others."

There is discussion concerning its chain of transmission. The state of ihram mentioned in this Hadith, in my view, is interpreted as meaning that one should not enter it except respecting it, since it is confirmed that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, entered on the Day of the Conquest of Mecca wearing a black turban without being in a state of ihram.

He said this concerning the appointment of the fixed boundaries (Mawāqīt) for those who intend Hajj and Umrah.

(The Ninth Hadith: Hoarding Food in Mecca)
