Muslim mentioned from the Hadith of Ya’la ibn Umayya that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Hoarding food in the Sanctuary is deviation (ilhād) in it." And the Exalted said: <<وَمَنْ يُرِدْ فِيهِ بِإِلْحَادٍ بِظُلْمٍ نُذِقْهُ مِنْ عَذَابٍ أَلِيمٍ>> (And whoever intends deviation [إلحاد] therein by wrongdoing, We will make him taste a painful punishment).

And no one is taken to task for intending evil or oppression outside the Sacred Precinct (حرم) of Mecca, and the traditions concerning its honor are numerous.

(As for the traditions concerning Medina)

The Hadith of Visitation, which is the first:

Al-Daraqutni narrated from Ibn Umar that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Whoever visits my grave, my intercession (شفاعتي) becomes due for him."

(The Second Hadith: Concerning the virtue of dying therein)

Al-Tirmidhi mentioned, on the authority of Ibn Umar, that the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Whoever is able to die in Medina, let him die there, for I shall intercede for whoever dies there." And this is an authentic hadith.

(The Third Hadith: Concerning the sacred precinct of Medina)

Muslim mentioned, on the authority of Sa'd ibn Abi Waqqas, who said that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "I declare sacred (أحرم) that which is between the two lava fields (لابتي) of Medina, that its thorny trees (عضاهها) should not be cut down, nor its game killed." And he said: "Medina is better for them, if only they knew. No one leaves it out of aversion except that Allah replaces him with someone better than him. And no one remains steadfast through its hardship (لأوائها) and difficulty (جهدها) except that I shall be an intercessor (شفيعا) or a witness (شهيدا) for him on the Day of Resurrection. And no one intends evil for the people of Medina except that Allah will melt him in the Fire like lead melts, or like salt melts in water."

(The Fourth Hadith: Concerning one who hunts in Medina)

Abu Dawud mentioned, on the authority of Sulayman ibn Abi Abdullah, who said: I saw Sa'd ibn Abi Waqqas seize a man who was hunting in the Sacred Precinct (حرم) of Medina which the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, had declared sacred. He stripped him of his clothes. His clients (مواليه) came and spoke to him about the matter. Sa'd said: "The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, declared this Sacred Precinct inviolable and said: 'Whoever seizes someone hunting therein, let him strip him of his belongings.' I shall not return to you the bounty (طعمة) with which the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, favored me. However, if you wish, I will pay you its price."

(The Fifth Hadith: Concerning the transfer of the fever of Medina to Al-Juhfa)

Muslim mentioned, on the authority of Aisha, who said: We arrived in Medina when it was plagued by fever. Abu Bakr fell ill, and Bilal fell ill. When the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, saw the sickness of his Companions, he said: "O Allah, make Medina beloved to us as You made Mecca beloved, or more so. Make it healthy for us, and bless us in its measure (صاعها) and its handful (مدها), and transfer its fever (حماها) to Al-Juhfa."

(The Sixth and Seventh Hadith: Concerning its purity and its expulsion of filth)

Muslim mentioned, from the hadith of Zayd ibn Thabit, that the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "It is pure (طيبة)—meaning Medina—and it expels filth (الخبث) just as fire expels the dross of silver."

And he, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Medina is like a blacksmith's bellows; it expels its filth (خبثها) and purifies its goodness (طيبها)." Muslim narrated this from the hadith of Jabir.

(The Eighth Hadith: Concerning the protection of Medina from the Dajjal and the Plague)

Muslim mentioned, from the hadith of Abu Hurayrah, who said that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "There are angels guarding the entrances (أنقاب) of Medina; neither the Dajjal (الدجال) nor the Plague (الطاعون) shall enter it."

(The Ninth Hadith: Concerning the same)

Al-Bukhari narrated from Abu Bakrah that the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "The terror of the False Messiah (المسيح الدجال) shall not enter Medina. It will have seven gates on that day, and at each gate, there will be two angels."

As for the hadith concerning the virtue of prayer in the Mosque of Medina, the Sacred Mosque [Mecca], and the Aqsa Mosque, it is well-known.

### (The Tenth Hadith: Concerning the sacred precinct of Wadi Wajj in Ta'if)

Abu Dawud mentioned its declaration of sacredness, on the authority of Urwah ibn al-Zubayr, who said: We approached with the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, from the mountain pass until we were near the Lote Tree (السدرة). The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, stood at the edge of the Black Peak (القرن الأسود) adjacent to it, facing Wadi Wajj with his gaze—and once he said "its valley"—and he stood until all the people had passed. Then he said: "The game and the thorny trees (عضاهه) of Wajj are absolutely sacred (حرام محرم) for Allah." This was before his descent upon Ta'if and his siege of Thaqif.

(A Continuation) As for the wisdom (حكمة) behind the Sacred Precinct of Medina:

It is because Allah coupled the testimony of Muhammad’s prophethood and messengership with the testimony of Unity (التوحيد) as an honor for him, and that faith (الايمان) is incomplete without both. Allah had declared Mecca sacred, so He made the declaration of Medina's sacredness belong to His Messenger, peace and blessings be upon him, as an affirmation of the honor of the Testimony (الشهادة). Thus, He allowed him to declare sacredness just as Allah had declared sacredness. Furthermore, Allah is Odd (وتر) and loves Oddness (الوتر). He paired the sacredness of the Haram [Mecca] with the sacredness of Medina, thereby establishing a third Haram for the sake of Oddness (الوترية). He made the declaration of its sacredness for Allah, not for the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, because He is the Odd One (الوتر). This is why He only declared sacred that which is adjacent to Mecca, indicating that the sacredness therein is for Allah, just like the sacredness of Mecca. This is why he said: "It is a sacred precinct declared sacred by Allah." With this, we have mentioned the traditions reported concerning the two Harams and the third Haram that made them odd.

### [The Wisdom of Visiting the Prophet]

As for visiting the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, it is because faith (الايمان) is not complete except through belief in him. Therefore, the believer must intend to visit him, for <<Whoever obeys the Messenger has obeyed Allah>> (مَنْ يُطِعِ الرَّسُولَ فَقَدْ أَطاعَ الله). Since intercession (الشفعية) came through obedience, and Allah is Odd (وتر) and loves Oddness (الوتر), He made obedience threefold for the Oddness (الوتر) required in all things, just as He did with the Haram. Thus, He said: <<Obey Allah and obey the Messenger and those in authority among you>> (أَطِيعُوا الله وأَطِيعُوا الرَّسُولَ وأُولِي الْأَمْرِ مِنْكُمْ). He thus made it odd. And among the conditions of the pledge of allegiance (المبايعة) to those in authority is hearing and obedience, in ease and in hardship.

### [The Four Sacred Months]

If it is asked: "The Sacred Months (الأشهر الحرم) are four," we reply: "You speak truly." When Allah knew them to be four, He did not make them consecutive, due to His love for Oddness (الوترية). He made three of them consecutive: Dhu al-Qa'dah, Dhu al-Hijjah, and Muharram, thus establishing the Oddness (الوترية). He made the fourth Rajab, and named it Rajab the Singular (رجب الفرد), confirming the Oddness (الوترية). This is because Allah is Odd (وتر) and loves Oddness (الوتر) in all things, so that the image of His Oddness (وتريته) may be seen within them. Thus, nothing is seen but His Degree (رتبته), and nothing is loved but His Attribute (صفته). This is why the World (العالم) was brought forth in the form of the Divine Names (الأسماء الإلهية), to be His manifestation (مجلاه). Therefore, nothing is seen in Existence (الوجود) but Him, glory be to Him, there is no god but He.

### (A Continuation) [The Mutual Boasting between the Two Harams]

We decided to record at the conclusion of this chapter what we have narrated concerning the mutual boasting (الافتخار) between the two Sacred Precincts (الحرمين). This is what Muhammad ibn Isma'il ibn Abi al-Sayf al-Yamani, resident of Mecca, related to us, saying: Hasan ibn Ali related to us, saying: Al-Husayn ibn Khalaf ibn Hibah ibn Qasim al-Shami related to us, saying: My father related to us, saying: Al-Husayn ibn Ahmad ibn Firas related to us, saying: My father related to us, on the authority of his father Ibrahim ibn Firas, on the authority of Abu Muhammad Ishaq ibn Nafi' al-Khuza'i, on the authority of Ibrahim ibn Abd al-Rahman al-Makki, on the authority of Muhammad ibn Abbas al-Makki, who said: Some of the Meccan Shaykhs informed us that when Dawud ibn Isa ibn Musa—who is Musa ibn Muhammad ibn Ali ibn Abdullah ibn al-Abbas, the uncle of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him—was appointed governor of Mecca and Medina, he resided in Mecca and appointed his son Sulayman over Medina. He stayed in Mecca for twenty months. The people of Medina wrote to him—and Al-Zubayr ibn Abi Bakr said that Yahya ibn Miskin ibn Ayyub ibn Mikhraq wrote to him—asking him to move to them, informing him that his residence in Medina was superior to his residence in Mecca. They sent him poetry regarding this, composed by their poet, who said therein:

### [The Virtues of Medina]

> O Dawud, you have attained high honors,
> And justice in the land of the Chosen One.
> You have become a refuge (ثمالا) for the people of the Hijaz,
> And you have followed the path of the pious.
> You are the refined one (المهذب) from Hashim,
> In the station of glory and hope.
> You are the one accepted (الرضي) for what befalls them,
> In every circumstance, the son of the accepted one.
> With the revenue (الفي‏ء), you have enriched the needy,
> Your justice among us is the ultimate goal.
> Mecca is not the dwelling place for residence,
> So migrate, like the migration of those who came before.
> Your stay of twenty months there
> Is long in the eyes of the people of wisdom (الحجى).
> So fast in the land of the Messenger, which
> Allah has singled out for the Prophet of Guidance.
> Let no advisor whose counsel is based on caprice
> Drive you away from his proximity.
> The grave of the Prophet and his relics
> Are more deserving of your proximity than Dhu Tuwa.

The narrator said: When the letter and the verses reached Dawud ibn Isa, he sent for men from Mecca and read the letter to them. A man among them, named Isa ibn Abd al-Aziz al-Sa'labus, responded to him with a poem, refuting him and mentioning the virtue of Mecca and the honor and merit with which Allah Almighty has singled it out, mentioning the sacred sites (المشاعر) and merits (المناقب). He—may Allah grant him success—said this poem:

### [The Virtue of Mecca and the Honors and Merits Allah has Granted It]

> O Dawud, you are the accepted Imam (الإمام الرضي),
> And you are the cousin of the Prophet of Guidance.
> You are refined (المهذب) from every fault,
> As an adult and before that, in childhood.
> You are the one hoped for (المؤمل) from Hashim,
> And you are the son of noble, pious people.
> You are the succor (غياث) for the needy,
> You fill their needs with wealth.
> A letter came to you from an envious, denying person,
> Who spoke ill and transgressed in his statement.
> He prefers Yathrib [Medina] in his poetry
> Over the Sacred Precinct of Allah, where He built [the Kaaba].
> If he speaks truly in what he says,
> Then let him not prostrate toward what is here.
> And what land surpasses its mother?
> And Mecca, Mecca is the Mother of Cities (أم القرى).
> My Lord spread the Earth from beneath it,
> And Yathrib, there is no doubt, is within what He spread.
> The House of the Sovereign (بيت المهيمن) stands firm among us,
> To which one prays, despite the enemy.
> And the virtue of our Mosque is manifest,
> Over all others; there is no doubt in this.
> The prayer of the worshipper is counted for him
> As hundreds of thousands of complete prayers.
> Thus it came in the Hadith of the Prophet,
> And what he said is truth to be followed.
> And your deeds every day are delegations
> Coming to us, rushing like flocks of birds (القطا).
> From these, my God raises up what
> He wills, and leaves what He does not will.
> And we are the ones to whom the servants make pilgrimage,
> Casting pebbles (الحصى) in odd numbers (بوتر) while disheveled (شعثا).
> And they come from <<every deep ravine>> (مِنْ كُلِّ فَجٍّ عَمِيقٍ),
> Upon lean, slender mounts like spears (القنا).
> To fulfill your rites (مناسككم) with us,
> Among them are the hungry and those with me.
> How many are those who chant the Talbiyah with a mournful voice,
> Whose sound you see rising in the air!
> And another remembers the Lord of the servants,
> And praises Him with beautiful praise.
> All of them are disheveled and dusty (أشعث أغبر),
> Heading for Arafat (المعرف) to the furthest extent.
> They remain there all day,
> Standing, crying out until the evening.
> Barefoot, in the morning, standing, they have
> A clamor, supplicating the Lord of the heavens.
> In hope and fear for what they have put forth,
> And everyone asks for the removal of affliction.
> They say: "O our Lord, forgive us,
> With Your pardon and forgiveness for whoever has done wrong."
> When the night drew near on their day,
> And the day departed, they intensified their weeping.
> And the pilgrims moved with a great commotion,
> Stopping at Muzdalifah (جمع) after the evening prayer.
> They all spent the night, and when the
> Pillar of dawn appeared and the darkness departed,
> They supplicated for an hour, then tightened the straps
> On their young camels, and headed for Mina.
> Among them is one who has completed his rites,
> And another who begins by shedding blood [sacrificing].
> And another offers a sacrifice to Mecca,
> To perform the Sa'y and call upon Him among those who call.
> And another trots (يرمل) around the circumambulation (الطواف),
> And another proceeds, heading for Safa.
> They return with better than what they hoped for,
> And what they sought of abundant bounty.
> And the honored angels made pilgrimage
> To our land before, in the past.
> And Adam made pilgrimage after them,
> And after him, Ahmad the Chosen One.
> And the Friend of God (خليل الإله) [Abraham] made pilgrimage to us,
> And stoned the devils (هجر بالرمي) among those who stoned.
> This, by my life, is an elevation for us,
> Granted to us by the Severely Strong (شديد القوي).
> And the Prophet, the Prophet of Guidance, is from us,
> And he prophesied among us, and from us he began.
> And Abu Bakr, son of the noble ones, is from us,
> And Abu Hafs [Umar], the hoped-for, is from us.
> And Uthman is from us, so who is like him,
> When people of modesty are counted?
> And Ali is from us, and Al-Zubayr is from us,
> And Talhah is from us, and he grew up among us.
> And Ibn Abbas, possessor of honors, is from us,
> The relative of the Prophet and the ally of generosity.
> And Quraysh and their forefathers are from us,
> So we are the ultimate point of our pride.
> And those by whom you boast are from us,
> So do not boast over us by means of them.
> For the pride of those is an elevation for us,
> And we have enough pride already.
> And Zamzam and the Stone (الحجر) are among us, so do
> You have honors like those we possess?
> And Zamzam is food and drink for whoever
> Desires food, and in it is healing (الشفا).
> And Zamzam removes the worries of the chests,
> And Zamzam is a cure for every ailment.
> And whoever comes to Zamzam while hungry,
> If he drinks his fill, he is satisfied.
> And it is not like Zamzam in your land,
> Just as we and you are not the same.
> And among us is the watering place (سقاية) of the Prophet's uncle,
> From which the Prophet filled himself and quenched his thirst.
> And among us is the Station [of Abraham] (المقام), so honor it,
> And among us are Al-Muhassab and Al-Mukhtaba.
> And among us is Al-Hajun, so boast of it,
> And among us are Kada' and Kudy.
> And among us are Al-Abatih and the two Marwahs,
> So bravo! Who is like us, O young man?
> And among us are the Sacred Sites (المشاعر), the Prophet's birthplace,
> And Ajyad, and the Corner (الركن), and the Resting Place (المتكى).
> And Thawr, and do you have anything like Thawr?
> And among us are Thabir and Hira.
> And in it was the hiding place of the Prophet of God,
> With him was Abu Bakr, the accepted one (المرتضى).
> How great is the difference between Uhud, if pride is mentioned,
> And Al-Qubaysi, in what you see!
> And our land has always been a Sacred Precinct (حرم),
> Where hunting has been forbidden in the past.
> And Yathrib was permissible (حلالا), so do not
> Lie, for how great is the difference between this and that!
> And the Prophet declared it sacred after that,
> And for that reason, this came to be so.
> If game were killed in Yathrib,
> The game would not be ransomed until the meeting [of the Day of Judgment].
> But if an ant were killed with us,
> You would be taken to task for it, or pay the ransom (الفداء).
> Were it not for the visitation of the Prophet's grave,
> You would be like the rest of those you see.
> And the Prophet is not merely resting there (ثاويا),
> But he is in the Gardens of the Most High.
> If you say a word contrary to what
> I say, then you have spoken an error.
> So do not use foul language against us in your speech,
> And do not utter obscene words (الخنا).
> And do not boast of what is not,
> Nor of what disgraces you before the assembly.
> And do not satirize the Land of the Haram with poetry,
> And restrain your tongue from Dhu Tuwa.
> Otherwise, what you do not desire will come to you,
> Of insults in your land and harm.
> For it is possible to speak in your land
> By reviling Al-Aqiq and the valley of Quba.

### [The Judgment upon Those Who Debated the Virtue of Mecca and Medina]

A man from Banu 'Ijl, an ascetic (ناسك) who was residing in Jeddah as a frontier guard (مرابطا), responded to both of them and judged between them, saying:

> I have judged those who debated
> The virtue of Mecca and Medina, so ask!
> I shall inform you of the truth, so understand,
> For judgment sometimes errs and sometimes is just.
> I am the young man of 'Ijl, Jeddah is my dwelling,
> And it is the treasury of the Haram that is not unknown.
> In it is Jihad along with the frontier guard duty (الرباط), and indeed,
> The great battle (الوقيعة) will inevitably descend upon it.
> From the descendants of Ham in the latter days,
> And its martyr is equal to the martyr of Badr.
> Our martyrs have been favored with happiness,
> And in it is joy for whoever dies and is killed.
> O man of Medina, the virtue of your land
> Is above all lands, but the virtue of Mecca is superior.
> A land in which the Sacred House (البيت المحرم) is the Qibla
> For all the worlds, and in it the mosques are equal [in reward].
> Its land and its game are a forbidden Sacred Precinct (حرم حرام),
> While hunting is permissible in all other lands.
> And in it are all the Sacred Sites (المشاعر) and the Rites (المناسك),
> And to its virtue, all creatures travel.
> In it is the Station [of Abraham] (المقام), and the overflowing basin of Zamzam,
> And the Stone (الحجر) and the Corner (الركن) that is not unknown.
> And the lofty, glorified Mosque, and Al-Safa,
> And the two Sacred Signs (المشعران), and those who circumambulate and trot (يرمل).
> Is there a known place in the lands
> Like Arafat (المعرف), or a place where one stays?
> Or like Muzdalifah (جمع) in all places,
> Or like the Khayf of Mina in a dwelling place?
> Those are places where nothing is seen in their desolation
> Except supplication, and one who is in the state of Ihram and one who is not.
> Honor to the one who arrives at Arafat as its guest,
> Honor to him and to his land when he descends.
> And in Mecca, good deeds are multiplied in reward,
> And therein the wrongdoer is questioned about his sin.
> The wrongdoer is recompensed for his sin with its like,
> But good deeds are multiplied and accepted.
> It is not fitting for you to boast, O young man,
> Against a land in which the Prophet, the Messenger, was born.
> In the valley (الشعب) below the mound (الردم) was his birthplace,
> And in it he grew up, upon him the Messenger [Gabriel] prayed.
> And in it he resided, and the revelation of the heavens came to him,
> And the lofty, descending Angel traveled with him by night.
> Was the prophethood of the Merciful revealed therein?
> And the religion therein was before your religion, the first.
> Is there a Hashimi residing in Medina,
> Or a young or old man from Quraysh?
> Except that Mecca is his land and his dwelling,
> But they were driven out from it, so they moved.
> Likewise, he migrated toward you when he came,
> Indeed, Medina is a migration (هجرة), so bear it.
> You gave refuge, you hosted, and you supported
> The best of creation; it was your right to do so.
> The virtue of Medina is clear, and for its people
> Is an ancient virtue whose light shines brightly.
> Whoever does not say that the virtue is with you,
> We say: "You have lied," and that statement is vile.
> There is no good in one who does not know your virtue,
> Whoever is ignorant of it, we are not ignorant.
> In your land is the grave of the Prophet and his house,
> And the lofty, elevated, long pulpit (المنبر).
> And in it are the graves of those who preceded in virtue:
> Umar and his companion, the superior friend [Abu Bakr].
> And the blessed progeny (العترة الميمونة) who, by their presence,
> Surpassed the virtue of everyone who is virtuous.
> The family of the Prophet built upon the fact that they
> Became a light that encompasses all creatures.
> O you whose eye looks down upon Medina,
> Humiliation is in you, and your cheek is turned down.
> We love it and we love its people,
> And affection for it is a duty upon whoever is rational.
> Say to the man of Medina who visits Dawud
> The Amir, and urges him and hastens him:
> Dawud has come to you after your letter;
> Your rope concerning your Amir was being twisted.
> So seek your Amir and ask him to visit, and do not fall
> Into a land that is magnified, for your admonition is better.
> God drove a downpour (ديمة) to the heart of Mecca,
> By which it is watered, and it pours down upon Medina.

The Seventy-Fourth Section is concluded. [The First Volume of Al-Futuhat al-Makkiyya is completed, followed by the Second Volume, the beginning of which is the Seventy-Third Chapter, which is the beginning of the Seventy-Fifth Section, according to the author's division.]

# [The Second Volume]

The Second Volume of the Book of The Meccan Revelations (الفتوحات المكية), which Allah unveiled to the Shaykh, the Imam, the Practicing Scholar, the Firmly Rooted, the Perfect, the Seal of the Inheriting Saints (خاتم الأولياء الوارثين), the Isthmus of Isthmuses (برزخ البرازخ), the Reviver of the Truth and the Religion (محيي الحق و الدين), Abu Abdullah Muhammad ibn Ali, known as Ibn Arabi al-Hatimi al-Ta'i, may Allah sanctify his soul and illuminate his shrine, Amen. Printed based on the copy collated against the author's manuscript found in the city of Konya. This important task was undertaken by a group of scholars by order of the late Amir Abd al-Qadir al-Jaza'irli, may Allah have mercy on all of them and grant them a high station. Printed at the Great Arab Book House Press in Egypt, at the expense of Al-Hajj Fida Muhammad al-Kashmiri and his partners.

In the Name of Allah, the Most Compassionate, the Most Merciful. (بسم الله الرحمن الرحيم)
